The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.

figure.head: The expert, and famous madam LOVYS BOURGEOIS Midwife to the Queene of France.

div.p: THE Compleat Midwife's PRACTICE ENLARGED, In the mot weighty and high concernments of the BIRTH of MAN.
Containing a perfect DIRECTORY, or Rules for Midwives and Nures.

As alo a Guide for Women in their Conception, Bearing and Nuring of Children: From the Experience of our Englih Authors. Viz.
Sir Theodore Mayern,
Dr. Chamberlain,
Mr. Nich. Culpeper.
And others of Forreign Nations.
With Intructions of the Queen of France's Midwife to her Daughter, a little before her death, touching the practice of the aid Art.
As alo a farther Dicovery of thoe Secrets kept cloe in the Breat of Sir Theodore Mayern, Mr. Nicholas Culpeper, and other Englih Writers, not made publick till now.
The Fifth Edition Corrected, and much Enlarged, By JOHN PECHET, Fellow of the College of Phyicians, London.
The whole Illutrated with Copper Plates.

London, Printed for H. Rhodes at the Corner of Bride-Lane, in Fleet-treet, J. Philips at the King's Arms, J. Taylor at the Ship in St. Paul's Church Yard, and K. Bentley, in Ruel-treet, Covent Garden. 1698.

div.head: THE PREFACE By Several PRACTITIONERS in and about the City of LONDON.
div.p: IT is high time, ince there have been already publihed many Treaties in this kind, for us to declare our thoughts for the publick good. We have perued all that have been in this nature in Englih, and find them trangely deficient, o crowded with unneceary Notions, and dangerous Mitakes, that we thought it fit to give you warning of them, to prevent for the future, the many unfortunate Michiefs attending upon ignorance of thee Matters.

It is admirable to us, that our Country hould be o much deluded, to build all their practice on uch Authors, that have not at all conduced to any coniderable advantage
in this o neceary and ueful Art, as the preerving of Mankind. How many mierable Volumes have thee late times brought forth? Not to diparage any that have deerved, but in o weighty a Concernment as this, we mut tand upon our integrity. There hath been a reaonable intention in the publihers of ome Books, viz. The Birth of Man, the mot Ancient, but very much unfurnihed; as alo the Books of Child-birth, The Expert Midwife, the wort that hath been written in that kind, in French; and it's almot a Miracle to us, that Mr. Culpeper, a Man whom we otherways repect, hould decend o low, as to borrow his imperfect Treatie from thoe wretched Volumes, ome of which are before mentioned; and we mut deal faithfully with you, that, that mall piece of his, intituled, The Directory for Midwifes, is the mot deperately deficient of them all; except he writ it for neceity, he could certainly have never been o idle to have expoed it to the light.

Now, to give you a true information of what we have here done for your good, we hall not only jutifie what is here contain'd from our own Experiences, but fully demontrate from the Writings of the bet Practiers both of the French, Spanih, and Italians, and other Nations; and we mut clearly confes, that we are highly obliged to the incomparable
labours of that mot Famous Woman of the World, Madam Louie Burgeois, late Midwife to the Queen of France: The praies that we read of all thoe that ever heard of her, are not o much a flourih, as truth; for her reaons are olid experiences, and her witnees have been all of the mot eminent Perons of France; and not only of her, but as we have already expret, of the mot excellent known Men and Women of this Art of other Countries: It's upon this account that we break the barriers, and boldly tand the brunt of all Cenures.
The chief occaion of this Book, is, to make it a great Exemplary, and School, where Medicine married to the Midwife's indutry, may teach every one the admirable effects of this art of Midwifry.

And now knowing, Reader, that the Receipts herein contain'd, which have ever had happy uccees, are not made publick to the World on any other deign, than for the aitance of uch perons, whom either the want of fortune, or opportunity denieth uch udden helps, neither can we be without bleeding hearts, if we but conider how many have been lot by the unskilfulnes of thoe that attempted this great Work; nor hould we have protrated our reputation and private experiences, but to correct the frequent mitake of mot Midwives, who,
reting too boldly upon the common way of delivering Women, neglect all the wholeome and profitable Rules of Art, which might concern them in the occult Dieaes of Women, as alo of the Anatomical parts of the Body. Thus having dicharged our Duty, we have no more to write, but refer you to the Book it elf. We are the hearty Well-wihers of your good,

signed.hi:
R.C. J.D. M.S.
T.B. W.C. M.H.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT TO THE READER.
div.p: THE Bookeller deigning another Edition of this Midwifry, took care to have the Anatomick part compleated, and the whole Enlarged coniderably, as may appear to any one that will compare the Fourth Edition with this.

It is a plain and ueful Treatie of Midwifry, and is moreover tock'd with great variety of approved Remedies for the Dieaes of Women and Children, and therefore may well deerve to be accounted the bet Book extant upon this Subject.

div.head: Books lately Printed for R. Bentley, J. Phillips, H. Rhodes, and J. Taylor.
div.p: 1. THE New World of Words; or, an Vniveral Englih Dictionary. Containing the proper Significations, and Derivations of all words from other Languages. Together with the Definitions of all thoe Forms that conduce to the Undertanding of any of the Arts or Sciences. Collected by E. P. The Fifth Edition, with large Editions, and Improvements from the bet Englih and Forreign Authors. A Work very neceary for Strangers, as well as our own Country-men, to the right Undertanding of what they Dicoure, Write, or Read.

2. The Grounds and Occaions of the Contempt of the Clergy and Religion. Enquired into, in a Letter to R. L. with Obervations on the Anwer thereto, in a Letter to the ame, to which are added. Coniderations on Mr. Hobbs's State of Nature. With everal other pieces of the ame Author.
3. Aeop's Fables, with their Morals in Proe and Meeter, Grammatically Tranlated: Illutrated with Pictures and Emblems. Together with the Hitory of his Life. The 13th Edition, by W. D. Price 2 s.

4. The Queen's Cloet opened, being Incomparable Secrets in Phyick, Chyrurgery, Cookery, Preerving, Candying, &c. Which were preented to the Queen, by the mot experienc'd Perons of the Times; many whereof were had in eteem, when Her Majety pleaed to decend to private Recreations. Price 2 s.

5. The Englih Rudiments for the Latin Tongue, Explain'd by way of Quetion and Anwer, which are o form'd, that a Child, omitting altogether the Quetions, may learn only the Anwers, and be fully intructed in the Rudiments of the Latine Tongue, By W. Dugard, Price 1 s.

6. The School of Phyick, or the Experimental Practice of the whole Art; a Work very ueful and neceary for the information of all in Phyick, Chyrurgery, Chymitry, &c. By N. Culpeper, late Student in Phyick. With on account of the Author's Life.

div.head: THE COMPLETE MIDWIFE'S Practice Enlarged. Of the Genitals, or Veels dedicated to Generation, in Men and Women.

div.p: THE conideration of thee things is o neceary for the purpoe of this Book, that they require not only a deep meditation but the preheminence to take up the firt thoughts of thoe who would arrive to the knowledge of a thing o much needful to all mankind. And it may be reaonably feared, that many Women do mis their deign, becaue they know nothing but the outide of things: o that in matters of extremity, becaue they are ignorant of the tructure of the parts, they cannot tell how to go about their work. We hall therefore begin with the Anatomy of the privy parts, the Organs of generation, whereby through procreation is conerved a perennity of mankind, which nature has denied to particulars. Thee parts being not alike in both Sexes, we mut necearily treat of each apart; and firt of thoe of Man.

In Man, ome of thee parts afford matter for the Seed, viz. the Spermatic Arteries; others bring back again the blood that is uperfluous to the making of the Seed, and to the nourihment of the Stones, and thee are the Spermatic Veins; and both the Arteries and Veins were formerly called preparing
Veels. Some make the Seed, as the Stones; ome carry the Seed back again; ome contain the Seed and an oyly matter, as the Seed-bladders the firt, and the Protats the latter. Some dicharge the Seed into the Womb; and this is done by the Yard.

div.head: CHAP. I. Of the Veels of Preparation.
div.p: AMong the Spermatic Veels are to be conidered firt, two veins, and two arteries: thee are carried downward from the mall guts to the Teticles, and are much bigger in Men than they are in Women.

The original of thee Veins is not always the ame; for commonly the right Vein rieth out of the Hollow vein, a little below the ource or original of the Emulgent; but the leat takes his original from the lower part of the Emulgent it elf. Yet ometimes it hath a branch carried to it from the trunk of the hollow Vein.

The middle part of thee veins runs directly through the Loyns, reting upon the Lumbal Mucle, a thin Membrane only intervening; and thus having gone above half its journey, it branches out and ditributes it elf to the near adjoyning filmy parts of the Body. The uttermot part of thee veels is carried beyond the Midriff to the Stones, yet do they not pas through the Peritonaeum, but decend with a mall nerve and the Mucle called Cremater, through the Duplicity of the Midriff; when it approaches near the Stones, it is joyned with an Artery: and now thee Veels which were before a little evered one from the other, are by a film riing from the Peritonaeum cloed up, and
bound both together; and o twiting up, like the young tendrils of a Vine, they are carried to the end of the Stones.

The arteries which are aociated to thee veins, take their original a little beneath the Emulgent vein, whence they decend downward, and a little from their beginning or original, they are joyn'd to thee veins, till they are cloed together by an Anatomôis or Inoculation, ending like a Piramid.

It has been generally taught, that there are everal Inoculations of the Arteries, with the Veins in their paage, whereby the blood of the Veins and Arteries are mixed; but ince the knowledge of the Circulation of the Blood, this Opinion has been rejected; for the blood in the Arteries goes down towards the Stones, and that in the veins acends from them; and therefore if thee two Veels hould open one into the other, the Blood in one of them mut necearily be thrut back, or ele topping, tretch and break the Veels; but the truth is, the blood, both for the nourihment of the Stones, and the making of Seed, flows down by the Arteries only in an even coure, without any windings and twinings, like the tendrils of Vines, o much talked of, as the excellent Anatomit de Graef ays he has found by frequent inpection. The Veins carry back from the Stones, what of the blood remains from their nourihment, and making of Seed, and thee indeed come out of the Stones, with a vat number of Roots, whereby they uck up the aid Blood, and are mot admirably interwoven, and inoculated one with another, 'till about four or five fingers breadth above the Stone, which pace is called the Pyramidal Body.

Two things are to be noted. Firt, That thee permatic Veins have from their rie to their end everal
Valves, which open upwards, and o uffer the Blood to acend towards the hollow Vein, but not to return back again. Secondly, That tho' the Spermatick Arteries go a direct coure in Men, yet in Brutes they are more complicated, and twited with the Veins, but without any opening of one into another. There are Nerves and Lympheducts, that pas into the Teticles together with the Veels of preparation.

div.head: CHAP. II. The Ve of the preparing Veels.
div.p: THE Ue of thoe Veels which are called the Veels of Preparation, is chiefly to attract out of the hollow Vein, or left Emulgent, the mot pure and exquiitely concocted Blood, which is mot apt to be converted into Seed; which they contain and prepare, giving unto it a certain rude form of Seed in thoe parts that lie as it were in certain pleights or folds, which they do by a peculiar property bequeathed to them.

Another Ue of them is gathered by their ituation; for as they are now ituated, that is to ay, the right Vein coming from the Hollow Vein, and the left from the Emulgent: This incovenience is avoided, that the left Vein is not forced to pas over the great Artery, and o be in danger of breaking, by reaon of the wift motion of the Artery. Moreover, there being a neceity that Male and Female hould be begot, it is fit that there hould be Seed proper for the generation of both Sexes, whereof ome mut be hotter, and ome mut be colder; and therefore Nature hath o ordered it, that the hotter Seed hould proceed from the right Vein for the generation of man, and the colder from the left, for the generation of Females. The left
Vein hath alo this property to draw from the Emulgent the more erous and les pure Blood, to the intent that the erous humour might tir up Venery by its alt and acrimonious ubtance; and therefore it is oberved, that thoe who have the left Stone bigger, are mot full of Seed, and mot prone to Venery.

Thee Veins are o far from preparing the Seed, as that they only bring back, what was uperfluous from the making it. And indeed the Arteries in Men do no more merit the name of preparing Veels, in regard to the Seed, than the Gullet in repect of the Chyle, or the chyliferous thoracick duct, in regard to the Blood. But however we continue the old Names, declaring only againt the reaon of them.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the Paratatae, or Veels where the Blood is firt changed.
div.p: THESE four Veels after many ingraftings and knittings together, eem at length to become only two bodies, full of little crumplings like the tendril of a Vine, white, and in the form of a Piramid, reting the right upon the right Stone, and the left upon the left Stone. Thee are called Paratatae, which, as they tand, pierce the tunicles of each Stone with certain fibers or extraordinary mall Veins, which afterwards dipere themelves through the body of thoe Stones. The ubtance of thee Paratatae is between that of the Stones, and that of the Preparing Veels; for they neither altogether conit of Membranes, neither are they altogether Glandulous or Kernelly.

Upon the Stones, as yet clad with the tunica albuginea, are fixed the epididymidae, called alo Paratatae; thee do not differ from the Stones, only thee conits
of divers ducts, but thoe, after their ix or even Roots, that rie out of the Stone, are united, (which they are in a hort pace) but of one, only a little thicker, and the Paratatae differ not from the vaa deferentia; aving, that thoe go by a winding paage; and thee by a treight, and that thoe are a little ofter, and narrower.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the Teticles in general.
div.p: THE Stones are in number two, very eldom one, and much eldomer 3 or 4 The ituation of the Stones in Men is without the Midriff, at the root of the Yard under the belly; and that for two caues, to keep men more chate; it being oberved, that thoe creatures which carry their tones within their Bodies, are more alacious, and bring forth in great numbers.
Their bignes is not always alike in all Creatures, but in men as big as a Pigeons Egg, or as a mall Hens Egg; and commonly the left is bigger than the right.

In the Anatomy of the Stones, divers things are to be conidered. Their Tunicles, or the skins in which they are wrapt, as well thoe which are common to both, as thoe which are peculiar to either; next, the mucles; then, the ubtance of which they are compoed; and latly, the Veels which are dipered through the body of the tones.

The Stones in Latin, are called Tetes, either becaue they tetifie one to be a Man, or becaue amongt the Romans, none could bear witnes but he that had them. They have a peculiar ubtance, uch as is not in all the Body beides, whitih and oft, made up of
an innumerable little Ropes of Seed carrying Veels. There is no cavity in them, but thoe aid Veels are continued to one another, and carry the Seed in their undicernable hollownes. Hippocrates held the right to be bigger and hotter than the left, and therefore called it the Male-getter, and the left the Female-getter; thee fancies eem ridiculous, eeing there is no uch difference of their bignes, and that their Veels are common; they have Arteries and Veins from the preparing Veels, which ome have thought to reach only to the inmot coat, becaue they are not conpicuous in the inner ubtance; but that comes to pas, by reaon that the arterial Blood preently loes its colour, and, by the eminifick faculty of the Stones, is turned into Seed, which being whitih, of the ame colour with the Veels, makes them undicernible; yet in thoe men, that have died of languihing Dieaes, and whoe Stones have their faculty impaired, Diemerbroeck ays, that he has often een Blood-bringing Veels in the inmot parts of the Stones, and has hew'd them to many, in the publick Anatomick Theatre: As to Nerves, Dr. Willis affirms, that he could never oberve more to go to them, than one from a vertebral pair, and that too was mot of it pent upon the Mucle cremater. Concerning the Ue of this Nerve, there is a great Controverie, Dr. Glion, Dr. Wharton, and others, will have it convey a eedy Juice, which makes the greatet part of the Seed: But Dr. Willis is of another Opinion; however the Seed mut needs conit of a nervous Juice, and plenty of Spirits brought from the Brain, becaue of the great weaknes, and enervation that is induced upon the Brain, and Nerves, by too great an ue of Venery.

Lympheducts they have alo, ariing from betwixt
their coats, and acending upwards into the belly with the Vaa Deferentia: thee have many valves looking upwards, which hinder any thing from decending by them to the Stones, but permit the Lympha to acend, which they convey into the Chyliferous Veels.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the Tunicles of the Stones.
div.p: THE Tunicles are wrapt up in divers coverings about the number of which there hath been great diention. But they are now reduced to five, whereof two are common, and are called Scrotum, and Dartos; three particular, the names of which are Elytroides, Erythroides and Epididymis.

The firt of thee, which is like a Satchel or Pure, and is common to both, conits of a skin and a cuticle. This contains the two Stones like a Pure, and is obvious to the touch. The skin of this part differs from any other part of the skin which covers the body: for whereas that is tretched out and pread cloe over the body, this is more looe, and made to tretch out, or to be wrinkled up together as occaion is; that is, as the tones either acend, or decend: they acend commonly in the time of Conjunction; they decend in Fevers, weaknes of the Teticles, or by reaon of old age.

The econd Tunicle.The econd is called Dartos, becaue it is eaily eparated from the others. In this, the Teticles lie as it were in a net, wrapping them about more cloe than the Scrotum doth. It takes its original from the Flehy Pannicle, which though it be thinner hereabouts than in any other part of the body, yet it is full of little veins and arteries.

The proper Tunicles, are,The proper Tunicle. firt the Elytroides, which is alo called Vaginalis, by reaon it upplies the office of a heath. It takes its original from the production of the Peritonaeum, for where the permatick Veels pas, they do not at all bruie the Peritonaeum, but carry it down to the Stones, and o contitute or make this Tunicle. To know this Tunicle, and the original of it, is very neceary for Phyick, becaue that hollownes, which the Procees of the Peritonaeum do make for the paage of the permatick Veels, is ometimes dilated as far as the beginning, or ource of this Tunicle, and both the mall guts and the Kall fall down upon the Teticles, which is the caue of that kind of Burtnes, which by the Phyicians is called Enterocele. This Tunicle grows to that which is called Dartos, being joyned to it by many nervous fibres. Underneath this is a Tunicle, called Erythroides, or the red Tunicle; o called from the multitude of red veins which are prinkled up and down in it. It ries from the other Membranes, and is encompaed without by the firt proper Tunick.

The third, and that which immediately compaeth the tones, is that which is called Epididymis: it is white, thick, and trong, to preerve the oft and looe ubtance of the Stones. It rieth from the Tunicle of the eminal Veels, being the thicket of all the Tunicles, and hath ome few veins cattered up and down in it.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the upenory Mucles.
div.p:
TO keep the Stones from oppreing, or tretching over-much the paages of the eminal Veels,
Nature hath provided them two mucles for them to hang by, on both ides one, in form oblong and lender.

The Original of thee Mucles.Thee Mucels derive their original from a thick membrane, which is joyned to the Hanchbone, in the further part of that region, where the hair grows; and is fatned to this bone with certain flehy and traight fibres; where the oblique Mucles of the Abdomen or Midriff end, thence reaching down upon the uperiour Members of the Teticles, they are extended through the whole length of that round Body.
Thee Mucles are never een in Women, being altogether ueles, becaue their Stones are not pendent, but are incloed within their bodies.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of the ubtance and temper of the Stones.
div.p: THE ubtance of the Stones is glandulous, or kernelly, white, oft, looe, pongy and hollow, having undry veels dipered thorow them.

Now although the ubtance of the Teticles be mot oft and moit, yet doth not this moitnes contitute an uniform, or homogeneal body; for the ubtance of the Stones is wholly diimilar, and full of fibres. Thee fibres alo eem to be of a different ubtance from that of the Stones, being only cloathed with the fleh of the Stones, as the fibres of the Mucles are inwardly nervous, but covered over with the fleh of the Mucles. Thee fibres again differ in this, that the fibres of the Teticles are hollow, but the fibres of the Stones full and ubtantial. Thee fibres are aid to come from the permatic veels, and thence branch themelves forth thorow the Teticles, by which that
part of the Seed, which is over and above what erves for the nourihment of the Teticles, is drawn forth and kept for procreation.

As concerning the temper of the Stones, they would ooner be thought cold than hot, if that Maxim, were true, that, All white things are cold, and all red things hot. Notwithtanding, becaue nature is known to abhor all coldnes in the work of generation; Therefore we mut preume to affirm the temper of the Stones to be hot, for they always abound with blood, and a pure pirit that can never be without heat: beides that, heat is requir'd for the concoction of this blood, and the changing it into eed; yet, it is very temperate, as appears by the oftnes of the ubtance: for as coldnes and drines is the caue of hardnes, o heat and moiture is the caue of oftnes.

Nevertheles, we are to undertand this, that the temper of the Stones are not alike in all, for in ome they are far colder than in others. And therefore thoe, who have hot Teticles, are more alacious and prone to venereal actions, having the places near about much more hairy, and their Teticles much harder than others. Thoe that have their Teticles cold, find every thing contrary.

The greatet heat is in the right Teticle, becaue it receives more pure, and hotter blood from the hollow Vein, and the great Artery; the left colder, becaue it receives a more impure, and erous blood from the Emulgent Vein.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of the Actions of the Teticles.
div.p:
THE action, and ue of the Teticles, is, To generate Seed, a gift which they obtain from an
inbred quality, which Nature hath betowed upon them. For the blood being received by the permatic Veels, and there beginning to change its colour, is by and by received by the deferent Veels, or the veels which carry the blood o prepared to the Teticles; where it is for a while contained, and afterwards being carried to the Stones, is by them made Seed, and the lat work perfected. And it may with more eaines be affirmed, that the Seed is generated by the Stones, becaue every like is aid to generate its like; now the ubtance of the Teticles is very like the Seed it elf, that is, white, moit, and vicous. Whether the Stones are the only efficient caue of the Seed is not here to be diputed, being only a nice point, and no way profitable. We hall rather with ilence adhere to that opinion, which affirms the function of the Teticles to be the generation of the Seed, which is mot likely; and proceed to the next.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Concerning the Utility of the Teticles and their parts.
div.p:
THE tructure of the Teticles being thus known; it remains that we hew you their ue. This is firt dicovered from their ituation. For of thoe Creatures that have Stones, ome have them in their bodies, as all Fowl; others have them without, though not pendent; others have them hanging downward, as men. Men therefore have their Teticles without their bodies for two caues; firt, becaue it is required that the Teticles of the Male hould be bigger and hotter than thoe of the Female; o that it were impoible for them to be contained within the body, becaue of their quantity. Beides, the Seed of the
Male being the effective original of the Creature, and therefore hottet; it is alo required that the Seed hould be more abundant than could be contained in the Teticles, were they placed within the body: for the eminary paages mut have been les, and the veins themelves would not have afforded uch plenty of matter as now they do.

The motion of the Teticles is alo to be conidered; by which they move ometimes upward and ometimes downward. The one of thee motions which is made upward is voluntary, as being made by the Mucles; but the motion downward is a forced motion, not hapning without the laxity of the Mucles; the Teticles, through their own weight, falling downwards. Thee Mucles are called Crematers, their ue being to draw up the Teticles to horten the way of the Ejaculation of the Seed; as alo to keep the veels from being ditended too far by the weight of the Teticles.

The ue of the Tunicles is now to be poken of; and firt, of that which is outermot, and is called by the Latins Scrotum, being the pure wherein the Teticles are contained. It is made to wrinkle it elf up, and to let it elf looe, that it may be large enough for the Teticles when they well with plenty of Seed, and to wrinkle up again, when the Teticles being emptied, and o becoming les, are drawn upward. The other Coats, or Tunicles, are alo made for the defence of the Stones, but o thin and light that they hould not oppres the Stones with their weight; that which is called Erythroides hath many veins for the nourihment of the adjacent parts. The Epididymis was made to wrap the Teticle round about, let the Humid matter of the Teticle hould flow about, and conequently be wated.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of the Veels that cat forth their Seed.
div.p: THat paage which comes from the head of the Teticles to the root of the Yard, is called the Ejaculatory Veel. This, as I aid before, ries from the head of the Teticles, and joyning downward to the Teticle, decends to the bottom, and thence being reflected again, and annext to the preparing Veel, it returns again to the head of the Teticle; from thence it proceeds upward from the Teticles, till it touch the bone of the mall guts, till keeping cloe to the preparing Veel, till it pierce the production of the Hypogatrium. Thence tending downward through the hollownes of the hip, it lides between the bladder and the treight Gut, till it reach the glandulous Protatae, or Foretanders, and fix it elf at the foot, or root of the Yard, and there end. It is not all one at the beginning, and at the end; for at the beginning, while it remains among the Tunicles of the Teticles, it is full of windings and turnings; near the end, it hath many little bladders like to warts.

Now we mut undertand that thee Seminary Veels do not only contain the Seed, but they perfect and concoct it, having a eminifick, or Seed-making quality, which they borrow from the Teticles: There are other ues of thee eminary Veels, for, near the original of this veel, that is to ay, the head of the Teticles, many mall paages, or as it were conduit-pipes, do tretch themelves forward into the body of the Teticle, into which the genital Seed that remains is remitted, and alo drawn, or ucked from thoe paages; this eminary paage is at length wound above the Teticles, adjoyning all along, but
no where incorporated into the body of the Teticle, unles at the bottom, in which place it is thought that the Seed doth again ininuate it elf into the Teticles through thoe hollow fibres: being thence propagated, and continually making upply to the Stones.

It is to be noted alo, that thee Veels while they move to the root of the Yard, do not go by treight paages, which would be then very hort but by crooked windings and turnings making the paages as long as may be, that they may have longer time to contain and prepare the Seed.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of the Seminary Bladders.
div.p: AT the end of the Deferent Veels on both ides, are certain little bladders, knit, and joyned together, and placed between the Bladder and the right gut; the lat of which, together with the eminary Veel, is terminated, in the Protatae, or Foretanders, by a little channel.

Thee Bladders have two everal ues; for they do not only trengthen the eminary Veels where they end, but alo eem to be the tores and magazeens of the Seed. They are many, that every time a man ues the act of Venery, he may have a new upply of matter from thee everal veicles. Thus that which is next the Yard being firt disburdened, the econd is the next time emptied, and o till all the tore is pent; and, were it not for thee veicles, a man could not lie with a woman more than once.

In thee Veels uch is the propenity of Nature to propagate, let the body be never o much emaciated, there is always found a leer or greater quantity of Seed. They are hollow and round, to contain a
greater quantity of Seed; they are alo full of membranes, that they may be contracted or extended as the plenty of Seed requires; they are crooked and full of windings and turnings, that the Seed contained may not eaily lip out.

Thee mall Bladders are little Cells, like thoe in a Pomgranate, or omething like a bunch of Grapes. De Graef compares them to the guts of a little Bird, diverly contorted. They conit of one thin membrane, thro' which ome mall twigs run, both of Veins, Arteries, and Nerves; they are about three Fingers breadth long, and one broad, but in ome places broader, and ome narrower, as they run in and out. They are two divided from one another by a little intertice, and they do everally, by a peculiar paage, cat the Seed contained in them into the Urethra: they are very winding, and conit of many little Cells, that they hould not pour out all the Seed contained in them in one act of Copulation, but might retain it for everal; they have no communication one with another, not even in their very opening into the Urethra, but the Seed that is brought to thee little bladders on the right ide iues by its proper paage into the Urethra, and that which is brought to the left likewie, o that if by any accident the bladders on the one ide be burt or cut, as in cuting for the Stone they mut needs be, yet thoe on the other being entire may till uffice for generation. When the Seed is cat out of thee bladders in the act of generation, it paes out the ame way it came in, which in this cae may eaily be, tho' it be unuual there hould be a contrary motion in the ame veel; for when it comes in, it drills along gently without any force, but in Copulation when the Mucles of the Yard, and all the bordering
parts are much welled, it is quirted out of them with ome violence, and paing along their neck, ouzes thro' a Caruncle like quick Silver thro' leather into the Urethra, or Duct of the Yard, that is common both to the Seed and Urine. I ay, it ouzes from the necks of the Bladders thro' a Caruncle into the Urethra; for there is one placed as a valve before the Orifice of each of them, partly to hinder the coming of the Urine into them, partly to hinder the involuntary effuion of the Seed. Now tho' the little holes thro' which the Seed paes out of the necks of the mall bladders into the Urethra, be naturally almot imperceptible, yet, if they be either eroded by the acrimony of the Seed, contracted by impure Copulation, or if of themelves they be weakened and o become more Laxe, as ometimes happens to old o • impotent Men that ue Copulation too frequently, then there happens a Gonorrhea, or continual Flux of Seed.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of the kernelly Protatae, or Foretanders.
div.p:
THE glandulous Protatae, or Foretanders, are two little Teticles, as it were eated at the foot of the Yard, a little above the Sphincter of the Urinary Veels; they are wrapt about with a membrane, which doth alo cloath the eminary Veels and veicles: before and behind they eem more flat, on the ides they are more round; they have a ubtance like other kernels, looe and pongy, only they differ from them by reaon of their whitenes and hardnes, they are endued with an exquiite feeling, to tir up greater deire of Copulation. Thee Glandulae or kernels have certain pores that open themelves into
the Urethra, through which the Seed (thee Foretanders being queezed by the lower Mucles of the Yard) ditils into the Yard.

The ue of thee Kernels are partly to beget an oyly, fat, and lippery ubtance, with which the urinary paage is ometimes anointed, to defend it from the acrimony both of the Seed and Urin, and to keep it always moit.

The other ue is taken from the name of Protatae; which word, in the ingular number, ignifies a Tutor or Defender; for they are there placed to preerve and trengthen the ends of the Deferent Veels, let by overmuch ditention of the Yard, the Seminary Veels hould be either burt, or moved out of their places.

They have a third ue: For, being placed between the Bladder and the right gut, they erve intead of Cuhions for the Veels to ret upon, and to guard them from all compreion: Hence it happens ometimes that thoe who are very much bound in their bodies, while they train themelves over-vehemently, do now and then void a kind of Seed, which happens by a violent compreion of thoe parts.

The Protats, in Englih, tanders by, or waiters, are placed near to the Seed-Bladders. De Graef calls them the glandulous body, uppoing them to be one body, and only divided by the common ducts of the eed-bladders, and the vaa deferentia coming through the midt of it. They are of a white, pungy, glandulous ubtance, about as big as a mall Wall-nut, encompaed with a trong and fibrous Membrane from the Bladder, to the beginning of whoe neck they are joined at the root of the Yard; in hape they come nearet to an Oval, ave that on their upper and lower part, they are a little depreed, and in that end,
whereby the vaa deferentia enter, they are omewhat hollow like a Tunnel.

The phincter Mucle of the Bladder encompaes them o, that for o far as they cover the neck of the Bladder, the phincter touches it not, they coming between. They have all orts of veels which run chiefly on their out-ide, in the inner part, they have ten or more mall Ducts, which unload themelves into the Urethra, by the ides of the great Caruncle, thro' which the Seed paes from the Seed Bladders into the Urethra; but themelves have each one, a mall one to top its Orifice, leat the liquor that is contained in the Protats, hould continually flow out, or the Urine flow in: and thee mall Ducts, I uppoe, are continued from thoe mall Bladders which are een in the Protats of thoe that dye uddenly, after having had to do with a Female; for in uch, the pungy part of the Protats is very full of a thin liquor, and in their inner part may be found the ame mall bladders, which if you pres upon, they will dicharge themelves into the above aid Ducts. There is a great variety of Opinions, what the liquor in them hould be, or what is their ue: Some think that the Seed that flows from the Teticles, is further elaborated here; but that cannot be, becaue the vaa deferentia depoit nothing in them, but all into the mall Seed Veels. Others think, that there is eparated from the Blood in them, an acrimonious and erous humour which erves for Titulation, or cauing the greater pleaure in Venery. As to this, de Graef appeals to the tate of it, which has nothing of Acrimony in it. Dr. Wharton thinks they make a particular kind of Seed, as the Stones do another, and the Seed Bladders a third; that thee lat make a different Seed from that made in the Stones, is
grounded on a mitake in Anatomy, viz. That the vaa deferentia have no communication with the Seed-Bladders, whereas they apparently open into them, and depoite in them all the Seed they contain; that the Protats make a peculiar ort, he endeavours to prove, becaue gelded Animals emit ome Seed; but tho' they do emit omething, it is not neceary it hould be any true Seed; or if it be, it may well be uppoed to proceed from the mall Seed-Bladders that were full when the Animal was gelt; for this reaon it has been oberved, that preently after gelding, they have ometimes got the Female with Young, but not afterwards when that tock was pent. Others think they make an oyly and lippery humour, which is preed out opon occaion to bemear the Urethra, to defend it from the acrimony of the Seed and Urine, and let it hould dry up. De Graef believes, that the Humour that is eparated in the Protats, erves for a vehicle of the Seed, which flowing but in mall quantity, thro' mall Poors into the Urethra, it was neceary, that this Humour hould be mixed with it, that it might the better reach the Womb; whatever this Humour be, it is queezed out partly by the welling and erection of the Yard, and partly, by compreion of the phincter of the Bladder, that girds the Protats about: Thee Protats are often the eat of a Gonorrhaea, and the Humour they contain, is that which flows out in the running of the Reins; for if it were true Seed, they could never endure a Gonorrhaea o long, ome thirty Years, without being much wated, the flux being o much as ometimes it is.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of the tructure of the Yard.
div.p: THE tructure of the Yard is not unknown, that is to ay, at the root of the hare bone in the hinder part of the Hypogatrion or lower part of the belly, where the hair grows; which bone is called, Os pubis. Though the greatet part of it, is not pendent without, but adjoining to the Podex, is ituated near the joining of the hare-bone, being fat knit to it in the Perinaeum, or pace between the Cods and the Fundament; the other part is pendent and is een hanging outward. This ituation is mot appropriated to the manner of the act of generation, uual and peculiar to men, who do not couple after the manner of Beats. The figure of it is in a manner round, though not exactly; broader in the upper part which is called the back of the Yard.

The thicknes and longitude of the Yard is o much as is required for Procreation; yet it is not o long as in many other creatures. Yea, and in everal men there is a very great diverity; little men being for the mot part, bet provided in that part: It is a general received opinion, that the often ue of Venery doth increae the quantity of it in all dimenions.

The Yard will alo be longer, if the Navel-trings are not bound up, or knit too cloe by the Midwife, in Children that are newly born; but at ome ditance from the Navel: This happens by reaon of the Ligament coming from the Navel to the bottom of the Bladder; which if it be too much abreviated, draws up the Bladder, and conequently hortens the Yard; but if the Navel-tring be left at a longer ditance, the Urachus is enlarged, and conequently the Yard hath
more liberty to extend it elf; And therefore the Midwives are from hence advertied, that they do not poil the harvet of generation, by cutting the ithe too hort.

As to the ubtance of the Yard; it is not of a bony ubtance, as in Dogs, Wolves, or Foxes; for o it would become always hard and erected, and hinder men from all buines but the act of Venery: Neither is it gritly, for o it could neither erect it elf, nor flag, when occaion required: Neither is it full of veins, for o it could not be emptied and repleted on uch a udden as often happens; beides, the Tunicles of the veins are o thin, that they could not uffer o great a ditention; neither can it be full of Arteries, becaue it wants a continual pulation; neither can it conit of Nerves, becaue they having no hollownes, cannot be extended and looned, as it mut of neceity happen to the Yard. It is therefore neceary that the Yard hould have uch a ubtance, as is not peculiar to any part of the body. It is to be undertood, that there do concur to the framing of the Yard, two nervous bodies, the paage for the Urine which is called Urethra, the Glans or Nut of the Yard, four Mucles, the Veels, and the skin.

Here doth arie a quetion, why the Yard hath not any fat? Which is in brief, thus; becaue that there hould be no hindrance to the perfect ene of the Yard, which could of neceity not be avoided, if that member were ubject to any obeity; the fat being ubject to be melted by frication.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Of the everal parts contituting the Yard.
div.p:
AMONG the parts that compoe the tructure of the Yard, is that skin which with its cuticle,
and flehly pannicle, is common not only to this, but to other members; only it hath this peculiar to it elf, that it may be reflexed, and drawn back from the Nut of the Yard. This skin that turns back is called the Praeputium; becaue that part in circumciion was cut away; with which prepuce, the Nut of the Yard is covered.

The Glans or Nut of the Yard is a flehy part, oft, thin,The Nut of the Yard. repleat with blood and pirits; endued with an exquiite ene; omething harp and acute at the end. This is fatned to the prepuce at the lower part by a certain ligament, which is therefore called the bridle, or the filet, which commonly is broken in the firt venereal aaults, which are for the mot part the mot furious.

The greatet part of the Yard is contituted by two nervous bodies,The two nervous bodies. on both ides one, which terminate both together in the Nut. They rie from a two-fold original, leaning or reting upon the Hip, under the Share-bone; whence as from a ure foundation they go on, till they arrive at the nut of the Yard.

They conit of a double ubtance, the firt is nervous, hard,Their ubtance. and thick; the inner part black, looe, oft, thin, and pongy. It is called the Nervous pipe. Thee two bodies are joyned together by a certain membrane, thin, yet nervous; which is trengthned by certain overthwart fibres, being there placed in the likenes of a Weavers huttle: and though in their original they are eparated the one from the other, that there might remain ome certain pace for the Urethra; yet they are joyned together about the
middle of the Share-bone; where they loe about the third part of their nervous ubtance.

The interiour ubtance, which is wrapt about by the exteriour nervous ubtance, hath this worthy obervation, That there appears tretched, through the whole length of it, a thin and tender Artery, proportionable to the bignes of the body which is diffued through the whole looe ubtance of the Yard, reaching as far as the root of the Yard. Beides thee two, there is another body which lies between thee two, as proper or rather more peculiar to the Yard than they are. This is a pipe placed at the inferiour part of the Yard, being called the Urethra, though it be a paage as proper to the Seed, as to the Urine; which is encompaed by the two fore-mentioned bodies. This is a certain Channel produced in length, and running through the middle of thoe nervous bodies, coniting of the ame ubtance that they do, being looe, thick, oft, and tender; every way equal from the neck of the bladder to the nut of the Yard, aving that it is a little wider at the beginning, than it is toward the place where it ends, which is at the head of the Glans or nut of the Yard.

The holes of the Vrethra.At the beginning of this Channel there are three holes; one in the middle, and omething bigger than the other two, ariing from the neck of the bladder; the other two, on both ides one, being omething narrower, proceeding from the paage that goes out of the eminary veels, and conveighs the Seed into this Channel.

This is further to be noted in this place, that in the Channel, where it is joyned to the Glans, together with the nervous bodies, there is a little kind of cavern,
in which ometimes either putrid Seed,Note. or any other corroding humour, happens in the Gonorrhaea; being collected, it is the caue of ulcers in that part, the caue of very great pain: and it many times alo comes to pas, that there is a certain little piece of fleh which grows out of this Ulcer, that oftentimes tops the paages of the urine.

To the tructure of the Yard,The Mucles of the Yard. there do moreover occurr two pair of Mucles, one more hort and thick, proceeding from a part of the Hip, near the beginning of the Yard, and being of a flehy ubtance. The ue of thee two Mucles, is to utain the Yard in the erection; and to bend the fore part of the Yard, which is to be inerted into the womb: the other pair is longer, and ries from the Sphincter of the Fundament, where they are endued with a more flehy ubtance, being in length full as long as the Yard; under which they are carried downward, ending at the ides of the Urethra, about the middle of the Yard. Their ue is to dilate the Urethra, both at the time of making water, and at the time of Conjunction; let it hould be topped up by the repletion of the nervous bodies, and o top up the paage of the Seed. They are alo thought to keep the Yard firm, let it lean too much to either ide, and alo to pres out the Seed out of the Protatae, or Foretanders.

There are Veels alo of all orts in the yard: firt of all,The Veels of the Yard. certain Veins appearing in the external parts, and in the cuticle; which do branch themelves out from the Hypogatrium. In the middle, between the pace of the fibres, they end out certain branches from the right ide to the left, and from the left to the right. Thee veins welling with a frothy blood and pirit,
erect the Yard. There are alo certain nerves which catter themelves from the pith or marrow of the Holy-bone, quite through the yard, bringing with them the caue of that pleaure and delight, which is perceived in the erection of the yard.

div.head: CHAP. XV. Of the Action of the Yard.
div.p: THE main cope of Nature in the ue of the Yard, was, the injection of Seed into the womb of the Woman, which injection could not be done, till the Seed were firt moved; neither could the Seed be moved but by frication of the parts, which could not be done, till it were heathed in the Womb; nor that neither, till the Yard were erected.

This ditention is caued by repletion; which is caued by the plenty of Seed: Secondly, by uperfluity of wind, which if it be too violent, is the caue of priapim: A third caue proceeds from the abundance of Urine contained in the Bladder. Sometimes, the heat of the reins is a caue thereof.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Of the ue of the Yard in general.
div.p:
THE Yard is ituated under the Midriff over againt the Womb. And is alo placed between the thighs, for the greater trengthning of it in the act of copulation: neither is this the only trength which it hath, for at the lower part it appears more flehy, which fleh is altogether mucely, for the greater trength thereof. Neither is it only contented with this Mucely fleh, it having two Mucles alo for the ame purpoe, on both ides to poie it eaven in
the act of erection; which though they are but little, yet are they exceeding trong.
The figure of the Yard is not abolutely round, but broader on the upper ide, let it hould be hindered by the the convexity of the uperior part, in the cating forth of the Seed.
Concerning the bignes of the Yard, it is by mot eteemed to be of a jut length, when it is extended the breadth of nine thumbs.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. Of the ue of the parts contituting the Yard.
div.p: THE firt thing in the contitution of the Yard, that offers it elf to view, is the Skin, which is long and looe, by reaon that the Yard which is ometimes to be extended, and ometimes to fall down again, o requires it. The extremity of the skin is o ordered, that it ometimes covers the Glans, and ometimes draws back; that, whilt it covers the Nut of the Yard, it may defend the Yard from frication, or provoking the motion of the Seed.

Moreover, this skin in the act of copulation, huts up the mouth of the Womb and hinders the ingres of the cold air. Concerning the two nervous bodies, contituting the ubtance of the Yard; their ue is for the vital pirit to run through the thin ubtance of them, and fill the Yard with pirits. Moreover, by their thicknes, they do prevent the two haty emptying and flying out of the pirits which are to tay in, for the greater and longer erection of the Yard.

The ue of the Urethra is for the paage of Seed and Urine through it. The ubtance of the Urethra is much of the ame with the two former bodies; the inide
being more thin and looe, the outide more nervous and thick; which is o ordained, that it may be more apt to be erected with the Yard. It goes forward from the place where it begins, to the end of the Spermatick Veels, and the neck of the bladder, and the warty Foretanders, where there aries a thin and tender membrane, which the Chyrurgeons ought to take a great deal of care let they break, while they thrut their Syringes toward thoe parts; It is endued with an exquiite ene to tir up pleaure and venereal deire.

The ue of the Glans. As to the ubtance of the Glans, it is the ame with that of the Yard; only it is not invelop'd with any nervous body. For this ought to be repleted and increaed, but not hardned; let it hould injure the bone of the Womb, by rubbing too hard upon it.

The figure of the Glans is uch, that at the top where it is mot acute, it hath a hole for the iuing forth both of Seed and Urine, which part coming to the mouth of the Womb, cats the eed into that concavity, at which time the neck of the Womb with her overthwart fibres, eems to take hold and imbrace the Glans; and, that it might take the better hold, Nature hath framed a round circle at the bottom of the Yard, for that purpoe, with a convenient jetting out round about from the body of the Yard; by the benefit of which circle, the Seed is kept in the womb, and not uffered to flye out. Latly, the Glans is o contituted, as if all the actions of the Yard conited in the Glans; whether in the act of erection, or copulation; or as to the pleaure which a man perceives, that lies all in this place.

div.head: SECT. II.
CHAP. I. Of the Genitals of Women.
div.p: AT the lower part of the belly appears the Pubes, or, the Region of the hair. Under this place are, as it were, lips of fleh, which in women that are ripe for man, are clad with hair at the upper part, becaue of the heat and moiture of the place; and this part is that which is mot properly called the Privy-member, being the exteriour orifice, into which the Yard of the man enters. In the middle it hath a cleft, on both ides of which are two flehy protuberances, beet with hair, being two oft oblong bodies compoed of skin and a pongy kind of fleh.

The parts that offer themelves to view, without any diduction, are the great chink, with the lips, the mountain of Venus, and the hairs. The great chink is called Cunnus by Galen, by Hypocrates Natura, and by many other names, invented by lutful Perons, and lacivious Poets. It reaches from the lower part of the os Pubis to within an Inch of the Fundament, being by Nature made o large, becaue the outward skin is not o apt to be extended in Travel, as the membranous heath; it is les and cloer in Maids, than in thoe that have born Children; it has two lips, which towards the Pubes grow thicker and more full, or protuberant, and meeting upon the middle of the os Pubis, make that riing, which is called the hill of Venus; its outward ubtance is skin covered with hair; as the lips are: the inner ubtance
of this hill, which makes it bunch o up, is mot of it fat, and erves, as it were for a oft Cuhion in copulation, to hinder the bone of the Pubes of the Man and Woman to hit one againt the other; for that would be painful and diturb the venereal Pleaures. Under this fat lies that Mucle, that traitens the Orifice of the heath.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of thoe parts called Nymphae, and the Clytoris.
div.p: THE Nymphae, or wings, are a membrany, or filmy ubtance, oft, and pongy, and partly flehy; they are of a ruddy colour, like the comb of a cock under his throat; they are two in number, though in the beginning they are joyned together by an acute Angle; where they produce a carneous ubtance, like the Praeputium which cloaths the Clytoris. Sometimes thee wings o far encreae, that there is many times need of inciion; a dieae common among the Egyptians.

The Clytoris is a certain ubtance in the upper part of the great Cleft,The Clytoris. where the two wings concur. This in Women is the eat of Venereal pleaure: It is like the Yard in ituation, ubtance, compoition, and erection, and hath omething correpondent both to the Prepuce, and to the Glans in men. Sometimes it grows out to the bignes of the Yard, o that it hath bin oberved to grow out of the body, the breadth of four fingers.

This Clytoris conits of two pongy and inewy bodies, having a ditinct original from the bone of the Pubes. The head of this is covered with a mot tender skin, and hath a hole like the Glans, though not
quite through; in which, and in the bignes, it differs only from the Yard. By a little drawing aide the lips, there then appear the Nymphs and Clytoris.

The Nymphs are o called, becaue they tand next to the Urine, as it pouts out from the Bladder, and keep it from wetting the lips; they are alo call'd wings; they are placed on each ide next within the lips, and are two flehy and oft productions, beginning at the upper part of the privity, (where they are joined in an Acute angle, and make that wrinkled membranous production that covers the Clytoris, like a fore-skin,) and decending cloe all the way to each other, reaching but about half the breadth of the Orifice of the heath, and ending each in an obtue angle: They are almot Triangular, and therefore, as alo for their colour, are compared to the thrills that hang under a cocks throat. They have a red ubtance, partly flehy, partly membranous, within oft and pongy, looly compoed of mall Membranes and Veels, o that they are very eaily tretched by the flowing in of the animal Spirits, and arterial Blood. The Spirits they have from the ame Nerves that run thro' the heath, and blood from one of the branches of the Iliack Artery: Veins they have alo, which carry away the arterial blood from them, when they become flaccid. They are larger in old Maids than in young, and larger yet in thoe that have ued Copulation, or born Children. They never, according to Nature reach above half way out from between the lips; their ue is to defend the inner parts, to cover the urinary paages, and a good part of the Orifice of the heath; and to the ame purpoes erve the lips.

Above betwixt the Nymphs, in the upper part of the privities, a part bunches out a little, that is called
Clytoris, from a Greek word, that ignifies laciviouly to grope the privities. It is like a mans Yard in hape, ituation, ubtance, repletion with Spirits, and erection, and differs from it only in length and bignes: in ome it grows to that length, as to hang out from betwixt the lips of the privities, yea, there are many tories of uch, as have had it o long and big, as to be able to convere with other Women like unto men, and uch are called Hermophridites, who, it is not probable, are truly of both Sexes, but only the Stones fall down into the lips, and this Clytoris is tretched preternaturally; but in mot it branches out o little, as that it does not appear but by drawing aide the lips; it is a little long and round body, coniting like a mans Yard of two nervous, and inwardly black, and pongy parts that arie on each ide from the bunching of the bone Ichium, and meet together at the Conjunction of the bones of the Pubes. It lies under the hill of Venus, at the top of the great Cleft, in Venery; by reaon of the two nervous bodies, it puffs up, and traightning the Orifice of the heath, contributes to the embracing the Yard more cloely. Its outward end is like to the Glans of a Mans Yard, and has the ame name, and as the Glans in men is the eat of the greatet pleaure in Copulation, o is this in Women; It has ome reemblance of a hole, but it is not pervious. It is mot of it covered with a thin Membrane, by the joyning of the Nymphs, which is called the Prepuce. The Clytoris has two pair of Mucles belonging to it, the upper are round, and pring from the bones of the hip, and paing along the two nervous bodies, are inerted into them; thee, by traitning the roots of the aid bodies, do detain the Blood and Spirits in them, and o erect the Clytoris, as thoe in men do the Yard: the other arie from the Sphincter of the fundament; it has veins, arteries, and nerves.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the flehy knobs, and the greater neck of the Womb.
div.p: PReently behind the wings, before we go far inward in the middle of the Cleft, there do appear four knobs of fleh, being placed in a quadrangular form, one againt the other; they are aid to reemble Myrtle-berries in form. In this place is incerted the Orifice of the bladder, which opens it elf into the fiure, to cat forth the Urine into the common Channel. Now leat any cold air, or dut, or any uch thing hould enter into the Bladder after the voiding of the Urine, one of thee knobs is eated o, that it huts the urinary paage. The econd, is right oppoite to the firt, the other two collateral. They are round in Virgins, but they hang flagging when Virginity is lot.

The lips of the Womb being gently eparated,The neck of the Womb. the neck of the Womb is to be een: In which, two things are to be oberved; the neck it elf, or the channel, and the Hymen, which is there placed: By the neck of the Womb, is undertood the channel, which is between the aid knobs, and the inner bone of the womb; which receives the Yard like a Sheath. The ubtance of it is inewy,The ubtance. and a little pongy, that it may be dilated; in this concavity there are certain folds, or orbicular pleights; thee are made by a certain Tunicle o wrinkled, as if a man hould fold the skin with his fingers. In Virgins they are plain; in Women, with often copulation, they are oftentimes worn out; ometimes they are wholly worn out, and the inner ide of the Neck appears mooth; as it happens to Whores, and Women that have often brought
forth, or have bin over troubled with their fluxes. In old Women it becomes more hard and grily. Now though this Channel be omething writhed and crooked, when it falls and inks down, yet in time of the flowers and copulation, or in time of travel, it is erected and extended; and this over-great extenion in Women that bring forth, is the caue of that great pain in Child-bed.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the Hymen.
div.p: THE Hymen is a Membrane not altogether without blood,The Hymen. neither o tender as the ret, but more ruddy, and catter'd up and down with little veins, and in a circular form; it is placed overthwart, and huts up the cavity of the neck of the Womb. In the middle it hath a little hole, through which the Menes are voided. This at the firt time of Copulation is broken, which caues ome pain, and guhing forth of ome quantity of blood; which is an evident ign of Virginity; for if the blood do not flow, there is a upicion of a former deflowring.

The Hymen is a thin, nervous membrane, interwoven with flehy fibres, and endowed with many little Arteries and Veins, coming acros the paage of the heath; behind the incertion of the neck of the bladder, with a hole in the midt, that will admit the top of ones little finger, whereby the Coures flow; where it is found, it is a certain note of Virginity, but upon the firt Copulation it is broke, and bleeds, and when it is once broke, it never cloes again. This Blood is called the flower of Virginity, and of this the Scripture makes mention, Dut. cap. 22. & 13.21. But tho'
a man when he finds thee igns of Virginity, may be fully atisfied he hath married a Maid, yet on the contrary, it will not necearily follow, that where they are wanting, Virginity is alo wanting; for the Hymen may be corroded by acrimonious fretting Humours, flowing thro' with the coures, or from the falling out, or inverion of the Womb, or heath at leat: It ometimes happens, even to Maids; for if a Maid be o inconiderate, as to marry while her coures flow, or within a Day after, then both the Hymen and the inner wrinkled Membrane of the Sheath are o flaggy and relaxed, that the Yard may eaily enter with out any lett, and o give upicion of Unchatity, when really he is unblameable, aving for her imprudence to marry at that eaon. Sometimes the Hymen grows o trong in old Maids, that a Man is forced to make many eays, before he can penetrate it, and in ome it is naturally quite cloed up, and thee by this means having their coures topt, are in great danger of their life, if they be not opened by ome Chyrurgical Intrument. Cloe to the Hymen lye the four Myrtle-berry Caruncles, o called from their reembling Myrtle-berries: The larget of them is uppermot, tanding jut at the Mouth of the Urinary paage, which it tops after rendring the Urine. Oppoite to this in the bottom of the heath, there is another, and one on each ide; but of thee four there is only the firt in Maids, the other three are not indeed Caruncles, but little knobs made of the angular parts of the broken Hymen, roll'd into a heap by the wrinkling of the heath: Thee three when the heath is extended in Womens labour, looe their roughnes, and become mooth, o that they diappear until it be again contracted, and indeed, the heath near its outer orifice, has a Mucle near three Fingers broad, that upon occaion, contracts
it, o that Men and Women need not be olicitous concerning their Genitals being proportionable one to the other.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the Veels that run through the neck of the Womb.
div.p: BEtween the Duplicity of the two Tunicles, that contitute the neck of the Womb, there are many Veins and Arteries that run along, ariing from thoe Veels that decend on both ides the thighs, and are incerted into the ide of the neck of the Womb: The great quantity and bignes of them deerves admiration; for they are much bigger than the nature and opennes of the place eems to require.

The caue of the largenes of the Veels.The caue of this is twofold; firt, Becaue it being requiite for the neck of the Womb to be filled with abundance of pirits, and to be extended and dilated for the better taking hold of the Yard; there is required a great heat for thee kind of motions, which growing more intene by the act of frication, doth conume a great quantity of moiture, o that great Veels are requiite, and only able to make that continual upply that is needful.

There is another caue of the longnes of thee Veels, which is this; Becaue that the monthly purgations are poured through thoe veins; for the flowers mut not come only out of the Womb, but out of the neck of the Womb alo.Note. Whence it happens, that Women with Child do ometimes continue their purgations, becaue that though the womb be hut up, yet the paages in the neck of the womb are open.

This is alo further to be noted in the neck of the womb, that as oon as ever your ight is entred within
the female fiure,The two holes, or pits, near the lips of the Pudendum. there do appear to the view, two certain little holes or pits, wherein is contained a erous humour; which being preed out in the act of copulation, does not a little add to the pleaure thereof.
This is the humour with which women do moiten the top of a mans Yard; not the Seed, but a humour proper to the place, voided out by the Womb.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the Fabrick of the Womb.
div.p: TO the neck of the Womb, the Womb it elf is adjoined in the lower part of the Hypogatrium, where the hips are widet and broadet; which are greater and broader thereabouts than thoe of men; which is the reaon alo, that they have broader Buttocks than men have.

The Womb is placed between the Bladder and the treight gut;The Womb. being joined to the bladder and leaning upon the treight gut: where it lies as between two Cuhions, this ituation of the womb was fittet, that o it might have liberty to be tretched, or contracted, according to the bignes of the Fruit contained in it.

The figure of the womb is round, and not unlike a Gourd, that leens,The figure. and grows more acute at the one end. The bottom of the womb is knit together by Ligaments of its own, which are peculiar: The neck of the womb is joined by its own ubtance, and by certain Membranes to the Share-bone, and the Sacred bone.

As to the bignes of it; that varies according to the age or contitution of the body,The bignes. and ue of Venery. For it is much greater in Women that have brought forth, than in thoe that are with Child, and after the birth.
It is of a ubtance o thick, as that it exceeds a thumbs breadth in thicknes; which after conception is o far from decreaing, that it increaes till to a greater bulk and proportion.
This ubtance, the more to confirm it,The Fibres. is interweaved with all manner of fibres, treight, oblique, and overthwart.
The Veels of the Womb are Veins, Arteries and Nerves.

There are two little Veins which are carried from the permatick Veels to the bottom of the womb;The Veins. and two greater from the Hypogatricks, which go not only to the bottom, but to the neck. The mouth of thee veins pierce as far as the inward concavity; in which place the extremities of them are called Acetabula; which in the time of the Flowers, gape and open themelves by reaon of the great plenty and tream of blood, that pours it elf from thence; and therefore they are, at that time, mot conpicuous; in women with Child, that which is called the Liver of the Womb, is joined to them, that it might draw blood for the nourihment of the Child; at which time their veins do o well, epecially in the time of, or near Delivery, that they are as big as the Emulgent veins, or at leat half as thick as the Hollow vein.
The Arteries.It hath two Arteries on both ides, the Spermatick, and the Hypogatrick, which every where do accompany the Veins.

The Womb hath alo divers little nerves knit together in form of a Net, which are carried not only to the interior part of the bottom of the Womb, but alo to the Neck, and as far as the privities themelves; and that chiefly for ene and pleaure; for which caue there is a great ympathy between the Womb and the Head.

This is alo further to be noted,Note that the Womb in its ituation is not fixed and immoveable, but moveable, by reaon of two ligaments which hang on both ides, from the Share-bone; and piercing through the Peritonaeum, are joined to the bone it elf, o that it ometimes happens that through thoe holes of the Peritonaeum, which give paage to thee ligaments being looened, either the Omentum, or the Entrails, do well outwardly, and caue the burtnes either of the Caul or of the Guts, and ometimes it happens by reaon of the looenes of thoe ligaments, that the womb is moved with uch force, that it falls down; and in the act of Copulation is moved up and down; ometimes it moves upward, that ome Women do affirm that it acends as high as their Stomack. Now though the Womb be one continued body, yet it is divided into the Mouth, and the Bottom.

The Bottom of the Womb is called all that which, by till acending, tretches it elf from the internal Orifice to the end; being narrow toward the Mouth, but dilating it elf by little and little, 'till it come at the entrails.

The Mouth of the womb, is that narrownes between the neck and the bottom; it is an oblong and tranvere Orifice; but, where it opens it elf, orbicular, and round; the circumference very thick, and of an exquiite feeling; and if this mouth be out of order, and be troubled with a Scirrhous brawn, or over-fatnes,
over-moiture, or relaxation, it is the caue of Barrennes. In thoe that are big with Child, there ues to tick to this Orifice, a thick vicous glutinous matter, that the parts moitned may be the more eaily opened. For in the delivery, this mouth is opened after a very trange and miraculous manner, o that according to the bignes of the birth, it uffers an equal dilatation, from the bottom of the womb to the privy member.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of the preparing Veels in Women.
div.p: THE Spermatick Preparing Veels,The Veels. are two Veins, and two Arteries, differing not at all from thoe of men, either in the number, original, action, or ue, but only in their bignes, and the manner of their inertion. For as to their number, there are o many veins, and o many Arteries as in men. They arie alo from the ame place as in men; that is to ay, the right, from the trunck of the hollow vein decending; the left, from the left Emulgent.
There are two Arteries alo, on both ides one, which grow from the Aorta; thee both bring vital blood for the work of Generation.

As to the Longitude and Latitude of thee Veels, they are narrower and horter in Women; only where they are wrinckled, they are much more wreathed and contorted than in men; for, the way being horter in women than in men, Nature required, for tretching out thee veels, that they hould be more wrinckled and crankled than in men, that the blood might tay there in greater quantity, for preparation of the Seed.

The Inertion of the veels.Thee veels in Women are carried with an oblique coure through the mall guts to the Stones, being
wrapt up in fatter membranes; but in the mid-way they are divided into two branches, whereof the greater branch goes to the Stone, contituting the various or winding body, and thoe wonderful inoculations, the leer branch ends in the womb; in the ides of which it is cattered up and down, and chiefly at the higher part of the bottom of the womb, for nourihment of the Womb, and of the birth; and that ome part of the flowers may be purged out through thoe Veels: now becaue the Stones of Women are eated near the womb, for that caue thee veels fall not from the Peritonaeum, neither make they uch paages as in men, neither reach they to the Share-bone.

The ue of thee Spermatic Veels, is to miniter to the generation of Seed, according to the ancient Doctrine; but to the nutrition of the Eggs in the Stones, according to the new, and for the nourihment of the Foetus, and of the olid parts, and the expurgation of the coures; in as much as blood is convey'd by the Arteries to all thoe parts, to which their Ramifications come, in which parts they leave what is to be eparated, according to the law of Nature, the remaining blood returning by the Veins.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of the Stones in Women.
div.p: THE Stones of Women, although they do perform the ame actions, and are for the ame ue as mens, yet they differ from them in ituation, ubtance, temperament, figure, magnitude, and in their Covering.

They are eated in the hollownes of the Abdomen;Their Situation. neither do they hang out as in men, but they ret
upon the Mucles of the Loins, and this for that caue that they might be more hot and fruitful; being to elaborate that matter, with which the Seed of man engenders man.

In this place aries a Quetion, not trivial;A doubt. whether the Seed of Woman be the efficient, or the material caue of generation? To which it is anwered, that though it have a power of acting, yet it receives the perfection of that power from the Seed of Man.

The Stones of Women differ from mens alo,Their figure. as to their figure, becaue they are not o round and oval as thoe of men, being in their fore and hinder part more depreed and broad, the external uperficies being more unequal, as if a great many knots and kernals were mixed together. There is alo another difference, as to the ubject, becaue they are ofter and moiter than thoe of men, being more looe and ill compacted.
Their bignes and temper.Their magnitude and temperament do alo make a difference: for the Stones of Women are much colder and leer than Mens; which is the reaon that they beget a thin and watry Seed.

Their coverings alo do make a difference: for mens are wrapt up in divers Tunicles, becaue being pendent outward, they were otherwie more ubject to external injuries; but the tones of women have but one tunicle, which though it tick very cloe to them, yet are they alo half cloathed over with the Peritonaeum.

They have but one membrane, that encompaes them round, but on their upper ide, where the preparing Veels enter them, they are about half way involved
in another membrane that accompanies thoe Veels, and prings from the Peritonaeum. When this cover is removed, their ubtance appears whitih, but is wholly different from the ubtance of Mens Stones; for mens are compoed of Seed-veels, which, being continued to one another, are twenty, or thirty ells long; if one could draw them out at length, without breaking: but Womens principally conit of a great many membranes, and mall fibres looly joined to one another; among which, there are everal little bladders full of a clear Liquor, thro' whoe membranes, the nerves, and preparing Veels run. Galen and Hypocrates, and their followers, imagine the Liquor contained in thee Bladders to be Seed; but from Dr. Harvey downwards, many learned Phyicians, and Anatomits, have denied that Women have Seed. Some Women, ays Dr. Harvey, end forth no uch humour as is called Seed, and yet they conceive; for I have known everal Women, ays he, that have bin fruitful enough without uch emiion, yea, ome that after they begun to emit uch an humour, tho' indeed they took greater pleaure in Copulation, yet grew les fruitful than before. There are alo infinite intances of Women, who tho' they have pleaure in Copulation, yet end forth nothing, and notwithtanding conceive. It is moreover to be oberved, that the humour is cat out, and iues mot commonly from about the Clytoris, and Orifice of the privities, and very rarely from any depth within the neck of the Womb, but never within the Womb it elf, o as that it hould be there mixed with the mans Seed; beides it is not ropy and oyly like Seed, but erous like Urine. We mut therefore agree with that new, but neceary Opinion, that uppoes thee little Bladders to contain nothing of Seed, both becaue the
Liquor is ent forth in a greater quantity, than can be upplyed from them, and alo, becaue they have no paage, whereby the Liquor contained in them might iue out; for if you pres them never o hard, unles you burt them, nothing will pas out of them; therefore it mut be concluded, that they are truly Eggs, Analogous to thoe of Fowl, and other Creatures, and that the Stones o called are not truly o, nor have any uch Office, as thoe of Men, but are indeed an Ovarium, wherein thee Eggs are nourihed by the blood Veels, dipered through them, and from whence one or more, as they are fecundated by the Mans Seed, eparate, and are convey'd into the womb by the Fallopian tubes. If you boyl thee Eggs, their Liquor will have the ame colour, tate, and conitency with the white of Birds eggs, and their difference in wanting hells is of no moment; for Birds eggs have need of a hell, becaue they are hatched without the Body, and are expoed to external injuries; but thee of Women, being fotered within their body, have no need of other fence than the Womb, whereby they are ufficiently defended. Thee Eggs in Women are commonly towards the number of twenty, in each Teticle, whereof ome are far les than others: The objection of the Galenits againt the Aritotelians, (viz. That the Stones of Females mut needs make Seed, becaue, when they are cut out, barrennes always follows) will be ufficiently obviated by this new Hypotheis, that agrees to the neceity of the tones o far, as to affirm, that the little Bladders contained in them, become, when they are impregnated by the maculine eed, the very conceptions themelves, which would be in vain to expect, if the female were catrated.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of the deferent, or Ejaculatory Veels.
div.p: THE Deferent Veels are two blind paages, on both ides one, nothing differing in ubtance from the permatick Veins.
