They rie in one part from the bottom of the Womb, neither do they reach from their other extremity, either to the Stone, or to any other part; but are hut up, and unpaable, adhering to the womb, jut as the blind Gut adheres to the Colon; but winding half way about the Stones, are every way remote from them, no where touching them; only are tied to them with certain Membranes, not unlike the wings of Bats, through which certain Veins and Arteries, being produced from the Stones do run; and end in thee paages. Where they begin, at the bottom of the womb, they are hollow and large; but as they proceed further on, they grow narrower, till, near their end, they do again obtain a larger bignes; thee two paages thus running from the corners of the womb to the Stones, are taken only to be certain ligaments, by which the Stones and the Womb are trongly knit together; and thee ligaments in Women, are the ame things with the Cremateres in men.

Galen and mot of the Antients counted thee hort procees, that go treight from the Stones to the bottom of the Womb, to be ejaculatory Veels, and that the eed was cat from the Stones thro' them into the bottom of the Womb, and ome others have thought, they have found a mall pipe paing on each ide out of thee procees, by the ides of the Womb to its neck, into which they were inerted, and opened near its Orifice. By the former it was uppoed, Women not with Child did cat their eed into the bottom
<1 page duplicate>
<1 page duplicate>
of the Womb, and by thee latter, uch as were already impregnated; for that if it hould have iued into the bottom of the womb, where the conception was, it would have corrupted, to the great prejudice of the Faetus. But many accurate Anatomits have not bin able to find the leat foot-tep of thee latter ducts; and as for the former, eeing they have not any cavity, and therefore can have nothing of eed in them, we mut conclude, that they are only ligaments of the tones to keep them in their place; and this may be proved farther, by oberving that they come not into the inner cavity of the womb, but are knit only to its outward Coat, and there are only two holes in the bottom of the womb, that admit a probe, and thoe lead to the fallopian tubes, and not to thee ligaments.

Seeing therefore, that thoe which have bin accounted ejaculatory Veels, either are not to be found at all, or are found unfit for uch an Office, and having withal rejected the Opinion of Womens having eed, and affirm'd, that that which makes the Conception, is one of thoe little bladders in the tones, dropping from thence, and conveyed into the womb, we mut enquire by what way they can pas; for if the aboveaid ligaments reputed deferent Veels, have no paage, whereby the eed, if there were any might pas, much les cou'd one of thee bladders be conveyed that way; and therefore, for deferent Veels, we aign thoe paages, that are called the fallopian tubes, they are very lender, and narrow paages, nervous and white, ariing from the ides of the womb, and at a little ditance from it, they become larger, and twit like the tendrel of a Vine, 'till near their end, where ceaing their winding, they grow very large, and eem membranous and flehy, which end is very much torn and jaggy, like the edge of rent Cloaths, and has
a large hole, which always lies cloed, becaue thoe jags fall together; but yet being opened they are like the outmot orifice of a bras Trumpet Thee tubes are the ame in Women, that the horns of the womb are in other Creatures, for they anwer to thoe, both in ituation, connection, amplitude, perforation, likenes, and alo office: For as other Creatures always conceive in the Horns, o it has been ometimes oberved, that a Conception has in a Woman bin contained in one of the tubes, which mut have happened, when the Egg, being received out of the tone into it, has been topt in its paage to the womb, either from its own bignes, or ome obtruction in the tube. The ubtance of the tubes is not nervous, as Fallopius affirms, but membranous; for they conit of two membranes, the outer and inner; the inner prings from, or at leat is common with that, which covers the inner ubtance of the womb: But whereas it is mooth in the womb, it is very wrinkled in the tubes, the outer is common with the outmot of the womb, and this is mooth.

The capacity of thee paages varies very much, for in the beginning, as it goes out of the womb, it only admits a britle; but in his progres, where it is mot capacious, it will receive ones little finger, but in the extremity, where it is jagged, it is but about a quarter o wide, their length alo is very uncertain, for they ometimes increae from four or five, to eight or nine fingers breadth long. Their ue is in a fruitful Copulation to grant a paage to the finer part of the man's Seed, or of a eminal fume towards the tones, to bedew the Eggs contained in them, which Eggs, one or more being thereby ripened, and dropping off from the tone, are received by the extremity of the tubes, and carried along their inner cavity to the womb.

Two objections may be made againt this ue: Firt, That the end of the tube not ticking cloe to the tone, when one of the Eggs drops from the tone, it would more probably fall into the cavity of the belly than light jut pat in the mouth of the tube. Secondly, when it is received by it, its paage is o narnow, that it is hard to imagin how it can pas by it: But as to the firt, the ame objection may lye againt the ue of the oviduct in Hens; for in them it does not join quite cloe to the Ovarium, and yet it is certain, that the rudiments of the Eggs do all pas by them to the womb. Moreover it is probable, that when all the other parts of the Genitals are turgid in the act of Copulation, thee tubes alo may be in ome meaure erected, and extend their open mouth to the tones, to impregnate the Eggs with the eminal fume thro' their paage, and if any one be ripened, and eparate, to receive it afterwards by its orifice. As to the econd objection againt the narrownes of thee tubes, he that coniders the traightnes of the inner orifice of the womb, both in maids and in women with Child, yet oberves to dilate o much upon occaion, as to grant a paage to the Child out of the womb, cannot wonder that to erve a neceary end of Nature, the mall paages of the tubes hould be o far tretched, as to make way for an Egg, eeing its proportion to their paage, is much les, than of the Child to the uual largenes of the aid orifice.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of the Actions and Ues of the Genital parts in Women.
div.p:
IN the privie part, are een the Pubes, the mountains of Venus, the two lips, the orifice under which the two wings lye hid, the little knobs of fleh, reembling
Myrtle-berries, the paages of the Urine, and the Clytoris.

As for the Pubes, and the Mountains of Venus, they erve for this ue, that the great Orifice might be the better hut, and to avoid compreion in copulation; for which caue they are beet with hair, and are covered with a hard kind of fat; the great Orifice receives the Yard, and gives paage to the Ur • ne and the birth. The ue of thee Wings, or knobs of fleh like myrtle-berries, are for the defence of the internal parts, hutting the Orifice of the neck let cold air, dut, or any other annoyances hould hurt it, from without; and while they well up, they caue titillation and deire in thoe parts. Latly, the paages of the Urine being hut up by the knobs of fleh, reembling myrtle-berries, hinders the unvoluntary paage of the Urine.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of the Action of the Clytoris.
div.p: THE action of the Clytoris is like that of the Yard, which is erection; which erection is for the motion, and attraction of the Seed.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of the action and ue of the Neck of the Womb.
div.p:
THE action of the neck of the Womb, is the ame with that of the Yard, that is to ay, Erection, which is occaioned divers ways. Firt, all this paage is erected, and made treight, for the better conveyance of the Yard to the Womb, Then, while the whole paage is erected, it is repleted with
pirit and vital blood, whereby it becomes narrower for the more treight embracing of the Yard.

The caues of this erection are; firt, becaue if the womb were not erected, the Yard could not have a convenient paage into the womb; econdly it would hinder convenient affrication, without which the Seed could not be drawn forth. Latly, it hinders any hurt, or damage which might be done by the violent force of the Yard.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of the ues of the veels running through the neck of the Womb.
div.p: FIRST, it is required that there hould be a concurrence of divers Veins and Arteries, for the nourihment of that part; and though that part it elf, being full of Membranes, does not require much nourihment, yet by reaon that it is to uffer Erection, that could not be done but by blood and pirits, which are contained in thee veels: Beides, although the ubtance of this part be of a cold temperament, being notwithtanding till heated by the act of Copulation, that heat would oon conume a lender nourihment; which nature hath upplied, by the concoure of thee Veels. Another caue of the plenty of thee veins, is nourihment of the Birth, and the excluion of flowers.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Of the actions of the Womb.
div.p: THE firt ue of the Womb is to attract the Seed by a familiar ympathy, jut as the Second ue is to retain it, which is properly called Conception.
The third is to cherih the Seed thus attracted, to alter it, and change into the Birth, by raiing up that power which before lay leeping in the Seed, and to reduce it from power into act.

The fourth action of the Womb is to end forth the birth at the time prefixed; the apt time of expulion, is, when the expulive faculty begins to be affected with ome ene of trouble, that is, when the Birth afflicts and opprees the Womb with its own weight.
Beides thee ues, it hath thee moreover; To nourih the Birth, and to dilate it elf, which it doth by the help of Veins and Arteries, which do fill more and more with matter, as nature requires.

The chiefet action of the Womb,The proper actions of the Womb. and mot proper to it, is, the retention of the Seed; without which, nothing of other actions could be performed for the Generation of man.

div.head: CHAP. XV. Of the Utility of the Womb.
div.p: FIRST, it is the mot fit place for Copulation, as being in a place furthet removed from the enes; near which it were not fit to be, by reaon of the inconveniencies which would necearily arie.
It is mot fit to receive the Birth, as being hollow; in which concavity the birth may increae to its full proportion every way.

It is mot fit for the excluion of the Birth, as being placed downward, whereby the birth might help it elf with its own weight; and alo by reaon of the Mucles of the Abdomen, which erve for compreion, and do help the endeavours of the mother.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Of the Utility of the preparing Veels in Women.
div.p: THE Utilities of thee Veels are taken from their Original, and from their Inertion, the right Vein riing from the Hollow; and the left from the Emulgent, as in men; that the more hot and purer blood might come from the right vein, for the procreation of Males; and the more erous and watry blood from the Emulgent, for the generation of Women.

The Veels alo in women are horter than in men, becaue the way is not o far to the Stones; which brevity of the Veels is lengthned out by the many turnings and windings with which thoe Veels are endued. In the middle way, thoe Veels divide themelves like a Fork, the greater part going to the Stones, carrying the matter for Seed; the leer is carried to the womb, where it catters it elf all along the ides of it, for the nutrition of the Womb.
As for the Arteries, they afford the blood which is more full of pirits to perfect the Seed.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. Of the Utility of the Stones.
div.p:
THE ue of the Stones in Women, is the ame as in men; that is to ay, to prepare the Seed, and to make it fit for procreation. They are eated within, that they hould not want a continual heat, to cherih them; for the matter of Seed being colder in women than in men, it requires a greater heat, which it would of neceity want, were the Stones placed outward, like thoe of men; and for that caue are they
covered only with one Tunicle, that the heat of thoe parts may more eaily pas to them. And therefore the Stones of women are ofter than thoe of men becaue they hould not perfect o ubtantial a Seed; and that the heat of the adjacent parts hould not be wholly taken up in the cherihing of them.

Their figure is not exactly round,Their figure. but depreed, that the little Meanders of the veins dipered through the Membrane, from the Stones to the deferent Veels, might have more room to be incerted for the attraction of the Seed, out of the whole ubtance of the Stones. The inequality and ruggednes of them makes for the longer tay of the Seed in thoe crooked and winding Veels.

div.head: SECT. III.
CHAP. I. Of the igns of Conception.
div.p: HAving thus hewed you the Anatomy and Ue of the parts,Signs of Conception. it will be requiite to dicoure of the Conception it elf, which is the main and chief end of thee Veels: And firt of the igns of Conception.
The igns of Conception on the Mothers ide, are certain and apparent; firt, if after he hath had the company of her Husband, he hath received more content than ordinary.

Pains in the head, giddines, dimnes of the eyes; all thee concurring together, portend conception; the apples of the eyes decreae, the eyes themelves well, and become of a dark colour, the veins of the eyes
wax red, and well with blood, the eyes ink, the eyebrows grow looe, various colours appear in the eyes, little red pimples rie in the face, the veins between the Noe and the Eyes well with blood, and are een more plain; the vein under the tongue looks greenih, the neck is hot, the back bone cold, the veins and arteries well, and the pules are oberved more eaily; the veins in the breat firt look of a black colour, but afterward turn yellowih, the Teats look red; if he drink cold drink, he feels the cold in her breat, he loaths her meat and drink, he hath divers longings, but her natural appetite is detroyed: Continual vomitings follow, and weaknes of the tomach, our belches worms about her Navel, faintnes of the loyns, the lower part of her belly welling, inward griping of the body, the retention of the Seed 7 days after the act of copulation: After which act there is a cold and trembling which eizes the external members; the attractive force of the womb increaes; the womb dries up. It is alo a certain ign of conception, if the Midwife touching with her finger the interiour neck of the womb, hall find it exactly cloed, o that the point of a needle will not go between: The womb waxeth round and wells, the flowers ceae to flow (for the Veins through which they come down, carry the blood to the nourihment of the birth;) the thighs well with ome pain, the whole body grows weak, and the face waxes pale; the Excrements proceed lower out of the body: The Urine is white, a little cloud wimming at the top, and many atoms appear in the Urine. Take the Urine of a Woman, and hut it up three days in a glas, if he have conceived, at the end of three days there will appear in the Urine certain live things, to creep up and down. Take alo the Urine of a Woman, and put it in a baon a whole
night together, with a clean and bright needle in it, if the woman have conceived, the needle will be cattered full of red peckles, but if not, it will be black and ruty.

Conception is an action of the Womb, whereby the fruitful Seed of the Man and Woman are received and kept, that a Child may be formed. There are two kinds of Conception, one true, to which ucceeds the generation of an Infant; the other purious, and contrary to Nature, in this cae the Seed changes into water, fale Conceptions, Moles, or any other trange matter.

It is to be noted, that there is no abolute neceity, that all the Seed hould be received, and retained entire, nor mut we imagine that tho' all of it be not received into the Womb, the Child formed out of it will want ome Limb, as an Arm, or Leg, or other member, for want of ufficient matter; for the leat drop of Seed, nay only a fume of it is ufficient to impregnate, and form a Child: But when the quantity of the Seed is mall, the Child may be the les and weaker for it, or if the Man, or the Woman be di
• aed, or the Womb tuft with ill humours, the Child will be ickly, or Moles, or fale Births, or Dropies of the Womb will be occaioned.

Tho' a Midwife may gues that a Woman has conceived, when all the igns concur, or mot part of them together, and ucceively according to their eaons, yet many of thee igns happen upon uppreion of the coures, and none of them are o very certain, as not ometimes to fail us; wherefore in trials of Women, and upon giving phyick to them, great caution mut be ued; for after the Execution of ome Women, they have been found with Child contrary to the judgment of the Midwifes, and others after a
long coure of Phyick to open obtructions, and to cure a Dropie, have been delivered of Children.

div.head: CHAP. II. Whether he have conceived a Male.
div.p: Conception of a Male.IF he have conceived a Male Child, the right eye will move wifter, and look more clear than the left. The right pap will alo rie and well beyond the left, and grow harder, and the colour of the Teats will change more uddenly. The milk will increae more uddenly, and if it be milked out, and be et in the Sun, it will harden into a clear Mas, not unlike pearl. If you cat the milk of the woman upon her Urine, it will preently ink to the bottom. Her right cheek is more ruddy, and the whole colour of her face is more chearful; he feels les numnes: The firt motion of the Child is felt more lively in the right ide, for the mot part upon the ixtieth day. If her flowers flow the fourtieth day after Conception. The belly is more acute toward the navel. As the Woman goes, he always puts her right leg forward, and in riing he eaes all he can her right ide ooner than her left.

div.head: CHAP. III. Whether he have conceived a Female.
div.p: Conception of a Female.IF he have conveived a Female, the igns are for the mot part contrary to thoe aforeaid.

The firt motion is made mot commonly the ninetieth day after conception, which motion is made in the left ide; Females are carried with greater pain, her Thighs and Genital Members well, her colour is
paler, he hath a more vehement longing Her flowers flow the thirtieth day after Conception. Girls are begot of Parents who are by nature more cold and moit, their Seed being more moit, cold, and liquid.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the Conception of Twins.
div.p: IF a Woman have conceived Twins, Conception of Twins. the igns thereof appear not, till the third or fourth month after her Conception; and then they will appear by the motion of the Infant, and by the extraordinary welling of her Belly. As to the motion, it is plain, that he doth bear twins, if he perceive a motion on the right and left ide at the ame intant, which he perceives more quick and violent. As for the greatnes of the belly; If the Woman perceive it bigger than at any other times of her being with Child; as alo if the two flanks be welled higher than the middle of the belly: if there do appear as it were a line of diviion from the navel to the groin, making a kind of Channel all along; if the Woman carry her burden with more than ordinary pain: Thee are commonly the igns of Twins.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of fale Conception.
div.p:
WOmen do oftentimes deceive themelves concerning their Conception;Fale Conception. for they do many times believe themelves to be big with Child, when it is nothing ele but either the Retention of their flowers, which do not fall down according to their accutomed Periods of
time; or ele that which is called the Moon-calf, which is a lump of fleh, for the mot part like the guiern of a bird, greater or leer, according to the time of its being there, which is mot commonly not above four or five months.

Several orts of Moles. Of Moles there are two orts; the one is called the true Mole, the other is called the fale mole. The true Mole is a flehy body, filled with many veels,Of the true Mole. which have many white, green, or black lines, or Membranes; it is without growth, without motion, without bones, without bowels, or entrails; receiving its nourihment through certain veins; it lives the Life of a Plant, without any figure or order, being engendered in the concavity of the Matrix, adhereing to the ides of it, but borrowing nothing of its ubtance.

Of the fale Mole there are four orts;Of the fale Mole. the Windy Mole, which is a conflux of Wind; the Watry Mole, which is a conflux of watry humours; the Humorous Mole, which is a conflux of various humours; the Membranous Mole, which is a thin bag filled with blood. All thee four are contained in the concavity of the Womb.

Thee Moles are ometimes engendered with the Infant,Signs of Moles. though they do often caue the Infant to die; either becaue it doth deprive the Infant of that nourihment which goes from the Infant to the encreae of that; or ele becaue it hinders the growth and perfection of the Infant. The caue of the flehy Mole doth not always proceed from the Mother, for the Man doth often contribute to the increae of it, when the Seed of the man is weak, imperfect, and barren, or, though
it be good if there be too mall a quantity of it, which after it is mingled with the Seed of the Woman, is choak'd by the mentrual blood, and o not being ufficient for the generation of the Infant, intead thereof produces this little mas of fleh, which by little and little grows bigger, being wrapt about in a caul, while nature trives to engender any thing rather than to be idle.

It happens alo, when the woman, during her monthly purgations, receives the company of her husband, her body being not yet purged and void; or ele when the woman lies with a great deire and lut with her husband, after he hath conceived; or when he hath retained her monthly coures beyond her time.

The windy mole is engendered by the weak heat of the Matrix,The Windy Mole. and the parts adjoyning, as the Liver and Spleen, which engender a quantity of wind, which fix in the concavity of the Matrix.

The watry mole is engendred of many confluences of water,The Watry Mole. which the Womb receives, either from the pleen, or the liver, or the parts adjoyning, or ele from the weaknes of the liver which cannot aimilate the blood which is ent thither, for the nourihment of the thing contained in it; part whereof turns into water, which cannot be voided, but remains in the Womb.

That which is called the Humorous Mole, is engendred of many moit humours, eroities, or the Whites, or certain watry purgations, which weat forth from the mentruous veins, and are contained in the concavity of the Matrix.

The membranous Mole,The membranous Mole. is a skin or bag, which is garnihed with many white and tranparent veels, filled up with
blood: This being cat into the water, the blood goes out, and the membrane is een only to gather like a heap of clotted eed.

The igns of the windy Mole are thee; when the Belly is equally tretched and welled up like a Bladder, more oft than when it bears the Flehy mole, and epecially near the groins, and mall of the belly; if it be truck on, it ounds like a drum; ometime the welling decreaes, but by and by it wells more and more; the woman feels her elf more light, it is engendered and encreaes wifter than the flehy mole, or the Watry, and it makes uch a ditention of the belly, as if one were tearing it aunder: For the watry and humorous mole, the igns are almot the ame; the Belly increaes and wells by little and little, as the woman lies upon her back, the ides of her belly are more welled and ditended than the middle, or the bottom of the belly, which grows flatter then, by reaon that the water and the humours fall down to the ides of the belly, moving up and down on the belly, as if it were a fluctuation of water there.

This ditinction is to be oberved in the Watry Mole, that the flank and thighs are more tretched
and wollen than in the humoral, becaue that the waters flow thither oftentimes. And that which comes forth through Nature's Conduit, is as clear as Rock-water, without any ill avour; but that which flows out in the humoral ditemper is more red, like water wherein fleh hath been wahed, and is of an ill avour. This is alo to be marked in fale conceptions, that the flowers never come down, and the Navel of the Mother advances it elf little or nothing, both which happen in true conceptions.

There are, beides thee above-written, certain other Tumours which the Women do take for Moles. Thee occaion a rotundity and welling in the belly, which are not dicovered till the woman be opened, and then they do appear, though the body of the womb be clean and neat, without any thing contained in it, at one or both corners of the womb, a quantity of water, contained as it were in little bags; in others are to be een a heap of kernels and uperfluous fleh clutered up together in the womb, which caue it to well. Yet in thee women it hath been oberved, that their purgations have been very regular, which hath been a ign that the womb it elf hath been in good temper.

The pendent mole.There is alo another Excrecency of Fleh, which may be termed a pendent Mole, which is a piece of fleh hanging within the inner neck of the womb, which at the place where it is fatned, is about a fingers breadth, till increaing bigger and bigger toward the bottom like a little bell: This fleh hanging in the interiour neck of the womb, poees the whole Orifice of the privy member, ometimes appearing outward, as big as the fit, as hath been oberved in ome Women. Of the cures of all thee, we hall treat in due place.

div.head: CHAP. VI. How Women with Child ought to govern themelves.
div.p: IN the firt place, he ought to chue a temperate and wholeome air, neither too hot nor too cold, nor in a watry and damp place, nor too ubject to fogs and winds, epecially the South-wind, which is a great enemy to Women with Child, cauing oft-times abortion in them. The Northwind is alo hurtful, engendring Rheums and Catarrhs, and Coughs, which do often force a woman to lie down before her time. Likewie thoe winds which carry with them evil odours and vapours, for thee being ucked with the air into the Lungs, are the caue of divers dieaes.

For her Diet, he ought to chooe meat that breeds good and wholome nourihment, and which breeds good juice;Her Diet. uch are meats that are moderately dry; the quantity ought to be ufficient, both for themelves, and for their children, and therefore they are to fat as little as may be; for abtinence, unles upon good occaion, renders the child ickly, and tender, and contrains it to be born before its time, to eek for nourihment; as the over-much diet tuffs it up, and renders it o big that it can hardly keep its place.

All meats too cold, too hot, and too moit, are to be avoided, as alo the ue of Salads and Spiced meats, and the too much ue of alt meats are alo forbidden, which will make the child to be born without nails, a ign of hort life. Her bread ought to be good wheat, well baked and levened. Her meats ought to be Pigeons, Turtles, Pheaants, Larks, Partridge, Veal, and Mutton. For herbs, he may ue Lettice, Endive, Buglos, and Burrage, abtaining from raw Salads:
for her lat coure, he may be permitted to eat Pears, Marmalade, as alo Cherries and Damins; he mut avoid all meats that provoke urine, or the terms; and uch meats as are windy, as Peae, and Beans. Yet becaue there are ome Women that have uch depraved tomachs,Of longing. by reaon of a certain alt and owre humour contained in the membranes of the tomach, as that they will eat coals, chalk, ahes, cinders, and uch like trah, o that it is impoible to hinder them; to uch therefore we can only ay thus much, that they ought to forbear as much as in them lies, auring them that uch trah does not only endanger their own health, but the health of the child. Yet if they cannot command that depraved appetite, let them o provide, though it be by giving ome mall atisfaction to their depraved longings, that they do not haten any further inconvenience; for though thoe trange meats be very contrary to nature, yet the trange deire that they have to them, does not a little avail to the digetion of them. For her drink, let it be mall Ale, though now and then a cup of pure Wine does not amis, to comfort the Stomach, and the parts dedicated to Generation.

Her leepingHer time of leep is bet in the night, for the concoction of thoe meats which he hath eat in the day time: She mut avoid by all means, the leeping after dinner; he may leep full out nine hours; her leeping beyond that time is prejudicial.

Her Exercie.She may exercie her elf moderately; for violent excrcie looens the Cotyledones, through which the Infant receives its nourihment: the riding in Coaches is forbid, epecially, for the lat three months.
She ought to avoid great noies,Other precepts. as the noie of Guns, or great Bells.
Laughing and crying, if it be immoderate, is extreamly hurtful, as alo immoderate anger.

In the firt four months he ought not to lye with her Husband, for that hakes and moves the fruit of her Womb, and caues the Flowers to decend; he mut alo abtain in the ixth and eighth; but in the eventh and ninth it is not denied, and is thought to facilitate the Delivery.

She ought alo to keep her body oluble, which if it hould not come of it elf, he mut take looening Syrups to help nature; as oon as ever they perceive themelves to be with Child, they mut lay aide their Busks, and not treighten themelves any way, for fear of hurting the fruit of their Womb, by not giving it its full liberty of growth.

A Woman with Child ought to be accounted ick, for the time of going with Child is called a icknes of nine Months, and he is indeed ubject to many inconveniences on that account; therefore he ought to ue her utmot endeavour to prevent thoe many accidents he is then ubject to, and that he may preerve her elf in health, as much as her preent condition will allow of, let her be careful to oberve a good diet, agreeable to her contitution and condition. The air of the place where he dwells ought to be temperate; for if it be too hot it diipats the humours and pirits, and if it be moit and cold it occaions rheums and coughs whereby micarriages have been caued; ill mells are alo very offenive to Women with Child, as the tink of a candle, the mell of char-coal. Their Stomach generally loath Meat, and are weak; and therefore they mut pleae their Stomachs, and let them not fat too long, for thereby their blood is unfit to nourih the Child;
but they mut not eat too much at a time; epecially for Supper, becaue the bignes of the belly hinders the Stomach from containing much; wherefore let the Woman eat little and often. Her bread mut be made of good Wheat, white, and well baked; her meat may be Mutton, Veal, Fowl, or Pullets, Pidgeons, or Partridges, boyled or roated according as he likes bet. New laid Eggs are alo a good Diet, and to purifie the Blood, which is generally ill during the time of pregnancy; he ought to eat ometimes Broths with uccory, borrage or orrel boyled in it, but hot eaoned Pyes and baked meats mut be avoided; if he long for Fih, River fih, and thoe of running treams are to be preferred before others. But note, that this ought to be a general rule in this cae, viz. That if Women earnetly long for any thing, they mut have it. And becaue their Stomachs are always weak, they ought to drink ome good Wine, or ome other good Liquor at Meals to help digetion. All things very hot, and uch things as force Urine ought to be hunned, becaue they are apt to force the coures, and o to caue micarriage.

They ought to leep moderately, becaue by leep, the functions and the concoction are trengthened, whereas exceive watchings wate the Spirits, and weaken the faculties; therefore a Woman with Child ought to leep nine or ten hours at leat in a Night. As to exercie and ret, repect mut be had to the various times of pregnancy. At the beginning of the Conception, if the Woman perceives it, he ought, if her condition will allow of it, to keep in Bed, at leat till the fifth or ixth day, and not to convere with her Husband all that time, for then a little matter will caue micarriage: She mut not ride on Hore-back, or in a Coach, or Waggon, all the time he is with Child, epecially
when he is near her time; becaue thee kind of motions increae the weight of that which is contained in the Womb, and often caues abortion. But he may be carried in a Chair, or Litter, or walk gently. She mut forbear carrying or lifting heavy burthens, nor mut he raie her Arms too high, or dres her own head; for many have micarried, the ligaments of the Womb being relaxed on this account. And it mut be c • refully noted, that when he walks, he mut walk in low heeled hoes; for big bellied Women are apt to tumble, becaue they cannot ee their feet, by reaon of the bignes of their bellies; and he mut rather ret too much, than ue motion too much; for immoderate motion is very dangerous, and I believe the exercie of bigg bellied Women, when it has been immoderate towards the latter end of their reckoning, has been the chiefet and mot general caue of hard Labours; for many times the Child is put into a wrong poition by the motion and exercie of the Mother, or the Birth is unduly hatned; both which ometimes prove very prejudicial. The Woman ought rather the two lat Months of her reckoning to abtain from Copulation, the Body being thereby much moved, and the Belly compreed, which makes the Child ometimes take a wrong poture; and without doubt if thee things, that have been aid concerning exercie and ret were well regarded, the lives of many Women and Children would be aved, and much pain and orrow prevented.
Some Women are o very apt to micarry, that being frightned, or urprized, by the noie of a great Gun, or the ound of a Bell or a clap of Thunder they have micarryed.

Women with Child are ubject to be bound in the Bodies, the Womb by its weight preing the right gut and o hindring an eay dicharge of the Excrements.
In this cae, uch things as looen the belly are to be frequently ued. She may now and then eat tewed Prunes, or Veal-broth, or a Gliter of Mallows may be injected, but harp Gliters, and things that purge too much, mut be avoided; for Hypocrates ays, that too great an evacuation downward is apt to occaion micarriage.

The Womans mind ought to be kept edate and quiet, all melancholly news, and frightful objects mut be removed far from her, nor mut any thing that may caue orrow, be uddenly told her. She mut moderate her paions, and exceive anger mut by all means be avoided, for the paions do wonderfully affect the Child and often caue micarraige; ome have been born dumb, others have had a continual haking of their Limbs, and the like, when the Mother has been uddenly and violently urprized or frighted; wherefore it is bet to be dicouring of uch things before big-bellied Women, as may moderately rejoyce them, and that uch objects be preented, as may pleae and divert them; and if it be abolutely neceary to acquaint them with orrowful things, great care and caution mut be ued, and the miery mut be dicovered piece-meal.

Some Women are o very vain, that they will lace themelves hard with Bodice tifned with Whale-bone, to preerve their hapes forooth: but they do not conider what injury they do themelves; for their Breats being pret too much, are apt to be inflamed and impotumated, and the growth of the Child is hindered, and the Limbs of it too often disfigured thereby, and ometimes micarriage happens. They ought therefore at this time, to have their Cloaths more looe and eaie.

Some Women have alo a cutom to bleed once or twice when they are with Child, tho' they have no need of it, but this is certainly an errour, for Women
with Child ought not to bleed but upon neceity, ome having micarried by bleeding but once, a little too much blood being taken away, tho' others I confes, having blouded nine or ten times whilt they were with Child, and yet have not micarried. Now eeing all are not of the ame contitution, they mut not be all treated alike. Thoe that have mot blood can bet bear bleeding,
If Purging be thought neceary, gentle things mut be only ued, as Manna, Rhubarb, or the like.

Women with Child are ubject to many accidents, the firt is Vomiting, whereby they often judge they are breeding, it is not always occaioned by ill humours in the tomach, but ometimes from a ympathy betwixt the Stomach and the Womb, by the nerves inerted in the upper Orifice of the Stomach, which have communication, by continuity with thoe that pas to the Womb. Now the Womb, which has a very exquiite Sene, becaue of its membranous compoition, beginning to wax bigger, feels ome pain, which being at the ame time communicated by this continuity of nerves to the upper Orifice of the Stomach, caue there thee Vomitings; for Women that were in good health, before they conceived, Vomit from the firt day of their being with Child, tho' they have no ill humours in their Stomach.

If the Vomiting continues a long while, it weakens the Stomach very much and hinders digetion, tho' it oftentimes continues till the Women are quick, and then they recover their Appetite; but in ome it does not go off till they are delivered, and ome are mot afflicted with it towards the end of their reckoning, and this ort eldom ceaes before they are brought to Bed.

Vomiting at the beginning, if it be gentle, and without great training, is not much minded, and ometimes
it is beneficial; but if it continue after the third or fourth Month it ought to be remedied, becaue the nourihment being daily Vomited up, the Mother and the Child will be much weakened; and moreover, the continual ubverion of the Stomach cauing great agitation, and compreion the Belly, occaions micarriage. It is very difficult to prevent wholly this Vomiting, yet it may be much leened by a good Diet, and by eating little at a time; and to trengthen the Stomach, let her eat her meat with the juice of Oranges, or the like. Marmalade of Quinces is alo very good, being eaten after dinner, or after meals, and he ought to drink Claret-wine with water, and it is convenient to quench Iron in her drink. She mut forbear fat Meats and Sauces, for they much often the membranes of the Stomach, which were too weak and relaxed. Sweet and Sugar Sauces are alo injurious.

But if the vomiting continue, tho' regular diet has bin ued, the corrupt humours mut be purged off by tool, by ome gentle purge made of Mallows, Caia, Rhubarb, and the like; but if the vomiting continues, tho' the woman oberves a good diet, and tho he has bin purged, we mut do no more, for there is great danger of micarriage.

There are ometimes great pains in the back, reins, and hips, epecially the firt time the woman is with child, by reaon of the dilatation of the womb, and the compreion it makes by its greatnes and weight on the neighbouring parts The ligaments as well round as large, caue thee pains, being much traightened and drawn by the bignes and weight of the womb, namely the large one of the back and loins, which anwer to the reins, becaue thee two ligaments are trongly fatned towards thee parts; the round ones caue pains in the groins and thighs; where they end, they are ome
times o violently extended by this extream bignes, and great weight of the womb, that they are torn, epecially if the woman happen to tumble, which caueth violent pain, and much michief. A woman being ix Months gone with Child, upon tumbling felt omething crack in her belly, near the loins, and he preently felt great pain in her back, and in one ide of her belly, he vomited violently, and the next day was eized with a continual Fever, this lated even or eight days without leeping or reting an hour, and all the while he vomited up all he took; and he was alo very much troubled with Hicoughs, and had great pains like thoe of labour: But by keeping her bed twelve days, and by bleeding in her arm thrice, and by the ue of a grain of laudanum divers times, and by corroborating cordials he was omewhat eaed, and all the ymptoms went off by little and little, and he went her full time; and indeed there is nothing that will mitigate the pains of the back and reins better, than ret in bed, and bleeding in the Arm, epecially if they were occaioned by the ligaments broke, or two much extended, it may be convenient to keep up the belly with a broad waith, if the Woman cannot keep her Bed. Oftentimes when a Woman has conceived, the coures being topt, a great quantity of blood flows to the Breats, which makes them well and be painful, therefore to prevent inflammations, Women ought to take great care that they are not trait-laced, o as to compres the breats, and this is all that needs to be done at the beginning, only he mut be ure, that he receives no blows upon them; but it's better to bleed in the Arm after the third or fourth Month, if a great deal of blood flow to the Breats, then to endeavour to repel it on ome other part by atringent or repelling Medicines; becaue it does leat hurt in the breats than any where ele. It may be alo
convenient to ue an orderly cooling Diet to leen the quantity, and qualifie the heat of the humours. Big bellied Women ometimes are troubled with incontinence, and difficulty of Urine, becaue the Womb by its bignes and weight prees the Bladder, o that the common extenion of it being hindred, it is rendred incapable of holding uch a quantity of water as it ues to do; and therefore the nearer a Woman is to her time, the oftner he is forced to make water: but on the contrary if the neck of the Womb be preed, he makes water with great difficulty, and ometimes an heat and inflammation in the neck of the Bladder is the occaion of the uppreion of the Urine, and ometimes a tone is the caue, and if o, the pain is more violent, and much more dangerous than at another time, the Womb by its weight and bignes cauing the tone perpetually to pres upon the bladder. Thee frequent endeavours to make water ought to be prevented if poibly, becaue the continual forcing downwards to make water looens the Womb, and o ometimes occaions micarriage; and therefore, when it comes from the bignes and weight of the Womb, as it dos mot commonly, the Woman mut eae her elf by lifting up the bottom of her Belly, when he has occaion to make water or he may have a large waith fitted for that purpoe, to keep her Belly from bearing too much upon the Bladder. But keeping in Bed is the bet and uret remedy.

If an Inflammation of the neck of the Bladder be occaioned by harp humours, the Woman mut have a cooling Diet, and forbear Wine, and Morning, and Evening he mut take an Emulion made of Whey, Syrup of Violets and the cold Seeds, and this is very afe; for it cools and cleanes the paages of the Urine, and is no way injurious to the Mother or Child.
But if the pain and inflammation do not go off by the ue of thee things, to prevent any ill accident that may happen, a little blood m • y be taken from the Womans Arm, and the outward entry of the neck of the bladder may be bathed with a cooling and Emollient Decoction, made of Mallows Marh-mallows, Violets, and Lineeds; or Injections made of the ame Decoction with honey of Violets, or warm Milk may be cat into the Bladder. But if thee things do not do the buines, a Catheter may be ued from time to time to draw forth the water, and if the pain be violent, a half bath lukewarm may be ued, if he be not too much moved thereby: But all Medicines that force Urine mut be forborne, for they are very injurious to Women with Child, for they are apt to occaion micarriage. And if a Stone be the caue, it mut for the preent be only thrut back with the Catheter, for if you hould endeavour to draw it out, the life of the Child or Mother will be hazarded; wherefore it is bet to let it alone till the Woman is delivered.

When the Child lies high, coughs and difficulty of breathing afflict big-bellied Women, and when the cough is o much as to caue Vomiting, it is a very dangerous Symptom, being the mot apt to occaion micarriage, becaue the Lungs endeavouring to cat out the offending matter, deprees the Diaphragm, and thereby all the parts of the belly, and epecially the Womb.

Many things may alo occaion this cough, as alt Rheums flowing from the whole Body to the Breat, the uppreion of the coure, cold taken and the like. If it proceed from harp humours, or alt rheums, alt and high eaoned meats mut be avoided, and alo uch things as are harp, as Vinegar, Oranges, and the like, and intead of them, he ought to ue uch things as
moothen the paages of the Lungs and Breat, as Sebetins, Jujubes, Raions of the Sun, Liquorih, Sugar-candy, Syrup of Violets, and the like. It is alo proper to turn the humours downwards by a gentle Glyter. If thee things will not do the buines, and there is a ign of a great deal of blood, the Woman mut be blooded in the Arm, and tho' it is not common practice, to bleed at the very beginning of being with Child, yet it mut be done, when the cough is continual, for moderate bleeding is not o dangerous as uch a cough. If the cough be occaioned by a cold, the Woman ought to keep her Chamber, and to have her neck well defended from the cold with cloaths; and at Bed time, let her take three poonfuls of Syrup of burnt Wine, which is very good for the Breat, and helps digetion. It is made of half a pint of good Wine, two drams of Cinnamon bruied, half a dozen of Cloves, four ounces of Sugar, boyl them over the fire, burn the Wine, and afterwards boyl it to the conitence of Syrup. It is to be noted, that in this cae, the Woman mut be never trait-laced, and ome gentle Medicine to caue leep, ought be given; for uch things are particularly proper to top Rheums, and to thicken the matter. The following Anodyne may be ued every other night at Bed time upon occaion.
Take of Cowlip-water two ounces, of the Syrrups of Jujubes, and Meconium, each half an ounce, mingle them, make a draught.

Some Women, by their firt Child are o much oppreed in their Breat, that they fear they hall be choaked preently after eating, walking, or going up Stairs, the Child lying very high, by reaon the Ligaments that upport the Womb are not yet relaxed; and if upon this account the Lungs be full of Blood, they will breath more eaily after a little Blood is taken
from the Arm. But if the difficulty of breathing is occaioned by the Womb's preing upon the Midrife, the Cloaths mut be worn looe, and the Woman mut eat little at a time, and often; for full feeding opprees the Midrife, and increaes the difficulty of breathing; and he mut be ure to avoid windy Meats, as Peae, ea • ns, and the like: And Grief and Fear, if poible mut be far removed; for thereby Women are in danger of being uffocated, when their Heart and Lungs are before oppreed.

Women with child are ubject to Pains and wellings of the Legs and Thighs, which are ometimes alo full of red Spots, which much obtructs their walking; thee are occaioned by abundance of Blood, for Women that are anguine are mot ubject to thee wellings and pains, much walking and excercie do alo occaion them; to remedy or prevent which, a Woman o affected hould keep her Bed, and if there be igns of fulnes of Blood, he may be blooded in the Arm; but if he be forced to walk about, her Legs mut be waithed, beginning below and waithing upwards. But in ome Women, thee wellings are occaioned by weaknes and flegmatick humours, and if you pres the welling it will pit, as is uual in Dropies. In this cae the natural heat is not able to concoct the nourihment, and to drive out that which is uperfluous; for this ort of welling make a bath of Camomile, Melilot and Lavender, and the Ahes of Vines, afterwards foment with Aromatic Wine, and in it dip comprees to be laid on, and to be repeated three or four times a day. But uually thee wellings go off of themelves, when the Woman is delivered, the whole Body being cleaned by the Child-bed purgations.

Many big bellied Women are ubject to the piles, becaue the coures that were wont to be evacuated
monthly, are collected in a great quantity, and flow back upon the Body. They are alo occaioned by the Cotivnes of the body; they are painful Swellings and Inflamations occaioned by a Flux of humours to the Fundament: Some are internal, ome external, ome mall, and with little or no pain, and ome very big and painful. It is eay enough to prevent their further growth by remedies, which hinder and turn the Flux from thoe parts, when they are mall and without pain; but the greatet care is to be taken, when they are large and painful. Firt, therefore you mut endeavour to eae the pain, for as long as that remains, the Flux is ever increaed; and if Bloud abounds, he may be blooded in the Arm-once, and again, if the cae require it, to divert the humours, and to leen them. If Cotivenes be the caue, an emollient Gliter mut be injected, made of the decoction of Mallows, Marhmallows, Violets, and weet Butter, or Oyl of Almonds; but you mut be ure to add nothing that may fret or provoke the parts, leat the dieae hould be increaed thereby, epecially when the piles are within. Some put the mall end of a pullets gut upon the end of the Gliter-pipe, that it may be the eaier injected. You may ele anoint the wellings with Galen's cooling Oyntment mixed with an equal part of Populeon; or you may ue the hot troakings of a Cow, or you may foment with a Decoction of Marhmallows and lineed Oyls of weet Almonds, Poppies, and water Lillies well beaten together with the Yolk of an Egg, and ground in a leaden Mortar, give great eae. A cooling Diet mut be ordered, and the woman mut keep her Bed, till the Flux of the Humours is gone. If the Swelling do not abate upon the ue of thee things, Leeches mut be apply'd. But it is to be noted, that in Women with Child, the bleeding of the Piles may be beneficial, if
the Bleeding be moderate, and without pain. But if it flow in too great quantity, the Mother and Child will be weakened thereby; therefore if o, it will be neceary to apply an atringent Fomentation made of a Decoction of Pomgranate Peel, Province Roes, Granat Flowers, and a little Allom, and to turn the Blood, bleeding in the Arm is requiite.

Women with Child are ubject to everal Fluxes, viz. a Looenes, the Flux of the Coures and Floodings. There are three orts of Looenees, a Lientery, wherein the meat paes through raw and undigeted, a frequent Ejection of Excrement and Humours, Latly, the Bloody Flux, which together with the Evacuation of Humours and Excrements, voids Blood with violent pains. But whatever ort of Flux it is, if it be much and of long continuance, the Woman is in danger of micarrying; for in a Lientary, the Mother and Child are much weakened, that being cat out by Stool, which hould be the Nourihment; and the Strength and Spirits are much weakened by a common Looenes; but the bloody Flux is mot dangerous, becaue the frequent endeavours to go to Stool, greatly diturb the Womb. As to the Cure of thee Fluxes, whereof great Care ought to be had in time; for they occaion Micarriages; the Woman afflicted with a Lientery ought to ue meat of eaie digetion, and little at a time, that o her Stomach may be able to concoct it and he ought to drink Claret mixed with water, wherein Iron hath been quenched, and before and after Meals, a little burnt Wine, or good Canary may be drank, or a little Marmalade of Quinces may be eat.

If it be only a loones, and is gentle, and is not of long continuance, it needs not be much regarded, and therefore ought to be left to Nature, but if it continues
five or ix days, ome gentle purging Medicine ought to be ued, as Syrup of Succory with Rhubarb, or the like.

But great care ought to be taken in the bloody flux, let by its continuance it hould caue micarriage. In this cae the ill humours mut be firt purged off with Syrup of Succory and Rhubarb or the like, and Broaths made of Veal and Chicken with cooling herbs in them mut be ued to qualifie the Acrimony of the humours; and he mut drink Claret wine and Water, wherein Iron has been quenched, or half a Spoonful of Syrup of Quinces may be mixed with Water, and every other Night at Bed time after purging, he may take fifteen or 20 Drops of liquid Laudanum, and Gliters may be injected made of Calves Head, or Sheeps head Broath; and to prevent the frequent Endeavours of going to Stool, a Gliter made of Milk, and the Yolk of an Egg mixed, may be now and then injected. When a Woman is with Child, generally peaking, he ought not to have her Coures, becaue their ordinary paage is topt, and alo becaue the Blood is then employ'd for the Nourihment of the Child; yet ome big bellied Women have their monthly purgations till the fifth Month, and yet go out their time, and do very well. A Woman having her coures, thought he was not with Child, and becaue he found her elf indipoed, he advied with a Phyician, who by Bleeding and purging her made her micarry, after he had bin three Months gone with Child.

It is to be noted, that when Women with Child have a Flux of Blood, you mut carefully conider whither it be the ordinary Coures, or a real Flooding; if if it be the ordinary Coures, the Blood comes at the accutomed times, and flows by degrees from the Neck, near the inward Orifice of the Womb, and not from
the Bottom of it as may be perceived, if trying with a Finger, you find the inward Orifice quite cloed, which could not be if the Blood iued from the Bottom. It mut be likewie conidered whether the Coures flow, by reaon of the Superfluity of the Blood, the Acrimomony of it, or the weaknes of the Veels. If abundance of Blood be alone the Caue there being more than enough for the Nourihment of the Child, it injures neither Mother nor Child, but is a Benefit to both, provided it be moderate. But if there be not abundance of Blood, and if the Woman ue to have but a mall quantity of her Coures, before he was with Child, it is a ign that the Flux proceeds from the Heat and Acrimony of the Blood, or the Weaknes of the Veels.

To prevent this Flux, when it ought to be topt, the Woman mut keep in Bed, and forbear all things that may heat her blood, and mut oberve a cooling and trengthening Diet, and feed on Meat that breeds good Blood, and thickens it; as Broths made of Chicken, Knuckels of Veal and the like, wherein may be boiled cooling Herbs; Rice Milk and Barley Broth is alo very good, and in all her Drink quench Iron. She mut forbear Converation with her Husband. And to comfort the Child, which in this cae is uually very weak, Linnen dipt in trong Wine, wherein Cinamon and Pomgranat Peel has bin infued, mut be applyed to the Mothers Belly.

Flooding is much more dangerous than a Flux of the Coures; for the Blood comes from the bottom of the Womb with pain, and in great Abundance, and continues flooding daily without Intermiion; only ometimes Clods of Blood top it for a while, but afterwards it flows more violently, and detroys both Mother and Child if not eaonably top'd by the delivery of the Woman.

A fale Conception or a Mole, which the Womb endeavours to expel is uually the Caue, when the flooding happens when young with Child, whereby ome Veels at the bottom of the Womb continually cat forth Blood until the trange Body is ejected. But when a flooding comes upon a woman, that has truly conceived, at whatoever time it be; it proceeds likewie from the opening of the Veels of the bottom of the womb, occaioned by ome blow, lip, or other hurt, and epecially, becaue the after-birth eparating in part, if not wholly from the in ide of the womb, opens all the Orifices of the Veels where it was joined; and for this reaon a great flux of blood follows and never tops 'till after the delivery of the woman; for if but part of the after-birth only be once looened, it never joins again to the womb; and therefore the opening of the Veels cannot be topt, 'till all that is in the womb is expelled, and afterwards the womb like a punge queezed, contracts it elf and tops the Veels.

But tho' it be neceary to deliver the Woman preently, to top a great flooding, which manifetly endangers the womans life; yet it is to be noted, that when the flooding is mall, other things are to be firt tryed; for ome mall floodings have for ometimes bin uppreed by keeping quietly in bed, by bleeding in the arm, and proper remedies; and perh • ps it may in a hort time, be found to be only an ordinary flux of the Coures; if therefore the trength of the woman keeps up, and the flux be not attended with ill ymptoms, it is bet to leave the whole buines to Nature, but if the flux be very much, and the woman is afflicted with Convulions and Fainting, he mut be intantly delivered, whether he has pains and throws or no.

Sometimes women with child are oppreed with a great weight at the bottom of their bellies, by reaon
the womb bears down, and ometimes he cannot walk without pain and difficulty: In this cae the large ligaments of the womb are much relaxed, either by the burthen upon them, or by a fall, haking, or great pains, or bad labour in a former delivery. Sometimes alo a great many humours are the caue, for they moiten and relax the ligaments: This bearing down of the womb hinders coition, and caues numnes in the Hips and Thighs, and difficulty of Urine, and cotivenes. The bet remedy in this cae, whatoever is the caue of the bearing down, is keeping the Bed, for the ligaments are continually more and more relaxed by the weight when he is up; but if her condition or circumtances are uch, as will not admit of continual ret in the bed, he ought at leat to keep up her belly with a waith, and if the weight caues a difficulty of rendring her water, he mut lift up her belly as oft as he has occaion to make water; if humours be the caue of the relaxation of the ligaments of the womb, a drying dyet mut be contantly ued, and her meat mut be roated, and the woman mut be very careful when there is uch a weight, and relaxation of the womb, from whatoever caue it proceeds, that he be not trait laced, becaue thereby the womb is forced down; but above all, when he is in labour, care mut be taken that neither by means of the throws, which trongly force down the womb, nor by the birth of the Child, nor the violent extraction of the Burthen, he gets a precipitation intead of a bearing down, as is een often.

If a woman chance to be infected with the Venereal Dieae during her pregnancy, the cae is very difficult, for thoe Methods and Medicines, that are proper for the Cure of it, are apt to occaion a micarriage; and yet notwithtanding, if he be infected at her firt being with Child, or if the ymptoms are violent and dangerous, when he is • ear her time,
omething mut be done, for hould the dieae lie unregarded upon her even or eight Months, her mas of blood would be corrupted, and the venom imparted to the Child in her Belly; and tho' he be near her time, if the ymptoms are violent, he will be in great danger of being ruined, if Medicines be not preently ued to mitigate them

If it be only a Gonorrhea, or running of the Reins, ten grains of Mercurius dulcis, more or les, according to her trength, mut be given at Bed time, in form of a Bolus, in conerve of Roes or the like, and ome gentle purge the next Morning, and at Bed-time after the purge, you mut be ure to give ome Anodyne, to appeae the commotion raied by the Purge. The Bolus and Purge mut be repeated twice a Week, or oftner, if the trength will permit, and if no ill accident intervene. If the Urine be very hot and harp, it will be convenient to ue an emulion to mitigate the pain and heat, the following is of good ue.

Take of blanched Almonds number 12, of the four greater cold Seeds, each one dram and an half, of the Seeds of Lettice, and white Poppies, each half a dram, beat them in a marble Mortar, and pour on them a ufficient quantity of barly Water, make an emulion for two Does; add an Ounce of Syrrup of Violets and half a dram of Sal Prunella. If the privy parts are excoriated or welled, you mut foment them with a decoction of Mallows, and Fenugreek-eeds, and afterwards anoint the excoriated parts with the white Ointment with Camphor; but if the Dieae arie to a confirm'd Pox, a gentle Salivation mut unavoidably be ordered. Some venture to raie it with a Mercurial Ointment, but I think it is much afer to do it by Mercurius dulcis inwardly taken, and great care mut be taken to prevent icknes of the tomach, gripes and tools; therefore as oon as ever you perceive any icknes
of the Stomach, faintnes, or gripes, you mut leave off the ue of Mercury for a while, 'till the ymptoms are quieted by Opiats, and great care mut be taken that the flux do not rie too high.

That her breats, after her delivery, may not grow big, and well overmuch,Precepts concerning the breats. as alo to avoid the danger of too much blood, which being converted into Milk, may chance to curd and breed ome dieae in the breat: Therefore as oon as he perceives her elf with child, let her carry about her neck, a mall neck-lace of Gold, though ome do more eteem of a neck-lace of teel, or a little ingot of Steel, to hang between the two breats: You may alo foment the breats a quarter of an hour every morning, with the ditilled waters of Sage, Periwinckle, or ground-Ivy, making them firt luke-warm: When the third or fourth month of her time is come, and that he perceives the Infant to begin to well, and to grow big,Concerning the belly. he may wathe it with a linnen wathe-band, which he may anoint with ome convenient Pomatum; this keeps the Belly mooth, and from wrinckles, and from hanging down like a Tripe.

div.head: She may ue this Liniment, or Pomatum.
div.p: Take the Gall of a Kid, and of a Sow, of each 3 ounces, Capon-greae and Gooe-greae of each an ounce, and a half; cut thee into little pieces, and melt them in an earthen dih, putting thereto as much water as will uffice to keep them from burning; then train it through a linnen cloath, and afterwards having wahed it in fair water, until it be very white, add to it of the marrow of a red Deer, about an ounce; then wah it again in Roe-water, or ome other water of a good cent, and anoint the wathe-band therewith.

div.head: Or this,
div.p: Take of the greae of a Dogg, and the fatt of Mutton which is about the Kidneys, of each two ounces; the Seed of a Whale, about an ounce; Oyl of weet Almonds, about an ounce and half; prepare the greaes as aboveaid; then mingle them with the other things, and wah them in Roe-water, as before.

Some women that are loath to greae their bellies with thee ointments, do carry the skin of a Dogg, or ele the outward and thin pilling of a Sheep's skin: Take the skin of a Dog ready dret, for the making of Gloves; wah it a good many times in fair water firt, and afterward in Roe-water, then dry it in the hade, and moiten it in the foreaid Oyls.

div.head: Take this one more Liniment.
div.p: Take a quarter of a pound of freh butter, well wahed in fair water; of Roe-water, and of Oyl of weet-Almonds, an ounce; of the eed of a Whale, half an ounce; melt thee altogether, and anoint the belly. Thee Ointments are to be kept in a Gally-pot, covered over with Roe-water.

In the firt days of this Month it might not be unprofitable to be bathed in the following decoction, for the pace of a quarter of an hour; and being afterwards put to bed, to let her elf be well rubbed, and afterwards anointed with ome good Ointment all about the Navel, along the Os facrum, and the bone of the mall guts, and all about her hips and thighs.

div.head: You may ue this Bath.
div.p: Take of Mallows, Mah-Mallows, Mother-wort, of each two handluis; Roots of Lillies three Ounces, of Camomile and Melilot-flowers, of each a good handful; Lineeed, Quinces, and Fenugreek, of each an Ounce; boil all thee in fair water to make a decoction, for a half Bath.

div.head: You may ue this Ointment.
div.p: Take Hens greae, three Ounces; the greae of a Duck, an Ounce and a half; Oyl of Lineed, an ounce and a half; freh butter two Ounces; melt all thee together, and then wah them well, either in Pellitory-water, or in the water of Mug-wort, adding thereto two Ounces of the Mucilage of Marh-mallows.
If the Woman all her time do complain that he feels little or no motion of the Child, let her carry upon her Navel this following Quilt, which will give trength to the Infant.

Take Powder of Roes, red Corral, Gilliflowers, of each three ounces and an half; Seed of Angelica, two drams; Matick, a dram and an half, Ambergreece two grains, Musk one grain; put all thee in a bag of fine linnen, and quilt them together for the ue aforeaid. Thus much is to be oberved by women with Child that are in health, and have no other dieaes hanging upon them: but of the other dieaes incident to women with Child, we hall take a time hereafter to Treat.

The Womb-cake, otherwie called the Womb-liver, is much like the Spleen, it has abundance of Fibres; and mall veels, it is two fingers breadth, thin near the edges, and thick in the middle. And when the Child is ready for Birth, it is a quarter of a Yard over: It is mooth and omewhat hollowih on the ide next the Child, and is joined to the Chorion, but is very unequal on that ide next the Womb, and has many Bunchings out, by which it ticks fat to the Womb. When there are Twins, there are two Womb-Cakes, either ditinct in Shape, or eperated by a Membrane one from the other, and a particular rope of umbilical Veels is inerted into each from each Child; it at firt appears like a woolly Subtance on the outide of the outward Membrane, that encompaes the Child about the
ninth week; and a red flehy oft ubtance grows upon it in a hort time, that is unequal, and in little knobs, and thereby preently ticks to the Womb, and is very viible about the thirteenth Week; till this time the Child is increaed and nourihed wholly by the appoition of the Chrytaline or Albugineous Liquor, wherein it wims looe in the inner Membrane call'd Amnios, having no umbilical Veels formed, whereby to receive any thing from the Womb-cake: But when it grows bigger, and begins to need more Nourihment, the extremities of the umbilical Veels begin to grow out of the Navel by little and little, and are extended towards the Womb-cake, that they may draw a more nourihing juice out of it. It has Arteries, Veins Nerves, and Lympheducts, ome from the Womb, and ome from the Chorion. But tho' they are very large and viible in the Womb, yet they end but very mall Capillaries to the Womb-cake. Thoe Veels that come from the Chorion are Arteries and Veins, and perhaps the Lympheducts, the Arteries and Veins that come from the Womb, Spring from the Hypogatricks, and from that Branch of the Spermaticks, that is inerted into the bottom of the Womb, the Umbilical Veels of the Child come from the Chorion. The Womb-cake for the firt Month ticks very fat to the Womb, but when the Child is come to Maturity, it eaily eperates from the Womb, and falls from it like ripe fruit from a Tree, and after the Birth makes part of the Secundine. Next to the Womb-cake follow the two Membranes in which the Child is wrapt, the outer is called Chorion, the inner Amnios, and when the Child is perfectly formed, there is a third betwixt the other two called Allantois. The Chorion is omewhat thick, mooth on the inide, but omething unequal or rough; and in that part of it, that ticks to the Womb-cake, and thereby to the womb, there are
many Veels which rie from the Womb-cake it elf, and the Umbilical Veels. Twins are both encompaed in one Chorion, but each a particular Amnios, it covers the Egg originally, and when the Egg is carried to the Womb, and becomes a Conception, this membrane ucks up the moiture that abounds in the womb at that time; for while the Conception is looe in the Womb, it is increaed in the ame manner, as an Egg in a Hen, which while it is in the knot, it is only a Yolk, and when it drops off from thence, and falls thro' the Infundibulum, it is not at all altered, but when it comes into the Cells of the Proces of the Womb, it begins to gather white, tho' it adhere to no part of the Womb, nor has any Umbilical Veels but as Eggs of Fihes and Frogs do without procure to themelves whites out of the Water, or as Beans, Peae, and other Pule, and bread Corn, being teep'd in Moiture, well and o acquire Nourihment from the Bud that is pringing out of them. In like manner, does a whitih Moiture flow out of the Wrinkles of the Womb, whence the Yolk gathers its white, and concocts it by its vegetative and innate heat: And indeed, the Liquor that abounds in the Wrinkles of the Womb, tats like the white; and in this manner, the Yolk falling by Degrees, is encompaed with a white, till at lat, the outmot Womb having got Skins and a Shell, is brought to perfection: Even o the Chorion ucks up the albugineous Liquor that from the firt Conception increaes daily in it, and weats thro' the Amnios, wherein the Embrio-wims, till the Umbilical Veels and the Womb-cake are formed, from and thro' which, the Child may receive Nourihment. The Liquor that it ucks up is uppoed to be nutritious juice weating out of the Capillary Orifices of the Hypogatrick and permatick Arteries.

That Membrane that immediately contains the Child is called Amnios; it is joined to the Chorion only where the Umbilical Veels pas thro' them both into the Womb-cake, it is oft, mooth, very thin and tranparent, and looely invets the Child, the hape of it is omewhat oval; it has Veels from the ame Origins, as the Chorion. This Membrane before the Egg is ripened, contains a clear Liquor, which after impregnation, is that out of which the Child is formed. In it reides the formative power, and the matter from whence the firt Lineaments of the Child are drawn. But becaue this Liquor is o very little, there weats thro' this Membrane preently part of that nutritious albugineous humour that is contained in the Chorion, which it had uckt out of the Womb, and the Child receives its increae by Addition of this humour to its undicernable Rudiments. Yet after the formation of the Umbilical Veels and the Womb cake, the Amnios receives a nutritious humour after another manner, and not as before, only by tranudation. Milky Veins come directly to the Womb-cake, acrording to the Opinion of ome, and out of it arie others that carry the Chyle to the Amnios, but it is doubted of by others.

The Membrane call'd Allantoides is the third that encompaes the whole Child; it is very probable that this as well as the other two was originally in the Egg, yet it does not appear, till after the formation of the Umbilical Veels and Womb-cake, and 'till the Albugineous Liquor ceaes to be uckt up by the Chorion out of the Womb: but as oon as the Child begins to be nourihed by the Umbilical Veels, and the Urachus is paable, then this Membrane begins preently to appear. It contains the Child's Urine, brought into it by the Urachus from the Bladder, and with which it is filled more and more daily till the birth. This Membrane
is very thin, mooth, oft, and yet dene, it may be ditinguihed from the Chorion and Amnios, becaue they have a great many Veels dipered thro' them, but this has neither Vein nor Artery that is viible. After opening the Membranes that encompas the Child, the Navel-tring appears, which is membranous, wreathed, and unequal, ariing from the Navel, and reaching to the Womb-cake; it is about half an ell long, and a finger thick. The Veels contained in this tring are four, one vein, two arteries, and the Urachus wrapt in a common Coat. The Vein ries from the Liver of the Child, and is larger than the Arteries, and from thence paing out of the Navel, it runs along the common Coat to the Womb-cake, into which it is implanted by many roots; but before it reaches it, it ends ome little twigs into the Amnios. It was formerly thought, that the only ue of this Vein was to carry the blood from the Womb-cake to the Child, and ome till think, that it carries chyle. In the common coat are included alo two mall Arteries; they pring from the inner Iliack branches of the great Artery, and paing by the ides of the bladder, they rie up to the Navel, out of which they are conducted with the Womb-cake, in the ame common cover with the Vein and Urachus; wherewith they are twined like a Rope. Spirituous blood is driven from the Child by the beating of its Heart to the Womb-cake, and the Membranes for their nourihment, from which, what blood remains circulates back again in the umbilical vein, together with the nutritious juice afreh imbibed by its Capillaries dipered in the Womb-cake; but Blood and Vital Spirits are not carried by the Arteries from the Mother to the Child, as Galen and many others have taught. The Urachus is the fourth Umbilical Veel, which is a mall membranous, round pipe, endued with a very traight Cavity,
it ries from the bottom of the Bladder up to the Navel, out of which it paes along within the common Cover, and opens into the allantoides; thee four Veels have one common Cover, which keeps each of them from touching the other, which is called funiculus, it is membranous, round and hollow, and conits of a double Coat, it has everal knots upon it here and there, whereby the Midwives gues how many Children more the Mother hall have; but this is vain and upertitious. This Navel Rope is wont to be tied, when the Infant is born, one or two fingers breadth from the Navel, with a trong thread cat about it everal times, and then about two or three fingers breadth beyond the ligature, to be cut off; what is not cut off, is uffer'd to remain, 'till it drop off of its own accord.

There have been great diputes among Phyicians, with what, and by what way the Child is nourihed, ome ay by blood alone received by the umbilical Vein, others by chile alone conveyed in by the mouth; but indeed, according to the different degrees of perfection, that an Egg paes from a Conception to a Child fit for the Birth, it is nourihed differently; for as oon as an Egg is ripened, and falls into the womb, it immediately ucks up thro' its outward membranes ome of that albugonious liquor, wherewith at this time the internal uperficies of the womb is much moitened; and therefore as oon as the firt liniaments of the Child begin to the drawn out of that Humour contained in the Amnios, they are immediately increaed by the appoition of the aid liquor trained out of the chorion thro' the amnios into its cavity; but when the parts of the Child begin to be a little more perfect, and the chorion is o dene, that not any more of the aid liquor is uckt up by it, the umbillical Veels begin to be formed, and to extend to the ide of the amnios, which
they penetrate, and both the Vein and the Arteries pas alo through the allantois and Chorion, and are implanted into the Womb-cake, that at this time, firt gathering upon the Chorion, joins it to the womb, and now the hypogatrick and permatick Arteries, that before carried the nutritious juice into the cavity of the womb, open by their orifices into the Womb-cake, where either by training through it, or by fermenting, they put off the aid juice, which is uckt up by the umbilical Vein, and carried by it, firt to the Liver, afterwards to the Heart of the Child, where the thin pirituous part of it is converted into blood, but the thick and earthy part going down by the aorta enters the umbilical Arteries, and by thoe branches of them, that run through the amnios, is dicharged into the cavity of it. Some perhaps may ridicule this paage of the nutritious juice, becaue it is uppoed, according to this account to chue its way, as if it were a reaonable Creature, but they may as well expoe the paage of the Chyle from the common duct to the Womb-cake, when the Child is in the Womb, for how hould the Chyle know, or the milky Veels by which it paes, that there is any Child in the Womb, that the one hould offer to go that way, and the other give it way to go thither at that time; whereas the paage is hut at other times; and yet this, they that laugh at this paage of the nutritious juice, allow; and how comes the Chyle to turn its coure preently after the Child is born, and intead of going down to the womb, rie up to the breats. What reaon can be given for thee and many other things in nature? We are therefore forced to confes, that there are many things in nature, that are only known to Almighty God, the maker of all things. There is alo another objection againt this opinion, becaue it allows none of the Mothers blood to be received
by the Child thro' the Umbilical Vein, but only nutritious juice, and how hould it come to pas that the blood hould be bred in the Child, eeing it has blood before the Liver, or Heart, or any other part that aits in the making blood, are in a condition to officiate. It is indeed very trange, how blood hould be made o oon, but that it is made out of the Nutritious Juice, without the mixture of any from the Mother, is manifet by Dr. Harvey's curious Obervations concerning the order of the generation of the parts in a Chicken, which from firt to lat receives nothing from the head; (ays he) there appears at the very firt a red leaping Speck, a beating Bladder, and Fibres drawn from thence containing blood in them; and as far as one can dicern by inpection, blood is made before the leaping Speck is formed, and the ame has vital heat, before it is tir'd by the Pule: And as the beating begins in the blood, and from it, o at lat, at the point of Death it ends in it. And becaue the beating Bladders, and the anguinous Fibres that are made from it, and are een firt of all, it eems as if the blood were before its Receptacles. This Worthy Author, in his Treatie of the generation of Animals, owns it is a Paradox, that blood hould be made, and moved, and have vital Spirit before any Organs for making blood or of motion have a being; and that the Body hould be nourihed and increaed before the Stomach and Bowels the Organs of Concoction are framed. But neither of thee are tranger, than that there hould be Sene and Motion before there is a Brain. And yet he ays in his 57th Exercitation, that the Faetus moves, contracts, and tretches out it elf, when there is nothing to be een for a Brain but clear water. Now if all thee wonderful and unaccountable things do undoubtedly come to pas in an Egg, by the warmth of the Hen
only, why hould we count it a wonderful thing, that nutritious Juice impregnated with the vital Spirits of the arterial blood wherewith it circulates thro' the Mother's Heart, hould be turned into blood in a Child, comforted with the friendly warmth of the Womb, tho' the Mother ends no humour to it under the form of Blood, and tho' it elf as yet has no perfect Organs to make Blood.

The thicker nutritious juice being put off in the Amnios, by the umbilical Arteries, the Child ucks in ome of it, as oon as the Mouth, Stomach, and the like are perfectly formed, which going down into the Stomach and Guts, is received by the milky Veins, as in grown people. Diemerbrock proves that the Child is nourihed this way, by the following Reaons; firt, becaue the Stomach of the Child is never empty, but has a milky whitih liquor in it, and in the mouth of the Child, there is alo uch an humour. 2dly. Becaue there are Excrements in the guts, and the Child voids them by tool, as oon as it is born, and certainly thee are Excrements of ome nourihment taken in by the Mouth. 3dly.
