Had not the Stomach been accutomed to perform Concoction in the Womb, it would not preently after the Birth perform the ame. 4thly. Becaue the Infant preently after it is born, knows how to uck the Breat, which it cannot be thought it could o readily do, if it had taken nothing by uction, while it was in the Womb. 5thly. Becaue many Children vomit up a milky nourihment, as oon as they are born, before they have uckt any Breat, or taken any thing by the Mouth, which therefore mut needs be received into the Stomach.

Some ay by way of Objection to what has bin before et down, if the Child be not nourihed by the Mothers blood, why hould her Coures be topt, all or mot of the time he goes with Child? to which may be anwer • d,
that it is for the ame reaon, that Nures that give uck commonly want them alo, for as in Nures, the Chyle paes in a great proportion to the Breats, whereby the Blood being defrauded of its due, and wonted hare, does not increae to that Degree, as to need to be leened by the flowing of the Coures, o there is o great a quantity of the nutritious Juice, in women with Child that paes to the Womb-cake, by the Hypogatrick and Spermatick Arteries, for the Nourihment of the Child, that the Coures top after the firt or econd Month, if the Woman be not very anguine.

The Child is nourihed three everal ways, by one and the ame humour, firt by appoition, whilt it is yet an imperfect Embryo, before the Umbilical Veels are framed: But when the Umbilical Veels are perfected, then it receives the ame Liquor by the Umbilical Vein, the mot pirituous and thin part whereof, it changes into blood, and ends the thicker part, by the Umbilical Artery into the Amnios, which the Child ucks in at its Mouth, and being concocted again in the Stomach, is received out of the Guts by the mill • y Veins, as after the Birth.

The parts of a Child in the Womb differ very much from thoe in a grown peron. All the parts are les the bones are ofter, and many of them grily and flexible; the head is proportionably bigger than the ret of the Body, the Crown is not covered with Bone, but with a membrane, the Bone of the fore-head and under jaw is divided, the Bone of the hinder part of the Head is ditinguihed into three, four, or five Bones; the Brain and Nerves are ofter than in grown perons, the Bones that erve for hearing are very hard and big, the Breats well, and out of them, in Children new born, whether Boy or Girl a erous milk flows forth, ometimes of its own accord, ometimes with a light preure.
The pinous procees of the Vertebrae of the Back are wanting; the Heart is very big, and its Ears large; there are two unions of the greater Veels that are not to be een in grown perons, namely, Firt the Oval Hole, whereby there is a paage open out of the hollow Vein into the Vein of the Lungs, jut as each of them are opening, the firt into the right ventricle, and the latter into the left Ventricle of the Heart; and this hole jut as it opens into the Vein of the Lungs has a Valve, that hinders any thing from returning out of the aid Vein into the hole. Secondly, the Arterial Channel, which two fingers breadth from the Bais of the Heart joins the Artery of the Lungs to the Aorta, it has a pretty large cavity, and acends a little obliquely from the aid Artery to the Aorta, into which it carries the Blood that was driven into the Artery of the Lungs out of the right Ventricle of the Heart, o that it never comes into the left Ventricle, as the Blood that is ent out of the left Ventricle into the Aorta, never came to the right, but immediatly pat into it out of the hollow Vein by the Oval hole, o that the Blood does not pas thro' both the ventricles as it does after the Child is born. The Lungs will ink before the Child is born, whereas if the Child be but born, and takes only half a dozen of breaths, they become pungy and light, that they will wim; and by this may be known whether thoe Children that are murdered by Wenches, and which they commonly affirm they are till-born, were really o or no; for if they were till born, the Lungs will ink, but if alive, o as to breath never o little a while, they will wim. The Umbilical Veels go out of the Belly, the Stomach is narrower, but pretty full of a whitih Liquor; the Caul can carce be een, being omewhat like a Spiders web, the Guts are even times longer than the Body; in the
mall Guts, the Excrements are flegmatick and yellow, but omewhat hard and blackih, ometimes greenih in the thick Gut, the blind Gut is larger than uual, and often fill'd with Excrements; the Liver is very large and has a paage more than in grown People, called the Veiny Channel, it carries the greatet part of what is brought by the umbilical Vein, directly and in a full tream into the hollow Vein above the Liver; but as oon as the Child is born, this Channel cloes preently, o do the Urachus, and the two umbilical Arteries, the pleen is mall, the Gall Bladder is full of Yellow or Green Choler, the Sweet-bread is very large and White, the Kidneys are big, and unequal, and eem, as if they were compounded of many Glaudules, the Ureteres are wide, and the Bladder is tretch'd with Urine.

div.head: SECT. IV. Of the formation of the Child in the Womb.
CHAP. I. Of the mixture of the Seed of both Sexes, as alo of its ubtance and form.
div.p: AFTER that the Womb, which is the Genital Member of the Female Sex hath received the Seed of the Man, he commixes alo her own Seed, o that there is now but one mixture made of the Seed of both Sexes.

Now of the next matter, of the birth; There is a difference among the Learned, which being unneceary
The natural forme of a child lying in ye womb.
for this place we hall let go, and tick cloe to them, who affirm, that the eed of both Sexes, being confued in the Womb, doth make up the firt matter of the Birth; o that if there were not a mixture of both Seeds, it were impoible that any generation could be. Yet though there be of neceity a confuion of both Seeds, we deny not but that their qualities are different, for the Seed of a man exceeds the Seed of a Woman, both in thicknes and heat, which is more cold and moit, and therefore more watry. Yet though they differ thus in quality, it is not to be denied, but that the Seed of the Woman gives a mutual aitance to the Seed of the Man, in the work of generation.

But it being unquetionable, that the mentruous Blood is the matter of the Womans Seed, therefore that ye may know the Original of it, it is to be undertood that the Mentruous blood is nothing ele but an Excrement of the third concoction, gathered together every Month, and purged out. Which Purgation being duly made, the Woman is then in perfect health of body; but if they come not down according to their accutomed times, and eaons, or do not come down at all, the Woman neither can conceive nor engender.

Thus the Seeds of both Sexes meeting in the Womb, and there mixing together, they are preently encloed in a little Tunicle, begot by the heat of the Womb, and are there as it were coagulated and curdled together.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the three Tunicles which the birth is wrapt in, in the the Womb.
div.p:
FIRST, out of the extreme uperficies of the Seed, by reaon of the more watry moiture of the womans Seed, a thin Membrane is generated, which by
reaon of its moit quality is dilated farther, being at firt tranparent; but, after the Birth comes forth, folded up together, and is called the Secundine.

But of the uperfluous moiture of thee two Tunicles, are begot two other Tunicles, which defend the Infant from being clogged with any uperfluities, as from the Flowers retained after Conception, which erve neither for the nourihment, nor for the increae of the Infant. Yet are they retained 'till the very time of the Birth: At which time they are either let out by the hand of the Midwife; or ele burting the Secondine wherein they are contained, they flow out of themelves.

The econd Tunicle is that which was anciently called Allantoides, wrapping about all the interiour parts, frrom the Navel downwards; this is full of folds and wrinckles; in which the Urine, Sweat, and other harp Humours that ditill from the Infant, almot grown to maturity, are contained and kept to the time of Delivery.

By this econd Tunicle, therefore the Infant is delivered, and defended from thoe humours, let they hould either corrode, and hurt the tender skin of the Infant, or ele any way defile and foul the Infant.
The third Tunicle, within all thee, compaes the whole Birth round about, defending it from all harp exteriour humours, being very oft and tender.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the true generation of the parts, and the increae of them, according to the everal days and eaons.
div.p:
AFTER the Womb hath received the Genital Seed, and by its heat hath hut them both up, curdled and coagulated together, from the firt to the eventh day are generated many fibres, bred by a hot
motion, in which not long after, the Liver with its chief Organs is firt formed. Through which Organs the vital pirit being ent to the Seed, within the tenth day forms, and ditinguihes the chiefet members. This Spirit is let in through certain Veins of the Secondine, through which the Blood flows in and out, of which the Navel is generated. At the ame time, in the clotted Seed there do appear three white lumps, not unlike curdled Milk, out of which arie the Liver, the Brain, and the Heart.
Preently after this, a Vein is directed through the Navel, to uch the thicker ort of the Blood that remains in the Seed, for the nourihment of the parts. This Vein is two-forked.

In the other branch of this Vein is a certain blood collected,The Liver framed. out of which the Liver is firt framed; for the Liver is nothing but a certain mas of Blood, or Blood coagulated, and hardned to a ubtance: And here you may ee what a company of Veins it hath, which erve both for the expulive, and attractive faculty. In the other Branch are generated thoe Textures of Veins, with a dilatation of other Veins, as alo of the Spleen, and the Guts in the lower part of the Belly; by and by all the Veins like branches gathering into one Trunk, toward the upper part of the Liver, meet all in the Concave or hollow Vein. This Trunk ends other branches of Veins, to contitute the Diaphragme, others it ends into the upper part of the back-bone, eated about the Diaphragme, as alo the lower parts, as far as the Thighs.
Afterwards the Heart with its Veins, directed from the Navel to that part of the Seed, and carried as far as the Back-bone, is formed.

Thee Veins uck the hottet,The Heart formed. and mot ubtil part of the Blood, out of which the
heart is generated in the membrane of the heart, otherwie called the Pericardium, being by nature thick and flehy, according as the heat of the Members requires. Now the hollow vein extending it elf and piercing the interior part of the right ide of the heart, carries blood thither for the nourihment of the heart: From the ame branch of this vein, in the ame part of the heart aries another vein called by ome the till vein, becaue it beats not with o quick a Pule as the others do, ordained to end the mot purely concocted blood in the heart to the lungs, being encompaed with two Tunicles like Arteries, But in the concavity of the left part of the heart aries a great beating vein, called the Aorta, diffuing the vital pirit from the heart into all the beating veins in the body.

Under the aid vein called the Aorta, in the concavity of the heart, there is another vein called the veiny Artery, which was therefore framed to carry the cool air from the lungs to temper the great heat of the heart.

Now there being many veins, which running from the concavity of the heart, are inerted into the lungs, therefore by thee veins the lungs are alo framed; for the vein which proceeds from the right concavity, produces a mot ubtile blood, which is turned into the ubtance of the lungs. By the great veins of the heart and liver the hollow vein, and the Aorta is the whole breat generated, and after that the arms, and legs in order.

Within the foreaid time, is generated the lat and chiefet part of this ubtance, that is to ay, Brain, in the third little skin of this mas: For the whole mas of the Seed being repleat with vital pirits, that vital pirit contracts a great part of the Genital moiture into one certain hollownes, where the Brain is formed; outwardly it is covered with a certain covering, which being baked and dried by the heat, is reduced into a bone, and o is the Skull made.

Now the Brain is o formed as to conceive, retain, and change the nature of all the vital pirits, whence are the beginings of Reaon, and of all the Senes; for, as out of the Liver arie the Veins, out of the Heart arie the Arteries, o out of the Brain arie the Nerves of a more oft and gentle nature, yet not hollow like Veins, but ollid. Thee are the cheifet intruments of all the Senes and by which all the motion of the Senes are made by the vital Spirit.

After the Nerves, is generated by the Brain, alo the pith of the back-bone, which cannot be called Marrow: For the Marrow is a uperfluous ubtance begot out of the Blood, detined for the moitening, and for the trengthening of the bones: but the brain and pith of the back-bone take their beginning from the Seed, being not detined for the nourihing, or trengthning of the members but to contitute certain private and particular parts of the body, for the motion and ue the Senes, that all the other. Nerves may take their begining thence; for from the pith of the back-bone, do arie many Nerves, by which the body obtains both ene and motion.

Here is alo to be noted, that out of the Seed it elf are generated gritles, bones, tunicles, for the Veins of the Liver, the arteries of the heart, the brain with its Nerves: beides, the tunicles and pannicles, and the other coverings which the Infant is wrapt in. Now of the proper blood of the Birth, the fleh is formed; and whatever parts are of a flehy ubtance; as the heart, the liver, the lights, Then are all thee nourihed by the mentrous blood, which is attracted through the veins of the Navel. This is all ditinctly done from the conception unto the eighteenth day of the firt month, in all which time it is called Seed. After which it receives the name of Birth.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the nourihment of the Birth in the Womb.
div.p: WHilt the Birth remains in the Womb, it is cherihed up with blood attracted through the Navel, which is the reaon that the flowers do ceae alwayes in Women, as oon as they have conceived.

Now this blood, preently after conception, is ditinguihed into three parts; the puret of it drawn by the Child for the nourihment of it elf; the econd, which is les pure and thin, the Womb forces upwards to the breat, where it is turned into milk. The third and mot impure part of the blood remains in the Matrix, and comes away with the Secondines, both in the Birth, and after the Birth,

Now the Infant being thus formed and perfected in the womb for the firt month ends forth its Urine thro' the paages of the navel; but in the lat month that paage being hut up through the privy-members; yet notwithtanding, while the child is in the Womb, he voids nothing out at the Fundament, becaue he hath taken no nourihment in at the Mouth. After the forty fifth day it receives life, and is then called an Infant.

Now, though the Infant hath by this time obtained ene, yet doth he not move: He mot commonly moves in twice the time that he was formed, and in thrice the pace after he began his motion, he hatens into the world; as for example, if the infant were formed in forty five days, it will move in ninety, and be born the ninth month after that.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the condition of the Infant in the Womb, in the ixth, eventh, and eighth month.
div.p: AFter the third and fourth month, the Infant is nourihed with more plenty of nourihment, until the time of delivery approach. Now you mut oberve that a child born in the ixth month cannot live, by reaon that it is not come to its jut perfection; but if it be born in the eventh month, it will very eaily live, becaue it is come to its full perfection. Now the reaon why thoe that are born in the eighth month do not live, when as thoe that are born in the eventh do, is plain; for in the eventh month the Infant tirs it elf to come forth; o that if it have o much trength it eaily performs its deire; if not, it remains in the womb, till it have gathered two months more trength. After this motion of the eventh month, if it be not able to come forth, it changes it elf into another part of the womb, by which motion it is o weakened, that if it hould be born in the eighth month, it were impoible that it hould live, for it is weakened by a double motion; not only that of the eventh month, but alo by that motion whereby it trives to go forth in the eighth month.

div.head: SECT. V.
CHAP. I. Of the ituation of the Child in the Womb.
div.p:
COncerning the ituation of the Child in the womb, it may be conidered either generally, or pecially;
pecially, either as it concerns the Male, or the Female.
The Male is commonly ituated in the right ide of the Womb the Female in the left.

The general ituation of the Child, either Male, or Female, in the Womb, is always the ame which hath been oberved and een to be in this poture, when the Infant lies with his Back and his Buttocks leaning againt the Back of the Mother, the Head inclined, and touching his Breat with his Chin; reting his two Hands upon his Knees; his Navel and his Noe between his two Knees, with his two Eyes upon his two Thumbs, his Legs folded backward, and touching his Buttocks with each Leg.
This Figure is the mot natural, as being leat ubject to uffer any accident, being les inconvenient, and les troubleome to the Mother.
The mot natural form for the Child to come into the World, is when the Head comes forward, the Hands being tretched upon the Hips.

The things which are the Caues of a Womans delivery, are three; firt, the want of repiration and Air for the Infant. The econd is the want of nourihment, of which, when the Infant finds a defect in his Mothers Womb he is forced to eek it in another place. The third is the narrownes of the place where the Infant lies, o that he is forced to eek room other where, which makes him to break the Membranes, wherein he was contained, preing and contraining the Mother by the harpnes of thoe Waters, to do her duty for his releae. Now as ome ay, there are three ways or manners of Childrens coming upon the Earth; Firt, when the Head comes foremot, and then the Woman is eaily delivered: The econd, when it comes forth a-cros, or one ide, or the Feet foremot, and then the Woman
uffers much, and either they both die, or one of them, As for thoe Births which are unnatural, we hall in another place treat of them, and their remedies. In this combate, the Infant and the Mother uffer very much, by reaon that Woman is a Creature delicate and timerous, and not patient of much labour: or, becaue women great with Child live a lazy and loathful life; and beides that, many times they eat bad victuals, which encreaes Humours and uperfluous Excrements, which quantity of Humours makes the Woman to breath hort, which is a thing very troubleome to the Infant; for a Woman that will expel the Birth quick, ought to keep her breath in, as much as he can. The third Reaon of the pain in Womens Travail, is by reaon that the Head of a Child is bigger, being compared to the Members, than the Head of any other Creature, which makes a greater opening and dilaceration.

But the Women that uffer mot pain, are they who were not delivered before, having not been accutomed to the ufferance of that labour; as alo elderly Women, by reaon that the Bone of the Pubes, the Bone of the Hip, and the Os Sacrum, are not o eaily eparated, the
• igaments being more trong and hard.
Now in the contention which the Child makes to iue forth, the Head comes firt, by reaon of the weight, being more heavy than the other Members.

div.head: Explanation of the Third Figure.
div.p: THIS Figure contains the Birth at full maturity, ready to come forth in the truet poture.

list.item: AAAA. The parts of the Midriff diected.
BBBB. The body of the Womb diected into four parts.
CCCC. The Membranes or Films, called Chorion, and the Amnios, diected likewie into four parts.
D. The Birth in its natural poture.

div.head: Explanation of the Fourth Figure.

p.hi: This Figure contains the Navel Veels, and the films or Covering of the Infant.

list.item: AAAA. The Mucles of the Midriff, the Peritoneum, and the skin it elf diected into four parts.
B. The Liver of the Infant.
C. The Urinary Veels.
D. The hole of the Liver, into which the Navel-vein doth pas.
E. The Umbilical, or Navel-vein it elf.
FF. The two Navel-arteries tending downwards to the mall Gut-Arteries.
G. The paage for the Urine proceeding from the bottom of the Bladder.
H. The Umbilical Veels taken out of the Body of the Infant, to hew how they are joined together.
I. The Membranes that involves the Navel Veels.
KKKK. The Guts or Intrailes of the Infant.
LLL. The Navel Veels extended from the Children to the Birth.
M. The place where the branches of the Navel-Veels are firt collected into one Trunk.
NN. A branch of the Navel-Veels cattered through The flehy parts of the Chorion.
OOO. A branch of the Navel-Arteries.
PPPP. The Conjunction of the Umbilical Vein and Arteries.
QQQQ. The extremities of the Navel-Veins and Arteries, ending the flehy parts of the Chorion.

div.head: SECT. IV.
CHAP. I. Of Midwives.
div.p: ALthough in thee days there are many unskilful Women that take upon them the knowledge of Midwifry, barely upon the priviledge of their age: Yet there are many things which ought to be oberved in a Midwife, that they are utterly wanting of. Let us therefore conider of the things required in a Midwife, in relation both to her Peron, and her manners: As for her Age, he ought to be neither too young, nor too old,Her Age. in a good habit of Body, and not ubject to Dieaes, nor mihapen in any parts of her Body, peculiar in her Habits, and in her Peron; her Hands mut be mall. with her Nails pared cloe, without any Rings upon them, in the time of her Duty, nor Bracelets upon her Writs; he mut be chearful, pleaant, trong, laborious, and ued to travel; it being required that he hould be tirring at all Hours, and abiding a long time together with her Patient.
For her Manners, he ought to be Courteous, Sober, Chate; not repining,Her Manners. Cholerick, Arrogant, or Covetous, nor apt to talk of what he ees in the Houes where he hath to do.
Her Spirit.For her Spirit; he ought to be prudent, wary, and cunning, oft-times to ue fair and flattering words.

She ought moreover to know, that God hath given to all things their Beginnings, their Increaings, their Etate of Perfection, and Declination: Therefore the aid Midwife, nor any of her aitants, mut not do any thing rahly, for to precipitate or haten Nature.

div.head: CHAP. II. What ought to be oberved, when the Woman is near the time of her lying down.
div.p: Of Women near the time of their lying down.THE Hour of the Womans lying down approaching, the Woman with Child ought to prepare her elf in this manner; he mut preently call her Midwife and Aitants to her, it being requiite to have them rather ooner than later.

Her Bed.She ought to prepare a little Bed, or Couch, of a moderate heighth, as well for the covenience of the Midwife, as for the eae of her elf, and others that hall be about her to ait her in her Travel: This mut be ituated in a place convenient for the People to pas up and down, near the fire, and far from Doors: It will be requiite for her to have change of Linnen, as alo a little Cricket for her to ret her feet on, having more force when her Feet are bowed.

In the time of Travel what to do.When he finds her Pains growing, it will be neceary for her to walk leiurely up and down the Chamber, afterwards he may lye down warm, and then rie and walk again, expecting the coming down of her Waters, and the opening of the Womb. For to keep her elf long a-bed, is very troubleome: Though when he is
a-bed notwithtanding that he hath ome certain pains ometimes, yet he may lie and ret her elf, and now and then take a nap: By which means, both the Mother and the Infant do with greater trength endure their ucceeding hardhip; beides that, her waters do come down better. If her Travel be long, he may take ome broth, or the yolk of a porched Egg, with ome bread, or a cup of wine, or ditilled water; yet he mut have a care let he over-charge her elf either with meat or drink.

It is certain, that all women are not delivered alike; for ome lie in their bed, others it in a chair, being upported and held up by others, or ele reting upon the ide of the bed or chair; others upon their knees, being upheld under their arms; but the bet and afet is to lie in their beds; and for her good and convenient delivery, let the Midwife and others oberve what follows.

Firt, the woman that is in travel, ought to be laid upon her back,Certain Rules. her head being lifted up a little higher with a pillow, having alo a pillow under her reins to utain her back; under her buttocks he mut have a larger pillow, to raie them a little, and that her rump may be elevated; for a woman that lies low in thoe parts, can never be well delivered, for the avoiding of which, this ituation is very convenient. Her thighs and knees mut be a good way eparated the one from the other, with her legs bowed, and drawn up towards her buttocks, the oles of her feet, and her heels, being fixed upon a board, laid thwart the bed for that purpoe.

Secondly, to ome women they do ue a wath-band four double; this wath-band mut be a foot broad or more; which being put under her reins, is to be held
up treight, by two perons tanding on each ide jut at the time of her pains, both of them, at the ame intant, heaving up both ends, with an exact evenes; for otherwie it does more harm than good. It is alo requiite, that two of her friends hould hold the upper part of her houlders, that he may be able to force out the Birth with more advantage; And it will not be amis, for ome of her friends to pres the upper parts of her belly, o to thrut down the Infant, by little and little. Such a oft compreion, will much facilitate the travel, and give eae to the womans pains.

Thirdly, as for the woman her elf, he mut be of a good heart, and force her elf by triving as much as poibly he can; topping her mouth, and keeping her breath, as if he were doing the ordinary deeds of nature.
As for the Cholick, if it eize Women in Travail, you may read the Remedies in the following Chapter.

div.head: CHAP. III. How to expel the Cholick from Women in Child-bed.
div.p: THere are ome women, who at the ame intant that they are in travel, are taken with fits of the Cholick; which is often caued by the crudities and indigetions of the tomach, which do torment women o extremely, that it exceeds the pain of their Travel; and while this pain lats, a woman advances nothing toward the end of her Travel: the pain of Travel being hardly to be ditinguihed from it.

For her eae therefore, the woman ought to take thee Remedies; two ounces of oyl of weet Almonds, with an ounce of Cinnamon water, or ele ome wind dipelling Clyter, and if the firt time uffice not, you may re-iterate it; and ometimes fomentations, that are
proper for the dipelling of wind, are very neceary for this purpoe.

div.head: CHAP. IV. How the Midwife may know when the pains of Travel do eize upon a woman.
div.p: WHen the Woman begins to cry out, and hath ent for her Widwife; the firt thing that the Midwife is to ask, is, when he did conceive? 2. Then is he to look diligently upon the belly of the Woman and to mark it well; for if he do behold the upper parts of the belly unk and hollow, and the lower parts of the belly full and big, he may then conclude that the Child is fallen down. 3. She ought then to ask her ome quetions concerning her pains; for if they be quick and trong, begining at the Reins, and liding down all along the belly, without ending at the Navel, but till falling down upon the groins, and inwardly at the bottom of the belly, below which is the interiour neck of the womb; thee are certain igns that the woman begins to be in Labour. 4. But for more certainty, the Midwife may put up her hand, being anointed firt with freh butter, and if he perceive the inner neck of the womb to dilate it elf, 'tis a certain ign that the pains of Child-bed are upon the woman, or if he perceive any thing to puh forwards her travel is alo undoubtable.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the falling down of the waters, a good while before the woman travels.
div.p:
THere are ome women, who have their waters come from them, a long time before their travel, ometimes
twelve days, ometimes eight Days, ometimes ix and ometimes four; though the ordinary time be not above three Hours before her travel; they remaining for the mot part not above twenty four Hours. This is caued by ome Ruptures of the Membranes, where, from the beginning of the formation of the Child, the Humour is contained, rather than by the abundance of Humours; and therefore though a Woman that hath abundance, and that the Membranes containing them, are o trong, that they will not break uddenly, though the Woman hall not travel 'till they break, yet the Midwife ought not to break them, but rather hold the Voman over a Veel of warm Water and alo ue ome oftning Liniment, to often the, Membranes, that o the Mother training, the Head or other Member of the Child, may break them more eaily.

But for thoe Women that have thee evacuations o long before they travel, they mut refrain going into the Air, for fear of injuring themelves, the paages being open; for though the Air cannot hinder the Child from coming forth, by reaon of its weight, yet oftentimes getting within the Secondine, it not only treightens the Veels, and Mouths of the Veins, that are at the bottom of the Womb, but alo caues everal Convulions, to the great danger of the Woman: But it is an eaie thing to remedy thee accidents, by keeping cloe in her Chamber, having alo a pecial regard to ditinguih, whether they be the Waters of the Birth, or any Hydropick humour of the Matrix.

div.head: CHAP. VI. What the Midwife ought to do in time of Travel.
div.p:
THE Midwife eeing the Birth come naturally, the Pains now coming thicker and thicker, the
Womb alo opening to be deliver'd of its Burden, and the endeavours of the Child being een to come forth; the Midwife mut now encourage her Patient, admonihing her to hut her Mouth, and to hold her breath, and to train and endeavour with her lower parts: Neither ought the Midwife to be too haty, either to widen or force the paage of the Infant, or to break the Membranes, but to tay 'till the Membranes do burt of their own accord.

And here is to be noted the ignorance of ome Women, who for hate to be gone to other Women do tear the Membranes with their Nails, to the danger both of the Woman and of the Child, which then remains dry, without that moiture which makes the paage lippery; which mut of neceity augment the pain of the Woman.

When the Head comes forth of the Womb, the Midwife mut take it gently between her two Hands, and then when her Pains encreae, lipping down her Hands under the Arm-holes, gently drawing forth the Infant, yet taying her Hand always, but when the Pains come upon the Woman: This mut be done with a very delicate and tender Hand, let the Child, by any rude or harh handling, hould receive any deformed hape of Body.

When the Child is come into the World, which is commonly with his Face downward, it mut be uddenly turned upon his back, let it hould be tifled for want of Air. Then let her cut the Navel-tring, leaving the length of four Fingers, tying it with a ilk Thread as near the Belly as may be: Which done, the Child if it be well, may be laid aide, only care mut be had, that the Head and the Stomach be well covered, and that nothing come upon his Face.

div.head: CHAP. VII. How to draw forth the Secondines.
div.p: THE Child being thus drawn forth, and in afety, the Midwife mut now apply her elf to the drawing out of the Secondines, which mut be done by wagging and tirring them up and down, and then gently drawing them forth, cauing the Woman to take Salt in both her Hands, and to hut them cloe, and then to blow in them whereby you hall know whether they be broken or no: It may be done alo by cauing her to put one Finger in her Mouth, to provoke a deire of vomiting, or ele by tirring, as when he is doing the ordinary deeds of Nature, or as Nature it elf contrained her to do, before the Head of the Child was come forth. All this mut be done peedily; yet if this be not ufficient, he may take the Yolk of an Egg raw, or he may take a mall draught of raw Elder-water, or you may caue her to mell to a piece of Aa Foetida. If he be troubled with Wind-Cholicks, or have taken Cold, which oftentimes doth breed Wind, which is a great hindrance to the coming forth of the Secondines; the Midwife ought to chafe the Womans Belly with her Hand, which doth not only break the wind, but caues the Secondine to come down. If this fails, the Midwife may with her Hand dilate the Orifice of the womb drawing it forth gently and by Degrees.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. What may be given to a Woman in Travel.
div.p: IN the firt place, hot and violent Remedies are to be avoided, but in caes of great neceity; for it many times happens that they are the caue of dangerous • eavers.

Two other things are alo very dangerous to a Woman in Travel, too much repletion, and too much emptines; for the Stomach of a Woman with Child doth not diget her meat in o hort a time as Women that are not with Child do; Therefore the Midwife ought to inform her elf how long it was ince he eat, and in what quantity; and if it were long ince he did eat, and that he grow feeble, they may give in the intermiions of her Pains ome warm cherihing and Cordial Broths, or the Yolk of a poached Egg: If her Travel endure long, then to trengthen her and comfort her, he may take a draught of Cinnamon-water, not exceeding an ounce, or at twice, a dram of the Confection of Alkermes; diolved into two poonfuls of Claret-Wine, and not more than one of thee three things. For if they take two much, as is before aid, it caues Fevers, and Heats in the whole Body, of which follow many inconveniencies, for it tops the Purgations, of which many trange Dieaes enue.

div.head: CHAP. IX. How to put the Womb again in its place.
div.p: SOME Women newly brought to Bed, are many times afflicted with greater Pains than thoe of their Travel, by reaon that the womb is not well put into its place, or if it have, the Swathe-band being looe, it is apt to roul upwards in the Belly. This happens to Women that are not well purged after their Delivery; for remedy hereof, having put the Matrix right into its place, rowl up two linnen Swathes pretty hard, bringing them alo round the Hips; then take whites of Eggs, beaten, and a dram of Pepper in Powder, which being pread upon Tow, is to be applied warm to the Navel; then let the Belly be well wathed. This is the only remedy to eae the Pain.

div.head: CHAP. X. Againt the extreme los of blood, which happens to women immediately after their delivery.
div.p:
THere are many women which immediately after their Delivery do uffer great los of blood, which proceeds from a great plentitude or fulnes; or by reaon that in their travel they took too many hot and corroive medecines; or, by training themelves too hard over-heated the blood, o that after Travel, it runs from them in great quantity. To remedy this, the woman ought to take a mall quantity of wine, in a poon; and if the weaknes be much, let her mix half a dram of Alkermes, with a draught of wine, and take care that he be well waithed upward; for that prees down and treightens the veels, and hinders the violent flux: Give her alo the yolk of an Egg to take, for that recalls the natural heat to the tomach, which was dipered through the whole. It would be neceary alo, to pread along the reins of the woman and all along the back-bone, by reaon of the hollow vein, a napkin dipt in Oxicrate, or Water mingled with Vinegar. You may alo lay upon each groin, a Skein of raw Silk, moitned in cold Water, Take alo of that well tempered Earth, of which they make the Floor of an Oven, and teep it in trong Vinegar, then pread it upon a linnen Cloath, and lay it upon the Reins; this moderates the heat of the Blood, and tops the violent flux of it: Great care mut be alo had, that all the while the blood comes from her, he do not leep, for many times they are taken away in that weaknes, when the people think they do but take their Ret: But when you ee this great Flux moderated, you may take away the atringent Medicines by little and little, o that the Blood may ceae
running by degrees, let any blood hould be retained that may chance to do michief.

div.head: CHAP. XI. What is to be done to a woman preently after her Delivery.
div.p: PReently after a woman is delivered, if he have had a ore Travel, they ought to cat her into the skin of a Sheep flead alive, and put about her Reins as hot as may be; upon her Belly alo lay the Skin of a Hare flead alive, having cut the Throat of it afterwards, and rubbed the Skin with the Blood, which is to be clapt as warm as may be to her Belly.
This cloes up the dilatations made by the Birth, and chaes from thoe parts the ill and melancholy Blood. Thee remedies are to be kept on two hours in Winter, and one hour in Summer.

After this wathe the Woman with a Napkin about a quarter of a yard large, having before chafed the belly with Oyl of St. John's-wort. Then raie up the Matrix with a linnen Cloath many times folded; then with a little pillow about a quarter of a yard long cover her Flanks, then ue the Swathe, beginning a little above the Hanches, yet rather higher than lower, winding it pretty tite, Lay alo warm Cloaths upon the nipples, letting alone thoe remedies which are proper for the driving back of the Milk, which are not o oon to be applied, for the body is now all in a commotion, and there is neither vein nor artery which doth not beat: Wherefore thoe Remedies that chae away the Milk, being all diolving, therefore it is not proper to put uch Medicines upon the Breat during that commotion, for fear that thoe medecines hould make a top of any thing hurtful in thoe parts, and
therefore it is better to give ten or twelve hours for the Blood to ettle in; as alo for that which was cat upon the Lungs by the agitation of Travel, to ditil down again into its place.

You may alo make a retrictive of the white and yellow of an Egg beaten together, with an Ounce af Oyl of St. John's-wort, and an ounce of Oyl of Roes, an ounce of Roe-water, and an ounce of Plantain-water, beat all thee together very well; in this you may dip a linnen cloath folded double, and apply it without warming of it to the Breats: This comforts and eaes the pains of that part.
She mut not leep preently; but a matter of four hours after her delivery, you may give her ome nourihing Broth, or Caudle, and then if he will, he may leep.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of women that have a great deal of Blood, and purge not, neither in their travel nor after.
div.p:
SOme women have great Superfluity of Blood, and yet purge not at all, neither in their Travel, nor afterwards; to which, if remedies be not applied, the Women do run great Hazards and Dangers in their lying in, great Suffocations of the Matrix, and continual Feavers; this may be remedied, being firt informed of their natural dipoition before they were with Child; knowing that when they had their purgations, they had them in great quantity, and for a good while together, as alo when they came, being a gros and thick Blood; and therefore eeing that now they do not purge in great quantity, and that they have divers unquietnees, weaknees of the Stomach, and pains of the head; wherefore you may give her in the Morning a little Syrup of Maiden-hair, and Hyop-water
mingled together, and Syrup of Wormwood, with White-wine; in their broths you may boyl Jacines and opening Herbs, keeping the belly oluble with Clyters; he mut eat no olid Meat, he mut be well chafed from the Groins down to the very Ankle-bone, always trokeing and carrying the hand down-ward; Blood-letting alo in the Foot in the morning is not amis; as alo fome Fumigation that cleanes the Matrix, and draws down the Blood: Yet care mut be had, that thee lat Remedies be not ued before the Matrix be put into its place, for fear that thee remedies hould draw it down too low, but about eight or ten Days after the Matrix was put into its place. For cleaning the Matrix, you may ue this Receipt.

Take Pellitory, Sanicle, Camomile, Melilot, Greenbalm, Red-balm, white Mullein, Mallows, Marhmallow, Betony, Margeram, Nipp, March-violets, Mugwort; take of each a like quantity, and cut them mall, and let them boyl in a new pot, with three pints of good White-wine; let the Woman take the fume of this Receipt three times in a day; if he have any gros Blood in the Matrix, it will undoubtedly bring it down: You may alo chafe the Womans Belly with Oyl of Violets, this helps the Purgations being once diolved. The reaon why this thick Blood tays in thee parts, is, becaue the Woman having it before he was with Child, the heat of the Womb, when he is with Child redoubling thickens it more, o that when he comes to lie down, it cannot flow; o that it is to be taken away as much as may be with the aforeaid means; Mollyfying Fomentations are alo proper for this purpoe, while the woman its over the fumigation.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. For thoe who have but a little blood.
div.p: THoe Women that have but little blood, ought not to lie in their beds as thoe who have a great deal. They ought to take good nourihment in a little quantity: As Eggs well boyld in the hell in a Morning: The juyce of Mutton and Veal, queezed out, and Mutton broth; and all thee being mingled together, nourih very much, and make very good blood; as alo Pigeons, Partridge, Mutton, Quaile, and uch other meats good for the tomach.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. What is to be done to the Infant.
div.p: THE Midwife having tied up the Navel-tring, as is before aid, he ought next to cleane the Infant, not only in the face, but alo over the whole body; anointing the groins, hips, buttocks, thighs and joynts with Oyl of weet Almonds, or freh Butter; this makes the skin more firm, and huts up the pores of the skin, o that the exterior air cannot come to hurt it; and beides this, it trengthens all the parts of the body.
It would not be amis to make a bath, or decoction of Roes and Sage in Wine, and with that to wah the Infant every morning

After the Infant is thus well anointed, and after that well dried and wrapped up, you may give to the Infant a little Sack and Sugar in a poon, or ele the quantity of a Peae bignes of Mithridate or Treacle diolved in Wine, with a little Carduus-Water.

div.head: CHAP. XV. How to Govern Women in Child-bed.
div.p:
THere is great difference in the governing Women in Child-bed; for he that thinks to order an ordinary labouring, or Country-woman, like a peron of quality, kills her, and he that thinks to govern a peron of quality like an ordinary Country-woman, does the ame to her. For the Stomach and Contitution of the one is tender and weak, and the Contitution and Stomach of the other trong and luty; which will not be atisfied with ordinary Viands: For if you give to one of thee trong Stomachs preently after their delivery, any trong Broth, or Eggs, or a draught of Milk, they are like Mills that always grind, and empty as fat as they pour in; and that that gives one Woman a fever, keeps another from it; and therefore Women in Child-bed are to be governed by their everal Contitutions. As for Women that are delicate, and have been accutomed to live delicately, greater care mut be taken of them, giving them meats that breed good nourihment, and do not clog the tomach, forbearing alo to give her thoe meats to which he has too great a dilike, agreeing to her humour, provided, that the meat which he loves be not hurtful; and giving her for the firt eight days of her lying in, boyled meats rather than roted, as gellies, &c. the juice of Veal, or Capon, but not Mutton, it being too feverih: giving her to drink Barly-water, or ele water boyled, wherein is boyled a dram of Cinnamon to every pint, and two ounces of Sugar diolved; or if he do not love Sugar, Coriander-eed water; if he drink wine, let it be two thirds of water to one third of wine, giving her in the morning white-wine, and in
the afternoon Claret, taking care of eating any thing that may breed any crudities: She may alo take at the dicretion of thoe about her, Almond-milk now and then. There are ome women that cannot be kept from leeping, and others that cannot leep at all. It will not be amis to give to thoe that cannot leep, French barley-water; the way to make it well, is to let it boyl well, and to take the broth without training it; neither ought it to be taken after the eight days are pat, by reaon that it nourihes exceedingly, and does not a little obtruct the Liver.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Of the Bathings that a Woman is to ue for the firt eight days of her lying in.
div.p: TAke a good handful of old or new Chervil, and boyl it in a ufficient quantity of water, then taking it from the fire, add to it a poonful of Honey of Roes; this draws down the Purgations, cleanes and heals the part. The herb it elf may erve for a fomentation, to take away any inflammation. There are ome that ue milk to the purpoe aforeaid, affirming that it is a great awager of the pain; but that having been proved by others, hath been oberved rather to engender filth, than to be any way a clearer, by reaon that the harp humour caueth it to curdle.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. How a Midwife ought to govern her elf, in cae a Woman be to be Delivered of two Children.
div.p:
TAE Travel of a Woman bringing forth two Infants is more tedious, and it many times happens that one of the Children comes forth very well,
and the other comes forth very hardly; and this is certain, that that which comes forth firt, is always the tronget having the power to go before the other, and to break the membranes that enveloped it. And ofttimes while the firt is born, the other remains behind, wrapt in uch membranes as the former was, o that it remains a good pace behind the other, ometimes two hours, and yet it hath been very well born. Now knowing, that that which came firt was the tronget, it would not be amis to ait the other in coming forth, by breaking the Membranes that contain the waters; and, if that fail, by giving trong Clyters to excite the pain; which were it not many times done, the Child would never be able to endure the pain of coming into the World, by reaon of its extraordinary weaknes; which is o great ometimes, that the bone of the Forehead is divided, and eparated down to the noe; although the Infant being born, it joyns together again, and the Infant does very well: Which if it happen, you mut have a great care to bind ome kind of oft pillow upon the place, that the air may not enter in. If the econd Child come forth ill, you mut not delay to break the Membranes, and to draw the Infant gently out by the feet: For (having ued all its endeavours to come forth) to keep it there, or to prolong the Travel any longer, is more dangerous than profitable; ometimes two come o uddenly the one after the other, that there eems to be but one Delivery of both, there being but a little Membrane that eparates them; In this cae, holding the firt, you mut cut the Navel-tring, and bind it about, and tye it about the Hip, while they draw forth the other Infant, which by a longer tay would be much weakned.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. Of the danger that a Woman hath, to purge her elf for the firt days of her Lying in.
div.p: IT is an ordinary thing for Women that lye in, by reaon of their bed to loe the benefit of their bellies, which hinders the evacuation of their Milk, which caues Fevers, by ending gros vapours to the head; yet can they not be freed by any Purgation taken in at the mouth; but it would be much to the purpoe to take pertinent Clyters which hinder the foreaid evils cauing their breats to become full, and to become, tiff, taking them as occaion requires, once in two or three days. There are ome unskilful women, that not undertanding the ill conequences which may follow, do give Sena to Women in the firt days of their lying in; of which ome have been very ill, and others have died. For Nature being now weakned by the Travel, and while it is labouring to retore the body to its former Etate, is not to be diturbed with violent Purgations. And therefore Clyters are always mot proper: Neither are laxative broths, nor the broth of prunes, nor baked apples fating; for thee do engender wind, but rather ome good Suppoitories would be more ueful.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Of the econd wahing for Women.
div.p: THE econd wahing for Women ought to be with Province Roes, put into little bags, and boiled in water and wine, of each a like proportion; and this is to be done for the econd eight days.

div.head: CHAP. XX. What is to be done to Infants as oon as they are born.
div.p: IT is an approved Maxim, that as oon as a Child is born, you ought to give it a poonful of pure wine; for that aits and helps the Child to regain its pirits Another advantage is this; that the wine cuts the flegm which the Child has in its throat; beides, the pirit of the wine riing up to the head, comforts and trengthens it; and it hinders alo from the Epilepie, which proceeds from the debility of the brain.

This being done, and the Mother fully delivered, you mut tye the Navel-vein with a ilk well twited, and many times doubled, and if there be any blood in the vein, you mut be ure to empty it, for fear, if it hould be left, it hould turn into corruption; then it mut be well dried with powder of rotten wood: You mut tye it two fingers breadth from the belly, and leave it long, three fingers breadths above the tying place; and if it be fat, you mut cloe it over and above, that the vein may be well cloed, then wind the tring twice about it, knitting as many knots. But if the Child be come afore its time, you need not tye it o trong, for fear of cutting it with the ilk; but if the Navel-vein be full of water and wind, you ought then, having tied it one time, and wrapt a linnen cloth about the end of it, which is till to be held upward, to uncover it again, about half an hour after, and then to tye it and wrap it about again, till keeping the end up; for fear, that if the vein were not fully cloed, there might be ome danger in the bleeding.
Some people give to the Infant Treacle diolved in Wine; but this mut be done warily in a very mall quantity, and that not commonly neither.

The Infant mut be wahed with water and wine luke-warm, to cleane it; afterwards wah the face, as alo chafe the throat, the arms and hands, with Oyl of Walnuts, drawn without fire, which ome ay will keep them from Sun-burning, then put one hand upon the bone of the Fore-head, and another upon the bone called the Coronal bone, and oftly cloe up the gap which was made during the time of travel, cloing alo the Sutures one againt another exactly; then gently put your finger under the tongue, to ee if the Infant have the tring or no; and if it have, it may be clipt away with the point of a pair of harp Cizzers, without danger. There are ome that think they can hape the head and noe of a Child as if it were of Wax, But let uch take notice that have flat noed Children, rather to let the noe alone, than by queezing and cloing it too much to render the noe obtructed; for that compreing the Gritles of the noe, renders the Child liable either to peak alway in the noe, or to loe his melling. There are ome Children that are born with their noes awry; for the help of which, you may with your finger moitned in fair water, gently troke the noe, but lay no tres upon it. That happens by reaon that the noe of the Child lights upon ome bone of the Mother as it was coming into the World.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. Of the lat wahing for Women.
div.p: THE lat wahing for Women, is to be for four days, with Province Roes boyled in Wine and Myrrh-water.

div.head: CHAP. XXII. Of an Atringent for Women, when they hall have occaion.
div.p: TAke Galls, Cypres-nuts, and Pomgranate-flowers, Roch-Allome, of each two ounces, Province Roes, four ounces, Knot-gras a good handful; the rind of Caia, the rind of Pomegranates, Scarlet berries, of each three ounces, the nature or Sperm of a Whale, one ounce, Roe-water, Myrrh-water, and Burnet-water, of each an ounce and a half, Wine and water of a Smiths forge, of each four ounces and a half, then make two little bags about a quarter of a Yard long, and half a quarter of a Yard broad, then boil all thee in the foreaid water in a new Pot, uing the bags one after another, as occaion erveth.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII. To make Cere-cloaths for Women.
div.p: TAke white Wax, half a pound, the perm of a Whale, and Venice-Turpentine, well wahed in Roe-water, and Plaintain-water, of each an ounce and a half, then melt all thee together, then mingle with them an ounce of Venice white Lead, then order your Cloath as you pleae, making ome for the Belly, and ome for the nipples, having firt rubbed it over with Oyl of Acorns or the perm of a Whale.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV. To cleane a Woman before he ries.
div.p:
TAke bitter Almonds and peel them, make thereof a Pate with the Powder of Orris, and the yolk
of Eggs, and put it in a little bag of Tammy, and temper within the bag, with black Wine luke-warm, and afterwards ue it upon the places where the ear-cloaths had been laid, then wah the places with black Wine mingled with Orange flower.

div.head: CHAP. XXV. How a Woman lying in of her firt Child, may avoid the gripings of her belly.
div.p: THere are ome women lying in of their firt Child who are troubled much with gripings in the belly, and thee Women commonly endure Pains when their Terms come down, by reaon of the malnes of the Veins which conveigh the blood into the Matrix; uch women have Gripings in their bellies, when they lie in of their firt Child, which other women are not troubled with, by reaon that they have larger Veels yet although they have them not in their firt lying in, it would not be amis to ue ome proper remedies, that o they may be never troubled with them; which if they receive not at their firt lying in, they will be uncapable of receiving them ever after; for though they may take remedies afterwards to leen the pain, yet they can never cure it wholly.

Now that which is ordinarily done to women is, as oon as ever they are brought to bed, to give them two Ounces of Oyl of weet Almonds drawn without fire, with two ounces of Syrup of Maiden-hair; 'tis true, this is good to make her purgations part away, but not to remedy the griping.

Some there are that do take two drops of the blood which comes out of the Navel tring of the Infant, and give it mingled to the Woman in the foreaid Syrups,
though there is much fault to be found with this, by reaon of the natines of it.

Others do boil a white Chicken, in the which they do put two ounces of Sugar, a dram of •• ne • Cinamon, half a Nutmed grated two or three Dates, five or ix Cloves; the Fowl being boiled, you may put into it a mall quantity of Claret, then boyl it altogether again letting it boil till the Fowl be well oaked, then train it, and give it to the Woman as oon as he is laid down; for want of a white Hen you may take a Pigeon, or a red Partridge for want of either: Only take heed to give her this if he be feverih, becaue it is omething hot.
The Seed of Savory taken in warm broth is very good, and it is alo very good for thoe that have the Cholick.

div.head: The Queen of France, her Receipt.
div.p: Take a dram of the root of the great Comfrey, one of the kernels of Peaches, Nutmegs, of each two cruples, yellow Amber half a dram, Amber-greece half a cruple, mingle all thee together, and give to the woman as oon as he is laid down, the quantity of a dram mingled in White-wine, or, if the Woman be feverih, in ome good warm broth.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI. Certain precepts concerning the delay and difficulty of bringing forth.
div.p:
BEing now come to talk of the impediments of the Birth, you may know that the Birth is hindered by a two-fold manner, the one natural, the other not natural; of the unnatural we hall treat in its place; for the natural take thee following directions: But in
the firt place let the Midwife be very skilful that he may decline, as much as in her lies, all the Impediments that may be avoided.

If the Birth be hindered by the drines and treightnes of the neck of the Womb, take a little beaten Hellebore or Pepper, and blow it into the notrils of the Mother. Her Mouth mut be held cloe, her Breath, kept in, and neezing mut be provoked as much as may be, whereby the Spirits being forced to the lower parts, may be the more available to force down the Child. You may alo give her Shepherds pure dried in a little Broth, or Wine; alo a little quantity of Honey mingled with twice as much luke-warm water, and given her, will not be unprofitable. The milk alo of another Woman mixt with Maiden-hair, and applyed warm to the Navel. She may take alo Oyl of Laurel in Wine, or warm Broth; two Grains of Pepper being taken inwardly, do not only force out the Birth, but alo drive out the Secondines.
This is alo an excellent remedy againt a difficult Travail.
Take Trochichs of Myrrhe one dram, grains of Saffron ten, Cinnamon one Scruple, mingle all this with two ounces of Penny-royal-water, and give it the Woman to drink.

Let her drink it warm, and let her go to her Bed for an hour, till he finds the Operation of the drink moving her to her Labour. If this profit and that the Infant coming with his head foremot tick in the Womb, you may ue thee pills, of which he may take even and then ret.

Take Gum Bdellium, Myrrh, Savin-eed, Liquid Storax, Agaric, of each half a cruple, Diagridium ix grains, mingle all thee with Caia extracted, as much as uffices, and make up Pills about the bignes of a Pea.

You may alo ue a peary, as long, and as thick as your finger, of pure wool, which mut be covered over with ilk, and dipt in the juice of Rue, where Scamony hath been diolved, and o ued. If thee things prove without effect, he may ue this enuing Bath above her Belly.

Take of the Root and Herb, Marh-Mallows ix handfuls, Mallows, Camomile, Melilot, Parley, of each four handfuls, Line-eed, and Seed of Fenugreek, of each two pound, Lavender, and Laurel Leaves, of each two handfuls.

Let all thee things be boyled together in Water, wherein the Woman is to it, or ele to have thoe parts well wet and moitned with Spunges, which being done, and the Woman well dried with warm Cloaths, let her be brought to the Bed, and anointed with this Ointment.

Take Oyl of weet Almonds, Hens Fat, Oyl of Lillies, Mucilage of Marh-mallows of each half an Ounce, Mingle all thee with as much wax as is ufficient, and make an Oyntment: This being done, give her this little Doe.

Take two Yolks of Eggs and boil them in old Wine, then mix with them thee Spices, Cinamon half an Ounce, rind of Caia, 2 drams; or you may leave out the Caia, and intead thereof put in the more Cinamon, Saffron half a Scruple, Savine, Betony, Venus-hair, Dittany, Fenugreek, Lawrel-berries, Mint, of each one dram: The bone of the Heart of a Hart, Pearls prepared, mingle all thee with Sugar, and make a thick Pouder and give it.
If the Secondine come before the Child, and hinder the Egres of the Child, is to be cut off, and this following Peary to be put up.

Take Marh-mallows with the Roots two handfuls, Mother-wort one handful, Rue one ounce and an half,
Fenugreek, Line-eed, of each an ounce, ten Figs; make of thee a decoction, with as much water as is ufficient, and when you have trained it, add this to it, Oyl of Lillies, Oyl of Lineed, of each two Ounces, Musk one grain: In this decoction, let the peary be dipt, and put up; he may afterwards ue this Electuary.

Take Myrrh, Cator, weet melling Flag, of each two drams, Cinamon one ounce, Saffron half a Scruple, Mace, Savin, of each a Scruple, clarified Honey half a pound: You may alo make an Electuary with the water of Thyme, and Mother-wort, wherein have been boiled Fenugreek, Lineed, grains of Juniper, of each one poonful.
Now, after that the Woman hath been weakned with thee Impediments, you may give her in Broth, Species Laetificans; or Manus Chriti, or Diamargariton.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII. How the Secondines are to be hatned out.
div.p:
THE Secondines, after that the Infant is born, may be many ways hindred; firt by the debility, or weaknes of the Matrix, which happens by the frequent motion and endeavouring of the Infant, as alo by reaon of the difficulty of the Birth, or by reaon that the womb doth not continue ditended, or becaue it is many times treightned, by which the womb is o weakned, that by its own force it is not able to expel the Secondines: Beides, the Secondines may inwardly tick cloe to the womb, which happens many times through the abundance of uperfluous Humours that are retained in the Matrix, by reaon of which glutinous Humours, the Secondines tick to the Matrix. Thee are no way ele to be pulled away, but by the Hand of the Midwife. Thirdly, the Secondines are hard to come
away, if all the waters come away with the Infant, for then the Secondines, being left without moiture, cannot come away by reaon of the drines of the womb; beides that, the Matrix and the Neck of the womb are rougher by reaon of the drines thereof, for thee waters render the way lippery and eaie, both for the Infant, and for the Secondines; which being lipped away, the womb is to be anointed with Juices and Oils. Fourthly, when the Mouth of the Matrix, by reaon of the pains of Child-bearing, wells, as often happens, unles there be a provident care taken to prevent it. Fifthly, when the Neck of the Matrix is treighter and more cloe, and for that reaon fat Women travel with much more difficulty: Therefore when the Secondines do make any extraordinary tay, the Midwife is to ue all her endeavour to make way for them; for that retention caues uffocation, and divers other Evils; for being long detained, they putrifie and caue an evil mell, which acending up to the Heart, Liver, Stomach, Diaphragme, and o to the Brain, caue pains in the Head and Lungs, hortnes of Breath, Faintnes, cold Sweats; o that there is great danger; and alo Apoplexies and Epilepies, are not a little to be feared. Now in all the time of their tay, the Women are to be refrehed with convenient Food, to add trength to them, giving them ometimes the Yolks of Eggs boiled in old wine with Sugar, and prinkled over with Saffron and Cinamon, or ome Broth made of Capon or Hen, eaoned with Cinamon and Saffron: It may not be amis to make certain Perfumes for the Woman to receive up into her womb, made of Saffron, Cator, Myrrh, and Cinamon, of each the quantity of a Bean, and care mut be had that the Fume pas no further than the Matrix, and this may be done till the Fume of thee Spices hall ceae. After this a little neezig Powder is to be put into
to her Notrils, compoed of Hellebore, or uch like; the Woman hutting her Mouth hard, and keeping her Breath: If thee things prevail not, give her this following Potion.

Take Trochich of Myrrh, ten grains of Saffron, one Scruple of Cinamon, Penny Royal waters two ounces; make of this one draught and give her; after he hath taken this, and reted a little while, let a Peary of Hellebore and Opoponax wrapt up in pure wool, be thrut up into the neck of the womb. This will certainly bring down the Secondines, for it is of o great vertue, that it is efficacious in expelling the Child which is dead, together with the Secondines.

Take Mallows, Hollihock, Wormwood, Mugwort, Calamint, Origanum, each one handful, make a Bath, and let her it therein up to the Navel, and troke ever downwards with her Hands, and give her inwardly Myrrh a Scruple, Cinamon poudered in Nutmeg-water or wine, or drink Calamint, or Penny-Royal in wine.

Neither will it be amis to anoint the Matrix with the Ointment called Bailicon; if this doth nothing avail toward the bringing down of the Secondines, and that the Woman is in great danger of her life, then with the Conent of her Husband and Kindred, give her even of the following Pills, which being taken, let her lie till 'till the vertue of them do provoke new Pains; for they are of o great Vertue, that they alo do expel the dead Child, together with the Secondines; yet herein it will not be amis to conult the skilful Phyician.

div.head: The Pills are thee.
div.p:
Take of Cator, Myrrh, Liquid Storax, of each a cruple; the bark of Cinamon, or Caia, and Birthwort, of each half a cruple; Agaric half an ounce, Diagridium 6 grains, Saffron, Siler of the Mountain, Savin,
of each 3 gr. Thebaic Opium, Aa faetida, of each one gr. mingle all thee with as much extracted Caia as is ufficient, and make of them certain Pills as big as peae, and give them to the Woman in a mall quantity of Penny-Royal water. It may be alo expedient to apply this enuing Plaiter.

Take one part of Coloquintida boiled in water, and as much of the juice of Rue, with thee mingle Lineeed, Fenugreek, Barly meal, of each a poonful, let them all boil together, and the Plaiter made of thee mut be laid upon all that part, from the Navel to the Privities.

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII. Of caes of Extremity; and firt, what is to be done to a Woman, who in her Travail is accompanied with a flux of blood, and with Convulions.
div.p:
IN the firt place, great care mut be had, as to the ituation of the Woman: The Woman in this cae mut be laid cros her Bed, where he mut be held by ome one that hath trength, that he may not lide, or move her elf in the operations of the Chirurgion. Her thighs mut be held hard and wide abroad, with her legs bent backwards towards her Hips, and her Head leaning upon a Bolter; the reins of her Back and her Crupper being a little elevated, with certain pillows put underneath her Thighs; beides this, he mut be well cover'd with linnen Cloaths laid upon her tomach, Belly, and Thighs, to defend her from the cold and wind: Being thus ituated, the Chyrurgion ought to put up his Hand, being firt well opened within the neck of the womb, to remove all thoe clots of blood, which may lie there to obtrut the paages of the blood. He may then try if the interiour neck of the womb be
ufficiently dilated, that he may put in his hand, and move the Infant, if it be needful, which mut be done as gently, and with as little violence as may be: He mut anoint it on all parts with weet-butter, or good Pomatum, and o opening it by little and little, he may put his hand quite in; and if the waters are not yet come down, he may without any difficulty let them forth; and then at the ame intant, if the Infant comes with the head forwards he hall gently turn it. to find out the feet, and when he hath found one of them, he hall gently draw it forth, and immediately tye a riband about it, with a knot hanging downward, then let him put it in again, uffering part of the riband to hang out, that he may more eaily be able to find out the other foot; which he hall quickly do, by thruting up his hand along the thigh of the Infant; when he hath found it, he hall take the other foot, and draw them both together at an even length, giving the woman now and then ome leiure to breath, but urging her till to train her elf, when he feels the pains coming on her: Then hall the Chirurgion or Midwife take a fine linnen cloth, and wrap about the thighs of the Child, let by taking it naked, his fingers hould lip; in that manner drawing it forth, 'till it appear all come forth, oberving till that the Belly and the Face be till kept downward.

Now if the woman hath a flux of blood, and that the neck of the Matrix be open, the Chirurgion ought to conider, whether the Infant or the Secondines come forth firt of all, for it oftentimes happens that the Secondines paing toward the mouth of the Matrix, do o top and obtruct it, that they do not give leave for the Child, or the Waters to come forth; o that ome perceiving that oftnes, are preently of opinion that the mouth of the Womb is not open. But this the
Midwife or Chirurgion may eaily dicern, by thruting up the middle finger as high as may be, and feeling therewith the circumference of the neck of the Womb, by which they will oon perceive whether the Womb be dilated or no, and whether it be the Secondines that preent themelves. Now when it is found to be the Secondines, and that they cannot eaily come forth, the Midwife may with her two fingers widen the paage, that he may have thereby the liberty to put up her hand, and eek for the Infant. Now if the Secondines be not placed in the middle, they mut be turned a little, as quickly as may be, that you may more conveniently eek for the feet of the Infant, to draw it forth as we have aid.
In uch a cae as this, all care mut be had that nothing be broken, and that every thing be brought out whole, for o though the woman hould die, the Midwife or Chirurgion would be blameles.

If the Secondines come firt, the bet way is to deliver the Woman with all the expedition that may be, by reaon of the great fluxes of blood that will follow, by reaon that the veins are opened: But here are two things to be conidered; the firt is, whether the Secondines are much, or little come forth; if they are but little advanced, they mut be put back with care and diligence; and if the head of the Child appear firt, it mut be guided directly toward the neck of the Womb, as in the mot natural birth; but if there appear any difficulty in the birth, by reaon of the weaknes, either of the Child, or of the Mother, then the mot convenient way will be to eek for the Feet, as we have aid before.

Another thing to be oberved is, that if the Secondines be o far advanced, that they cannot be put back, and that the Child follow it cloe, then are the Secondines
to be pulled away with all the care and expedition that can be, and to be laid aide without cutting the Entrail that ticks to them, for by that you may be guided to the Infant, which whether it be alive or dead,Of the Child dead in the Mothers Belly. is to be pulled out by the feet with as much care and quicknes as may be; though it is not to be done but in cae of great neceity, for otherwie the Secondines ought to come lat.
If the Child be dead in the Womb of the Mother, the Woman is then to be ituated in the ame poture, as when he is troubled with a flux of blood.

If it preent it elf dead, with the head foremot, and that there is little or no hope that the woman may be delivered without aitance, and that her trength begins to fail her, the mot certain and afe way is to put up the hand: For the Chirurgion mut then lide up his left hand being hollowed, as when a Man trives to hold water in it, cauing it to lide in the neck of the Womb, along the lower part thereof toward the feet, and that between the head of the Infant, and the neck of the Matrix: And having thus opened the Womb with his left hand, he hall with his right put up his hook above his left hand, between the head of the Child, and the flat of his hand, and fix in in the bone of the temple, toward the ear, or ele in the hollow of the eye, or in the Occipital bone, keeping his left hand till in its place; after this, gently moving and tirring the head with his left hand, with his right hand holding the hook well fixed, he hall draw the Child forth by degrees, exhorting the Woman all the while to force and train her elf with all her power, and then is the bet time to draw forth the Child, when the pains hall eize her; now if it happen that he loe his hold in one place, the danger is nothing, for he
hath the liberty to fix his Intrument better in another place. The head being thus drawn forth, he mut with all peed that may be, lip his hands down the Child's arm-holes, to draw forth his houlders, and the ret of his body: In the mean while it will be requiite to give the Woman a mall draught of wine, or a tot opt in wine of Hipocras.

If, after thee Medicines following adhibited,Another way. the Child make no hate into the World, but lies unmoved in the Womb, then you may proceed to Intruments after another manner. Firt of all, as oon as the Woman is brought to bed, let her take this following potion hot, and abtain from all other meat, and remain quiet for the pace of an hour or two, 'till he feel the power and efficacy of the Medicine.

Take even cut Figs, Fenugreek, Motherwort-eed, and Rue, of each two drams, water of Peny-royal and Motherwort, of each ix ounces, boil all thee to the conumption of half, train them; and to the training add Trochichs of Myrrh one dram, three grains of Saffron, Sugar as much as is ufficient; make one draught of this, and pice it with a little Cinamon.

After he hath reted a little upon this, let her again return to her travel, at what time certain perfumes mut be made ready of Trochichs, compoed of thee following Spices to be cat on the coals, and o ued, as that the perfume may only come to the Matrix, and no further.
Take Cator, Sulphur, Galbanum, Opoponax, Pigeons-dung, Aa-faetida, of each half a dram, mingle all thee with the juyce of Rue, and make a Trochich of them in the form of a Filberd.
If thee produce no effect, you may ue this following Emplaiter.

Take Galbanum an ounce and a half, Coloquintida without the grains two drams, the juyces of Rue and Motherwort, new wax, as much of each as is ufficient, of each make a plaiter. Let this be pread upon a cloth to reach from the Navil to the Privities, and in breadth to both the ides, which he may keep on for the pace of an hour or two. A Peary may be alo convenient, made of Wool, and cloed over with ilk, and then moitned in the following Decoction.

Take of round Birth-wort brought from France, Savin, and Coloquintida, with Grains, Staves-acre, black Ellebore, of each half a dram, bruie thee together, and make a Peary, with as much of the juyce of Rue as is ufficient.

But now if all thee things avail not, and that the Midwife is not able to dilate the paage for the Infant, then you mut have recoure to the Chirurgion; to which purpoe, he is to be placed in a eat, o that he may turn her crupper as much from the back of the Chair as may be; drawn up her legs as cloe as he can, but preading her Hips abroad as much as may be. Or ele if it eem more commodious, he may be laid upon the Bed, with her head downwards, her buttocks raied, and her thighs drawn up as much as can be: then you may go to work, either with your peculum matricis, or his Apertory; o that the womb being ufficiently widened by the help of thee Intruments, the birth may be drawn out by the hands of the Chirurgion, together with the Secondines, if poible may be. The womb mut then be wahed and anointed, the woman then mut be laid in her bed, and well comforted with pices, as alo with ome comfortable meat and drink. This coure mut be taken with all dead Infants, and alo with Moles and Secondines, which are hindred in their coming forth naturally.

If by thee Intruments the Womb cannot be ufficiently widened for the egres of the Infants, there are yet other Intruments, by which the Womb may be widened without damage to the Mother, and the Birth be brought forth, uch as are Drakes-bill, and the long Pincers, by which the Womb is not only widened, but the Birth taken hold of by them for the more forcible drawing it forth.

If there be any welling, or inflammation, or concrete blood, gathered together in the preputium of the Matrix, under the skin, thoe tumours either before or after the Birth, where the matter appears thinnet and ripet, the Midwife may cut with a pen-knife and queeze out the matter; anointing it afterwards often with a peary dipt in Oil of Roes, until it be whole.

If it happen that the Child be wollen in the Womb in any part of it, by reaon of Wind or any watry Humour, yet if it be alive, uch means are to be ued, as may be leat to the detriment of the Child and of the Mother; but if it be dead, in whatever part thoe humours be, either in the breat, arms, or legs, the Midwife may then put up her hand, and with a little knife for that purpoe, cut the wollen part, that by letting out of the Wind or humour, the Child may grow les and be brought forth with les difficulty.

Many times it happens that the Child comes into the World with the feet foremot; and the hands dilating themelves from the hips. In this cae the Midwife ought to be well furnihed with Oyntments, helping the egres of the Infant, by anointing and troaking it, let it be carried backward. Having alo a great care to take hold of both the arms of the Infant, and keep them cloe to the hips, that the Child may come forth after its own manner. If by reaon of this deduction of
the Arms, from the ides of the Infant, and the narrownes of the Matrix, it o happen that the Child cannot make a total egres, the womb of the Woman, and the Infant it elf, are to be well anointed, neezing Powders being adminitred to the Woman, to help her endeavours; the womb is alo to be preed hard with both hands, that the Child make no retirement back, but may till move forward.

It happens ometime that the Child comes forward with its feet, with the Arms not cloe to its ides, but extended above its head; which when it comes to pas, the Midwife is by no means to receive this Birth, unles the Child be very mall, and the Matrix o wide, that it may afford an eaie paage to the Child; yet may he not then receive it, till he hath well anointed both the Child and the Matrix. But it would be much more afe and convenient, for both the Child and the Mother, to put back the Child into the Womb and bring it to its natural form, which may be done in this manner. The woman mut lie on her back upon her bed, with her head downward, and her buttocks a little elevated, which being done, the Midwife hall gently compres the belly of the Woman toward the Midriff, thereby to put back the Infant into the Womb. But above all, things let her take care that he turn the Face of the Child toward the back of the Mother, raiing up the thighs and buttocks of the Child, toward the navel of the Mother, to bring the Child to a more legitimate and natural production.

If the Child happen to come forth but with one Foot, the Arm being extended along the ides, with the other Foot turned backward, the Woman is intantly to be brought to her bed, and laid in the ame poture as we have before told you, and then is the other foot which came forth firt to be put back into the Womb; which being done, let the woman rock her elf from one
ide of the bed to the other, (lying alwaies with her head low, and her Buttocks raied) 'till he apprehend the Child to be turned, upon which he may immediately expect her pains with all the aitance that may be given; and in the mean while to be comforted as much as may be with Cordial Potions, and wholome Medicines.
