Many times it happens that the Child lies athwart, and falls upon his ide, which when it comes to pas, the Mother is not to be urged to her labour, neither is the Birth to be expected after that manner, for it is impoible that the Child hould be o born without ome converion; and therefore the Midwife is to do all he can to reduce it to a more natural form of Birth, by moving the Buttocks, and teering the Head to the paage; if this ucceed not, let her try by often rocking the Woman to and fro, to bring the Child to its natural form of being born.

If it happen that the Child haten to the Birth, with the Legs and Arms ditorted, the Midwife ought not to haten the Woman, but immediately cat her on her Bed, where he may direct the Woman to roul her elf to and fro; or ele he may gently troke the womb of the Woman as he lies, 'till he have reduced the Infant to a better poture; If this profit not, the Midwife mut take the Legs and cloe them together, then if he can, he mut get her Hand about the Arms of the Child, and in the afet way he can, direct it to its coming forth; though it be the afet way to turn the Infant in the Womb, and by that means compoe it to the natural Birth.

If the Infant come into the World with both knees forward, with the Hands hanging down upon the Thighs. The Midwife may then put up both the Knees upward, 'till the Feet happen to come forward, and then with her left Hand let her take hold of the
Feet, and keep her right Hand about the ides of the Child, and in that poture endeavour the Birth of the Child; but if that ucceed not, let the Woman as is aid before, be brought to her Bed, and there wallow from ide to ide, 'till he have moved the Child into a better poture.

But when it happens that the Child hatens forwards, with one Arm extended upon the Thigh, and the other tretched over the Head, the Feet being tretched out at length in the Womb, the Midwife may by no means receive the Child in this poture, but mut lay the Patient upon the Bed, as we have aid before; then mut the Womans Belly be gently preed backward, that the Infant may retire into the Womb, and if it give not backward of its own accord, the Midwife may with her Hand gently thrut back the Shoulder, and bring the Arm that was tretched back to its right place.

The mot dangerous of all thoe that we have poken of is this, and therefore the Midwife mut take care to put back the Infant in this cae into the Womb: Firt of all therefore anoint well her Hands, as alo the Womb of the Woman, then, if he can, let her thrut in her Hand near the Arms of the Infant, and o move the Shoulders that the Infant may fall back into the womb; and then to bring it to the natural form, let her thrut up her other Hand, and reduce the Arms of the Infant to the ides of it; If this ucceed not, the Woman mut be laid on her Bed, and after a little ret, he mut be ordered as before we have aid: If this avail not, he mut be brought back to her Seat, as we have before reheared; then mut her womb, by the help of thoe Women that ait her be gently pret downward, and on both ides, while the Midwife having anointed the Matrix, and both the Arms of the Infant, joins them as cloe together as he can, and in that manner receives
the Infant. And there is the les danger in this form, if the Midwife be diligent, and the Child lender.

If the Infant thrut it elf forwards with the buttocks formot, the Midwife mut put up her Hand well anointed, and o by heaving up and putting back the Buttocks trive to turn the Head to the Paage. Yet overmuch hate mut not be made, let the Infant hould fall back into ome wore Poture; and therefore if it cannot be turned by putting up the Hand, the Woman mut be brought to her Bed, and ordered as we have often aid before; comfortable things being conveniently minitred to her.

If the Child come forward with the neck bowed, and the houlders forward, with the Hands and Feet tretched upwards; in this cae the Midwife mut carefully move the houlders backward that he may be able to bring the Head forwards, which may be eaily done, for the houlders being removed, the Head will oon appear formot, yet if this uffice not, the Woman mut be laid on her back upon the Bed, and ordered according to the former Precepts.

When the Infant thruts forth the Hands and Feet formot care mut be had to avoid the danger of this mihapen poture, and therefore the Midwife mut trive by removing the Feet, to lay hold on the Head, and, as much as in her lies, to direct it to the paage; the Hands are alo to be removed, unles of their own accord they fall down to the ides. If by this means it cannot be done, the former Precepts of converting the Child are to be oberved.

Sometimes it happens that the Child trives to force its paage in this poture which is very dangerous. Firt of all therefore let the Midwife anoint her Hands well, and the Womb of the Woman; which being done, let her put up her Hand, and eek for the Arms of the
Child, which when he hath found, let her hold them fat, till he hath hold of the Head alo, which he mut with all her skill endeavour to bring formot, then let her remove the Hands of the Infant, and fix them upon the ides of the Infant. Yet if this do not avail, it will be the afet way to lay the Woman on her Bed, and to proceed according to the former Precepts, to try if by that delay he may have the more advantage to proceed as before

The ame method which is to be oberved in ingle Birth, is alo to be oberved in cae of Twins or of tripple Birth; for as the ingle Birth hath but one natural way, and many unnatural Forms, o is it with the Birth of many Children; and therefore when it happens that Twins appear, coming into the World according to the natural form, the Midwife mut oberve to receive that firt which is nearet the paage; yet be ure not to let go the other, let it hould fall back into the womb, and tumble into ome other form, but the one being born, immediately to receive the other; this Birth is the more eaie in the natural form, becaue the firt Child widens the paage for the latter, but in unnatural Births there is mot difficulty in the paage of the econd Child: Care mut be alo had in the birth of Twins, that the Secondine be naturally brought forth, let the womb being deliver'd of its Burthen, hould fall, and the Secondine by that means be delayed to the damage of the Woman in Child-bed.

If there be Twins in the Womb, and one of them endeavour to come forth with the Head formot, and the other with the Feet: Firt of all the Midwife mut conider, which of the two the Woman may be delivered of with mot expedition; if the Head of the one be les forward than the Feet of the econd, it will be mot convenient to draw that forth by the Feet, turning
the head of the other a little to the other ide; and that being delivered, he mut preenty lay hold of the Head of that which is within, and direct it jut to the paage of the Womb; which may be done with more eae, by reaon of the gap which the formot hath made.

If it happen, in drawing forth the firt by the feet, that the other change its ituation, the Midwife may then draw forth the other by the Feet as he did the firt; and if the head of the firt be more forward, then he mut put back the Feet of the firt, and receive that which comes with the head formot.

If both of them pres together to the paage of the Womb, the Midwife mut take great care; and therefore he mut put up her hand to ee which of them is mot forward, as alo to try whether it be not ome montrous Conception, as two heads upon one body, or two bodies joined in one, either at the houlders, or at the ides, which may be known, if he put up her hand gently between the two heads as high as he can; and if he find that they are twins, he may gently put the one to one ide, to make way for the paage of the other, which is mot advanced; which mut be directed jut to the orifice of the Womb, having a great care that he do not change the ituation of the econd; and as he feels the pains of the Mother coming on her, he mut by all means bring forward the Child he would receive, till keeping the other back, with two or three fingers of the left hand: and thus having delivered the firt, if the econd be not well ituated, he mut bring the head to <> neck of the Womb, where it will find the paage <> to it, by the delivery of the firt.

Now let the firt Child hould be in danger of its life, you mut take it from the Mother, and carefully tie up the Navel-tring, as is formerly mentioned, and alo bind again with a large and long fillet, that part of the
Navel which is fat to the Secondines, that they may be more eaily found, Then the econd Child being born the Midwife mut ee if there be not two Secondines, for by reaon of the hortnes of the ligature, it may have hapned to retire back again, to the damage of the Woman; and therefore the Secondines mut be hatened forth as oon as may be, let the Womb hould cloe.

If the two Infants have but one body, the better way is to turn the head upwards, and to draw it forth by the Feet, than by the head: Taking care when you come to the Hips, to draw it forth as quick as may be.

The econd form of unnatural Birth is very dangerous, and therefore requires the greater care of the Midwife. Firt, therefore let her well anoint the Womb of the Woman that the paage may be more lippery; which being done, let her take hold of the hands of one of the Infants, and keeping them cloe to the ides, direct the head to the orifice of the Womb; that being born, let her proceed in the ame manner toward the other. If he cannot come to take hold of either of the Infants Arms, he mut bring the Woman again to her Bed, and try by the aforeaid Agitation of her body, if the Infants may be brought to a more convenient form of delivery.

div.head: CHAP. XXIX. Of ordering the Woman after he is delivered,
div.p:
In Italy the perons, of <…> account do ue this water. Take two <…> the Feathers being well pulled off <…>
• he bowels wholly taken out, which you led off boyl in a glaz'd earthen pot, in a ufficient quantity of water till they be half boyled, then mut they be taken out of the pot, together with the Broth; and being cut to peices are to be put into a Lembick in manner following.

Take Buglos, Borage, and Time, two good handfuls, and with that cover the bottom of the hell, then lay upon that a row of fleh, then upon that a rank of leaf-Gold, with a dram of powder of Pearls, and upon that pour the broth; let all this be ditilled in Balneo Mariae, drawing forth a pint at a time, which you hall re-iterate as often as you have any thing left, to give to the Woman in Child-bed, for the pace of ten or twelve days. This water mut be drawn ix weeks or two months before it be ued; if the Woman be not troubled with a Fever, let her drink a little white
Wine, or Claret, with twice as much hot Water; If he have a mind to drink between Meals, or at night, it may be convenient to give her ome yrup of Maiden-hair, or any other Syrup that is not atringent, with a little boyled water. After the upition of a Fever, or heat of her breats is over, he may be nourihed more plentifully, and you may give her, together with her Broth, ome other meat, as Pullet, Capon, Pidgeon, Mutton, or Veal boyled. After the eight day is pat; at what time the Womb is well purged and dicharged, it will be expedient to give her good meat in greater quantity, that he may be enabled to gain trength; during all this time, he mut ret very quiet, and be <> from all manner of diturbance; he mut leep as <…> the day time as may be. If he go not well to tool, <…> ome uch kind of Clyter as this.

Take of Mallows, <…> mallows, and Pellitory of the wall, each one handful, <…>
• f Camomile, and Melliot, of each a mall handful, A •
<…> and Fennel-eeds, of each two ounces; boyl thee in <…>
••
coction of a Weathers-head, take of this three quarters of a pint, and diolve in them of coure Sugar and common Hony, of each two ounces, new freh butter three ounces; of this make a Clyter, and if occaion erve, add to this an ounce of Catholicon.

div.head: What is to be done to the Breat, Belly, and lower parts of the Woman in Child-bed.
div.p: IN the firt place you may lay the skin of a Hare, or Sheep, for the pace of four or five hours; which being taken away, you may then anoint it with this following Oyntment, and then lay a linnen Towel all over her belly and hips, which mut be continued on for the firt even days, looking after it, and turning every Morning.

div.head: The Oyntment may be this.
div.p: Take the Oyl of weet-Almonds, Camomile, and St. John's wort, each one ounce and a half, Sperma ceti two Ounces, Goats fat one Ounce, Oyl of Miriles half an Ounce, melt all thee, and make an Oyntment to anoint the Belly: Now before the Cerecloth be put on, you mut apply a little Plaiter of Galbanum, about the bignes of 2 or 3 fingers to the Navel, in the middle of which may be put two or three grains of Civet, yet o as that the Woman may not perceive the ent of it. The Cerecloth may be this.

Take White Wax four ounces, Pomatum without Musk, Calfs-greae, of each one ounce, Sperma ceti an ounce and a half, Oyl of St. John's-wort, and Sweet Almonds, of each one ounce; Venice-Turpentine wahed in Pellitory-water half an ounce; melt thee in Balneo Mariae, and pread them upon a cloath about the bignes of the belly, and when it is cool apply it.

The next care is to be had of the Breats, upon thee ome put round Cerecloth made thus; Take ix ounces of new Wax, Oyl of Myrtle, Roes and Honey of Narbon, of each two ounces; melt thee altogether, and make a Cerecloth, let them have holes in the middle for the Nipples to go through.

div.head: This Oyntment is alo very good to keep the Milk from clotting.
div.p: Take Oyntment of Populeon one ounce, Galen's refrigerating Oyntment half an ounce, Oyl of Roes ix drams, Vinegar a mall quantity; melt them together and make an Oyntment.

div.head: This fomentation is alo much commended.
div.p:
Take Fennel, Parly, Mallows, Marh-mallows, of each a mall handful, Laurel and Camomile-flowers, of each half a handful, boyl thee according to Art, and make a Fomentation for the Nipples. After this Fomentation,
anoint them with Oleum Roatum, Omphacium, and then apply this following Plaiter.

Take Venice-Turpentine four ounces, well wahed in trong wine, and Roe-water, adding to it two whole Eggs, and a cruple of Saffron, with as much wax as is ufficient; pread this upon a linnen cloath, and apply it. As for the lower parts, for the three firt days they are to be fomented with a certain fomentation of Milk, wherein hath been boiled a few Roes, ome Chervil, and a little Plantain. From the next day to the eighth day, you may ue this bath; Wine and water, of each half a pint; red Roes and flowers of St. John's wort, of each two handfuls; Agrimony one handful, mak of this a decoction; after bathing once, or twice, lay this following Oyntment along the lips of the Privities upon a linnen cloth.
Take Oyl of St. John's wort 2 ounces, Sperma ceti an ounce and a half, a little white wax, mix all thee together, melt them, and make an Oyntment.
After the eight days are pat, you may lay upon her belly this following Plaiter.

Take Oyl of St. John's wort, Camomile, and Annieeds, of each one ounce, Oyl of Matick an ounce and a half, Oyl of Mirtles ix drams, Sperma ceti two ounces, the fat of the Reins of a Goat an ounce and a half, Deers uet one ounce; of this make an Oyntment to anoint the belly of the woman in Child-bed, and then apply this following Plaiter.

Take Oyl of Myrtles, and St. Johns-wort, of each an ounce and a half, Oyl of Nip one ounce, Venice-Turpentine, wahed in water of Motherwort, four ounces; melt all thee together, and put them upon a Hempen cloath, that may cover all the belly, and let her wear it the pace of eight days.
Thee fifteen days being pat, for the pace of eight days more, you may lay upon her belly and her hips this following Plaiter.

Take Oyl of Matick, Myrtles, Jamine, and Quinces, of each an ounce and a half, Oyl of Acorns two ounces, Sperma ceti one ounce, Venice-Turpentine wahed in Plantain-water, half an ounce; wax ix ounces, melt all thee together, adding powder of Matick, and eal'd earth, of each half an ounce, Florentine Orrice one ounce, pread all thee upon a hempen cloath, and lay it upon her belly, to be kept there for the pace of eight or ten days; for the lower parts, this Fomentation may be needful.

Take Leaves of Plantain, Mullein, Knot-gras, and Hore-tail, of each one handful, Cypres-leaves a handful and a half; of the rind of Pomgranates, Cypres-Nuts, and Pomgranate-flowers, of each half an ounce; red Roes, Camomile and Melilot, of each a handful; Roch-allum two ounces, Sweet melling-Flag and Florentine-Orrice, of each three drams, Gilliflowers one dram; make of thee two bags, and boyl them in like quantities of owre wine, and Smith's water, for the exteriour mouth of the neck of the Womb.

div.head: Of the choice of a good Nure.
div.p:
THE choice of a good Nure is very important, and therefore you mut firt look upon her apect, and ee whether her ight be no way imperfect, as whether he be quint-eyed, or have a down-cat look; you mut have a pecial care that he be not red haired, for their Milk is extreamly hot; ee moreover, whether her teeth be ound and white, and well et; know whether he come of Parents that have been troubled with the Conumption; and if he have not, nor be conumptive her elf, you may judge of her
tomach, and whether he be ubject to Catarrhs; you mut alo take heed that he end no tinking-breath, either from her mouth, or notrils, for that corrupts the Lungs of the Infant. Enquire whether neither he, nor any of her kindred have been troubled with Leproie, by reaon that it is very contagious, or with the Falling-Sicknes. And therefore thoe Women that either cannot or will not nure their own Children, mut make ue of uch women as are mot fit to the humour they would have the Child to be of: For the Nure is now to be the econd Mother of the Child, from whom the Infant draws all her Conditions, be they good, be they bad; and it is often een, that Children do partake more of the Conditions of the Nure, than the Mother, and therefore care mut be taken that the Nure be good conditioned, good teeth, brown hair, of a healthy generation; that neither he nor her Husband have had the French Dieae; that he be not peevih nor cholerick, that he have Milk in abundance, and a good flehy breat, that her breat be not over-flehy, that he be not over fat; and, above all, that he be not of too amorous a humour, and deirous to be with her Husband, for that is perfect venom to the milk.

div.head: What is to be done in the extream pains of the Child.
div.p:
IF a Child have extream throws preently after it be born, you mut rub it with Pellitory and freh butter, or Spinage, or ele with Hogs-greace, and apply it upon the Navel, having firt a great care that it be not too hot. Or ele make a little cake of Eggs, and Oyl of Nuts, and apply it in the very ame place; if this avail not, give it a little Clyter of Milk, the yolk of
an Egg, and a little Sugar; this eaeth the pain of the Intetines.

div.head: What is to be done with thoe Children that are troubled with Flegm.
div.p: THere are ome Children born of ill-contitution'd Women, or ele of Women that have not ued good nourihment in the time of their being with Child, who are very full of flegm, thee you mut lay upon one ide, and omtimes upon the other; for if you lay them upon their backs, you may perchance choak them; you mut be ure to keep their bellies oluble, cauing them to void that blood kept in the Entrails from the time of their being in the womb, by giving it a little Suppoitory of black Sope well rubbed in freh butter, to take away the Acrimony of it; then give it a poonful of Syrup of Violets, this caues the flegm to pas down. If you perceive that the Infant hath not much heat, you may mix with it half the quantity of Oyl of weet Almonds, and half of the yrup of Violets, and continue it, troaking the tomach an • the belly of the Infant with freh butter, every time tha • they undres him.

div.head: That which ought to be done to Children that have their Cods full of wind.
div.p: WHen Infants have their Cods full, ye mut examine whether it be with wind, or water; if it be with water, by rubbing and chafing the skin with freh butter, the waters will weat out; if it be wind, the Children mut be tirred, and wung gently, mingling in their drink the decoction of Anieeds.

div.head: How to take away the Canker from the mouths of Infants.
div.p:
THere have been known certain Children which have ben nourihed with cold milk, which hath been thick, and in great quantity, which a few days after its birth, hath heated the mouth of the Infant in uch a fahion, that it caued a white Canker, which preently poeed the tongue, palate, the gums, the throat, and all the mouth, whereupon it was taken with a Fever, and it could no longer uck, all the aitance that could be was till applied, and when no other Medicine did avail, there was found one, a particular remedy, which was half a handful of Sage, a handful of Chervil bruied a little, and boyled in a ufficient quantity of water, about a dozen eethings, to which you mut add a poonful of Vinegar; when you have trained it, you mut put to it an ounce of Honey of Roes, then you mut have a little hooked tick, with a little piece of Scarlet tied at the end, then putting the water in a Sawcer, dip the end of the tick where the Scarlet is tied, and then rub the place affected gently, and you hall find the Canker <> a •
wage by little and little.

div.head: What is to be done to Children whoe Intetines are falle • .
div.p:
THERE are a great many Infants, whoe great gut falls; which is a thing very eaily remedied at the beginning, and therefore you mut put it up again: Firt, lay the Child with the Head lowermot, then you mut have a thick Cuhion, oaked in Smiths Water, then you mut have an emplaiter made of the Roots of great Comfrey craped, and put upon it as an Ointment; then looking to it every day, taking care
that it cry but little, and never unbind him, but as he lyes, let the Gut tumble down again, and o the Cure be delayed; as the Child grows big, the Hole leens, and the Intetine grows big. This is an experienced way.

div.head: To make an Oyntment to trengthen the Thighs and legs of the Child, and make him go.
div.p: TAKE Sage, Marjoram, Dwarf-Elder, bruie them a good while together, 'till you have beaten out a good deal of Juyce, then put it into a Glas Vial, 'till it be full, and top up the Hole with pate, and round the ides alo of the aid Pate; put it then in an Oven, to bake as long as a good big Loaf, then draw it forth, and uffer it to cool, then break the Pate which is round the Vial; break the Bottle, and keep up that which is within, which you hall find turned to an Oyntment: And when you would ue it, you mut add to it ome of the Marrow of the Hoof of an Ox, melting it altogether, and when ye have o done, you mut rub the hinder part of the legs, and thighs of the Child. This hath been done to a Child, whom a famous Phyician, after 3 Years having in hand, gave over, aying, that it would never go.

div.head: Of the relaxations of the Matrix, and the caue.
div.p:
THere are many caues of the relaxation of the Matrix, the one proceeding from great Fluxes, which fall down upon the ligaments thereof, cauing them to wax looe; Others come to this Dieae by ome falls, others by reaon of carrying in their womb too great Burdens, others by training themelves in travail before their time, and becaue the Orifice of the Womb is not open; ometimes, and very often by reaon of the Midwifes, who putting up their Hands into the
Womb, tear down they know not what, which is oftentimes a part of the Matrix, to the bottom of which the Secondines adhere, drawing down part of the womb, which they take to be the Secondines; which is oftentimes brought alo to a wore condition, when the unskilful Women force her to the Remedies, for bringing down the Secondines; as holding Bay alt in her Hand, treining to Vomit, and the like. For remedy whereof, all thee telaxations of the Matrix, are by the ame Remedies, except thoe which are occaion'd by trong Fluxes, for in this cae other Remedies are not ufficient, being that you are to take away the caue of thoe defluxions, before you can proceed to the Cure of the relaxation. Among the ret, I will relate one that hath been found very profitable and experienced, which is this atringent. Take Gall-nuts, Cypres nuts, and Pomgranate Flowers, Roche-Alum, of each two Ounces, Province Roes four ounces, Knot-gras a good big handful, the Rind of Caia, the Rind of Pomegranates, Scarlet Grains, of each three Ounces, the nature of a Whale one ounce; Mirrh-water, Roe-water, and Sloe-water, an ounce and a half, thick Wine, and Smiths-water, of each four ounces and a half; then make two little bags of a quarter of a Yard long, cauing them to boil in the aforeaid waters, in a new pot, uing one after another as you have occaion, letting it lie upon the Bone of the Pubes, paing in between the Hips, chafing her often, and holding her Head and her Reins low, uing in the Morning ometimes a little Matick in an Egg, or ometimes Plantain Seed: If the Dieae be not too old, it may be cured by this means; but if it be of a long tanding, you mut make a peary half round, and half Oval, of great thick Cork, pierced through in the middle; tye a little Pack-thred to the end, then cover it over with white Wax, that
it may do no hurt, and to make it more thick, this mut be dipped in Oyl of Olives to make it enter, and it mut be traight, that it may not eaily fall out; and if it be too little, to have another bigger, and when the Woman goes to do her neceary occaions, he mut hold it in, let he hould force it out; the Hole is made, that the Vapours of the womb may have a vent, and to give way for her purgations to flow, neither mut it be taken away 'till after the Purgations are paed, the thicknes caues the Matrix to mount up as long, as it is very thick, for the Ligaments being cloe do then retire. If they be Women that bear Children, the Midwife ought not to uffer them to force themelves, but as Nature contrains her, having her own hand ready after the throw, to put back the Matrix with her finger, and when he is brought to bed, lay her low with her head and with her reins, raiing her up with pillows put under her hips; and for Women that are troubled with this Dieae, they ought not to lace themelves over hard, for that thr • ts down the Matrix, and makes the Woman pouch bellied, and hinders the Infant from being well ituated in her Body, cauing her to carry the Child all upon her Hips, and makes her Belly as deformed as her Wate is handome.

div.head: Of a dieae that happens by reaon of the fall of the Matrix.
div.p:
THere is ometimes a relaxation of the Membrane, that covers the rectum Intetinum, when the head of the Child, at the begining of the Travel falls downward, and draws it low; oftentimes it comes by reaon of Women with Child lacing themelves, which caues uch a conflux of wind to thee parts, that it eems to the Woman to be the head of the Child, inomuch
that he is hardly able to tand upright, neither can he go. For remedy hereof, you mut keep the woman oluble, giving her Anie, and Coriander eeds to diipate the winds. You mut take Sage, Agrimony, Motherworth, Balm, white Wormwood, Margerom, a little Rue, and a little Thyme, and Camomile and having picked all the above written Herbs, you mut cut them very mall, and having well mingled them, put them into a maple platter, and then put hot Cinders upon them, and upon thoe another handful of Herbs, covering the platter with a cloe cloth, that the woman may receive the moak; this is a remedy which hath been much approved and experimented.

div.head: To remedy the fall of the Fundament in Infants:
div.p: TAke of the green hrub whereof they make • rooms, and cut, it mall, and lay it upon the Coals, and et the Child over the moak thereof, and it will certainly cure it.

div.head: Of the dieaes of Women, and firt of the inflammation of the breat.
div.p:
THe Inflammation of the Breats is a hard welling together with a beating pain, rednes, and hooting. The chief caue of this is the abundance of blood, drawn up together in that place, though there be ometime other caues alo, as the uppreion of the coures, the Haemorrhoids, or a blow received upon the Breats. The igns of it are eaie to be known, that is to ay, a certain rednes and burning heat, oft-times joined with a Fever. For the cure of this, there are four orts of remedies; Firt, the order of diet, which mut be comforting and moitning, as Broth of Pullets, where Endive, Borage, Lettice, and Purlain may be boyled alo; he may drink the Juyce of Pomgranates, or Barley
water, with Annieeds boyled in it: the ue of Wine, and all orts of Spices are very dangerous, and if the Woman go not freely to the tool, there is nothing better than a Lenitive Clyte •
; he may leep much, and mut not diturb her elf with any paion. The next way of Remedy is by diverting the humours, which is done by frictions, letting blood in the foot, carrification of the legs, or veficatories applied to thoe places, epecially if the flowers are topped, or ready to come down; if not, it will be expedient to open a vein in the arm.

You may alo prepare the humour to void it out of the place affected, by opening either the middle vein, or the Bailic, or the Vena Saphena, which may be done two or three times, as occaion erves; after blood-letting, purge, but let this be done with gentle Medicines; uch are Caia, Manna, Tamarind, Syrup of Roes or Violets Solutive, having a little before ued certain Syrups which may awage and temper the humours.

Take yrup of Roes and Purlain, of each one ounce, Endive water and Plantain-water, of each an ounce, give this to the Patient, neither will it be amis to give her Syrup of Succory, or Endive, or uch like; for thee Syrups have a cooling and refrehing faculty, epecially being mingled with Plantain or Endive-water, or uch like, or the decoction of the aid Herbs; now when the humour is thus prepared you may give her ome gentle Purges. As for Example, take of the pulp of Caia, and Tamarinds, of each ix drams; of this make a little Bolus with ome Sugar, and give it to the Patient; or with this Potion.

Take of the Leaves of Italian Orach three drams, of Anieed one cruple, infue thee into four ounces of the foreaid waters. Into this being trained, infue an
ounce of Caia, and into the treining of this, diolve an ounce of Solutive Syrup of Roes, of this make a Potion and give it. The fourth way of cure conits in Topicks, uch as may drive back and repres the humour, though care mut be had that they be not over-trong, let you thereby do cool the heart too much, and thereupon drive the humour upon the heart it elf. And therefore temperate Medicines are chiefly to be choen, and uch epecially as are to diget and diolve the humour: Wherefore it hall not be amis to apply a linnen cloth dipt in white trong vinegar, and a little cold water, which mut be applied to the Breats, and often changed. Or ele you may dip linnen cloaths alo in a decoction of Camomile-flowers, and Violet-flowers, with a mall quantity of Oyl of Roes, and a drop of vinegar or two; or you may ue this Fomentation. Take of the juyce of Night-hade and Oyl of Roes, of each an ounce and a half; of the decoction of Fenugreek, Camomile, and Line-eed, two ounces, vinegar one ounce.
This Medicine you may ue by dipping a punge therein, and o wahing and fomenting the Breat therewith.

div.head: CHAP. XXX. Of Swellings from Milk.
div.p:
MILK is certainly the occaion of many tumours of divers kinds; if the ferment of the Breat be over-active and vigorous, it eparates Milk with too great Violence, cauing thereby an over-fermentation of the parts, which uually occaions an Inflammation; if the Serum be hot or partake much of blood, otherwie it raies a flegmatic Swelling; or if the matter be dipoed to coagulation, the Kings-evil; and thee are
the mot frequent pecies of Swellings commonly uppoed to arie from milk. Any of thee three may degenerate into a Scirrhus, and that Scirrhus into a Cancer. The igns are viible; if the firt happen, there are all the Symptoms of an Inflammation, namely Heat, Rednes, Tenion, pulation, and the like. If the econd, large Ditenion with pain, but no heat: If the Kings-evil, then hard Kernels are eaily felt. Swellings made by the over eagernes of the milky Ferment go eaily off, if no other Symptom attend them; ucking and drawing the breats commonly dicharges the Milk as fat as it can be made, and then all the danger is over. But if the fermentation occaion any diorder in the Blood, the Patient is more or les endangered, according to the quality of the welling produced, namely an inflammation occaions a Fever. Flegmatick wellings are apt to grow Ulcerous, and ometimes turn to the King's Evil, or a Scirrhus, and require a long time for their Cure. Abundance of Milk caues inflammations, and apotumations, and the like, and therefore the Woman ought to ue a lender diet, and it ought to be of uch a quality as may les dipoe the Humours to ferment. Panadoes, Barly grewel, and uch like cooling and moitening Spoon-meat ought to be ued; Chicken Broth is the highet Dyet whilt the Humour is fermenting; the Medicines proper to diminih the Milk, are Lettice, Purlain, Endive, Succory, Smallage and the like; the Milk is uually drawn out of the Breats by the Infant's ucking; but if the Child be o weak it cannot uck, or not ufficiently, the Milk mut be dicharged by Whelps ucking, or the Mother may draw her own Breats her elf by an Intrument old for that purpoe. The welling made by the Milk is retrained by the application of Night-hade, Lettice, Plantain, Vine tops, Bramble-buds, Hore-tail,
and the like, or Oyl of Roes, Myrtles with Vinegar and the like. The Tumour may be dicued by the application of Mints, Cat-mints, Rue; the Seeds of Fenugreek, Cumin, Fennel, and the like; or dry'd up by applying Cloaths dipt in Lime-water, or in a olution of Sacharum Saturni made in Frogs Spawn-water, during which time fine Towe prinkl'd with Cerus, may be applied to the Arm-pits. When the Swelling is very painful, a Cataplam made of the Meals of Barly, Beans and Lentils boiled in Oxymel, is proper; at the ame time Towe dipt in Oxycrat may be applied under the Arms: If the Inflammation be gone too far towards Suppuration, it mut be promoted with Suppuratives, and opened by Inciion or cautick. When the Swelling is hard and not inflamed, apply the following Cerate.

Take of the tops of Worm-wood powdered, two drams, of the Seeds of Lentils, Fenugreek, and Fennel, each an ounce; of the juice of Henbane and Hemlock, each three ounces, of ointment of Marhmallows two ounces, of Ducks and Gooe greae, each one ounce, of Deers Suet two ounces, of liquid Storax half an ounce; with a ufficient quantity of Wax make a Cerat. Hemlock boil'd in Wine, and beaten up with Hogs lard, reolves the hardnes in the Breats; but if it be applyed alone, it tirs up Heat, and occaions Ulcers in the skin. Green Mints or Chick-weed are common applications, and of good ue, either alone, or mixed with other Medicines in all the hard Swellings of the Breats occaioned by Milk. All Plaiters applyed to the Breats, ought to have a hole nipt in them for the Nipples, let they be fretted by them, epecially that the Milk may be drawn forth while the Medicines lye on.

A young Woman after Child-birth was afflicted with a welling in her Breats, one was called, that perwaded
her Relations it was a Cancer, and treated her accordingly, but her Breats growing more painful, and much danger being apprehended from uch a Dieae, a Phyician was advied with; but he being wary in giving his judgment in Surgery, where there might happen any dipute, deired that a Surgeon might be fetched; upon their view, the Breat appeared big, and inflamed; it was apotumated, and the matter perfectly digeted, and the skin thin and ready to break. The Surgeon propoed the applying of a Pultes of white-Bread and Milk, auring them before Morning, they hould find a Porringer full of matter dicharged; they did o, and the welling broke, and was cured by the ue of Bailicon without any more trouble; and indeed when the matter is well uppurated, and a convenient opening made for dicharge, thee Tumours generally heal of themelves, if the Habit of the Body be good; but where it is otherwie, or the management ill, the Cure is many times very troubleome.

A Young Gentlewoman after Child-bed, being indipoed in her Health, her left Breat became dieaed and well'd, and after ome days by ill management, growing more painful and welled, one was called in who endeavoured uppuration, and after ome time opened it; but the fluxion increaed, and other obcees were raied, and from the everal Apotumations, inous Ulcers were afterwards made, and o the work became difficult; the abces begun deep in the body of the Glands, and thro' length of time, corrupted them, and rendred the welling hard, and the Tents topping in the matter between dreings, had occaioned a large dicharge: The method of Cure conited in the enlarging of that Orifice, where the matter eemed to be detained, and then to proceed with deterives and the like; a cautick was applied to the part round about the Orifice,
toping the hole with Lint. by which means in a hort time, a clear way was made for the matter, as the Echar eparated, a Fungus thrut forth, which was prinkled with red Precipitat, and the Echar was dreed with Bailicon, and the other openings with Diapompholigos, and the Cerate of Marh-mallows over all: After a more full-eparation of the Echar, oberving the Fungus to rie more large, a Stupe was applied, wrung out of a decoction of the tops of Worm wood, Rue Mint, the Flowers of red Roes and Balautines made in Wine and Water, and Chalcanthum was applyed upon the Fungus, and pledgets of the Ointment of Tutty over the Ulcerated parts. The econd day after the Dreings were took off, and the Echar was found to be made by the Catheretick, which was thrut off, and it was dreed again with the ame, and the ue of the Echaroticks was continued; during thee applicationss a Plaiter of Bole was applied over the Breat to retrain the fluxion, yet notwithtanding the fungus encreaed, and raied the welling between that and the other Orifices, and therefore a large Cautick was applied upon the welling, which laid ome of the Orifices into this, the Echar was divided, and dreed up with lenients, and the Fungus was cover'd with echaroticks, wherever it began to thrut out, by which it was kept down: But after the eparation of this latter Echar, the Fingus appeared great, and the way of extirpating it by Echaroticks being low, the Surgeon thrut his Finger under it, and at once broke it, and pulled it out in pieces, and then filled up the place with Par • celus's mundificative upon Pledgits prinkled with red Precipitat, and the foreaid Plaiter being applied over the whole Breat, it was bound up. The econd day after it was opened again, and by this method often repeated, the remainder of the Fungus
was ubdued, and a firm bais raied, on which to incarn with an addition of powders of the roots of orris, myrrh, and Sarcacoll to the fore-mentioned Mundificative, and Agripa's Cerate was applied over the breat and in a few days it was cicatrized with a mooth Cicatrix, the lips falling in by the benefit of Nature, which was aited the while by traumatick decoctions, and the like. When one of the Breats has been Cured, it happens often that the other wells from the abundance of Milk, and grows hard and apotuntats; ometimes both Breats are thus dieaed at one time. A Gentlewoman had both her Breats welled a long time, and afterwards they apotumated by reaon of the pain; everal abcees were made, and the matter dicharged by uch openings. In proces of time the Ulcers became inuous, and callous, with hardnes of the glands; the Cure was begun by Fomentations, and dicuing and reolving Pultees made of the roots and leaves of Marh-mallows, henbane, the tops of hemlock, mint, rue, the flowers of elder, the eeds of fenugreek, flax, and the like, and with the meal of lentiles, barly, hogs-lard, ducks and gooe greae, and the like; and dilating the orifices, and cleaning with paracelues mundificative, red precipitat and allom; while the Surgeon was endeavouring by the methods aboveaid, new troubles aroe within, which forced him to lay uch places open by cautick, as might bet erve for the dicharge of matter, after eparation of the Echar, he again cleaned and healed them.

div.head: Of windy Tumours in the Breats.
div.p:
THE flatuous Tumour of the Breats is caued by a thick vapour, which ries from the mentrual blood which is retained or corrupted in the Matrix.
The caues of which are; firt, the uppreion of the flowers; or when the flowers are not dicharged into their proper place, and in their proper time; as alo from the corruption of the humours, by which are ingendered divers bad fumes and vapours; for, this being received into the Breats, caues a ditention much like a true welling. The ign by which it is known, is the pain which it brings along with it, which is harp and prickling, cauing a ditention of the part. The heart is not a little out of order, by reaon of the windinees which lye o near it; and commonly the left Breat is mow woln, communicating its pain to the arm, houlder, and ribs of the ame ide. And the igns differ from thoe of a Cancer; for in this ditemper the Breat is white and hining, by reaon of the ditention; and if you touch it, it ounds like a drum. And if you pres it with your hands, you will find that it is welled in all parts alike, and not in one more than another. This is Cured firt by a good order of diet, taking little victuals, whereby crudities may be avoided that do afford matter to the obtructions, and increae windines: For which caue he mut alo drink little, and that, water boyled with Cinamon, Anieed, and rind of Citrons. The next remedy is by uing things which are good to provoke the Coures, (among which ue this Receit, train Celandine tampt into poet-ale, and drink it four days before the new-moon, and four days after.) And it will not be amis to let blood three or four times in the year, about the time that the Coures ought to begin. For by this means you may provoke the flowers, and hinder the increae either of a Scirrhus, or of a Cancer; to which purpoe, baths and frictions are not a little to be ued. In the next place, you mut prepare the humours that foment this windines
both in the Matrix and in the Veins, and that by Syrups which do expell flegm and melancholly; after which you mut purge your Patient; for which purpoe you may ue this gentle Apozem. Take of the root of Tamarinds, Cypres, Buglos, of each an ounce and a half; flowers of Borage, Epithymum, Sena, of each half a handful, flowers of Balm one handful, Raiins one ounce, Prunes in number twelve, boyl them in a ufficient quantity of water, and then in a pint of the water diolve four ounces of the yrup of Violets; make of this an Apozem clarified according to Art, and weeten it with a ufficient quantity of Sugar, giving four or five ounces at a time. In the next place, you may ue Topicks to attenuate and reolve; to which purpoe you may bathe or foment the Breat with a Sponge dipt in Lye, and then lay upon it a linnen cloth, dipt and moytned in Aqua-vitae, and dryed in the hade, or ele dipt in freh butter that hath boyled a good while, or in oyl of Lillies, or in oyl both of the root and eed of Angelica; or you may foment the Breat with this Decoction. Take wheat-bran two handfuls, leaves of Dill and Melilot, of each half a handful; Anieed, Fennel, and Cumineed, of each two drams, Camomile-flowers one handful; boyl all thee in a ufficient quantity of water and white-wine, and let them boyl to the conumption of the third part. In this decoction you may wet a ponge, and wah or foment the Breat therewith. After you have fomented the part, you may put this Oyntment upon the part affected: Take oyl of Lillies and Elder, of each an ounce and a half, of the bet Balom half an ounce, powder of burnt-lead unwaht, Anieed one dram, and as much wax as is ufficient.

div.head: Of the watry Tumour of the Breat.
div.p:
THE watry tumour is ingendered by a thick and watry flegm gathered together in great abundance in the Breat and parts adjoyning, and it happens many times that this watry and flegmy ubtance is not always gathered to one particular place, but alo diffued through all the parts of the Breat, which caues a general welling in that part. This welling (that we may define it) is a looe and oft tumour without much pain, yielding to the touch and preing of the fingers, o that the hole which is made by the preing of the fingers remains a pretty while after; yet it oon becomes painful, if there be any Acrimony joyned with it; or if there be any ditention by reaon of the pres of Vapours to that part. This oftentimes happens by reaon of the uppreion of the Coures; ometimes it is occaioned by reaon of a clear and watry flegm, which dicharges it elf upon thee parts. This welling is eaily ditinguihed from other wellings, by reaon of the looenes and oftnes thereof, and by the pain, which is always les than in other wellings: and in this kind of tumour the pain acends up to the arms and houlders, and the whole Breat is altogether woln and raied; and this pain comes at certain times, chiefly when the Flowers ought to come down, which being once come down, the pain diminihes, by reaon that the Woman is then throughly Purged. Yet notwithtanding, there doth remain ome certain kind of welling, which happens not in the windy tumours, by reaon that the purgations of the Flowers do totally diipate the matter of thoe wellings. Thee flegmy tumours do eaily turn into Cancers, and are therefore to be diligently looked after.
As to the Cure of thee tumours, there is required firt an orderly Diet, which mut be drying, her Bread mut be well baked and levened, dryed Raiins, parched Almonds, Aparagus, roted Fleh, and mall Birds. Before meat he may take a little Honey of Roes upon a wafer-cake. For her drink, let it be the decoction of Anieeds, China-roots, Saafras, and Saraparil. If the retention of the Flowers be the caue of this evil, let her then ue rather boyled than roted meats, and then let her boyl them with Sage, Bettony and Hyop. All meats made of Milk are dangerous, as alo leep after dinner, and unleavened bread.

You may in the next place, ue things to divert the humour, as Frictions, and Baths. If her Flowers are uppreed, let a vein be opened in the Feet. Next after you have prepared the humour by the ue of Syrups, as thoe of Mint, Wormwood, Hyop, Liquorih, Maidenhair, Hony of Roes, with Fennel-water, water of Hyop, Marjoram, Roemary, Betony, Mint, then may you ue ome Purges with thoe Pills, call'd Sine quibus, Agarick Pills, and Cochy Pills. If the Patient be trong, and not to be worked upon by weak Phyick, you may then add two or three grains of Diagridium, or of Troches of Alhandal; thee Pills are to be ued for eight days, half a dram at a time. Another way may be by Topicks, to attenuate and reolve; for which purpoe the Fomentations pecified in the foregoing Chapters, may be very fitly ued, being prepared with Vine-ahes, or Figtree-ahes, whereto a little Vinegar may be put; though the ue of things that drive back the humour are not here to be ued; you may alo rub and chafe the Breat with this Oyntment. Take of Oyl of weet-almonds, Oyl of Line-eed, of each one ounce, Ganders-greae of each half an ounce, a little Diachylon intead of Wax; a plaiter of
great Diachylon would not be amis in this Dieae; if the Woman feel any pain, or heat in her Breats, let her anoint them with Oyl of Roes, a little burnt-lead, and a little white wax, or with a little Oleum Omphacinum, and Oyl of weet almonds tempered together in a Mortar. In the dipering and reolving of the humour, you may ue baths of Alum and Sulphur prepared with the decoction of Hyop, Mint, and Sage, and after that uch Oyntments as are mot approved for the ame purpoe, always taking heed of too boyterous Remedies. If you would uppurate, or mature the welling, you mut ue uch Remedies as we have decribed in the following and foregoing Chapters; the tronget of which you may here apply, becaue the matter is more obtinate and tenacious, mingling with them, for that purpoe, other more effective Remedies, as are the roots of Mallows, Marh-mallows, Lillies, Figs, gooe-greae, and the like; when the ore is opened, you mut tend it after the ame manner, as is before reheared. There are other Remedies, either to be taken inwardly, or to be outwardly applied, which erve to fortifie and comfort the Stomach, as to take every morning a poonful of Conerve of Roemary, preerved Orange, or Trochiques of Aromaticum Roatum, Diagalanga, or Diacuminum.

div.head: Of the Kernels in the Breats.
div.p:
THE Kernels of the Breat are little round Bodies oft and thin like a ponge, which ometimes grow hard by reaon of the phlegmy humour which is ometimes purely o, and ometimes is mingled with other harp and acrimonious humours: But ometimes it comes to pas, that not only the kernels of the Breat are wollen, but alo that there do grow others which ought not to be there, which may not unfitly be termed
a kind of Kings-evil, being a welling which proceeds of thick flegm, or ele of a thick mattry blood hardned under the skin; they are caued many times by the detention of the flowers, the blood oftentimes mounting up into the Breat.

The Cure of thee is undertaken two ways; by oftning the hard tumour, and preventing the Cancer; and then alo a trict diet is to be oberved, which mut be moderately attenuating, and by keeping themelves warm, which is perform'd by moderate exercie before meals, as alo by uing ulphury baths; but full diet, eae, idlenes, and meats of hard digetion are very dangerous; and indeed in all repects beides, the cure is the ame as is et down in the foregoing Chapter. but if the kernel be welled up with a harp tumour, thoe topicks are to be ued that are precribed alo in the foregoing Chapter, only in cae the fluxion remain any time, you may mingle thoe things which do a little more refreh; uch are oil of Roes, and oil of Violets; when the flux of humours ceaes, you may then add oyl of Camomile, and Lillies, and other uch like things, to diolve and diipate the humour. If you find that this kernel is become a kind of Kings-evil, you mut then ue tronger Medicines; adding to the forementioned purgation, a dram and a half of the root of Mechoacan, or three drams of Diaturbith. For topicks you may ue uch as do often and dipel, but uch as are tronger than thee, we have expreed in the former Chapter. You mut at length, when all other ways do fail, ue the operation of the hand to take away the root of the dieae; but this is not to be done, 'till you have ued all other means to often and dipell the humour, which may perhaps be done by the ue of Diachylon, or by a plaiter of melilot, to
which you may add half an ounce of Ammoniach, an ounce of Oly of Lillies, and an ounce and an half of the root of Flower-deluce of Florence. Neither may this following Plaiter be amis: Take of the roots of Marh-mallows two ounces, boil them and train them, and add to that Oyl of Lillies, Ganders-greae, of each an ounce, burnt Lead, and roots of Orrice, of each an ounce and an half; mingle all thee together, and make of them an Emplaiter: If this avail not, the operation of the Hand mut be ued, in which the skill of the Surgeon mut be very able, and ready.

div.head: Of the Scirrhus of the Breats.
div.p:
THE Scirrhus of the Breats is a hard welling without pain: Of this there are two kinds, the one ingendred of a Melancholy, and produced by a feculent and gros blood, or ele from a thick Flegm; now this exquiite Scirrhus is without pain, in which it differs from the other: The other is not o exquiite an hardnes, perhaps becaue it is not yet come to its full maturity, or ele becaue it hath certain other humours mixt with it. This exquiite kind of Scirrhus is ingendred, either becaue the Spleen is obtructed, and cannot purge away the melancholy Blood, which for that reaon abounding in the Body, dicharges and empties it elf upon the Breats; or by reaon of the upreion of the Coures, which caues the feculent and gros humour to digorge it elf upon the Breat, gathering together in the Veins and Fleh of the ame. Many times the ignorance of the Surgeon is the caue of it, when they apply an unreaonable company of refrigerating Medicines to the inflammations of the Breat, or too many reolving and heating Medicines to it, in cae the Breats be over-hard. This Scirrhus is known by its hardnes without pain, from the unevennes of
the Body, and the colour of the part either inclining to black or brown. Now though the cure of thee hardnees be omething difficult, yet is there great hopes that they may be overcome; which is to be done two ways, by mollifying diligently that which is hard, and by taking that away which remains hard and knotty in the Breat. And firt of all, care is to be had to keep good order of diet; to which purpoe he mut ue Wheaten bread, rear Eggs, Pullets Capons, Partridge, Veal and Mutton, which mut be boiled with Spinage. Buglos and Borage; he mut abtain from Beef, Venion, Hares-fleh and Brawn, from Peae and Beans, and unlevened Bread, from all Salt and Smoaked Meats; as alo from all things that have a harp biting quality; alo he mut abtain from all care and adnes, immoderate exercie and going in the Winds. If the monthly Coures be topt, you mut eek to provoke them gently, which may be done by letting Blood in the Foot, or to let blood with Hore-leeches: In the next place, it will not be amis to purge well with Sena, and Rheubarb, to which you may add Catholicon, or Triphera Perica, if you find that the Dieae needs a more trong purgation. Between every purge it will not be amis to take good Cordial and Comfortable things, as Confection of Alkermes, Triaantalon, Electuarium de gemmis, conerve of the Roots of Borage, Conerve of Orange-flowers. You may after all this ue Topicks, that is to ay, uch Medicines as heat and dry moderately, being hot in the econd degree, and dry in the firt; uch are Sheeps greae, epecially that greaie ubtance that grows upon the flank of a Sheep; Wax, Oyl of weet Almonds, Oyl of Camomile, Oyl of Dill, Capons-greae, Gooe-greae, Hogs-greae, Bears-greae, &c. Veal-marrow, Deers-marrow, Emulions of Mallows, Lillies, and other things of more
force: As liquid-pitch. Liquid Storax, Galbanum, Cummin-eed, Rue-eed, Broom-flowers, and Dill-eed. If this welling come of a hard Flegm, which is known becaue it yields not o much to the touch as the other; you mut ue the ame Topicks to this, as to the watry tumour before reheared. If melancholy be the caue of it, you may ue a Fomentation of the leaves of Mallows, and Marh-mallows, of each a handful and a half, of Fenugreek and Lineeed, of each two drams, Cucumbers, Bears-foot, of each two ounces; boil them in as much water as is ufficient, and Foment the breat with this twice or thrice a day After that, take this Oyntment: Take of the root of Mallows one ounce, when it is boiled and bruied, take it out, and add to it Sheeps greae, and Capons-greae of each two ounces, and with a little Wax make an Ointment: This you may ue for ome few days, after which you may, if need require, ue this Ointment: Take Hyop-leaves, Dill-leaves, and Thyme-leaves, of each half a handful; roots of Mallows, and Fenugreek-eed, of each half an ounce, boil them in as much Wine and Vinegar as is ufficient, 'till half be boiled away; then take of the aforeaid Vinegar, Gooe-greae, Ducks-greae, and the marrow of the leg of a Hart, of each two ounces, boil it to the Conumption of half the Vinegar: You may add to this two drams of Diachylon, and make it into the form of a Plaiter: You may alo ue for this purpoe plaiters of Melilot, or Oxycroceum. At length, if all remedies fail, the operation of the hand mut be the lat uccour, which we leave to the Surgeon.

In the Cure of a Scirrhus three intentions are required, the firt is the regulation of Diet, and manner of living; the econd is the preparing and evacuating the antecedent or peccant Humour, the third is the application of external Medicines; in order to the firt, the Air
ought to be clear and temperately hot and moit, their Food uch as may breed good blood, as new laid Eggs, Chicken Pullets, Mutton, Veal, Lamb, Kid, and thee boyled with Spinage, Borrage, Endive Succory, Lettice, Sorrel, and the like, their Bread ought to be of good Wheat, and well baked, their Drink a well boi •
ed mall Ale, or mall white Wine, Rhenih or the like, their exercie and leep mut be moderate, their minds mut be chearful and their bodies oluble by Gliters, or otherwie. The econd intention is the evacuation of the Humour, which abounds in the Body, whether flegm, or Melancholy be the caue of the Scirrhus or whether it proceeds from obtructions of the Coures, or a uppreion of the Hemorrhoids; if from any of thee caues blood abounds, and be feculent, bleeding is allowed, but if Bloud do not abound, forbear bleeding, and proceed in preparing and evacuating the humours; the Antients ued for preparatives the Syrrups of the juice of Borrage, Buglos, of Hops, of Apples, and the Bizantine Syrup, and the like, and alo the detill'd waters of the ame Plants or Whey The following are alo ued, Gerion's decoction of Senna, the decoction of Dodder of Time, alo the decoctions of Caia, Tamarinds and the like, with the purging Syrup of Apples. Thee Humours being tough, require frequent purging, but the Purges mut not be trong. After evacuations, you mut endeavour revulion to contrary parts by Frictions, Cupping, Iues, and the like; for obtructions of the Hemorrhoid, Leeches may be applyed; and in a uppreion of the Coures, a Vein may be opened in the Leg or Arm. The third intention is performed in treating the Humour it elf, in doing which, thee directions are to be followed: Firt, you mut not ue repe •• ents, for cold and tough Humours, whereof thee Swellings conit, cannot return
back as hot humours, but do increae thereby. In the next place you ought to be cautious in the ue of Emollients alone; for thereby they are frequently exaperated, and end in Cancers. You ought alo to forbear the ue of trong Dicutients, let thereby you reolve the erous thin humours, and convert the thicker part into a more olid ubtance; therefore you are to conider well the habit of the body, and whether the Scirrhus be old or new. As to the habit of the Body, young People, and uch as live effeminately mut be treated with milder reolvents than thoe who live a laborious life. So alo a new Scirrhus, whilt it is increaing, requires milder applications than the confirmed and inveterate one, the milder reolvents are freh Butter, Hens-greae, oyl of weet Almonds and Lillies, Ducks and Gooe-greae, the Suet of a Calf, a Goat, Cow, old Lard, the roots of Marh-mallows, Lillies, and the like; the tronger are the roots of wild Cucumber, Briony, Solamons eal, Orris, Shippitch, Liquid-pitch, Turpentine, Galbanum, Ammoniacum, Bdellium, Opoponax, and the like. Vinegar, by reaon of its penetrative quality, is properly mixed with other Medicines to diolve thick humours. For Fomentations ue the following

Take of the roots of Marh-mallows and Lillies, each four ounces, of the roots of wild Cucumber two ounces, of the tops of Hemlock two handfuls, of the tops of Marjoram one handful, of the flowers of Melilot and Elder, each one Pugil, of the eeds of Flax, Fenugreek and Marh-mallows each one ounce, boyl them in a ufficient quantity of Fountain-water, to the trained liquor add a little Vinegar.
In oft Bodies when the Scirrhous is new.

Take of the roots of Marh-mallows half a pound, of the roots of Lillies three ounces, of the eeds of Flax
and Fenugreek each one ounce, boyl them in Broth made of the feet and head of a Sheep, then beat them and pulp them thro' a Sive, and add to them of the oyl of Camomile and Lillies each two ounces, of Oeypus one ounce and an half, of imple Diachylon Plaiter diolved in oyl of Lillies three ounces, with a ufficient quantity of white wax make a Cerate.

In dry bodies, where the Scirrhous is more confirmed, a fume of Vinegar, or of Spirit of Wine prinkled upon a hot tone, are of excellent ue for reolving thee tumours; afterwards you mut chafe the part, and apply the following.

Take of Galbanum, Ammoniacum, and Bdellium diolved in Vinegar, and of liquid Storax, each one ounce, of great Diachylon two ounces, of oyl of Lillies, and Gooe greae, each one ounce; of the cerate of Oeypus two ounces, melt them all together, and with white wax make a oft Cerate.
If by the ue of thee Medicines, the Scirrhus tend to uppuration, it mut be treated accordingly; but be careful you be not deceived, and the uppuration prove fale, and end in a Cancer.

A Gentlewoman of a full body having been long dieaed by an immoderate flux of the Coures, and ubject to a Cough, and hortnes of breath, and the like, at length recovered her Health by the precriptions of her Phyician, and enjoyed it the pace of a year, but was afterwards eiz'd with a traitnes and pain in her right Breat, which encreaed much with inflamation. At firt ight it eemed to be a confirmed Cancer fixed to the ribs. but upon more mature deliberation, and handling of it, the Surgeon found the Dieae was in the skin, and that the Glands and Muculous fleh underneath were not hard, or otherwie affected, than as they were bound in by the intene
hardnes of the skin, which kept them immoveable; from that uneaines an Eriypelas was raied, which overpread the skin of the Breat, and parts about with great heat. The Surgeon uppoed the hardnes proceeded from a concretion of the nutritious juices, he applied over the parts affected, Galen's Cerate, to repres the heat, and upplied her with Medicines to dres her elf, that he might according to her deire, return to her houe in the Country, where he was let blood, and purged with Manna, and Cream of Tartar, diolved in Whey; and he was afterwards purged with Epom waters. But after all, growing more indipoed, he returned to London at which time her Breat was inflamed, and excoriated and everal hard Tubercles were upon the skin, that gleeted much; the Scirrhus was alo pread up that ide of the neck by the Matoide Mucle, to the bone of the houlder, and Scapula, and o under that arm-pit, and down that ide; ome of the excoriations were dreed with Vigo's Oyntment of Tutty, and others with Pledgets dipt in this following Lotion.

Take of Frog pawn-water one pint, of the eeds of Quinces two drams, of the eeds of Plantain one dr • m, infue them hot twenty four hours; to the trained liquor add of the white Troches of Rhais powdered one dram, of Sugar of Saturn half a Scruple.
Over all was applied ome of the following Cerate.

Take of the Mucilage of the eeds of Quinces, and Fleabane extracted in Night-hade-water, each four ounces, Unguentum-nutritum three ounces, Populeon Oyntment ix ounces, with a ufficient quantity of white wax make a Cerate.

Thus the Inflamation remitted, and the Excoriations were heal'd in ome places, and checkt in others.
Many inward Remedies were alo precribed, viz. Emulions, Cordials, and the like, according to the accidents which hapened; but the Scirrhus till preading, over-ran the other Breat, and ide of the neck, and in a few weeks made her neck tiff and immoveable, and by reaon of the compreion which was made in the arm-pit, and about the houlder, there was a tagnation of the humours, and the arm well'd to the fingers ends. The arm was fomented with a decoction of the leaves and roots of Marh mallows, of the leaves of Violets, Plantain, Night-hade, Willow, Ducks-meat, of the flowers of Camomile and Melilot, of the eeds of Flax and Fenugreek, and Embrocations, Cerates, Emollients and Reolvents were ued to uccour the parts; but all this while he was afflicted, either with the Collick, a Looenes or Vomiting, Mercurius dulcis was alo ued inwardly to carry off the matter, and Mercurial Oyntments outwardly, and the Surgeon would have Salivated her, if he would have permitted. The Scirrhus eized on both ides of her neck, her houlders, arms, breats, and ides, and began to invade the skin of her loins and hips, yet he was not ick or pained, but eat her dinner well; he at length grew weary of Medicine, and with patience endured the remaining accidents of her dieae, 'till it kill • d her. She was eiz'd with this Scirrhus in May, and died the Augut following.

div.head: Of the Cancer in the Breat.
div.p:
THE Cancer is a venomous tumour, hard, and very much welled, hot, and durable, more exaperated oftentimes by remedies than awaged. The Cancer proceeds from a feculent and gros humour, which being gathered together in the pleen, is chaed away from thence after it grows too hot; which when
Nature cannot void, it mot commonly in Women empties it elf upon the Breats, by reaon of their cavernous and pongy nature: the matter of it is a hot melancholy blood, and it is known by the crooked windings, and retored veins that are about it, tretching out long roots a good way from it, being ometimes blackih, and ometimes inclined to black and blue It is oft to ee to, but it is very hard to the touch, extending the pain as far as the houlders. It will ometimes remain for two years together, no bigger than a Bean; afterwards it grows to be as big as a Nut, then to the bignes of an Egg; and after that increaing to a larger ize. When the skin breaks, there iues out a great deal of petilent matter, thin, and blackih, and having a very bad mell. The Ulcer it it elf is very unequal, the lips and orifice thereof being well'd with hardnes, and inverted; a light Fever poeeth the body, and often woonings. And many times the petilency of the humour having corroded a Vein, there iues out a great deal of blood. If the Cancer be ulcerated, or in any inward part of the body, no Medicine can prevail; for remedies do more exaperate than help it. To burn it with Iron is petilent, and if it be cut with a Pen knife, it returns again as oon as it is but skin • d over. But if it be an exulcerated Cancer (which is eaily known) and aries from a more harp matter, for then the fleh is corrupted, ending forth a very noyom matter, being very irkom to the ight, and accompanied with a gentle Fever, and wooning, and iuing out of blood;) The cure of this is to be done by drying and refrigerating Medicines, or by inciion to the quick, and expreion of the corrupted blood afterwards; after which the wound mut be well cleaned; For which purpoe the powder which is called Hartman's bleed Powder,
is very prevalent. The diet mut be of meats that moiten and refrigerate; blood letting alo is profitable, as alo preparation of the Humour, with the juyce of weet melling Apples, and extract of Ellebore, and often purgation with Lapis Lazuli pills; and particularly if the Cancer be not ulcerated, you may apply this Ointment. Take Litharge one ounce, beat it in a marble Mortar with a leaden Petle, incorporating into it two ounces of Roe-water and Oil of Roes. In cae the pain be great, ue this remedy, Take white Poppyeed one ounce, Oil of Roes four ounces, Henbane eed and Opium, of each a dram and a half; Gumme Arabick half an ounce, a little Wax, of which you may make an ointment. If the Cancer be already ulcerated, take this water: Take of the juyces of Night-hade, Houleek, Sorrel, Scabious, Honey-ucles, Mullein, Figwo • t, Dropwort, Plantain, Toads flax, Agrimony, of each half a pound, juice of green Olives one pint, the Fleh of Frogs, and River-Crabs, of each a pound and a half, the whites of ix Eggs, Alum three ounces; Camphire one dram; let all thee be ditilled in a leaden Limbeck, and with the ditilled water foment the part affected. Take alo Allum as much as a Nut, Honey two penniworth, red Wine a pint, eeth them together 'till the fifth part be pent, trein it through a cloth, and wah the Cancer therewith.

A Woman having a pain in her Breat, advied with a Surgeon, who felt one of the Glands well'd; he advied her to forbear handling it, and to forbear lacing her elf too trait It lay ome Years quiet; but then the death of her Husband happening, and one affliction following another, and the Coures topping, the humours • omented in this Gland, and afterwards the breat well'd, and eem • d to apotumate. Some aured her, it was a imple apothumation, and requir'd digetives,
and he was perwaded to follow their advice, 'till he became extreamly pained. It was without inflammation, but well'd very big, and eem'd to be full of matter; it was not without hard tubercles, and other ymptoms to hew it would end in a Cancer, whenoever it hould break; therefore a skilful Surgeon refued to open it, but advied the bet he could to give her eae, and promied to come to her, if after it brake he would end for him. Some Months after he ent for him, and hew'd him a great quantity of curdled matter newly burt forth; the Breat was lank, but very hard Glands lay within, and in the circumference of the tumour, there were ome tubercles that required to be eradicated; to which purpoe, he deign'd to have lit open the abces, and to have pull'd away the Cancerated Glands, but he would not permit him o much as to enlarge the orifice; upon which conideration he left her, and he died within half a year after.

div.head: Of the greatnes of the Breats.
div.p:
THE greatnes of the Breats is very unightly, the caue of their greatnes is often handling of them, tore of windy Vapours, and retention of the monthly Coures; The cure of them is not to be neglected, becaue the leer the Breats be, the les ubject they are to be cancered; they are cured by diet firt, wherein the ue of atringent meats is to be recommended, o that they be not windy by repercuion of the humours and blood which flow to that part, uch are the juyce of Hemlock, and the anointing of the place with Partridge Eggs: Or you may ue this following Cataplam; Take of the juyce of Hemlock, three ounces, of white lead, Acacia, and Frankincene, of each three drams, of Vinegar one ounce, mingle all thee together, to which you may add powder of Spunge, burnt Alum, burnt
Lead, bole Armoniack, and of thee with a ufficient quantity of Wax and oyl of Myrtle, make a very profitable Ointment. Thirdly, by the dicuion of that which is gathered together in that part; for which purpoe you may make an Ointment in this manner; take of the mud or lome, found in molis Tonorum, two ounces; Oil of Myrtle one ounce, Vinegar half an ounce; or thus, take of the ame lome and Bole Armoniack, of each an ounce, white Lead two drams, Oil of Matick two ounces and a half, of the Emulion of Henbaneeed one dram and a half, anoint the Breat with this, and then upon that put a linnen cloath dipt in the deco • tion of Oke-apples. Fourthly, by compreion of the part, which is done by uing a kind of plate of Lead upon the Breat anointed within ide with Oil of Henbane-eed.

div.head: Of the defect, abundance, and coagulation of the Milk.
div.p:
THE defect of Milk aries from a double caue; for either it is a defect in the blood, which is dried up by reaon of ome hot maladies of the body, either through intemperancy of the Liver through fating, or too much evacuation. If the deficiency of milk come from thee caues, it may be increaed again, either by prepared Crytal; The leaves alo, root and eed of Fennel do avail much in this particular, and the powder of Earth-Worms prepared and drunk in Wine, as alo the Electuary called Electuarium Zacuthi. There is another caue which proceeds from the Lactifying quality, which is many times o weak, that it can neither attract nor concoct the Blood, by reaon of ome outward refrigerating, and atringent qualities, or by reaon of ome other Dieaes. The Cure of which being looked after in their repective places, much conduceth to the retoring of that defect. The redundance
of milk proceeds from too great a plenty of blood, and a trong lactifying quality. In the cure of which the increae of blood is to be impeded, which is done by drying up that humour, and diverion; to which blood-letting conduceth much: Medicines alo that drive it back are to be put upon the Breats towards the Arms; to which purpoe Hemlock boiled in Chervil-water and Vinegar avails.

Curdling of the milk is when the thinner part of the milk exhales, and the more gros and heavy part tays behind, which many times is the caue of tumours, kernels, and Apothumes. In this cae the Infant is not to uck the part affected; though that Breat is alo to be uckt for fear, let the milk which is newly generated, hould be curdled and knotted by that which is there already; and o that part of the coagulated milk may be hindred from putrifying. To the diolving of the Milk it much conduceth to wah the Breat with Water, Wine, and Vinegar mixt together; as alo a Fomentation made of the decoction of Marh-mallows, Fenugreek, and Melilote, and then anointing them with a liniment of Oil of Roes, Oil of weet Almonds, juice of Parley and Vinegar, wherein let the Gall of a Hare be firt diolved. Hemlock water in this cae alo is not a little commended.

div.head: Of the Dieaes of the neck of the Womb, and firt of the Dieae called Tentigo.
div.p:
TENTIGO is a Dieae in Women, when the Clitoris increaes to an over great meaure; the ubject of this Dieae is the Clytoris, or nervous piece of fleh, which the lips or wings of the privities do embrace, and which uffers erection in the act of Venery: The igns of it are evident, for it hangs below the orifice of the Privities as big as the neck of a Gooe:
The caues hereof are a great concoure of Humours, or nutriment, by reaon of the laxity of it, which happens by often handling. The Cure is performed by the diminution of the blood, and drawing out of the other humours. A lender and refrigerating diet is alo neceary, and uch things as have a dicuive faculty, as the leaves of Matick-tree, and the leaves of Olive-tree. In the next place, by taking away the excrecence, to which purpoe gentle Cauticks may be firt applied, as Allum, and the Aegyptiack Ointment, and that Lie whereof Sope is made, being boiled with Roman Vitriol, to which at lat you may add ome Opium, and form the compoition into Trochiques, which being afterwards made into a powder, is to be prinkled upon the flehy excrecence: At length the fleh is to be out away, either by binding hard, or by ection; care being taken that you avoid an inflammation.

There is another Dieae, which is called Cauda, which is a carnous ubtance proceeding from the mouth of the Womb, which ometimes fills up the privy parts, and ometimes thruts it elf outwards like a tail. The Cure of this is the ame with the former; only if it come to Section, it may be done either with a Hore-hair, or a ilken thread wound about it, being firt dipt in Sublimat water; or ele with a Knife.

div.head: Of the narrownes of the neck of the Womb.
div.p:
THIS narrownes is either of the Womb it elf, or of the Orifice of the Womb; the igns are the toppage of the Coures, followed with a depreing and weighty pain. The caue is partly natural from the Nativity, and partly varies according to the differences of the Dieae: The difference is in this, it hapning ometimes that this treightnes conits in the exterior orifice, whereby neither the Flowers have free
paage, neither can he enjoy coition, or conceive with Child, becaue he cannot receive either the Man or the Seed. Sometimes the narrownes is in the interior orifice of the Womb, into which the flowing retires back again, to the abolute hindrance of Conception; ometimes it is occaioned by way of compreion, when the Caul being fatter than ordinary, lies upon the neck of the Womb. Sometimes the playing of the thighs tone in the Bladder, or ome tumour in the traight gut. Sometimes it happens by the clinging of other parts together which happens either from the Birth, and then either the Fleh which appears red, and is oft to the touch, intercepts the paage; or ele the Membrane which eems, white feels hard being touched. In the Cure of this, the ue of moit Fomentations is very prevalent, and an inection is to be made perpendicularly; great care being taken for fear of hurting the neck of the Bladder. The Humour is next to be provoked forth, and a Tent dipt in ome uppurating Plaiter is to be put up; the next day it is to be wahed with water and Honey, and cicatrizing Plaiters to be applied; if it come after the Birth, it is either occaion • d by an Ulcer, and then either the ides of the neck cling together, in which cae either inciion, or cauterization is to be ued; or ele there is a brawny ubtance which is to be cut away with a Penknife; or ele ome pongy and luxuriant fleh, in which cae drying and d •• cu •• ng Medicines • re to be ued, as Birthwort, Frankincen • Myrrh, and Matick, afterwards you may apply things to eat it away; and lat of all to cut it away by inciion.

div.head: Of Wheals, Condyloma's of the Womb, and of the Hemorrhoids.
div.p: THE Wheals of the Womb are certain riings in the neck of the womb, which by their acrimony excite both pain and itching. The igns of them are an itching pain, and full of curf from that part, for the better earching of which, the Intrument called peculum Matricis is to be ued. The Caues of this are, certain cholerick, harp, and adut humours, and thick. Among the preparing Medicines, Syrup of Fumitory is much commended, and Chichory with a decoction of Lupines. Topicks alo are ueful that dicus and mitigate the humour, as Baths, and ineions, and the wahing of the place with Wine and Nitre, which is often to be ued. Thee Wheals are divided into gentle, and venemous, which are aid to be contagious; they are to be wahed in a water thus made. Take of Aloes the quantity of a Pea; of the flower of bras the quantity of half a Pea, powder thee, and mingle them in an ounce of white-wine, Plantain-water, and Roe-water, of each an ounce, which is to be kept in a glas veel.

Condyloma's are certain welling wrinckles in the neck of the Womb, with pain and heat. There is no need to tell the igns of thee, for they are apparent to the eye; the wrinkles are like thoe which appear in the hand when you cloe the firt; but are much bigger when the coures flow: they are caued by adut and thick humours; ome of thee are with an inflamation, which have more pain and heat, and the welling is hard: In the cure of which, you mut ue ineions, and fomentations that eae pain; ometimes they come
without any inflammation, which if they be new come are to be dried up; if they be old, they are firt to be oftned afterwards to be digeted and dried up; for which purpoe you may ue powder of Egg-hels burnt, or this Oyntment: Take of the Trochiques of Steel one dram powdered, mixt with a little Oyl of Roes and Wax, with half an ounce of the juyce of Mullein; if this profit not, the Warts are to be haved away with a knife, and an atringent powder laid upon them.

Hemorrhoids of the Womb are little protuberancies like thoe of the Fundament, produced in the neck of the Womb, through the abundance of feculent blood; the ubject is the neck of the Womb, for where the Veins end, there do grow thee extuberancies, jut as in the Hemorrhoids.
The igns are evident, and eaily een by the help of the Speculum Matricis: The women who are thus affected look pale, and are troubled with a wearines.
