The caue is a feculent blood, which flowing to thee Veins before its eaon, and etling there, grows thicker, o that it cannot pierce the orifice of the Veins. They are cured by a revulion of the humour; Firt, by letting blood in the Arm. Secondly, by drawing it to another part, as by letting blood in the heel. Sometimes thee Hemorrhoids are very painful, and are ditinguihed from that mentruous effluxion, by the pain which they bring: they are cured by mittigating and awaging in • e •• ions, • s alo by Opiates carefully applied. Others are without pain, to which the foreaid remedies may be applied

Others are open, and do ometim • s run moderately (and then Nature is to be • et alon • ) or violent • y, o that thereby the trength of the peron is impaired, in
which cae a Vein mut be opened in the arm, two or three times, purgation is alo to be ued by Myrobolans, Tamarind, and Rheubarb; and at length you mut apply thoe things which ceae the blood.

Others are termed blind, out of which there iues no blood; they are cured by blood-letting; the part is to be alo oftned and fomented with things that often and open the orifices of the Veins, and dipel the humour; uch are an Oyntment made of the pith of Coloquintida, and Oyl of weet Almonds, or the juyce of Capers mixt with Aloes; neither is the applying of Horeleaches amis.

The Cure of thee Excrecences at their firt budding forth, may be attempted by drying and atringent Medicines, as with the tops of Brambles and Hore-tail, with the Leaves and Berries of Myrtles and Sumach, with the rind of Pomgranats, Balautins, cales of Bras, wah'd Lime, Allom, and the like, made into fomentations, or powder'd and mixed with Oyntments, and applied upon Tow. If thee do not check their growth, you may cut them off with a Knife, or Scizers, and conume the remaining roots by Echaroticks, or actual Cautery, and then proceed in the cure by digetion, and Epuloticks accordingly. To prevent their growing again, Authors commend the ahes of Vine and Bean-talks mix'd with Vinegar, to apply upon the part.
The Cure of Chaps or Fiures conits in removing the Calloity, and Cicatrizing them mooth; if moiture abound, things that are dry mut be ued. To which purpoe,

Take of the flowers of Red-Roes, of Myrtle-Berries, of the tops of Brambles, each one handful; of the roots of Tormentil and Bitort, each one ounce; of Allom one dram, boyl them in a pint and an half
of Steel-water; towards the end of boyling, add four ounces of red wine, wherewith foment the part, then apply what follows.

Take of Litharge and Cerue, each three drams, of Sarcocoal, Matick, and Frankincene, each one Scruple, of Sealed-earth two Scruples, of Oyl of Roes four ounces, of Wax a ufficient quantity, mingle them over the fire, then beat them in a leaden Mortar for ue.
If drynes be the fault, you mut dres them with Medicines that are moitening; as,
Take of Calves fat, of Ducks and Hens-greae, each two drams, of Litharge of Gold one dram, mingle them in a leaden Mortar, according to art.

The material caue of all thee orts of Excrecences, is flegmatic or gros clammy blood thrut forth, by the trength of the expulive faculty, out of the Pores of the skin, and dry'd up into thee forms in which you ee them. All thee pecies of Excrecences, are for the mot part Symptoms of the French Pox.

div.head: Of the Ulcers of the neck of the Womb.
div.p: THE igns of thee Ulcers is a pain, and perpetual twinging, which increaes, if any thing that hath an abterive quality be cat in; the iuing out of putrid humours, and matter with blood, if the Ulcer be great, or the Flowers come down; often making water, and the water hot; as alo a pain in the fore-part of the head toward the roots of the eyes; as alo ome kind of gentle Fever.

The Cure of this is hard, becaue of its being in a place of o exquiite ene, and moit, and having uch a ympathy with other parts of the Body: For the eaing of the pain, Chalybeated milk is very much conducing; and to the drying of them up, drying baths
are the bet and mot prevalent remedy. Thee differ much, coming either from external caues, as rah Phyick, hard labours, and violent coiture; or from internal caues, as the corruption of the Secondines, the Coures retained, and the Urine flux, a virulent Gonorrhea the Pox, inflammations turned into Apotems, humors flowing from other parts of the body, and there etling; all which mut be duly conidered in the Cure. Others are in the outward part, and may be eaily come at with Medicines; others deep, and mut be come at only with injection; for which purpoe, ue this following.

Take whites of four Eggs, beat them well, and put to them an equal quantity of Roe water, and Plantain-water, as much in quantity as they come to, C • mphire, Cerue, Litharge of Gold, and Bole-Armoni • ck of each a like quantity, green Copperas, half as much as of any of them, beat all to powder, mix it, and train it through a cloth, and make your injection 'till the part infected be whole; and if there be any pain, ometimes inject a little new warm milk.

Others are more gentle, with a little tinking matter flowing from them. For the cure of which, gentle abterives are profitable, as Honey of Roes with Barly-water, Whey with Sugar, and the decoction of Lentiles: after thee, gentle atringents mut be applied. Others are ordid, with much matter lowing from them: In which cae tronger Medicines mut be applied. Others do eat into the Fleh, having a coloured, green, and tinking matter flowing from them. For the cleaning of which, Aloes and Wormwood are very much commended, or the foreaid injection.

There are another ort of Ulcers, little and long, which eat the skin of the neck of the Womb; they are known by the pain and blood which they produce immediately
after congreion; they are een alo by looking into the neck of the Womb, being much like chilblains that come upon the hands in Winter time. They are caued divers ways, either by a difficult Lying in, or by a violent coiture, and cured by an atringent Clyter: or they are produced by ome Inflammation, or Flux of harp humours; Purgations are here needful, before Topicks be applied, among which is much commended the greae that fries out of wooden ladles, much ued in Kitchens being held to the fire; as alo the Oyntment called Pomatum

The Cure of the Ulcer mut be perform • d by topping the defluction of acrid humours, and by cleaning and conglutinating the Ulcer. And firt, if the body be Plethorick, or if the Ulcer be accompanied with an inflammation, a vein mut be open'd in the arm, and bleeding mut be repeated as often as there is danger of a new Fluxion, epecially at the time of the Coures, to leen them, which are wont to increae the matter of the Ulcer, and to promote the Flux of other humors to the Womb. Purging is alo very neceary to cleane the body from ill humors, but it ought to conit of gentle Catharticks, as of Sena, Rhubarb, Tamarinds, Myrobalans, and the like; it mut be often repeated, that the vitious humors may be diverted; and this is of o great moment that a Noble Matron was cur'd of an Ulcer of the Womb, by taking every day five ounces of a decoction of Sena, dodder of Thyme, red Roes. Indian Myrobalans weetned with Sugar, and by injecting a cleaning decoction into the Womb.

If the Sick vomits eaily, a Vomit is mot ueful; for it m • kes a revulion of the humors from the Womb, and the days the ick does not purge, a vulnerarary decoction
mut be ued a long while, made in the following manner.

Take of the leaves of Agrimony, Knot-gras, Burnet and Plaintain, each half an handful, of the roots of China three drams, of Coriander-eed one dram, of Raiins half an ounce, of red Sanders one Scruple, boyl them in Chicken Broth, train it, let the ick take of it Morning and Evening.

If the Fever be violent, and if a great quantity of Sanies be evacuated, Whey is very proper, half a pint or more being taken in a morning with a little honey of Roes. If the Body begins to w • te, and there is a Hectick Fever, Aes milk mut be taken with Sugar of Roes for a whole Month, Sudor ••• ks may alo do good to dry the Ulcer; and to drive the erous humour towards the habit of the body, if the • e be no inflammation or hot intemperies, Turpen • ine wahed in ome proper water for the Womb, as in Mugwort, or Feverfew-water, or in ome water proper for the Ulcer, taken with Sugar of Roes by intervals, cleanes and heals the Ulcer, Pills of Bdellium taken dayly, or every other day, are alo very good.

Take of Bdellium three drams, of Myrrh and Frankincene, each one dram, of Sarc • coal, Amber, S • orax, and Myrobalans call'd Chebule, each one dr • m, of red Coral two Scruples, with Syrup of Poppi •• , make a mas for Pills, to which, when the pain is violent, may be added a little Opium. Troches of Al ••
kengy with Opium may be alo ued, when the pain is violent. The following powder is alo very e •• ectual to dry the Ulcer.

Take of Acatia, and Hypocitis, each one dram, of Dragons-blood, white Starch, the roots of Pl • ntai • , and of round Birthwort, each half a dram, of Bole Armoniack one dram, of Matich and Sarcacoal, each half
a dram of thee make a fine Powder. The Doe is one dram in Plantain • or Roe-water, or in ome Chalybe •• Water.

To cleane, heal, and dry the Ulcer, various In • ections are prepared; but they mut not be ued 'till the inflammation is taken off and 'till the pain is e • ed and therefore upon account of the inflammation and acrimony, Emulions of the cold eeds, the whey of Goats Milk, or the Milk it elf, or mixed with the juyce of Plantain, or Shepherd's-Pure, may be injected firt If neceity requires, a decoction of Poppy heads, and tops of Mallows may be injected. Some Practitioners ay, the Sick may be much relieved by injecting frequently warm water.

The hot intemperies, and the pain being quieted, at leat diminih'd, uch things mut be ued as cleane, beginning with the gentle, as Whey with Sugar, a d • coction of B • rly with Sugar, or hony of Roes; but imple Hydr • mel cleanes more. A decoction will be a little tronger made with Barly, Lentils, Beans not excorticated, of the leaves of Smallage, Plantain, and Pellitory a little hony of Roes may be added. When the Ulcer is very ordid, the following decoction may be ued.

Take of the roots of Gentian, Rhaponticum, Zedoary, and round Birthwort, each one ounce, of white Wine three pints, boyl them to the conumption of a third part; in the train'd Liquor diolve half a pound of Sugar, and keep it for ue.
If the Ulcer be very faetid, a little Aegyptiac Oyntment may be added to the decoction; when the Ulcer is well cleaned, you mut ue uch things as dry and conolidate.

Take of the Roots of Comfry, and Bitort, each one ounce, of the leaves of Plantain, Hore-tail, Shepherds-pure,
Sanicle, Moue-ear, Milfoil, each one handful, of red Roes half an handful; boil them in a meaure of Water for an injection. The following arcotic powder may be added to it.
Take of the Roots of Orris, Birthwort, and Comfry, each half an Ounce, of Myrrh one ounce, of Aloes three drams, make a Powder, whereof let half an ounce be mingled with every injection.

Take of Turpentine wahed in Plantain-water, two Drams, diolve it with Honey and the Yolk of an Egg, and mingle it with the injection. This is very effectual, and is more o, if the Sarcotic Powder be alo added.
Fumes mut be ued for deep Ulcers, for they penetrate to the bottom of the Womb, and dry the Ulcers.
Take of Frankincene, Myrrh, Matick, Gum of Juniper, Labdanum, each one ounce, with a ufficient quantity of Turpentine, make troches for a fume.

When the Ulcer is very obtinate, Cinnabar mut be added, which is of excellent ue. The Bath-waters have cured ome Women, when all other Medicines have bin ineffectual. After you have ufficiently cleaned the Ulcer, you mut apply a drying and cicatrizing Ointment. Take of Tutty wahed half an ounce, and of Litharge, Cerue, and Sarcacoal, each two drams, of Oyl and Wax a ufficient quantity, make an Ointment. Sometimes the Ulcer penetrates the right gut, and ometimes the bladder, which may be known by the matter evacuated by thoe parts; if it flow by the right gut, lenitive, cleaning, and drying Gliters mut be injected; but if it flow from the Bladder, gentle and cooling diureticks mut be ued, as an emulion of the greater cold Seeds, Turpentine, and the like. If the Ulcer turn to a Fitula, which chiefly happens, when it is opened outwardly towards the Hip, tho' it may happen in the
womb it elf, or in the neck of it. In this cae we mut conider, whether it be bet to leave the accutomed paage untouched, thro' which nature endeavours to evacuate various Excrements, or to undertake the • ure of it: But if that be thought mot proper for the ick, a Cure that is call'd palliative, mut be intituted by purges frequently-repeated, and by weatlng twice a Year, and by cleaning and trengthening injections, and by applying over a plaiter of Diapalma, or the like; but if there be any hopes of a Cure, the ame Remedies mut be ued, which are proper for other Fitula's. If the Ulcer be occaion'd by the French Pox, it cannot be cured without an univeral Cure; in performing which, the fumes of Cinnabar receiv'd thro' a Tunnel into the womb, are peculiarly proper. Alo the anointing the inner parts of the womb with a Mercurial Ointment

In all Ulcers of the womb if there be a troubleome itching about the neck, as it frequently happens, by reaon of a defluxion of an acid and Salt Humour to the part, a peary mut be made to qualifie it, dipt in the ointment of Elecampane with Mercury, or in Aegyptiacum diolved in Sea or Allom-water, or in freh Butter, wherein Quick-Silver has been extinguihed, to which mut be added Sulphur.

div.head: Of the Dieaes of the Womb. Of the Womb being out of temper.
div.p:
THE intemperance of the Womb is when it hath lot its natural temper, and is affected with a preternatural intemperancy ariing both from inward and outward caues. The one of thee is hot, and is known by the womans pronenes to Venery, by the mall Flux of the Monthly Coures, by their adutnes, harpnes, inordinate, and difficult Flux. (Hence in proces of time they are very Hypochondriack) by early growing of
the hairs about the Privities, by rednes of the Face, and drines of the lips, and frequent pains of the head, and abundance of cholerick humours in the Body; it arieth either at firt from the Birth, which caues Women to be Virago's, and to be barren; or after their Nativity, from outward caues, as the ue of hot things, overmuch Venery, and uch Medicines as bring the heat and blood to the Womb. The cure conits in a contrary diet, and cooling Medicines, both internal and external, which are to be applyed to the back and ides; which mut be very moderate, that the heat which is neceary for Conception may not be weakened, and the cold and membranous ubtance of the womb come to any harm; or let the Veels which erve for the carrying away of the Coures hould be thickned, and the Nerves of the back and ides be any way michieved.

The next way of cure is performed by evacuating Medicines, namely, Rheubarb and olutive Syrup of Roes, Manna alo profiteth much; the flower of Vitriol of Venus and Mars, taken from three grains to ix, and put in any proper Syrup, purges the Womb.

There is another intemperancy which comes of cold, which is known by a leer pronenes to Venery, and little pleaure taken in it, a etling in the Coures, with a limy and flegmy matter mixed, and an inordinate flowing of them by reaon of the plenty of Humours collected in the Womb, which caues obtructions, by reaon of abundance of windy vapours in the Womb, crudities and watrines of the Seed, which caues it to flow without any pleaure, a pale colour in the Face: It aries from caues contrary to the former, it is cured by contrary diet, by hot Medicines applyed to the womb, among which the roots of Birthwort, Clove-Gilliflowers, Angelica, and Eringo's, are very much
commended. The leaves alo of Mercury, Balm, Dittany, Penny-royal, Sage, Roemary, Mugwort, flowers of Centaury, Marigolds, Sage, Roemary, Borage; and undry pices, as Nutmegs, Cubebs, Saffron and Cinamon. Thee kind of Compounds are alo very ueful, as Oyl of Mace, Oyl of Amber, Oyl of Myrrh, and of Cinamon.

There is another intemperancy of the womb, which comes of moiture, and is joined mot commonly with the cold intemperancy: it is known by the plenty of the Coures, and by the thinnes and watrines of them; as alo the moitnes of the Privities, by reaon of the moitnes of the Excrements; no pleaure in the act of Venery, and pronenes to abortion, by reaon of the growth of the Birth. It hath the ame original with the frigid intemperancy, and happens mot commonly to Women, who are lazy and edentary: It is cured with the ame Medicines as the former; only this may be added, that a fume may be made of the havings of Ivory: And the decoction of Sage, being received into thoe parts before upper, is very much commended. Baths of Sulphur do alo profit much.

There is another ditemper of the Womb, which is dry, which is dicerned by the want of Seed, and the defect of the Coures, by lownes to Venery, drines of the Mouth of the Womb, by a blackih colour of the lower lip, which is always chopt. It ometimes aries from the very Nativity, which caues a dry and lean contitution of Body; ometime through age, and then Women ceae to bring Children; ometimes from inflammations and uch like Dieaes; ometimes from a defect of blood, which ought to moiten the parts; which happens either through a narrownes and obtruction of the Veins, or ele becaue it being voided out at the neck of the Womb, cannot pierce to the bottom.
The cure of this is performed firt by a contrary diet, where you mut alo avoid much labour, watching, hunger, and adnes. Secondly, by the ue of moitning things, amongt which are mot commended, Borage, Buglos, Mercury, Mallows, Violets. Among outward means, Baths of weet water, and unctions with Oyl of weet Almonds, Oyl of white Lillies, Hens-greae, and the marrow of Calves legs. The cure is the more hard, if the drines have been of any long continuance.

There is another which is a compound ditemper, which is mot often cold and moit, which is dicerned by comparing the igns of the imple ditemperatures together. It aries from Flegmy humours: The cure is performed by preparing the matter with hot things, by evacuation of the matter with uch Medicines as are mot proper to purge Flegm: As alo by a particular purgation of the Womb it elf; to which purpoe pearies do very much conduce; as alo ulphury and drying baths; as alo the ue of Sudorificks, or things that provoke weat may be very profitable, as the decoctions of Lignum anctum, China, Saraparella, and Matick wood.

div.head: Of the narrownes of the Veels of the Womb.
div.p: THE igns of the narrownes of the veels of the Womb, are partly the retention of the Flowers o that they cannot flow, as alo the hindrance of conception, by reaon that the paage of the blood is intercepted.
The caues are partly external, as from atringent baths and medicines, which is known from the relation of the party affected; it is cured more eaily by moitning and mollifying Medicines.

The other caues are internal, as from Fleh, or Membrane, clinging to the orifice of the Womb, or by a cloing up of the orifices of the veins, by reaon of ome violent extraction of the Secondines, which is commonly incurable; the only cure which may be tryed is by mollifying applications. Another caue is deduced from obtruction, which aries from certain thick vicous and copious humours flowing from other parts of the Body, the heat of thoe places not being able to attenuate them; or ele gather together in the Womb it elf, by reaon of the weaknes of the heat of that part; it is dicerned by the ame igns as the cold Ditemper, there being alo a limy matter which now and then comes down from the Womb: It is cured as other obtructions, by harp and bitter Medicines, and teel-wine, as alo baths made with opening and mollifying things.

Sometime • this narrownes aries from a compreion of the parts, occaioned either by ome welling or Schirrus, either within or without the Womb; if this be, there do appear manifet igns of welling: It is an evil for the mot part incurable; many times it is occaioned by an over-fatnes of thoe parts, which is plain to the ene.

div.head: Of the puffing up of the Womb.
div.p:
THE puffing up of the Womb is a windy welling of that part, occaioned from cold, flegmy and flatulent matter, which is increaed through the defect of natural heat in the Womb. This is called the windy Mole, it giving hopes of a conception. The igns of this, are a ditention of the Womb not far from the Midriff, which is now increaed, now diminihed; ometimes extending it elf to the Navel, ometimes to the Loins and Diaphragm. It differs
from the Dropie, partly becaue the welling is not o great, and the party affected is not much troubled with thirt, by the increaing and diminihing of the tumor; and by the upper part not being o lean.

It is ditinguih'd from the Dropie of the Womb by the fore apprehenion of the caues that beget thoe windy vapors, by the ound, and les ponderoity, as as alo by a feeling of an extenive and pricking pain in the womb, and parts adjoyning. It is alo ditinguihed from the inflammation of the intetines, becaue here is no great pain, neither is the Patient hard bound; yet the Flowers are uppreed, and the feet and hollow of the eyes do well, and the colour of the body is changed, the woman draws her breath hort and is ad, and when he awakes is fain to lift up her head to take breath. It differs from a Mole, becaue there is not that heavines and ponderoity in the womb; beides the woman doth not feel the burden of her womb tumble from one ide to the other: It is ditinguihed from conception by the ound, and by the increaing and decreaing of the welling, and by the deadnes of the motion, not unlike that of a dead Infant: for if the Midriff be violently compreed, the wind being then compelled to the part adjoyning, there is a kind of palpitating motion perceived through all the Midriff.

The matter of this ditemper is generated either in the Womb it elf, or by reaon of the uppreion of the Coures, or by the interception of due purgation after delivery. Many times it comes through the veins and eminal veels. Now the weaknes of the heat proceeds ometimes from the external air, ometimes from hard Delivery, from the uppreion of the Coures, from abortion, &c. The Cure is performed after the ame way that other Cures are managed: among thoe
things that purge, Species Hierae, and Diaphaenicon, with Cator, are mot commended; for Fumes, Nutmeg is counted the bet; for Potions, Nutmegs bruied and boyled with the roots of Mather, and drunk in ix ounces of wine, and two drams of Sugar. Sometimes this wind gets into the cavity of the Womb, and then the neck and orifice of the Womb is cloed, o that nothing can go forth, when the woman is moved, or when the Midriff is preed down with her hand, and then a kind of noie and ound is perceived. Sometimes the wind gets into the tunicles of the Womb, and then the mouth of the Womb may be open: by reaon of the hutting up of the windy vapours in a narrow place, there goes a noie forth, and the pain grows greater, and extends farther. This is more hard and difficult to be cured than that which is in the concavity of the Womb.

div.head: Of the inflammation of the Womb.
div.p: THE inflammation of the Womb is a welling of the ame through the putrefaction of blood which is fallen down into its ubtance, having many ymptoms, and now tending to a Scirrhus, now towards an Apotem.

The igns are various; there is a welling in the Womb with heat and pain, and a retraction of the Womb to the more inward parts; the neck of the Womb appears red, with little veins cattered up and down in it, like the web of a Spider. There is ometimes a difficulty of breathing, with ome kind of Pleuriie, becaue the interior tunicle of the Womb being extended, which ries from, and is joyned to the Peritonaeum; th • parts alo to which that coheres, are tretched.

The excrements of the belly and bladder are detained by reaon of the heat and drines of the belly, and the compreion of the paages. Sometimes the whole body of the belly eems empty, or filled with water, and the Navel hangs forward, and the mouth of the womb is made very lender and cloe; and upon a udden few depraved coures come down: then happens a burning Fever by reaon of the great ympathy with the womb and the heart, occaioned through the Arteries and great Veels. There is a pain in the breats, with a welling in them, by reaon of the conent and agreement between the groyns, the hips, the eptum tranverum claviculare, and the forepart of the head, which is extended to the roots of the eyes; as alo from vapours which rie from the putrified blood to the head, through the Arteries that run along through the neck, paing by both parts of the infundibulum into the fore part of the head.
The caue of this conits in the blood, which is ometimes with Choler, and ometimes with Melancholy.

The Cure is difficult, if the blood in that part be wholly putrified; for that caueth a ordid humor which conumes the Patient with a continual Fever. If it be an Eriypelas, or St. Anthonies fire, there is no cure at all, becaue the Birth dies by reaon of the exceive heat which caues abortion to follow, which kills the Woman; if it turn to a gangrene, it is deadly: it is cured as other inflammations, which may be oberved in the following Chapters. Only oberve that for revulion you mut not let blood in the veins of the thighs, for that draws down the blood to the womb; but in the arm, the blood flowing from the Liver, and the parts adjoyning. For deriving of the matter, you may cut a vein in the ham, unles the Woman be with
Child, for that will caue abortion: Refrigerating and moitning Topicks, without any binding faculty, may be well applied; to which purpoe the decoction of wild Thyme, prepared with Chalybeat water, and outwardly applied with a ponge, is an excellent Remedy.

Thee inflammations ometimes affect the whole womb, and ometimes either ide of the Womb, which caues the heat to decend into the Hip, becaue of the ligaments of the Womb which are carred thither; the thigh is difficultly moved, and the groins are inflamed; ometimes the inflammation poeeth the poterior part, which caues the belly to be bound, and a pain in the loins and back-bone; ometimes it poeeth the forepart, which becaue it coheres to the bladder, the Urine is uppreed, or made very difficultly; and the pain is extended above the Privities: Semetimes it poees the bottom of the Womb, which caues uch a pain in the lower part of the Belly, that it is hardly to be touched, and the pain extends to the Navel.

There is another inflammation which degenerates into a Scirrhus, whereall the ymptoms are not o dangerous, yet there is a great heavines perceived in the parts adjoyning. This evil is diuturnal, and commonly ends in the Dropie; ometimes it turns to an Apotem, welling 'till it break: In this cae, the body is troubled with a hivering, epecially towards the Evening; when the Apotem is broken, ometimes it empties it elf into the concavity of the Womb, wherein there is les danger; and ometimes in other parts of the Body; which caues ometimes a toppage in the Urine, and ometimes in the Belly, with a welling of the hairy parts, and the feeling of omething floating up and down.

div.head: Of the Schirrus of the Womb.
div.p: THE Schirrus of the Womb is a hard welling of the aid part without pain, begot by ome thick earthly and feculent Humour; the igns, beides others that are general, are thee in particular: The Flowers at the beginning are either wholly topt, or flow very paringly, the evil increaing, there is a great flux of blood by intervals, the mouths of the Veins being opened more than ordinary, or becaue the Womb is not able to receive, or to retain its wonted proportion of blood: It is ditinguih'd from the Mole, becaue in that ditemper the Flowers, if they flow, flow inordinately; the Breats well with Milk, which in the Schirrus grow very lank.

The caue of this is a gros feculent humour, being a thick blood, ometimes Flegmy, ometimes melancholy, which happens to thoe who decline in their age; or to thoe who have been troubled with a queamih and naughty tomach: Often it aries from an ill cured Inflammation, through the ue of Medicines that cool too much.

The Cure is difficult, either becaue having been dried for a long time they cannot be oftned, or becaue the natural heat in thoe places where the Schirrus is, is for the mot part extinct; and then becaue while the humour is mollifying, if it have conceived any putrefaction, it eaily turns to the Cancer: For the cure, it is the ame as of the Breats.

It differs either as being in, and poeing the ubtance of the Womb, which caues the Womb to lean downward upon the Hip, and Back, and there begets pain; ometimes poeing the neck of the Womb, which is dicerned by touching it, and is cured more eaily than the former: If it be in the upper part of the
neck of the Womb, the Woman is hindred; in the lower part of the neck of the Womb, the treight gut is affected.

div.head: Of the Dropie of the Womb.
div.p: THE Dropie of the Womb is a ditemper from water collected in the Womb, either by ome fault in the part it elf, or in the parts adjoining. The igns of this are a looe welling at the bottom of the belly, extending it elf according to the proportion of the Womb; the fewnes and naughtines of the Coures; a moitnes, and lendernes of the neck of the Womb, oftnes of the Breat, want of Milk, a hivering in the Body, and ometimes a Fever: It differs from an inflammation by the ymptoms above related; and from an inflation, in the defect of ound and ditention; from a Mole, becaue in this there is a greater weight perceived at the bottom of the belly, and the Breats at the time of delivery are not without milk. It differs from Conception, becaue in the Dropie the welling is jut according to the form of the Womb; but in Conception it is always harper. In Women with Child the Flowers do not flow; but in this Dieae there flows uch a certain bloody vitious humour, without any order, which ceaes quickly. It differs from the Dropie of the Belly, becaue the face of the Patient is coloured, unles the Liver be any way affected, the want of thirt, and the acent of the welling from the lower part to the upper.

The caue of this is a water gathered there through ome defect of the Liver or Spleen, or through ome weaknes in the Womb; by reaon whereof it is not able to concoct or expel the Excrements; or through a too immoderate defluxion of the Coures, which oppreeth the natural heat; or through a uppreion of them, which uffocates the heat.

The cure is to be performed by the eduction of the water, and trengthening of the Womb; for which purpoe the ue of Antimonial Pills is not a little to be commended. Her diet mut be of meats that breed good Juice; he mut drink little, he mut ue intead of drink, a Ptian or Barly-broth, made with Saafras, or Saraparilla, if her Coures be topt, you may let her blood in the foot; if the repletion be great, then to let her blood in the arm will not be amis. The ue of Clyters is not amis, and Fomentations are alo very neceary, made with the decoction of Broom, wild Cucumbers, Flowers of Camomile, Melilot, with Origan, Cumin, Fenel, Anieed, of which you may make everal injections. Ointments alo may be ueful, made of Oil of Lillies, or Oil of Dill: Then may you apply upon the Belly this Plaiter: Take of the emplaiter of Laurel berries two Ounces; Oil of Camomile and Melilot, two ounces and a half; Pigeons dung and Goats dung, of each half an ounce; mix them altogether, and make a Plaiter, adding thereto a little Venice Turpentine.

div.head: Of the falling of the Womb.
div.p: THE falling of the Womb is the falling of it down below the Abdomen or Midriff, proceeding from a looenes of the Ligamants.

The general igns of this, are a pain in the loins, and hairy parts, and of the Os acrum, or holy Bone, to which the Womb is fatned; at the beginning the pain is not very great, nor after long continuance, by reaon of ue: The weight thereof being only troubleome, which is an impediment to the Patient in going The particular igns do vary according as the fall is greater or les; for in the one the Womb decends to the middle of the Hips and lower; in the latter there
is perceived the ditention of the skin, and as it were the weight of a good big Egg about the Privities.

The Cure of this is difficult, if there be the greater falling of the Womb, if the Woman be in Age, if a Fever, Convulion, or other ymptoms happen; if that be in women with Child, it is deadly; and ometimes it is corrupted by the ambient Air, and turns into a Gangrene. The Cure conits in the re-putting of it into its own place, where you mut oberve, firt to top the inflammation, if there be any; or if there be any welling caued by the cold Air, you mut foment the part firt with decoction of Mallows, Marh-mallows, Flowers of Camomile, and Lawrel Berries: If there be any wind or excrement in the Gut, you mut ue Clyters firt; it is alo to be fomented and anointed with agglutinating and atringent, or binding Medicines, there is a Fumigation to be made of the skin of a alt Eel dried, and poudered. When it is to be put into its place, the woman mut be laid with her Belly upwards; then mut the Midwife, or other Party employed, with a linnen Cloth dipt in Oyl of Roes, a little warmed, gently thrut up the part affected which is fallen, as gently as may be, turning a little. Now to keep it up, the woman mut be kept lying on her back, with her thighs tretched out, and one laid upon another acros; the Belly mut not be too much bound, let in the ejection of the excrement, the Womb hould be again precipitated, neither mut it be looe, let the Membranes binding the Womb hould be unlooed: Then mut you ue agglutinating Medicines, Pearies, Fomentations, and Injections; yet great care mut be had, let you uppres the Coures. Of this there be ome differences, either by reaon of the looenes of the Ligaments which are four, which is dicerned in that it is generated by degrees, and with les pain: It aries
either from hard labour, or a ponderoity or heavines of the Child, or from the concoure of flegmy humours; it is cured by the evacuation of humors, and by the ue of atringent and corroborating Medicines; uch as are the decoction of Musk of the Oak, Hartshorn, Laurel-leaves, and the atringent Plaiter.

Another caue and difference arieth from the rupture of the Ligaments; which is dicerned by this, that the evil comes uddenly, and is more painful, and is ometimes followed with a Flux of blood; it aries from the heavines of the birth, or from a difficult labour, or from Abortion, or a difficult and violent extraction of the Secondines.
Sometimes it happens, becaue the Ligaments are eaten away, and then the igns of ome Ulcer are dicerned by the flowing forth of matter.

div.head: Of the acent of the Matrix, as alo of the Wounds and Ulcers of the ame.
div.p: SOme have thought that it is poible for the Womb to acend up to the Stomach, which opinion is altogether fale; for firt it is tyed o fat with four Ligaments, that it is impoible for it to move to the upper parts: Beides, uppoe it had a natural motion by the Fibres, yet the Womb being o firmly annexed to the right gut, and to the Privities, it would necearily follow that thoe parts hould be alo tretched. And though it happen to be tretched, and ditended by the windy vapours, yet it follows not that therefore it hould be moved upward: and whereas women do ay that they do ometimes perceive a certain round body moving about the region of the Navel, that may rather be aid to be the tones, and that blind Veel, than the Womb.

Of the wounds of the Matrix this mut be noted, that they are very difficult to be cured. Yet the cure is to be aayed five manner of ways; by the ue of things which do evacuate the peccant humor, which is done partly by a good order of diet, and living in a dry and temperate air; longer leep than ordinary, and the avoiding of exercie in this cae is to be oberved; and intead thereof to ue moderate frictions: All repletion, and a looe belly are naught; the meat that he eats mut be little, and contrary to the humour that offends, as rear Eggs, Milk, Chicken-broths, and the meat of them, dry Raiins, Almonds, and Pitaches. For her drink, it ought to be chiefly the decoction of Barly or Liquorih.

In the next place, it will not be amis to let blood in the Bailick Vein: let her take ome convenient purge according to the humour which abounds: Vomitings alo and frictions may be ued, and the provoking of weat by the decoction of Guaiacum, Salaparil, and China-root, which are very proper to turn away the humors from the Matrix.

Sometimes this happens from an intemperancy of the womb, which if it be cold, the womb is not able to concoct ufficient quantity of nourihment, and therefore heaps up together many excrements; if it be moit, it is not able to contain either the blood, or the eed, or the birth, as it hould do. The cure of this is above touched in the Chapter of Ditempers.

There is another difference which is taken from the occult qualities which the womb is een to have, there being a ympathy and antipathy between that and divers things, as to covet the eed of Man, and to love weet things; and then the affection aries from no evident caue, there being no exces of coldnes, or moiture to be apprehended. The Medicines which
are to be applied for the cure of this, mut be proper in their whole ubtance.

Sometimes the difference arieth in this, that the natural heat is either uffocated or diipated; this affection is omething dangerous, becaue it is a difficult matter to retore the natural heat. In the cure of this, retoratives mut be notwithtanding ued; uch are Cinamon, Nutmeg, Species diaxylo, Aloes, Aromaticum Roatum.

div.head: Of the pain of the Womb.
div.p:
THere is no need to give other igns of this than the complaint of the Woman; it affects both women that are free, and women that are with Child: It happens ometimes from corroding humors, epecially caued by Ulcers, or vitious Flowers The cure whereof is referred to thee heads; ometimes it happens from a ditention caued either by ome curdled blood ticking in the cavity of the Womb, and then there is a copious Flux of blood out of the Womb, and the pain is fixed chiefly about the orifice of the Womb; the right Gut and the Bladder being affected by reaon of the continual deire of expelling forth the humor. In the Cure, firt you mut eek to diolve the clotted blood, which is done by the ue of Treacle diolved in wine; and then to evacuate, which is performed with Agaric, Aloes, with the juice of Savin, decoction of Roemary, with the Flowers of Cheiri, in Wine. Sometimes it is caued by the mentruous blood, when the veels are more open, or the blood too thick; which happens through the over-much ue of cold drink, epecially when the woman is hot. The cure may be found in the cure of the uppreion of the Flowers. Sometimes it is caued by other vitious humours collected in the concavity of the womb, or adhering to the other Veels; and then
thee humours are to be removed with purging and evacuating Medicines. Sometimes windy vapours are the caue hereof, ariing from the heat of the vitious humors caued by copulation. It is cured by things that dicus the wind; to which purpoe it may not be amis to ue a Clyter made of Malmey and Oyl of Nuts, of each three ounces, of Aqua vitae one ounce, of Oyl of Juniper and ditilled Rue of each two drams, and applied warm; or a mixture of pirit of wine and pirit of Nitre, of each half a dram or two cruples, exhibited in the pirit of Wine, Sperma ceti, with Oyl of weet Almonds, or a Plaiter of Caranna and Tachamahacca applied to the Navel. Sometimes it is occaioned by the retention and corruption of the eed. For the Cure, look the Chapter of the uffocation of the Matrix.

div.head: Of the Suppreion of the Flowers.
div.p: THE uppreion of the Flowers is the retention of the mentrual blood, either by reaon of the narrownes of the veels, or through ome corruption of the blood. The igns are evident from the relation of the Woman: Yet if they are loth to confes, it may be dicerned by this; for in Virgins the uppreed blood wanders up and down the Veins, and begets obtructions, changing the colour of the Body, and cauing Fevers. In Women, becaue the blood is carried down to the Womb, where it begets many dieaes, it is ditinguihed from retention after Conception, becaue women with Child find no alteration of affections of the mind, and retain the native colour of their bodies; and in the third month they hall perceive the motion and ituation of the Infant; and latly, the mouth of the womb is cloed up.

The Caues of this ditemper are the narrownes of the Veins, and the vitiounes of the blood. The Cure of this mut be hatened, becaue this uppreion if it tay long begets many more dieaes, as Fevers, Dropies, Vomiting of blood, and the like: The Cure is hard if it be of any continuance, and if it tay beyond the ixth month, it is almot incurable; epecially if it happen through any perverion of the neck of the Womb; for then the woman is troubled with often wooning, and vomiting of blood, and a pain eizes the parts of the Belly, the Back, and the Backbone, which is attended with a Fever, and the excrements of the Belly and Bladder are uppreed; a wearines poees the whole Body, becaue of the diffuion of the retained blood through the whole body, and epecially the hips and thighs, becaue of the ympathy of thoe parts with the veins of the Womb. In the firt place, the letting of blood is commended; for the blood which every month tays in the body, and ticks in the Veins, is to be provoked downward to the Womb; and therefore a vein is to be opened in the heel, for o the plenty of blood is diminihed, and the motion of the blood is made toward the Womb; if neceity requires that it hould be done more than once, one day a vein mut be opened in one thigh, and another day in the other; and that which is opened for evacuation mut be firt opened, that which is opened in the ham, or heel, mut be done after Purgation, three, or four, or five days before the time that the accutomed evacuations of the Woman ought to come down. Cupping-glaes alo are to be applied firt to the more remote places, as to the thighs; and then to the nearer parts, as to the hips: Ligatures, or bindings and frictions, at the time of the coming down of the Flowers, after Purgation of the whole body, are
not to be omitted. In the econd place the matter is to be prepared, for which purpoe, in bodies troubled with Flegm, the decoction of Guaiacum, with Cretan Dittany, doth much avail without provoking weat. In the third place evacuation is to be made at everal times. Among evacuating Medicines are commended Agaric, Aloes, with the juice of Savin, and thee Pills: Take Aloes Succotrine three drams; the bet Myrrh one cruple, extract of weet melling Flag, Carduus, Saffron, of each three drams; Roots of Gentian and Dittany, of each five grains; make them up with Syrup of Laurel-berries, taking the quantity of one crup • e at evening before upper. In the fourth place, by opening obtructions by thoe things which provoke the Flowers, of which thee are mot to be commended, the decoction of Roemary with Flowers of Cheiri, Pennyroyal-water twice ditilled, and mingled with Cinnamon-water; Extract of Zedoary, Angelica, and Cator, and the Earth which is found in Iron Mines prepared in the ame manner as Steel, pirit of Tartar, the fat of an Eel, Colubrina with the ditill'd water of Savin: And in the fifth place, by the dicuion of the dregs and relicks that remain, by udoroficks, or things that provoke weat, with a potion made of a Chalybeate decoction, with pirit of Tartar, &c.

The differences of this Dieae arie, partly from the obtruction of the Veins of the Womb, caued by a cold and thick blood, and thick limy humours mixed with the blood, and coming either from ome hot ditemper of the Womb, which diipates the harp and ubtil humours, and leaves behind the gros and earthy parts, or from the cold Contitution of the Liver and Spleen; epecially if at the time of the mentrual Flux (at what time the Flux of Blood is more violent) thoe ubtil humours happen to be diipated, and then at the
time of the monthly Purgation, the Party affected feels a great pain in the loins, and parts adjoining; and if any thing come down, it is lymy, whitih, and blackih: The whole Body is poeed with a numnes, the Colour pale, a low Pule, and raw Urines. The Cure is the ame with the former, great care being taken of a gros and ill diet.

There is another difference of this Dieae when it happens by Compreion, which aries from external caues, as the Northern wind, and long tanding in cold water, which may be known from the relation of the ick Peron. The Blood in this cae is to be drawn to the lower parts by Frictions and Baths; or from internal caues, as fatnes, or welling of the Womb, or of the lower parts; in which cae Medicines mut be applied that awage the welling. There is another difference which is in the hardnes of the skin which happens either from the firt Nativity, and then the dieae is not eaily taken away; or long after, from ome cold and dry ditemper: Concerning which look the former Chapters.

Another difference there is, when there happens a cloing up of the skin, which is caued after Cicatriing of an Ulcer, or by reaon of ome skin or Membrane growing to the Veels of the Womb, or by reaon of frequent Abortion; after which thee Veins to which the Secondines adhere, do grow together o cloe that they cannot be afterwards opened.

Another difference of this Dieae there is, when it happens through want of Blood, which is not generated, either by reaon of external caues, as Famine, over much evacuation, Iues, and uch like; or through internal caues, as a frigid Contitution of the principal parts, old Age, and Fevers; or when it is converted to other ues, as before full growth, to the nourihment of
the Body: In Women with Child, to the nourihment of the Birth: In thoe that give uck, to the increae of Milk: And in fat people, to the augmentation of the Fat: Or when it is conumed either by External caues, as over much Exercie, Affrights, Terrors, Sadnes, Baths, overmuch Sweating, which do conume the erous quality of the Blood; or through Internal Caues, as are hot and dry Dieaes, or over-great evacuations in other parts of the Body. Sometimes another difference of this Dieae proceeds from the drynes of the Blood, which happens to Women, who in the Winter time do too much heat their lower parts, by putting Coals under their Coats. For the cure thereof you mut ue refrigerating and moitning Medicines.

div.head: Of the dropping of the Flowers, and the difficulty of their coming down.
div.p: THE dropping of the Flowers is, when they are coming down for many days together drop by drop.
This happens both from external caues, as over hard labour, &c.
And ometimes from the droines of the blood, the paage not being wide enough. For the cure of this, it is convenient to open a Vein in the Arm with gentle purging, as in the former Chapter.

Sometimes from the weaknes of the retentive faculty, there being at that time great plenty, thinnes, and eroity of the blood. In this cae there is no pain; Medicines that bind and corroborate the Stomach here mut have place.

The difficulty of the Flowers is when they come down with pain and trouble, either through defect in the Veins, or in the Blood. The igns of this are gathered from the relation of the ick peron, who is then much troubled with pain in the Head, Stomach, and Loins, and lower parts of the body. And they do either
flow altogether, or drop by drop, as in the former dieae; It is a Dieae more incident to Maids than married Women, becaue the Veins of the Womb are les open in them, than in thoe who brought forth Children.

It happens ometimes from a corruption of the blood, that is, from the droines and thicknes thereof, and then the blood clots together; and there is a great pain long before the Flowers begin to come down. The Cure of this is performed by attenuating Medicines. Sometimes from the harpnes and acrimony of the Blood, which proceeds from a mixture of harp humours with the Body, and then the genital parts do itch. It is cured by thoe Medicines that temper the harpnes of the Humour, as the four greater Seeds, Violets, and Flowers of Nenuphar. Sometimes from windy Vapours, and then the pain comes by intervals, and is uddenly exaperated, rumbling up and down; and when the wind is forth, the pain ceaeth. The cure hereof is procured by evacuation of the matter, and dipelling of the wind, as is before declared.

div.head: Of the dicolouring of the Flowers.
div.p: THE dicolouring of the Flowers is when their right colour, which ought to be red, declines either to palenes, whitenes, greennes, yellownes, or blewihnes, through ome defect, or vitiounes of the blood.

The igns are apparent by the ight of the blood; beides that it is accompanied with an ill mell, many times alo it is the caue of Fevers, trembling of the body, loathing of the meat, pain in the tomach, &c.

The differences of this dieae conit firt in the vitiounes of the blood, which is caued through ome ditemper either of the whole body, or ome part thereof. Sometimes the blood is affected by reaon of ome toppage thereof, and then the Flowers are uppreed,
which caueth pains in the Breat, and trong beating of the Breat; and if the woman begin to amend the Blood flows out with a tinking putrefaction, which continues 'till the eighth day; or it may be, becaue the Blood is foul'd by the Womb, being full of excrements; and then you may perceive the igns of a foul Womb.

Sometimes the difference of this dieae conits in the mixture of the Blood with other vitious humors. The Cure conits in preparation and evacuation, but care mut be had, that becaue the thick humors need attenuation, and that over attenuating things do melt the erous humor, that you therefore do not ue over attenuating things, as Vinegar, &c.

Another difference is, when the Flowers decline to a whitih colour, which 'proceeds from abundance of Flegm, or from Putrefaction, and then Ulcers follow in the Womb, and barrennes follows; unles the womans Flowers do happen to flow for even or eight days together, by which the woman is freed from the dieae; or ele they break out to the parts above the groin without any tumor, and burt forth a little above the Hypochondrium, and then the woman eldom lives, or ele there will appear after ome few days a great welling in the Groyn, without a head of a red colour, becaue the Fleh is there filled up with the Blood.
When it inclines to yellownes, or greennes, the ditemper comes of Choler; when to a blacknes and blewnes, from Melancholy.

div.head: Of the inordinate Flux of the Flowers.
div.p:
THE diorderly Flux of the Coures is either the coming of them down before their time, or ele the toppage of them for ome time after the uual
coure of Nature. They come down ometimes before their time, partly by reaon of internal Caues, and partly by reaon of external Caues, as falls, blows, and uch like caualties that open the veins: Or from the expulive faculty of the Womb too much provoked. Firt, by the plenty of blood, which is known by this, that the blood which is ent to the womb from all part is fluid, and of its natural contitution; igns of a Plethora, or fulnes of blood, are apparent in the Woman. It is Cured by blood letting if the blood abound by good diet, and frequent though gentle exercie. Secondly, it proceeds from the Acrimony and harpnes of the blood which is known by the hot temper of the body, the blood it elf is more thin and yellowih. It mut be Cured by evacuating Medicines, as Rheubarb, and uch things as temper the blood, whereof we have already poken.

It comes alo when the retentive faculty of the womb grows lank, which may be known by the looenes of the Veels of the Womb, beides a moit and faint habit of the body: In the Cure, beware of things which are too Atringent; baths, wherein the force and trength of Iron may be effectual, may with afety be ued. The ubitence and tay of the Coures beyond the accutomed time, proceeds from a frutration of the expulive faculty; as when there is mall tore of blood, which is known by this, that the Woman is not troubled with the tay of the Coures; and epecially, if he have over-exercied her elf, or ued a pare diet before. Secondly, the thicknes of the blood, which is known by the whitenes and clammines thereof. In the performance of the Cure, you mut purge before too much blood be gathered together: Next, the Coures are to be attenuated, for the performance of which, Calamint and Mercurialis are to
be mot commended. In this Cae carification of the heels is not amis.

There is another difference of this Dieae, which aries from the weaknes of the expelling faculty, caued either by the frigid ditemper of the Womb, of which we have poken already; or by a kind of numnes thereof, of which we hall peak anon.

div.head: Of the over abundance of the Coures.
div.p: THE over much flux of the Coures is either a more abundant, or a more lating Purgation of the Coures, through ome defect, either in the blood, or the womb, or the veins of the womb.
The igns are evident, viz. want of Appetite, Crudities, a bad colour in the face, a welling in the feet, and the ret of the body, a waxing lean of the body; and in brief, a general ill habit of body.

The Cure (if it be of any continuance) is difficult; if it happen to an aged woman, there is none at all. It requires a revulion, or drawing back of the blood, interception, and incraation, or thickning thereof, and a cloing up of the Veels by atringent Medicines. Yet oberve that they mut be topt by degrees. To this effect, you may take this Powder.

Take of the eed of White Henbane, red Coral, of each half a dram, white Camphor half a cruple, and give the quantity of half a dram at a time; powder of Amber, Dragons-blood, Bloodtones, Red Coral, Lettice eed, of each one dram, Balaut two cruples, Bole armoniack two drams, given in three ounces of Plantain-water, Aes milk heated with Steel. You may externally alo apply a girdle made of the bruied leaves of Baresfoot.

Of this Dieae there are many differences: Sometimes it happens from the blood which is derived from the bottom of the Womb, where for the mot part lies
the blacket and mot clotted blood; or from the neck of the Womb, which is more red and fluid. Another difference arieth from the plenty of blood, which appears by this, that the Veels are either broken or much opened, epecially in thoe women who have had a toppage in their Coures for a time, which preently break out again. The igns of this are evident; that is to ay, a fulnes of blood in the body; beides that, the blood which comes forth eaily curdles.

In the Cure, you mut have recoure to blood-letting, which if you do for evacuation, it mut be done in the Hepatick Vein: If the woman be weak, in Salvatella of both hands. In the next place the ue of Cupping-Glaes is to be commended, being applied with carification to the back, &c. Or, without carification to the Breat, being ued again when the woman is troubled with difficulty of breathing. In the third place, ligatures and frictions of the Arms are to be ued.

Another difference of this dieae aries from a harp blood, which is known by the gnawing of the humor upon the Veels. In the Cure, you mut purge with yrup of Roes olutive, or with leaves of Sena; a peary of Sows dung and Aes dung, which is made up with Plantain water, and the mucilage of the eed of Quinces, is here of ue if need require.

Another difference aries from a erous and watry blood; for either the Liver is weakned, or the Veins o debilitated, that it cannot attract the erous or wheyie humour in the blood: in this cae, the blood flows not forth in uch a quantity, nor is eaily curdled: If a Cloth be dipped in it, and then dried in the hade, it preently dicolours. In the Cure hereof you mut look to the rectifying of the weaknes of the
Reins and Liver with convenient remedies, for which purpoe the Livers of Foxes, Calves, Hens, &c. are very good.

Sometimes from a Rupture of the Veins, which proceeds either from a fulnes of blood, or from Caues that do vehemently tir up the blood, epecially from hard labour; if it be needful, you mut let blood, and apply conglutinating Medicines.

Or from a gnawing of the Veels, which is known by this, that ometimes there flows forth little blood, and that purulent, and full of the wheyie or erous humor. It aries from a harp and corrupt blood, and ometimes from the ue of harp Medicines. Among the atringent Medicines, the root of Filipendula is much to be commended, or a decoction of the ame Root.

div.head: Of the Whites and Gonorrhea in Women.
div.p: THE Whites is an inordinate eruption of an excrementitious humour collected together through ome vitiounes of the blood. It affects Women chiefly, and ometimes alo Virgins, of which there are Examples: Yet it is more often in women, epecially if they be of a moit contitution, and live an idle and delicate life, eating uch things as are cold and moit. Old women alo are affected herewith through the abundance of Flegm, and the weaknes of the concoctive faculty.

It differs from the Gonorrhea, becaue in that the eminal matter is white, and thicker; and flows by long intervals, and iues forth in a leer quantity from a nocturnal pollution; for that is joyned with venereal imaginations, and only happens in the time of leep. It differs from the dicolouring of the Flowers; for they though not exactly, do always oberve their
times of Flowing. Beides, they happen not to Women with Child, or uch whoe Coures are topped. It differs from the putrid humour that iues from the Ulcers of the Womb, becaue that is joyned with the igns of an Ulcer, and the putrefaction is thicker and whiter; if it be mattery, it is coloured with blood, and iues forth with pain.

The Cure of this mut be hatned, becaue in a hort time it endangers the making of women barren, cauing them to be lean, to fall into a Conumption, Melancholy, the Dropie, fall of the Womb, Swoonings, and Convulions; which is the caue that though it be not hard to be cured in the beginning, yet it is afterwards very difficult; for by this means the whole body accutoms it elf to end forth its excrements this way, and the Womb being now weakned, gathers excrements apace.

Sometimes it proceeds from the whole body, and then you may perceive the igns of an ill humor through the whole body. In the Cure of this, you mut avoid blood-letting, for that the bad humor mut not be recalled to defile the blood; beides, that the dieae is a ufficient weakning and conuming of the body. The humor is dicued by the decoction of Guaiacum and China, and Lentisk-wood. For the drying up of the humor, the Root of Filipendula doth very much conduce. For atringent Medicines you may ue chiefly the powder of dead men's bones, the ahes of Capons-dung in rain water. The Patient mut avoid leeping upon her back, let the heat of the Lungs hould carry the humors toward the Womb: Frictions alo of the upper parts, for the diverion of the humor may be ued.

Sometimes it is caued by the Womb it elf, and then there will appear igns of the affection of the
Womb, and the Flux is not o great. For the Cure of this, Suffumigations of Frankincene, Labdanum, Matick, and Sanders are very requiite.

div.head: Of the Green-Sicknes.
div.p: THE Green-Sicknes is a changing of the colour of the Face into a green and pale colour, proceeding from the rawnes of the humors. The igns of this appear in the Face, to which may be added a great pain in the Head, difficulty of breathing, with a palpitation of the heart, a mall and thick beating of the Arteries in the Neck, Back, and Temples; ometimes inordinate Fevers through the vitiounes of the humors, loathing of Meat, Vomiting, ditention of the Hypocondriack part, by reaon of the reflux of the mentrous blood to the greater Veels; a welling of the whole body by reaon of the abundance of humors, or of the Thighs and Legs above the heels, by reaon of the abundance of erous humors.

The Caue is the crudity and rawnes of the humor, and quantity withal, ariing from the uppreion of the Coures through the natural narrownes of the veels, or through an acquired narrownes of the veels by the eating of Oatmeal, Chalk, Earth, Nutmegs, and drinking of Vinegar; or from the obtruction of the other bowels. Hence aries an ill concoction in the bowels, and the humors are carried into the habit of the body, or become habitual thereunto.

The Cure is performed by the letting of blood, epecially in the heel; if the Dieae be of any continuance, by Purgation, preparation of the humour being firt conidered; which is performed by the decoction of Guaiacum, with • retan Dittany; purging of the humor is performed with Agarick, Aloes Succotrin, with the •• ice of Savin; for the unobtructing of the
humor, prepared Steel, the root of Scorzonera, Bezoartone, in diet, Vinegar is utterly to be avoided.

The Cure of this Dieae is performed by opening Obtructions, by purging off vitious Humours, by correcting the intemperies of the Bowels, and by trengthening them. Firt therefore, a gentle purging Medicine mut be given, that is agreeable to the Contitution, that the firt region may be emptied, and if the Belly be bound, a Gliter mut be given firt of all, afterwards bleeding mut be ordered, unles the Dieae is very inveterate, and the Maid be inclined to a Cachexy. But a Vein in the Arm mut be opened, tho' the Coures are topt; for at that time, if you bleed in the Foot, the obtructions of the Veins, and of the Womb would be increaed. That quantity of Blood being taken away, that is neceary, proper purges mut be ued.

Take of the Pill Coch. major two cruples, of Cator powdered two grains, of Peruvian Balom four drops, make four Pills, let her take them at five in the Morning, and leep after them if he can. Let thee Pills be repeated twice or thrice every Morning, or every other Morning, according to the trength of the ick, and their operation.
After the purging Pills let her take the following.

Take of the fileings of Steel eight grains, with a ufficient quantity of extract of Wormwood, make two Pills to be taken in the Morning, and they mut be repeated at five in the Afternoon. She mut continue this Coure for a Month, drinking preently after the Pills a draught of Wormwood-wine.
If a Bolus be more pleaing,

Take of the conerve of Roman Wormwood, and of the conerve of the inner peell of Oranges, each one ounce; of candied Angelica, and Nutmegs candied,
and of Venice Treacle, each half an ounce, of Ginger candied two drams, with a ufficient quantity of Syrup of Oranges make an Electuary, take of this Electuary one dram and an half, of the filings of Steel well powdered eight grains, with a ufficient quantity of Syrup of Oranges, make a Bolus to be taken in the Morning, and at five in the Afternoon, drinking upon it a draught of Wormwood wine.

div.head: Of the uffocation of the Matrix.
div.p: THE igns of the Suffocation of the Womb, are a wearines of the whole body, with a weaknes of the Thighs; a palenes and adnes of the Face; a naueounes though eldom vomiting; oftentimes a loathing and ditate of Meat, and that ometimes with a grumbling and noie in the Belly, and ometimes without.

The igns of the preent Dieae are, that when the Vapours are carried up to the Heart, and do there top the vital Spirits, a light wooning follows, the Pule changes and is little, the Body grows cold, all the pirits flying up into the Heart; the Vapour being thrut up to the Head and Chaps, the Chaps are many times et fat, the Patient eeming to be tifled; the motion of the Breat and Diaphragm is diturbed and hindred, o that the breath is almot topt, the Patient living only by tranpiration. Sometimes there is joined with it a kind of Uterine fury, with talking and anger: Sometimes it caues other madnes; ometimes the Woman falls into a dead leep, which makes her eem as though he were dead.

It differs from the Epilepie, becaue in that the Convulive motions are more general; nor is there any memory of thoe things which happen about them after the Fit; the Pule is great, and the Mouth of the Party
affected fomes with a froth: It differs from the Apoplexy, becaue in that the Fit comes uddenly without any notice; and the Patient is affected with a kind of norting, and there is uch a Reolution of the parts, that they feel not although they be pricked: It differs from a Syncope, in that there are no igns when the Fit will be, the Pule ceaes to the apprehenion, and the Patient is troubled with cold weats. They differ from dead people by neezing, which may be provoked by putting omething for that purpoe into the Noe.

The caue of this is a venemous, ubtle, and thin Vapour, piercing in one moment through the whole body, and carried up from the matter in the Womb, corrupted after a peculiar manner, either by it elf or from external means, uch are perfumes, anger, fear, &c. and not only acending through the veins, but alo through all the other breathing holes, and ecret paages of the body.

The Cure is doubtful if it have poeed old Women for a time, for it begets weaknes, conumes the trength, and hews abundance of humour; or if it poeeth Child-bearing Women, either after a difficult Travel, or after an Abortion; or if it poeeth Women with Child, becaue it induces fear of Abortion; there is more hope, if the act of Repiration be not too much impeded, and if the Fits do not return too often.

The Cure regards firt the time of the Fit, being performed firt by means of interception, which may be done by binding the Belly under the Navel with a girdle made of the skin of a Hart, killed in the very act of Copulation. Secondly, by keeping the natural Spirits awaked and rouzed up by painful friction, by pulling the hairs of the Privities with violence and uffumigations made with Partridge feathers burnt, as alo
Eel-skins, the application of Aa faetida and Oil of Tartar to the mouth. Thirdly, by way of revulion of the humour, by Frictions and Glyters dipelling the winds, and the application of Cupping-glaes with much flame, firt to the Thighs, and then to the Hips, putting weet things into the Privities; uch as are Oil of Sivet half a cruple, Oil of Nutmegs one cruple: Fourthly, by dicuion of the humour, which is performed inwardly by the Oil of white Amber, with the pouder of Walnut Flowers, extract of Cator; externally by an Emplaiter of the fat of a black Heifer, Sclarea boiled in butter, adding to it a ufficient quantity of Tachamahacca and Caranna: After the fit is pat, evacuation is to be regarded, firt with purgation, for which purpoe it will not be amis to ue thee enuing Pills: Take Siler mountain, Pennyroyal, Madder, the innermot part of Caia Pipe, Pomegranate Kernels, Piony roots, and Calamus, of each three drams; Mucus and Spike of India, of each half a dram; then make Pills thereof with the juice of Mugwort, of which he may take every day, or every other day, before Supper. If the dieae proceed from the terms, let the Woman affected take an Ounce of Agarick poudered in Wine or honied water, or a dram of Agnus Catus powder'd with an ounce of Honey of Roes: The Womb is alo to be trengthned by the internal and external application of uch things as reit the malignity of the Dieae; among which are numbred, Faecula Brioniae, and Cator: The difference of this Dieae conits in this, that ometimes it happens that it is occaioned by the retention of the Seed, which is known by this, that the ymptoms of the Dieae are more violent; and after the fit is pat, there flows out of the Womb a matter like to that of the eed. It is cur'd by evacuation of the eed, uch as are Rue, and Agnus Catus,
and anointing with odoriferous alves, epecially if the woman be to live without the ue of man.

If it come from the uppreion of the terms, which is known by the Coures being mingled with a melancholy blood, take powdered Agaric, a dram of Pioney eeds, or the weight of a dram and a half of Triphera magna.

But take this for a ecret, that for a married Woman in cae of the preent uffocation, there is nothing better than for the Man to anoint the top of his Yard with a little Oyl of Gilliflowers, and Oyl of weet Almonds together, and o to lye with her; for this auredly brings down the Matrix again.

This Dieae is very frequent, the Procatartick or external Caues of it, are either violent motions of the body, or, which is much oftner, vehement commotions of the Mind from ome udden aault, either of Anger or Grief, or the like Paions. Therefore as often as Women are troubled with this or that diorder of Body, the reaon whereof cannot be deduced from the common Axioms; for finding out Dieaes, we mut diligently enquire whether they are not chiefly afflicted with that indipoition which they complain of, when they have been diturbed in their minds, and afflicted with grief; which if they confes, we may be fully atisfied that this diorder proceeds from this Dieae we are now peaking of; epecially if Urine as clear as Chrytal evacuated copiouly ome certain times, makes the Diagnotick more manifet. But to thee diorders of the Mind, which are uually the occaions of this Dieae, is to be added emptines of the tomach, by reaon of long fating, immoderate bleeding, and a Vomit or Purge that worked too much; and certainly this Dieae proceeds from a confuion
of the Spirits, upon which account too many of them in a crowd, contrary to proportion, are hurried violently upon this or that part, occaioning Convulions and pain, when they ruh upon parts indued with exquiite ene, perverting the functions of the Organs, both of that into which they thrut themelves, and alo of that from whence they departed, both being much injured by this unequal ditribution, which is quite contrary to the Oeconomy of Nature.

The Origen and Antecedent Caue of this confuion, is a weak contitution of the Spirits, whether it is natural or adventitious; for which Reaon they are eaily diipated upon any occaion, and their Sytem oon broke: For as the outward Man is framed with parts obvious to ene, o without doubt the inward Man conits of a due Series, and as it were a Fabrick of the Spirits, to be viewed only by the eye of Reaon; and as this is nearly joyned, and as it were united with the contitution of the Body, o much the more eaily or more difficultly is its frame diordered, by how much the Contitutive Principles that are allotted us by Nature, are more or les firm. That the aid Confuion of the Spirits is the caue of Hyteric Dieaes, will appear by Mother-Fits, wherein the Spirits are crowded in the lower Belly, and ruhing together violently towards the Jaws, occaion Convulions in every region thro' which they pas, blowing up the Belly like a great Ball, which is yet nothing but the rowling together or conglobation of the parts eized with the Convulion, which cannot be uppreed without great violence. The external parts in the the mean while, and the Fleh being in a manner detitute of Spirits, by reaon they are carried another way, are often o very cold, not only in this kind, but in all other kind of Hyteric Dieaes, that dead
Bodies are not colder, but the Pule are as good as thoe of People that are well; nor is the Womans life in danger by this cold, unles it is occaioned by ome very large evacuation going before.

And the inordinate agitation of the Spirits diturbing the blood, is the caue of the clear and copious Urine; for when the Oeconomy of the blood is interrupted, the Sick cannot long enough contain the erum that is imported, but lets it go, before it is impregnated with aline particles, whereby the Citron colour is to be imparted to it, whereof we have daily experiment in thoe that drink much, epecially of thin and attenuating Liquors; for then their Urine is very clear; in which cae, the blood being over-power'd by that quantity of erum, and being wholly unable to retain it, puts it off quite clear, not yet died by the juice of the Body, by reaon of its too hort tay.

As to the Cold, by which the external parts are o often chilled, it is very manifet that that happens, becaue the Spirits foraking their tations too officiouly, intrude themelves into this or that part. Nor is it to be doubted, that weeping and laughing fits, which often eie hyterical women without any occaion, are procured by the Animal Spirits forcing themelves violently upon the Organs that perform thee Animal functions.

And now I uppoe it is manifet, that this whole Dieae is occaioned by the Animal Spirits being not rightly dipoed, and not by eed and mentruous blood corrupted, and ending up malignant Vapours to the parts affected, nor from I know not what depravation of the juices, and congetion of acrid humors as others think, but from thoe Caues we have aign • d; for that the fomes of the Dieae does not lurk in matter, will plainly appear by this one intance,
viz. A Woman that ued to enjoy perfect health, being delicate, and of a thin habit of body, if he chance to be weakned, and exhauted by ome error, or by ome trong Vomit or Purge, will certainly be afflicted with ome one of thoe Symptoms that accompany this Dieae, which would rather be removed, than occaioned by uch Vomiting or Purging, if the fomes of the Dieae was contained in matter. The ame may be aid of a great los of blood, whether it is taken away by opening a vein, or flows immoderately in Labour; or of emptines, or too long abtinence from Fleh; all which would rather prevent hyteric Dieaes, than occaion them, if the fomes of them was involved in ome matter; whereas on the contrary, nothing does o contantly occaion this Dieae, as thee evacuations But tho' it is apparent enough, that the Original fomes of this Dieae is not lodged in the humors, yet it mut be confeed that the confuion of the Spirits produces putrid humors in the Body, by reaon the function, as well of thee parts which are ditended by the violent impule of the Spirits, as of thoe which are deprived of them, are wholly perverted; and mot of thee being as it were eparatory Organs deigned for the reception of the impurities of the blood, if their functions are any way hurt, it can not be but a great many feculencies will be heaped up, which had been elimmated, and o the mas of blood purified, if the Organs had performed their office, which they had certainly done, if a due Oeconomy of the Spirits had invigorated them. To this Caue is to be attributed great Cachexies, los of appetite, a Chlorois, and the White Fever in young Women, which is a pecies of hyteric Dieaes, and the ource of many mieries.

From what has been aid, it is very manifet that that is the chief indication in this Dieae, which directs the corroboration of the blood, that is the Fountain and Origin of the Spirits, which being done, the invigorated Spirits can preerve that tenure that is agreeable to the Oeconomy of the whole body, and the particular parts; and therefore when the confuion of the Spirits has vitiated the humors by long continuance, it will be proper, firt to leen thoe humors o corrupted by bleeding, and purging, if the Patient has ufficient trength before we endeavour to corroberate the blood, and which indeed we can carce do, whilt a feculent heap of humors lies in the way. But foramuch as Pains, Vomiting, and Looenes, are ometimes o very evere that they will not bear a truce o long, until we have atisfied the firt intention of fortifying the blood; therefore ometimes we mut begin the Cure by quieting the effects (the caue being let alone a little while) with ome anodyne Medicine, and then we mut endeavour to rectifie the Spirits, whoe infirm contitution is the caue of this Dieae, by which we may again endeavour to Cure uch kind of Symptoms. And becaue experience teaches, that there are many tinking things that will repell the inordination of the Spirits, and contain them in their places, which are therefore call'd hyterics, we mut make ue of them when we would anwer uch intentions.

According to what has been aid, I order the Sick to be blooded in the arm, and that after bleeding, he be purged three or four Mornings following. The Woman thinks her elf wore of thoe days he is blooded and purged; for thee evacuations promote the confuion of the Spirits, which I take care to forewarn her of, that he may not depair, the Dieae of it elf
being apt to incline her o to do: But however thoe ill humours heapt up by the long continuance of the Dieae, are in ome ort to be evacuated, before we can well anwer the prime intention. After thee evacuations, ome teel Remedy mut be precribed, to be taken about a Month, to comfort the blood, and o conequently the Spirits, that proceed from it, and nothing will more certainly anwer your intention in this cae than teel; for it raies a volatile ferment in the vapid and languid blood, whereby the weak Spirits are roued, that before were kept down by their own weight; and this is very manifet, for as often as Chalybeats are given in the Green Sicknes, the Pule are preently greater and quicker, and the outward parts grow warm, and the pale and dead Countenance is changed, and becomes freh and lively. But here we mut take notice, that bleeding and purging mut not always be ued before Chalibeats, or when the Woman is weak, and almot worn out by the long continuance of the Dieae, they may and ought to be omitted, and you mut begin with teel, which mut be well minded.

I think teel is mot conveniently given in ubtance, and as I never oberved, nor heard, that o taken it ever injur'd any peron, o I have been fully atisfied by frequent experience, that the bare ubtance performs the Cure ooner, and better than any of the common Preparations of it; for buie Chymits make this, as well as other excellent Medicines wore rather than better, by their pervere and over-officious diligence. I have alo heard, and if it be true, it much trengthens our aertion, that the crude Mine, as it is digg'd out of the Earth, is more effectual in curing Dieaes, than Iron that has pas'd the Fire, and bin purified by fuion: So the Author affirms, but I have not yet try'd whether it be o or not. This I certainly know, that
there is no excellent and powerful Remedy, which has not received its chief Vertues from Nature: Upon which account, grateful Antiquity call'd excellent Medicines God's handicraft. Next to the ubtance of the teel, I chue the Syrrup of it, prepared with the fileings of Steel or Iron, infued in the cold in Rhenih Wine, 'till the Wine is ufficiently impregnated, and afterwards trained, and boiled up to the conitence of a Syrrup, with a ufficient quantity of Sugar. Nor do I ue any purging Medicine at et times, during the whole Chalybeat coure, for I think the Vertue of the Steel is detroy'd by a purge in hyterical Dieaes; and when the chief deign is to reduce the Spirits to order, and to renew and confirm their Sytem.
