If any one objects that fileings of Steel may hurt thoe that take them, by ticking in their Bowels, unles they are purged now and then; I anwer firt, that I never found any uch thing in any one, and it is much more probable, that being involved in the lime, and with the Excrementious humours of the parts, they hould at length pas away with them, than when they are exagitated by purging Medicines, which occaion unuual compreions, twiting and contraction of the guts, whereby the particles of the teel, thrut upon the coats of the Bowels, may penetrate deeper into them. When the patient is in a Steel coure, remedies commonly call'd Hyterics are to be ued, as it were by the by, to comfort the Blood and animal Spirits; in that manner and form, which is mot agreeable to the ick. But if he can take them in a olid form, they will more powerfully retain the Spirits in their office and place, than things that are liquid; for the very ubtance affects the Stomach longer with its avour, and works more forcibly upon the body, than either decoctions or infuions. Being about to anwer all the indications
I have touched upon above, I ue to precribe thee few and common things, which commonly do what I deire. Let eight ounces of blood be taken from the Arm, the next Morning let her enter upon the ue of the Pills of Coch. Major and of Cator, as they are mentioned in the Chapter of the Green-Sicknes, and let them be repeated, as it is there ordered. Take of Galbanum diolved in tincture of Cator, and trained three drams, Tachamacha two drams, make a Plaiter to be apply'd to the Navel.

Take of black Cherry-water, of Rue-water, and compound Briony-water, each three ounces, of Cator tyed up in a Rag, and hanged in a glas half a dram, of fine Sugar a ufficient quantity, make a Julep, whereof let her take four or five poonfuls when he is faint, dropping into the firt Doe, if the Fit is violent, twenty drops of Spirit of Harts-horn.

After the Purging Pills are taken, let her ue the other Pills made of fileings of Steel and extract of Wormwood, mentioned in the Chapter of the Green-icknes, according to the directions there et down; or he may take the Bolus there mention'd, if he likes a Bolus better than Pills.

Take of choice Myrrh and Galbanum, each one dram and an half, of Cator fifteen grains, with a ufficient quantity of Peruvian Balome, make twelve Pills of every dram; let her take three every Night, and drink upon them three or four poonfuls of compound Briony-water thro' the whole Coure of this proces.
But if the Pills lat precribed move the Belly, which ometimes happens in Bodies that are very eaily purged, by reaon of the Gum that is in them, the following are to be ued.

Take of Cator one dram, of volatile Salt, Amber, half a dram, with a ufficient quantity of extract of Rue,
make 24 mall Pills, let her take three every Night.

But it is to be noted that Steel Medicines in whatoever form or Doe they are taken, occaion ometimes in Women great diorders both of Body and Mind, and that not only on the firt days, which is uual almot in every body, but alo almot all the time they are taken; in this cae the ue of Steel mut not preently be interrupted at thoe times, but Laudanum mut be given every night for ome time in ome hyteric water, that they may the better bear it; but when the ymptoms are mild, and it eems that the buines may be done without taking teel, I think it ufficient to bleed, and to purge three or four times, and then to give the altering hyteric Pills above-mentioned, Morning and Evening for ten days.
It is to be noted that ome Women do o abhor hyteric Medicines, that they are much injured thereby, therefore they mut not be given to uch.

If the blood is o very feeble, and the confuion of the Spirits o great, that teel ordered to be us'd, according to the method precribed, is not ufficient to cure the dieae, the Patient mut drink ome mineral waters impregnated with the Iron Mine, uch as are Tunbridge, and ome others lately found out. But this is more epecially to be oberved in drinking of them, viz. That if any Sicknes happens, that is to be refer'd to hyteric ymptoms, in this Cae the Patient mut forbear drinking them a day or two, 'till that ymptom that hindered their paage is quite gone.

But if the Dieae by reaon of its obtinacy will not yield to teel-waters, the Patient mut go to the Bath; and when he has ued thee waters inwardly three Mornings following, the next day let her go into the Bath, and the day following let her drink them again; and o let her do by turns for two whole Months.
Venice Treacle alone, if it be ued often, and a long while, is a great remedy in this Dieae.

Spanih Wine medicated with Gentian, Angelica, Wormwood, Centaury, the yellow rind of Oranges, and other Corroboratives infus'd in it, does a great deal of good, ome poonfuls of it being taken thrice a day, if the woman be not of a thin and cholerick habit of Body.

The Peruvian-Bark alo wonderfully comforts and invigorates the Blood and Spirits, a Scruple being taken Morning and Evening. But if any of the Remedies above-mention'd do not well agree, which often happens in cholerick and thin Constitutions, then a Milk Diet may be ued; but nothing does o much trengthen the Blood and Spirits, as riding much on Horeback every day for a long while. If the Dieae be uch, or o great a one, that it will not bear a truce 'till it may be cured with Medicines that corroborate the Blood and Spirits, we mut preently make ue of hyteric Remedies, as Aa-faetida, Galbanum, Cator, Spirit of Sal-Armoniack, and whatever ele has a filthy and ungrateful mell.

To conclude, if ome intolerable pain accompanies this Dieae, or if their be violent Vomitings, or a Loones, then beides hyteric Medicines above-mentioned, Laudanum mut be ued, which is only able to retrain thee ymptoms. But in quieting thee pains which vomiting occaions, we mut take great care that they are not mitigated, either by Laudanum, or any other Paregorick, before due evacuations have been made, unles they almot exceed all humane patience; but if the Sick has vomited a great while, you mut give Laudanum without delay, and uch a doe as is not only equal to the violence and duration of the ymptom, but uch an one as is ufficient to vanquih it.

div.head: Of Barrennes.
div.p: BArrennes is an impotence to conceive, coming from defect either of the Genitals, or of the blood, or of the mentruous blood.

Firt, through the defect of the Genitals, either by the cloing up of the Orifice of the womb, which may be cut and opened by Art; or through the narrownes of the parts, for o they will not admit the Yard; or by reaon of ome Ulcers or Excrecencies in the neck of the womb. Or by reaon of ome fault in the eed, either the woman being too young, or too old, or through ome ditemper in the Veels dedicated to generation, and then the woman perceives very little or no pleaure in the act of Copulation. The Cure of this is referred to the Chapter of the ditempers of the womb.
Or when there is not that due proportion of eed which ought to be in both parties, which chiefly aries from the ue of thoe things that extinguih barrennes, as Mint, Rue, Camphire.

Or from Inchantments; and then the man cannot lye with his wife; or though he hould, yet cannot emit the eed: Againt which it is affirmed that the drinking a draught of cold water that drops from the mouth of a young Stone-hore as he drinks, and aved in a little veel, is very potent.

Or when the womb doth not draw the eed which is ejected, and that by reaon of ome cold and moit ditemper; in which cae all orrow, anger, and much leep are to be avoided; as alo the eating of Milk, freh Cheee, and any thing that is made of dough. Neither is he to eat Endive, Spinage, Beets, Lettice, Nuts, Cherries, Purlane, Onions, Garlick, or uch like; nor much broth, vinegar, and fat fleh. In the
next place, the womb mut be cleaned from over-abundance of moiture, with yrup of Wormwood, with the decoction of Harts-tongue, Fennel, Cumin, and Anieed.
After this take once every 14 days, a dram of bleed Pills, fating five hours after them.

Take alo of thee following Pills. Take of Labdanum, Agaric, Wax, and Sheep uet tryed, of which you may make Pills to take two or three of them every morning, or ue this confection: Take haven Ivory, Ah keys, yellow and wild Rape-eed, Siler mountain, with red and white Behen, of each one dram, Cinamon, Galingale, long Pepper, Cloves and Mace, Balam-wood, Roemary-flowers, Blatrae, Byzantiae, Marjoram, Penny-royal, of each four cruples, Baulm, Buglos, Citron Pils, of each two cruples, Pearls one cruple, Musk 2 grains, white ugar twenty four ounces; eeth this with Malmey, and make thereof a Confection.

Or becaue of ome Dieaes in the parts; where note, that too much fatnes of the Call doth cloe the mouth of the womb: uch women mut not leep much, epecially in the day time; they mut ue trong Clyters that are warm and dry, and purge often.

Or when the Womb doth not attract the eed when it is cat in; which proceeds from a moit intemperance, which is by the looenes of the fibres of the Womb, o that the Womb cannot contract it elf; which is cured as in the moit ditemper: Or by reaon of the thicknes of the Womb; for then the blood that increaes the eed doth not lide down to that place. The cure hereof requires a thin diet, purging and weating; or by reaon of the lipperines thereof, which happens by reaon of the running of the whites in women: The cure whereof conits in the topping
of the whites, which hath been already treated of, or by reaon of the gaping of the Orifice, which hath been occaioned either by difficult birth, or by ome abortion. The cure is performed by atringent Medicines, among which the chiefet are the fomentation of Lentisk and Myrtle; or by reaon of ome udden cough or neezing, immediately after copulation, by which the eed is haken forth. Or when the Womb doth not alter the eed that is cat in, through an immoderate cold ditemper.

Sometimes through heat, and then it would be requiite to avoid hot air, and to keep the part about the womb cold; the eating of hot meats and pices mut be avoided. Purge after blood-letting in the Bailick vein of the right hand, with Electurium de Epythymo, and juyce of Roes, of each two drams and a half, whey four ounces, mix them well together, and take them in the morning, leeping on, and fating four hours upon. Purge alo with Triphera Saracenica, and Rheubarb, with potions prepared and mixed with yrup of Roes, Violets, and Endive. Take Pitacia, Eringo's, of each half an ounce, of Saffron a dram, Lignum Aloes, Galangal, Avens, Mace, red and white Behen, Baulm-flowers, of each four cruple, havings of Ivory, and Caia rinds, of each two cruples, yrup of Ginger confected twelve ounces, white Sugar ix ounces; eeth thee together with the yrup in 12 ounces of Baulm-water, untill it be all boyled away; when it is cold, put ome more water to it, and tir them together; and at lat of all, mix with it a cruple and a half of Musk and Amber: of this Conerve let the woman take thrice a day; to wit, in the morning, an hour before upper, and an hour after dinner.

Or it proceeds from obtruction of the Flowers; in which cae, firt let blood in the Bailick vein, then
purge with Opoponax, and Hiera Compoita, of each half a dram, to be made up into even Pills, to be taken in the morning, leeping upon them an hour and a half, with a draught of ugar'd water five hours after; or with a potion of yrup of vinegar compounded, yrup of Hemp agrimony, of each three quarters of an ounce; Feverfew, Mugwort, and Elecampane roots, of each an ounce, and mix them together: Then he may put up into the Womb a peary of Musk, Amber, Aloes-Wood, and Ah keys, of each three grains, Saffron half a cruple, Hares rennet as much as uffices, which being made up like a good big Tent, he mut keep a whole day in her Body.

div.head: Of the bringing up of Children, and of their Dieaes.
Of the Dieaes of the Head.
div.p: THE Dieaes common to Children, are firt certain little ulcerous riings, chiefly in the Head; ometimes in the whole Body; they arie from ome vitious humour either collected in the Womb, or out of the Womb, by reaon of the badnes of the milk containing a erous, alt, and nitrous quality: If there be no ill to be upected, the humour may be driven forth by giving the Child ome Syrup of Fumatory, or Harts-horn burnt: The Nure is to be purged, and the matter offending to be tempered with Syrup of Borage, or Fumary: If there be much corruption under the Crut of the Scab, the Head of the Child is to bo bathed with ome oftning decoction, and then to be anointed with ome drying Ointments.

Sometimes they are troubled with an inflamation of the Head, with which is joined a hollownes in the forepart of the Head; and in the Eyes; it may arie from the milk, if the Nure be ubject to drink overmuch
trong drink; in the Cure, you mut beware of applying things which are too refrigerating.

They are alo many times affected with a kind of Epilepie, which proceeds ometimes from extraordinary frights, from Milk that lies corrupted in the tomach, and ometimes from Worms moving themelves in the guts; and ometimes it is the conequent of other Dieaes. The Cure is to be oberved, partly in the Fit, and partly after the Fit: The Smaragd-tone, and the Hoof of a wild Elk put into the left Ear are very profitable, and take good effect; vomiting alo, and this Emplaiter of white Amber, Frankincene, and Matick, of each a dram and a half, Galbanum, Opopanax of each a cruple, Mileto of an Oak two drams, Ambergreece ix grains, Musk three grains, eed of Male Peonie half a dram, Labdanum, one dram and a half, a little Oil of Nutmeg, and prinkled with the dut of Cubebs; the forepart of the head may be alo anointed with Oil of white Amber. Fears and tarting in the Child's leep, are occaioned from the putrid Vapours which are carried up with the animal Spirits, and arie from the Stomach; therefore they happen to Infants that uck greedily. In the Cure, care mut be taken that the Child do not fill it elf too unreaonably, and provide that good and ound Milk may be generated, and that the Children be not put to leep upon a full tomach: The tomach of the Child anointed near the orifice with Oil of Quinces, and Matick, and Oil of Nutmegs. Before leep diolve a little roll of Diamoch in Milk, and give the Child; unles the Child be over-much troubled with heat, you may give it a little Treacle once in a week; over-much watching, or weaknes, is occaioned by harp Vapours which arie out of the tomach, by reaon of the badnes of the Milk; ometimes it is occaioned
by Feavers, and pain of ome peculiar parts; there is nothing better than to anoint the oles of the Childs feet with Marrow, which hath no danger in it, rather than to give the Child tronger Opiates. A looking aquint; in new born Children is cured by putting a Candle oppoite to the place where the Child cats its Eyes.

Moitnes of the Ears, by reaon of the moitnes of the Head, gathers quantity of humours together: The Cure of this mut not be over-haty; yet the Urine of Children ditilled and dropt into the Ear, is a very approved Remedy.

div.head: Bignes and welling of the Head in little Children.
div.p: SOmetimes in Children that are newly born, the Head grows to an extraordinary bignes which come to pas, either by reaon of abundance of water contained in the ame, which water is contained, either between the skin and the Pericraneum, or between the bone and the Pericranium, or between the bone and the Membranes called the Dura Mater, and the Pia Mater.

Or by reaon of abundance of Vapours gathered together between the bones and the skin of the head, which caue the head to grow to uch an extraordinary bignes, that it caues oftentimes the death of the Child.

If water be gathered together between the bone of the head, and the Membranes of the Brain, it caues a giddines and Epilepy to the Infant, without being able to take any ret. For the Cure of the windy affection you may ue fomentations, in cae the wind be contained only between the skin and the Pericranium; for which purpoe, you may take of the leaves of Sage, Betony, Agrimony, weet melling flag, and wild Margerom, of each a handful; Anieed and Fennel eed, of each two drams; Camomile flowers, Melilot, and red Roes, of each one handful; boil all thee in common
water, adding to it a little Wine, and thereof make a Fomentation for the part affected, which may be aited with a plaiter made of Oil of Anieeds, and bitter Almonds, of each one Ounce, Oil of Camomile an Ounce and a half, Laurel and Juniper Berries, of each two drams, Anieeds and Fennel-eeds, of each one dram and a half, of the bet Wine a pint; boyl them to the conumption of the Wine, adding to the ret half an ounce of Venice Turpentine, and as much Wax as is ufficient: As for the watry ditemper though it be difficult to Cure, yet you mut try this Fomentation to diget this Humour: Take Wormwood, Betony, creeping Time, Pennyroyal leaves, of each a handful, red Roe leaves, and leaves of Stoechas, a little handful, Cypres Nuts, Orange-flowers, and Florentine Orrice, of each two drams, boil them all in a Lye made of Vine-twigs and talks; after which you may ue this Plaiter. Take the powder of Bettony, Sage and Wormwood, of each two drams, Oil of Camomile and Roes, of each two Ounces, Unguenti Comitiae one ounce, as much Wax as is ufficient: But if thee Remedies profit nothing, the only means left is to open the Head.

div.head: Of the Dieaes of the Eyes, Ears, and Noes in Children.
div.p: MANY times Children are troubled with a light inflamation in their Eyes, with a certain gum, and thicknes which hinders them from opening the eyelid: The mot preent remedies are, either for the Nure to wah the Eyes with a little of her Breat milk, or ele with a little Plantain and Roe-water mixt together.

Sometimes the Notrils are o topt that they are not able to draw their Breath, but with much pain. For the Cure of which, the Nure mut moiten a linnen Cloath in a little Ointment of Roes, or a little very good Pomatum, 'till the hard matter within be diolved.

Many times there flows a moit humor from their heads, which happens to thoe who have moit brains in the cure of this it mut be the care of the Nure to cleane the ears, both within and without; afterwards let her drop into them a little oyl of bitter Almonds, and Honey of Roes mixt together.

div.head: Of certain Ulcers in Childrens mouths.
div.p: THere do many times grow a certain kind of Ulcers in Childrens mouths: For the cure of which the Nure in the firt place mut ue a good and ound diet, then mut the Ulcers themelves be rub'd with a little Honey of Roes, and yrup of Violets, with a drop or two of Plantain-water; or you may wah them with half an ounce of Roe-water, or Plantain-water, in which put half a dram of Vitriol; if they be very red and inflamed, take Brambles, flowers of Pomgranates, Roes, Sanders, of each two drams, Allum half a dram; boyl them in water, afterwards train them to the quantity of three ounces, in which diolve half an ounce of yrup of Mulberries.

If they be white, take Amber, Frankincene-wood, Cypres-Nuts, Pomegranate flowers, of each two drams, flowers of Roes and Myrtles, of each half a handful; boyl them in water to the conumption of four ounces, wherein diolve an ounce and a half of Honey of Roes.

div.head: Of certain other Tumours, called Paroulis and Epoulis.
div.p:
PAroulis is a little welling, red, and inflamed, and is ingendered commonly of a hot cholerick blood, or ele from a alt flegm that falls down upon the gums, cauing not only the gums, but the neck and chaps to be welled. For the cure, you may anoint the gums with this oyntment: Take of fine Flower eleven drams, powder of Tragachanth one dram, burnt Allum one cruple, Roe-water one ounce; if there be any
inflammation, rub the gums with a mucilage made of the eed of Quinces, made with Roe-water, and Plantain-water, adding to it a little yrup of Jujubes. If the welling be obtinate, bring it to a uppuration with Figs, Raiins, Jujubes, Liquorih, and French Barley, well boyled; when it is opened and launced, cleane and dry it with hony of Roes yrup of Roes and Cherries.

The Epoulis is a little excrecence of Fleh hapning between the teeth, but mot commonly the great teeth. Take the root of Buglos an ounce and a half, Plantain, Agrimony a handful, whole Barly a mall handful, red Roes half a handful, Pomgranate flowers 2 drams, 4 Dates, a dram and a half of Liquorih; make a decoction and train it, and then add to it an ounce of yrup of Roes, and Pomgranates, to wah the place affected: you alo may wah it with this Remedy. Take of the juice of Pomgranates and Quinces, of each half an ounce, juice of Barberies and Lettice of each two drams, a little of the decoction of Lentils, and red Roes.

div.head: Of the two trings under the Tongue of a Child,
div.p: THere is one of thee Strings or Ligaments, which appears, reaching from the bottom of the tongue, and extending it elf to the top of the tongue; this mut be cut off firt with a pair of Cizers, and the place rub'd with a little Moche Salt.

There is another Ligament which ries from the root, and extendeth it elf to the middle of the tongue, which is more hard and large, which hinders the tongue either from being tretched out, or to be moved in the mouth. The Cure hereof belongs wholly to the Chirurgeon.

div.head: Of the Cough in Children.
div.p: THE Cough in Children comes either from the ditillation of ome cold and harp humor ditilling from the brain: If the humor be cold, the Child is alo troubled with a vicous and limy Flegm, which lies in the paages of repiration: If the humor flowing down be hot, the face of the Infant will be red; if it come of a cold humor, the Child mut be kept indifferently warm, giving it a little oyl of weet Almonds and Sugar-candy; it will not be amis alo to wah the feet of the Child in Ale, wherein certain Cephalick herbs have been boiled, and after that to anoint the plants, or oles of his feet with Gooes fat.

The breat of the Child may be alo rubbed with oyl of weet Almonds, and freh-butter, and upon this put little linnen cloaths omething warm. If it be accompanied with any vicous matter, or flegm, you may give the Infant a little yrup of Maiden-hair, or yrup of Liquorih, and Hyop mingled together; or give the Infant this water to drink; Take of Rain-water, and Fountain-water, of each a pint, white Sugar one ounce, Honey an ounce, Vinegar two drams; boyl them altogether, and clarifie them, and let the Infant drink it.

div.head: Of breeding Teeth.
div.p:
IN breeding Teeth, the difficulty and pain that the Child endures, is eaily perceived; and whether that be the thing which the Child is afflicted with, may be eaily gueed at by the time of breeding teeth, which is about the eventh month; beide, the Infant is perceived to be often putting his fingers in his mouth, and the Nure perceives the Infant to gripe her breats hard, &c. the place where the teeth are about to break out looks white; there are alo watchings, and the ene of a very great pain. The welling gums are to
be anointed with Hares brains boyled, or the fat of it. If they be inflamed, wah them with oyl of Roes, and white Wax, and the juyce of Night-hade: if they be exulcerated anoint them with butter that hath no Salt in it, with a little Honey and powder of Frankincene.

div.head: Of the inflammation of the Navel-tring in Infants.
div.p: SOmetimes after the binding of the Navel-tring, it happens to exulcerate: for the cure ue an emplaiter of Pompholyx, or anoint it with oyl of Roes, and a little Populeon.

div.head: Of the Worms.
div.p: OFtentimes Children are extreamly troubled with Worms; they are generated of a vicous and flegmy humor; are ometimes round, and then Children are commonly troubled with a Feaver, and grow lean, their appetite fails them, they tart in their leep, they have a dry cough joyned with it, with a tinking breath, and an ill colour in their faces; the eyes hollow and dark with a kind of irregular Feaver, which comes three or four times a night, and they often rub their noes; if they be little worms, they have always a deire to go to tool, and their excrements are very purous. If the Infant be young, the Nure mut be ure to keep a good diet, abtaining from all raw fruits, Peae and Beans, and all milky things, and any thing that hall be of a hard concoction: Next, you may lay a plaiter of the Mas of Pills Sine quibus, half a dram, pouder of Wormwood one dram, Myrrh and Aloes of each two cruples, meal of Lupines a dram and a half, the Gall of an Ox as much as ufficeth; if the Infant be any thing grown, you may give him in a little broth a mall quantity of Harts-horn.

div.head: Of the Convulion in Infants.
div.p:
THe Signs of Convulion are the hanging backward of the head, inomuch that the hinder part of the
head eemeth to touch the houlders; ometimes the head and the neck hang o far forward, that the Chin touches the Breat.

The Cure of this: If it come of too great abundance of humours, let the Air wherein the Child is nured be hot and dry, and exercie much; let the Nure not leep long, epecially after dinner; and let her diet be rather drying than any way moit. If the Child do not uck he mut avoid Meats that do trouble the head, and fill it up with Vapors, or limy meats that may top the paages of the Veins: Sweet things are very hurtful, but Honey and Water wherein a little Sage and Betony have been boiled, it will not be amis to give him: If purgation be needful, let the Nure rather than the Child purge, which may be performed with Caia or Manna. If the Child be any thing big, let his Belly be kept looe, by giving him a little water wherein Sena hath been teeped 24 hours, tempering it with a very mall quantity of the juice of Citron; or you may give him a little of the pouder of Diacarthamum in the pap of an Apple.

If the Convulion comes of drines or emptines, or by reaon of ome great evacuation, flux of the Belly, vomiting, hunger, or the like, the Child mut be nured in an Air more moit than dry, and his diet mut be the ame. The bet and mot approved remedy is to apply a cautery in the hinder part of the Head to the nook of the Neck, between the econd and third Vertebra, which may be done to new born Children; Frictions alo of the Legs, Back-bone and Thighs are very profitable; as alo Cupping-Glaes applied to the Thighs and Legs.

If the Convulion come by reaon of the Worms, you may give him this Clyter. Take of imple Hydromel four ounces, new butter one ounce, powdered
Aloes half a dram, and make a Clyter. Or you may give him two drams of Earthworms killed, dried and poudered, Sugar poudered one ounce, and let the Child take two drams of it every day in a poonful of Lettice-water.
If any venemous Vapour be the caue hereof, let him take ix grains of Treacle, or Mithridate in Mint-water.

div.head: Of the welling of the Hypochondria in Infants.
div.p: WHICH caueth Children by reaon of the narrownes of the Mouth of the Stomach to be troubled with a difficulty of breathing: It arieth from the greedines of the Infant, which either ucks too great a quantity of Milk, or of other Meats. The inward Cure of this is performed by adminitring the Powder of the root of Orrice or Paeonie.

div.head: Of Cotivenes in Children.
div.p: THIS proceeds from the unskilfulnes of the Nure in the Dieting of the Child, or from a cold and dry Ditemper of the Guts, or from the hot and dry Ditemper of the Bowels; in this cae the Belly may be well looned with Caia, or with a liniment compoed of new Oil of weet Almonds, Gooe fat, May butter, Ointment of Marhmallows, of each two drams, Colocynth. gr. ixteen, one cruple of Salt, Species Hierae one cruple, Diagridion four grains; make of this an ointment, and anoint the Navel.

Or it proceeds from a vicous Flegm, which wraps about and holds the dregs, which may be remedied by a uppoitory of Moue Dung, and Goats uet, or by the ue of an Emplaiter of Aloes, Bulls-gall, Myrrh, and May butter, to be laid upon the Navel.

div.head: Of looenes in Children.
div.p:
LOoenes of the Belly happens either in the time of Teeth breeding, or out of the time; in the time of breeding Teeth, either by reaon of the corruption
of the nutriment, or by reaon of overmuch watching through the pain of the Teeth, or by reaon of a Fever, and ome unnatural heat: It mut not be uddenly topt, if it be not over copious, and that the Infant can endure it; the Belly mut be afterwards cleaned with Roes olutive, and afterwards topped; great obervation being had whether the caue come from a hot or cold Ditemper.

div.head: Of Burtnes in Children.
div.p: BUrtnes happens to Children, either by reaon that the Peritonaeum is burt through crying, or falling, or playing with the Thighs: For the Cure whereof the Child mut be kept quiet, and till from crying; upon which, after the part affected is well bound up, you may give the Child inwardly of the eence of the greater Comfrey one poonful, with two drops of Balam of Sal Gemma. You may alo foment the place with a fomentation made of the roots of the greater Comfrey, and Omund Royal, the bark of Elm, and Ah, Knot-gras, each half an ounce, the leaves of Plantain, Mullein, Rupture wort, Horetail, Flowers of Camomile, red Roes, and Melilot, of each a handful and a half, Balaut, Cypres Nuts and Acorns, of each two drams; put thee into two bags, and boil them in equal parts of owre Wine and Smiths water, for a Fomentation to be ued for a quarter of an hour; then you may lay on a Plaiter of the red drying Ointment eleven ounces, pouder of Matick, Olibanum, and Sarcocol, Cypret Nuts, of each one dram, with a little Wax and Oil of Matick to make a Plaiter, which mut be put upon the place affected, and bound down with a little pillow.

Sometimes this burtnes proceeds from a watry humour abounding in the Abdomen, which decending into the Cods caueth them to well; for which you
may ue with good ucces this Ointment: Take of Unguent. Comitis. and the red drying Ointment, of each two ounces, Pigeons dung half an ounce, live Sulphur three drams, powder of Lawrel Berries, and Mutardeed, of each a dram, Oil of Dill, and Venice Turpentine of each three drams, Wax as much as ufficeth: This is alo an extraordinary remedy for the burtnes proceeding from Wind.

div.head: Of the Inflammation of the Navel.
div.p: THE Inflammation of the Navel arieth when the blood gathers thither by reaon of ome external hurt; the danger is very great, if it hould Apotemate, and o the Guts fall down; and therefore uppuration mut be hindred as much as may be.

div.head: Of the jutting forth of the Navel.
div.p: THIS differs from the Inflamation, becaue here the Navel doth not give way to the touch, neither is the colour of the Skin changed, neither is there any very great pain, or Pule, unles the Intetines are very much fallen; it proceeds from the ill binding thereof at firt, which is incurable; or when a greater portion than needs of the Navel tring is left. Secondly, from a laxation of the Peritonaeum, and then the tumour is equal, nor doth the Navel jut forth very far: In the Cure hereof, you mut let the Child abtain from all windy meats, and from much crying. Sometimes it is occaioned by the rupture of the Peritonaeum; the welling is hardly perceived when the Child lies upon his back, but increaeth and wells forward when he walks, its, cries and bawls: In the Cure of this, the Mos that grows upon the wild Prune Tree, is very much commended; or you may make little wathbands of Leather, and anoint them with Oxycroceum.

div.head: Of the Stone in the Bladder.
div.p:
THIS is known by the coming forth of the Urine by drops and with pain, which is ometimes unmixed,
ometimes containing a kind of erous humour, ometimes died with a little blood: It is produced either by the Milk which is engendred of meats that do increae the Stone, or through a hot ditemper of the Liver, which attracts the Chyle, and ends it unaltered to the Bladder: For the Cure you mut ue Baths, among which this is commended to anoint the Bladder withal; take Oyl of Scorpions, Oyl of bitter Almonds, Conies Greae, and Hens Greae, of each an ounce and a half, and of the juice of Pellitory of the Wall two ounces: Or take Sal Tartar one ounce, Parly-water a Pint, mix them through a fine paper rubbed over with the Rinds of Oranges, and give a mall quantity thereof.

div.head: Of the not holding of the Urine.
div.p: THis arieth either from the Mucle, which huts the orifice of the Bladder, which is o dipoed, that it is looed upon the leat exciting of the Urine, and grows o into a habit, that it many times accompanies them to their Graves; or from the tone in the Bladder, or from the weaknes of the Sphincter proceeding from a cold and moit ditemper; which is cured partly by the good diet of the Nure, and partly by convenient Medicines, among which a bath made of Sulphur, Nitre, and the leaves of Oak, is exceeding good.

div.head: Of the Intertrigo.
div.p: WHen the little skin in the Hips is eparated from the true skin; it aries firt from the harpnes of the Urine, epecially in Children that are more corpulent, by reaon of the dirt which frets the skin, being gathered together in the wrinkles. Bath the place, and then prinkle upon it either white Nihili, or anoint it with Oyl of Litharge.

div.head: Of Leannes.
div.p:
THis aries either from a ubtle kind of Worms, which are generated in the mot muclely parts
of the Back and Arms, and conume the Body; they break forth ometimes like to black hairs; if you wah thoe parts with a Bath mixed with Bread and Honey, they are taken away either with a Razor, or with a crut of bread. Secondly, it aries from the mall quantity of milk, which is oftentimes remedied by changing the Nure.

div.head: Of the difficulty which Children have to make water.
div.p: IF the Dieae proceed from harpnes of the Urine, the Nure mut ue uch a way of diet as is proper for the tempering and cooling of the blood; he mut be purged, and let blood, uing afterwards cooling and refrigerating broths. If it proceed from any gros humor ingendered in the Bladder, the Nure mut abtain from all meats that do breed gros humors, as milky meats, Peae and Beans, and uch like.

If the Child be troubled with gravel, which may be perceived by the whitenes and rawnes of the Urine, with a gravelly etling at the bottom, and the continual pain in making water: If the Child be any thing big, let a potion be given him of an ounce and a half of weet Almonds, an ounce of Pellitory water, and two drams of the juyce of Lemons; ue as much of this at a time as is convenient. Or take of this powder, of the blood of a Hare ix ounces, of the root of Saxifrage one ounce, burn them in an earthen pot; and if the Infant uck, give him a cruple of this powder in a little milk.

div.head: Of the Inflammation of the Almonds of the Ears.
div.p:
IF the Child be very mall, you mut wah the throat as near the root of the Tongue as may be with a linnen cloth, tied to a tick dipped in this Gargarim; Take of new extracted Caia one dram, yrup of dry Roes one dram and a half, ix ounces of the decoction of Coriander. Or you may anoint the Neck with Oyl of Violets, and Camomile, binding the Neck with a
little roller well anointed with the ame; when the Child goes to bed, you may give him in a poon a little yrup of dried Roes, of Pavot and Nenuphar mingled together, Oxycrate alone doth make an excellent Gargarim.

If they come to a Suppuration, you mut ue this Gargarim: Take of the decoction of Barley, Plantain, Agrimony, Speedwell, Honey-uckle, and herb Rob ix ounces; in which diolve Honey of Roes, and Sugar-Candy, of each half an ounce, to make a Gargarim.

div.head: Of Vomiting.
div.p: IF it proceed from abundance of milk which the Child ucks, you mut take care that the Child uck les and often.

If it come from any ill humor contained in the tomach, beides that the Nure mut keep a very good diet, the Infant mut be purged with a mall expreion of Rheubarb, giving it afterwards a little Mint-water, weetned with yrup of Quinces to comfort the tomach; putting afterwards upon his tomach this Plaiter: Take of the pulp of condited Quinces two ounces, red Roes, Wormwood, and red Saunders, of each two drams, Oyl of Quinces as much as ufficeth; make a plaiter of this, and lay it upon the tomach of the Child.

div.head: Of the Hicquet.
div.p:
IF it come from an over much repletion, it will not be amis to make him Vomit, of whatoever age he be; or if it be neceary that a greater force hould be ued, you mut try to make him Vomit by putting down the Throat a feather dipt in oyl: If from the badnes of the Nures mi • k, he mut be changed for a better; if from the coldnes of the tomach, you mut ue remedies to comfort it, as little Tablets of Diarrhodon,
of which you mut diolve a cruple in the Milk of the Nure; you mut alo chafe the tomach of the Child with Oyl of Wormwood, Matick, and Quinces.

div.head: Of the pain of the Belly in Children.
div.p: IF the dieae come from indigetion, and moitnes, the little Infant will Vomit, and be troubled with a Flux of the Belly, and the Belly will be hard. In which cae, you may give the Infant one ounce of weet Almonds drawn without fire, and mingled with a quantity of Sugar-candy, or anoint the Belly with this ointment: Take Oyl of Camomile, and Oyl of weet Almonds, of each an ounce and a half, mingle them, and therewith anoint the Belly: If wind be the caue, you may mingle a little Oyl of Rue in the foreaid Oyntment.

div.head: Of the Small Pox in Children.
div.p: THE igns of this dieae are pains in the Head, accompanied with a Fever, rednes about the Eyes, a dry Cough, and you hall mark in the skin up and down the body, certain little pots upon the Face, Back, Breat, and Thighs. The mall Pox is dangerous if they come forth with much pain, if they be greenih, blewih, or blackih.
For the cure of this; If the Infant uck, the Nure mut keep a good order of diet, he may eat broth of Hens, with Endive, Cichory, Buglos, and Borage boiled therein.

Now to make the mall Pox come forth the more quickly; if the Child be little, the Nure mut drink this following Potion. Take of fat Figs one ounce, peeled Lentils half an ounce, Gum Lacca two drams, Gum Tragacanth, and Fennel-eed, of each two drams and a half; make of this a decoction in Fountain-water, and train it to the quantity of two pints, weeten
this either with Sugar, or yrup of Maiden-hair; let her drink of this in the morning a good glas full.

Or, you may give the Child, if it be able to take it, this Julep to be ued very often: Take of Cordial-waters two ounces and a half, yrup of Lemons one ounce, mingle it, and ue it often; four or five hours after, give him of powder of Unicorns-horn, and Bezoar. Now to keep this venomous humor from attacking the eyes, temper a little Saffron in a mall quantity of Plantain and Roe-water, and rub the eye-lids, or you may anoint them with Tutie: For keeping them from the Noe; take Roe-water, and Betony-water, of each an ounce, Vinegar half an ounce, juyce of Pomegranates ix ounces, in which teep two drams of Sanders, and two drams of the powder of Citron-peel; add to this ix grains of Saffron, and make a Medicine for the Child to mell often to; the ame Medicine will erve for the ears, by topping them with a little Cotton.

To preerve the Mouth and Throat, and Tongue, take this Gargarim; Take whole Barley one handful, Plantain leaves, leaves of Sorrel, Arnoglos, Agrimony, and Vervein, of each one handful; boyl this to the quantity of ix ounces, diolving in it yrup of dry Roes, and Pomgranates, of each half an ounce, Saffron half a cruple.

To preerve the Lungs, ue yrup of Jujubes, Violets, and Nenuphar; when they are fully come out, to make them die the more quickly, rub the Face with Oyl of weet Almonds drawn without fire. Or ue this Oyntment; Take old Lard, cut it in mall pieces, and melt it in a pot, then train it, then beat it, and mingle it with water for your ue.

When the Pox is totally dead, take this Remedy to take away the marks. Take Half the weight of two
Crowns, clear Cream two ounces, mix them together, and with a Feather dipt therein anoint the Face of the Child two or three days; this caueth the skin to grow mooth, leaving not a pit in the Face.

div.head: A Full SUPPLY

argument.p: Of uch mot ueful and admirable Secrets, which Mr. Nicholas Culpepper in his brief Treatie, and other Englih Writers in the Art of Midwifery, have hitherto wilfully paed by, kept cloe to themelves, and wholly omitted; now at lat made publick for the general good:

div.head: CHAP. I. In what manner the Generative, or Begetting Seed hath its beginning; and particularly of the four Degrees of Concoction.
div.p: THAT we may the better dicern the whole coure and order of Generation, I have thought it convenient to demontrate how great a imilitude it bears with the production of Plants: but firt it is neceary to take notice what Generative Seed is, and how extracted out of the three Concoctions.

We may oberve the natural Procreation of man to be altogether uch, as we perceive the generation and beginning of Plants or Herbs of every kind to be: For
as they every one of them from the Seed of his Kind, cat into the Womb of the Earth, do bud or increae, and do naturally grow to the perfect Form of its proper Nature: So Man alo being a reaonable Creature according to the quality of the Body, doth naturally draw his Original and Begining from the perm and eed of Man, projected and cat forth into the Womb of Woman, as into a Field: But that matter of Generation which we call perm or eed, by its original and nature, is only a uperfluous Humor, the reidue and remainder, I ay, of the nutriment and food, and the uperfluity of the third concoction in the Body, derived and conveyed along through the hidden and ecret organs or intruments from the chiefet Members of the body unto the generative parts, and erveth for generation And it hath its beginning and breeding from the reidues and remnants of all the meats belonging to the nourihment of Man, after they be altered and tranmuted even to the third Concoction: Of the uperfluity of which concocted food collected and gathered together in its proper and due manner, it is evident that the ame is ingendred, according to the contitution of the age and nature; for there is made a three-fold concoction of any meat, altered and converted into the nourihment of the living Creature, even to generation of eed, that concoction nevertheles following, which is the puret of all Concoctions: For the Food being ent down into the tomach, by chewing treightway the pure Nutriment which is ordained to the other part (the dry Excrement being driven downward thorough the Guts to the Belly) through the ucking Veins (named in Latin mearaicae) carried as it were to one Gate flowing out of innumerable Channels, is brought to the Liver; where to the dipoition of the former concoction, made in the tomach, there is forthwith
made the econd concoction in the Liver of the food derived unto it, the uperfluous matter being eparated, that is to ay, both kinds of choler, and the watrih humour drawn and attracted by the emulgent veels (in Latin vaa emulgentia) that it being trained through the kidnies, might decend down into the bladder; then the reidue, refined and cleaned in the Liver by this concoction, that is to ay blood, is conveyed over to the Heart, to receive its vital adminitration and office. In the Heart again, is made the third Concoction of the food being received at one time; for there blood having taken unto it vital and lively pirit, being diffued and ent abroad throughout the everal members of the body, doth again expel and void out that which is uperfluous in it elf, by the ecret pores and paages. At length here the Spirit changeth and turneth the blood conveyed through the permatical or eed-veels (being branches of vena cava) there alo further concocted into the nature of perm or eed, by the twined revolutions and back-turnings of the mallet veels for this purpoe, and by the glandulous or kernel'd ubtance of the Teticles, and the eed paages (which they call Paratatae) available in that behalf: So the blood, exquiitely wrought and laboured, and for the mot part converted into vital pirits, is traight-way conveyed by the Artery named Aorta, and branches thereof to all the other Members of the whole body. But in the fourth place (that we may add one thing over and above our purpoe) there is made an alteration of the food into the like ubtance of the thing nourihed, this juyce quickning and trengthning life, which being the puret of all, remained latly with the vital pirit; that in like ort being expelled, if any impure thing hall be remaining or engendred.

div.head: CHAP. II. The Generation of Man, compared with the production of Plants.
div.p:
THAT the reaon of this Generation may be made the more plain and evident unto us, we will declare by a brief demontration, that there is the ame begining of Plants and Herbs, and of other things which fall under the ame conideration; therefore as in the eeds of every kind, the grain it elf cat into the Earth, is the food, and as it were the firt ubject of all the alteration following, whereby it buds and prings, is augmented and grows up into a nature like unto it; o meat being taken, affordeth in mans body the firt matter to a variable concoction. And as in Plants we may oberve a mot certain eparation of the pure from the impure, and of the remnant from the uperfluous matter; o here we perceive a natural eparation and equetration of that which is unprofitable, from that which is profitable, by their certain degrees: For firt the eed being committed to the Earth, by and by welling with the moiture of the ame, trippeth it elf from that little skin, in which it was incloed, and pringing upward, cateth forth the ame being empty, as a dry Excrement, the grain in the mean time budding and prouting forth, that it may proceed forward toward the increae; afterward the increae and growth tretching even to the fruit dirobed and bereaved of the Flower, the econd purging cateth down the flower prung up in the top of the bough, but preerveth the hope of the Fruit, being tripped of his flower, as that thing which remaineth pure and profitable by the econd purging. Afterwards the Fruit being grown to its jut quantity, the third alteration cateth down the leaves, as the uperfluity of this degree; but ordaineth the fruit, being now o often
cleaned and purged, for the utility of mans nourihment, maturity, and ripenes being granted unto it. Put now, either the eed breaketh, the fruit lying hid in it, or ele it endeth it out by putrefaction; and being cat into the ground it hateneth again into the property of its own nature, not tending towards it elf, which is remaining, but to the likenes of its firt original, from whence it had its begining; o that in this it appeareth abolutely true, that Nature ingendereth things like unto it elf; for every thing doth naturally covet and deire the form and likenes of that form whence it is bred: Hence it comes to pas, that Apples grow not from Pears, nor Pears from any other kind of fruit, unles it be o brought about by the means of grafting and planting. And the ame thing is to be acknowledged in the generation of Man and Woman, which is to be confeed in the growing of Plants and Herbs; that becaue we ee bodies well ditinguihed by Members to be engendred of eed, we may alo believe that the ame eed is derived from the ditinct and everal parts of the body; wherefore let thoe be advied what they ay, who affirm the eed of generation to be ingendred of the Brain only, when as it is not o agreeable to the conideration of the Concoctions, nor to the contitution of the bodies. True it is, that ome, and that not a mall part, is derived from the Brain, but the chiefet part is collected together from the chiefet parts of the whole body: For if we ay, that this hould be ingendred of one or two parts only; every one would find that this conequence would follow by an infallible reaon, namely, that thoe ame parts only hould be ingendred again: Therefore we may more rightly conclude, that beides that beginning which it draweth from the Brain, it is ingendred from the whole body, and the mot epecial parts of the ame,
the effect it elf manifeting the caue, mot epecially when we ee ditinct members, and perfectly finiht, according to the due form of the body, and o truly, that the thing begotten doth anwer and agree to the contitution of the thing begetting; of feeble eed, a feeble man being born; of trong eed, a trong and luty man: By which means it happeneth that we many times ee the infirmities and ill favoured marks of the body in the Children, which are inherent in the Parents, and thee we firmly believe to have paed into them by the corruption of the eed. And thee things thus determined, may uffice to have been poken concerning the beginning and ubtance of Ingendring Seed.

div.head: CHAP. III. What coure Parents ought to take that they may beget wie Children.
div.p:
IT may well be admired, what the reaon hould be, that Nature being o wie and provident in all her actings, hould nevertheles be o overeen in a work of o pecial regard as Mankind, that for one whom he produceth wie, olid and judicious, he bringeth o many into the World of thoe that are hallow, half witted, and void of prudence: But having eriouly conider'd with my elf, and earcht into the reaon of natural caues of this o trange a matter; I eaily found the true reaon to be this, namely, that Parents apply not themelves to the act of generation, with that order and diligence that is required by nature, nor know the conditions which ought to be oberved, that their Children may prove wie and judicious. Now if by art we may procure a remedy for this, we hall have brought to the Common-wealth the greatet benefit he can receive. The main difficulty of this matter
chiefly coniteth herein, that we cannot dicoure hereof in terms o eemly and modet, as exact decency would require; but if for this reaon I hould forbear to init upon any particular note or obervation, the whole buines would be of mall validity; foramuch as divers grave Authors are of opinion, that wie men ordinarily beget foolih Children, becaue in the act of Copulation they abtain from certain diligences, which are of importance that the Son may partake of the Fathers Widom.

For the more Methodical proceeding, I have thought good to divide the matter of this dicoure into four principal parts. The firt is to hew the natural qualities and temperature which Man and Woman ought to poes, that they may ue Generation. The econd, what diligence the Parents ought to imploy, that their Children may be male, and not Female. The third, how they may become wie and not fools. The fourth, how they are to be ordered after their birth for preervation of their wit. As to the firt point: Divers both ancient and modern Authors have delivered their opinions to this effect, that in a well ordered Common-wealth, there ought to be aigned certain urveyors of Marriages, who hould have skill and judgment ufficient to look into the qualities of the perons that are to be married; and to allot to every woman a husband, and to every man a wife agreeable and proportionable to them in all repects: But whether uch a thing be of abolute neceity in a State, or no, let it lye upon the care and conideration of uch as take upon them to manage, and dipoe the affairs of Common-wealths. Hippocrates and Galen took much pains in precribing certain Precepts about this matter, with everal rules to know what ort of Women were fruitful, and what not; what men were able for generation, and what diable:
But touching all this, they deliver very little to the purpoe, and that not with uch ditinction as is requiite for the buines in hand, therefore it will be neceary to begin this dicoure from its principles, and briefly to give the ame its due order and method that o we may plainly and clearly demontrate from what Union of Parents wie children are generated, and from what fools and faineants iue. To which end is needful: Firt to be informed of a particular point of Philoophy, upon the knowledge of which depends all that which is to be delivered touching this firt point; and that's this, that man is different from Woman in nothing ele, as Galen alo oberves, than in having his genital Members without his body whereas a woman hath all the very ame parts within, o that if, when nature hath finihed her work in the formation of man, he would convert him into a Woman, there needs nothing ele to be done, aving only to turn the Organs of generation inward, and if, having formed a woman he would transform her to a man, he may effect it by doing the contrary: But whether or no thee things have hapned, as ome affirm they have, and of the certainty of Hermaphrodites being found in nature, may more commodiouly be referred to a dicoure by it elf. Now what might be the caue that the genital Members are ingendred within, or without, and that the creature becometh Male or Female, is a thing plain and evident enough to demontrate, conidering that heat extendeth and enlargeth all things, and cold retaineth and cloeth them up; o that it is concluded by all that are knowing in Philoophy and natural caues, that if the eed be cold and moit, a woman is begotten, not a man: And if the ame be hot and dry, a man is begotten, not a Woman: Whence it is to be inferred, that there is no man to be termed cold in repect of a woman, nor woman hot in repect of a man.

This therefore is to be noted as a thing without all controverie or exception, that the qualities which render a woman fruitful, are cold and moiture, the womb holding the ame proportion with mans eed, that the earth doth with Corn or any other grain; and we ee, that if the earth want cold and moiture, the eed will not proper; and that thoe are the mot fertile oyls which partake mot of cold and moit: yet thee two qualities ought to keep a certain meaurablenes, let that, either by exces, or deficiency, generation be poyled; for as the Corn is vitiated by exces of rain, and overmuch cold; o in conception the eed may be choaked by over-abundance of thee qualities; and on the other ide, if thoe parts in a woman hould be temperate as in a man, it were impoible he hould conceive, or be a woman: Nor could he breed that flegmatick blood which ingendereth milk, by which, as Galen and Hypocrates affirm, the birth is nourihed while it remaineth in the mothers belly; neither could he be beardles, or void of hair, if he were overmuch inclining to hot and dry. Nevertheles, all women are not cold and moit alike, there being of thee qualities everal degrees, ome being cold and moit in the firt degree, ome in the econd, ome in the third, and in each of thee they may conceive, if a man anwer them in proportion of heat. As for the igns of thee everal degrees of coldnes and moiture in women, though hitherto they have not been taken notice of by any, yet it will be very requiite in this place to conider them according to the everal effects, which each of thee degrees produceth. Firt, by the quick apprehenion and acutenes of wit in women, for if they be very witty and acute, they are to be judged cold and moit in the firt degree only; if very hallow and imple, in the third degree, but if they partake of a middle nature
between thee two extreams, it ignifieth that they are in the econd degree. Secondly, their Conditions; they being either curt, or good natured, according to thee three degrees. Thirdly, their voice; which is either hrill, or big according as they are more or les cold and moit. Fourthly, their ubtance in fleh; leannes being a ign of little coldnes and moiture; grones or over much corpulency, of the redundance of thoe qualities: to be meanly flehed, betokeneth the econd degree. Fifthly, the colour of their face; which is either white, or warthy, as thee qualities are intene or remis; of the econd degree is compoed a freh and lively colour. Sixthly, their hair; which is alo either much, or little, according to the exuberance, or defect of cold and moit. Seventhly, a handom form and proportion of body is the reult of the middlemot degree; deformity ariing from either Extream.

Now from all thee Signs it may be concluded, that thoe women who are cold and moit in the econd degree, are of the perfectet temper, and in the bet capacity, as to their own proper nature, of bringing forth Children.

div.head: CHAP. IV. The igns to know the everal degrees of hot and dry in a Man.
div.p:
AS there are in Women three degrees of cold and moit, o likewie in Men there are as many of hot and dry; and the ame igns which dicover thoe in women, pecifie thee in men; only, the firt, or remis degree in women holdeth a proportion with the third, or intene degree in men; as namely, whereas among women thoe have the bigget voices that are cold and moit in the firt degree; the like is to be concluded
of men that are hot and dry in the third, the defect in thoe anwering to the exces in thee: now to undertand thee temperatures the more exactly, we mut take notice of a very obervable point mentioned by Galen, which is; that the temperature of all parts of the body, epecially the brain, follows the temperature of the Teticles: and he affirmeth that they are of more importance than the Heart, alledging this reaon; namely, that the Heart is the beginning of the life only, but the Teticles are the beginning of living healthfully, and without ditempers.

div.head: CHAP. V. What Women ought to marry with what men, that they may have Children.
div.p:
IN repect of married Women that prove Childles, Hypocrates advieth this experiment to be tried, to know whether the defect be on the Womans part, or on her Husbands, which is to make her uffumigations with Incene, or Storax, with a Garment cloe wrapped about her, which may hang down on the ground, in uch ort, that no vapor, or fume may iue out, and if within a while after he feel the avour of the Incene in her mouth, he may conclude that the barrennes comes not through her own defect, but through her husbands; for as much as the fumes found the paages open, whereby it pierced up to the Notrils: But although this proof perform that effect which Hippocrates peaketh of, namely, the piercing up to the inner part of the mouth; yet this is no infallible argument of the Husbands barrennes, nor of the fruitfulnes of the Wife: Since want of Children may arie through an unapt dipoition in them both, in repect of the correpondency of qualities, for it hath oftentimes hapned that a man who could not have Children by one
wife, hath had them by another; the like alo hath befallen Women. What the correpondency hould be, which the man and wife ought to bear each to other, is expreed by Hypocrates in thee words. If the hot anwer not the cold, and the dry the moit, with meaure and quantity; that is, if there meet not in the Womb two Seeds, the one hot, the other cold, the one dry, the other moit, extended in equal degree, there can be no generation: For o marvellous a work as the formation of Man could not be perform'd, without a proportionable commixture of eeds, which could not be, if the mans eed and the womans were both of the ame temperature. To exemplify what I have aid, it is to be concluded, that a woman who is wily, ill-condition'd, hrill-voiced, lean, warthy-coloured, and deformed, (which are the igns of cold, and moit in the firt degree) may conceive by a man who is ignorant, good natured, weet voic'd, corpulent, having little hair, a well-coloured face, and a handome body, which are the igns of hot and dry in the firt degree; a woman cold and moit in the econd degree, in regard he retaineth a mean in all thoe igns above-mentioned is mot like to be fruitful, becaue he comes nearet in proportion to men of each everal temperature: But from the firt of thee Unions or Conjoynings of man and woman, are mot likely to iue the wiet children, becaue the drynes of the mother, correcteth and amendeth the defect of the father. Moreover, it is requiite that women be dryed by a mature age, and not marry over young; for from thence it comes to pas mot commonly, that children prove hallow, and indued with little wit.

div.head: CHAP. VI. What coure is to be taken that Male Children be brought into the World, not Female.
div.p:
THoe who ee the comfort of having wie Children, mut indeavour that they be born Male; for the Female, through the cold and moitnes of their Sex, cannot be endowed with o profound a judgment. We find indeed, that they talk with appearance of knowledge in light and eaie matters, but eldom reach any further than to a light uperficial mattering in any deep Science. It is a thing very well worth obervation, that, whereas the right ide of the reins, and the right teticle, are naturally more hot and dry, and the left ide of the reins with the left teticle, more hot and moit, Nature eems to have intended that which at the beginning of the World is recorded in Hitory to have been very frequent; as namely, that a woman brought forth two Children at a birth, the one Male, the other Female, the right ide which is hot and dry, being aigned to the generation of Males the left ide which is cold and moit, to the generation of Females, and it eems to have been o ordained, to that end, that for every man there might be a wife: But after the Earth came to be well increaed with people, it hapned as it appears, that this method and deign of Nature was broken off, and now not only the double Child-bearing is very rare, but a far greater number of women are daily brought forth into the World than men: Whence it is to be gathered, that either Nature is grown weary, or ele interrupted in her coure of working: However, ince this defect of Nature is to be remedied with care and diligence, if men would imploy their erious coniderations in a matter of uch importance; there are ix things to be oberved
by thoe that would obtain the accomplihment of their deire, in the deign whereof this Chapter treats. The firt is, the eating thoe orts of meats which are hot and dry, provided they have not thoe qualities in too high an exces, let thereof be engenderd a man extreamly wily and malicious, and uch a one whoe actions may prove pernicious to the Common-wealth; but rather let thoe viands be hot and dry in a moderate degree, uch as are Hens, Partridges, Turtles, Thruhes, Goats, &c. and thoe roated. The econd thing is the feeding o moderately, that the tomach may overcome and diget that meat which is eaten; for thoe very orts of meat which are in their proper nature hot and dry, yet being eaten in o great a quantity, that the nature cannot diget them, they become cold and moit alo, the immoderate drinking Wine is abolutely to be forbidden, there being no rawnes which o much endamageth generation, as that of Wine, being o vaporous and ubtle a Liquor. Whereupon a Law was anciently enacted in the Carthaginian Commonwealth, which prohibited the married couple to tate of Wine that day they were to perform the rights of the Marriage Bed. The third is, to ue much exercie, which by fretting and conuming the exceive moiture of the Seed, heateth and dryeth the ame; whereas eae, and overmuch delicacy breedeth coldnes and moiture in the Seed. And hence it comes to pas, that rich and great perons that live at eae and feed high, have for the mot part Daughters: And Hypocrates reporteth that the principal perons of the ancient Scythians, who were very effeminate and womanih, mot commonly either begot Females, or ele they proved either Eunuches, or Hermaphrodites: and being ignorant of the natural caue of this defect, he aith (and derides them for it)
that they ued to acrifice to their gods, imploring from them a remedy of that which was an effect of their mi-governance. The fourth diligence is, not to ue the act of Generation untill the Seed be well concocted and ripened, it being convenient for even or eight days before, to ue thoe meats which we have already precribed, and oberving the ame coure as Gardiners do with the Seeds which they would preerve; for they attend till they ripen, and cleane, and wax dry, ince if they hould pluck them from the talk before they are deeply eaoned, and arrived to that point which is to be required, though they hould lye in the ground never o long, they would not grow at all. The fifth point, for a man to accompany with his Wife four or five days before her natural Coures, in regard the Child immediately tandeth in need of much food to nourih it. The ixth and lat point is to procure, that both the Seed of the Husband and Wife fall into the right ide of the Womb, by which means it hapneth that Males are ingendred; the reaon of which is, as Galen affirmeth, that the right ide of the Womb holdeth affinity in temperature with the Liver, the right ide of the Reins, and the right Teticle, which we have already delivered to be more hot, as the left ide is more cold, by which Females are ingendered: To thee things there is another conideration to be added, which Galen hath alo oberved, namely, that the Seed of each Teticle, are of a different nature, for whereas that of the right Teticle cometh out more hot, more peedily, and in a leer quantity, that of the left cometh out more cold, more lowly, and in greater abundance.

div.head: CHAP. VII. What means are to be ued for preerving the Childrens wit, after they are formed.
div.p:
MAN is compounded of a ubtance o ubject to alteration and corruption, that at the ame intant in which he begins to be formed, he alo begins to fade and decline; whereupon Nature hath provided, that in mans body there hould be four natural faculties: Attractive, Retentive, Concoctive, and Expulive; the firt, concocting and altering the aliments which we eat, return to repair the ubtance that was lot, each ucceeding in his place; So that it little availeth to have ingendered a Child of the perfectet Seed, if we make no choice of the meats which afterwards we feed upon: For the Creation being finihed, there remaineth not for the creature any part of the ubtance whereof it was compoed. True it is, that the firt Seed, if it be well concocted, poeeth uch vertue, that digeting, and altering the meats, it maketh them (though bad and gros of themelves) to turn to its own good temperature and ubtance; but yet we may o far forth ue contrary meats, as the creature hall loe thoe good qualities which it receiveth from the eed whereof it was made; therefore Plato aid, that one of the things which mot brought mans wit and his manners to ruine, was, his evil bringing up in diet: For which caue, he counelled that we hould give children delicate meats and drinks, and of good temperature, that, as they grow up, they may know to abandon evil, and embrace good; the reaon whereof is very clear: For, ince at the beginning the brain was made of delicate eed, and that this member is every day impairing and conuming, and is to be repaired with meats which we eat; it followeth certainly,
that by uing uch meats as are gros, and of evil temperature, the brains will become of the ame nature: Therefore it will not uffice that the Child is born of good eed; but alo that the meat which he eateth after he is born, be indued with the ame qualities.

The ancient Greeks were very curious in this particular; Galen, and other Greek Phyicians, precribed to thoe parents who were deirous of begetting wie children, to eat much Goats milk boyled, for about even or eight days before Copulation; this meat being of a moderate ubtance, the heat exceeding not the cold, nor the moit the dry. The Greeks alo ued to extract out of the milk, the Cheee and Whey, as being the groer parts of the Milk, and left the butter; which being of a more pairy ubtance, they gave their Children, mingling it with Honey. They alo gave them Cracknels of white bread, of very delicate water, with Honey, and a little Salt. But yet, in this way of regiment and ordering of the diet, there arieth one great Inconvenience; namely, that children uing uch kind of delicate meats, will not enjoy trength ufficient to reit the injuries of the Air, or other occaions which ue to breed Maladies: And o by endeavouring that our Children may become wie, we hall caue them to become unhealthful, and hort-liv'd; Therefore it is to be conidered, how things may be o ordered, that the advancing of Childrens wit by their diet and education, may not prove inconitent with the preervation of their health and trength; which may be eaily effected, if Parents will put in practice thee Rules and Precepts which I hall precribe. Hypocrates takes notice of eight things which make the fleh plump and fat: The firt is, to be merry, and enjoy content and eae of heart; the econd, to leep
much; the third, to lie in a oft bed; the fourth, to fare well; the fifth, to be well furnihed and apparelled; the ixth, to ride much on horeback; the eventh, to have ones will, and not be croed in any thing; the eighth, to be much converant in all kind of Plays and patimes, that yield contentment and delight. That this manner of life produceth the aforeaid effect, is mot true; but is likewie true, that it caueth the eed to be moit, and that the children engendred of that Seed, mut alo abound with uperfluous moiture, which both for the production of Wit, and the preervation of health, ought to be dried up; for as much as this quality tifleth the operations of the rational oul, and alo occaioneth icknes and hort life: So that it appears, that a good wit, and a ound body, arie from one and the ame quality, namely, drynes; whence it is to be oberved, that the ame rules which we are to lay down for the making Children wie, will alo be effectual for the making of them healthy and long lived.

Firt, it behoveth for thoe Children that are born of delicious Parents, whoe contitution mut therefore necearily conit of more cold and moit than is convenient, to be wahed as oon as they are born with hot alt water, which, according to the opinion of all Phyitians, oaketh and drieth up the fleh, trengthneth the Nerves, and by conuming the uperfluous moiture of the brain, increaeth the wit, and freeth him from many dangerous Dieaes; whereas a Bath of hot water that is freh, breeds (as Hypocrates affirmeth) five inconveniences; namely, the effeminating of the fleh, weaknes of the inews, dulnes of the pirits, fluxes of the blood, and a naueating in the tomach: But thoe that are born with exceive drynes, are to be bathed in hot freh water, that the extremity of their temper may be corrected by a contrary quality. Now the reaon
why hot alt water is available for thoe that are over moit, is, becaue it toppeth the pores of the skin, and of two extreams, it is more conducing to health to have a skin hard and omewhat cloe, than thin and open.

The econd thing requiite to be performed when the Child is new born, is to make him acquainted with the winds, and with change of air, and not to keep him lockt up in a Chamber, which much enfeebleth the trength, and wateth the pirits; nothing being o advantageous to a healthful kind of living, as to expoe ones elf to all kind of winds and weathers, hot, moit, cold and dry; it is no wonder therefore that Shepherds of all men living enjoy the oundet health, ince they accutom themelves to all the everal qualities of the Air, and their nature is dimayed at nothing; whereas on the contrary we find that thoe men that give themelves to live deliciouly, and to beware let the Sun, the Wind, the Evening, or the Cold, offend them, are within a mall time dipatched with a Pot-Letter to another World. So far were the ancient Germans from nicety in this point, that they ue to dip their Children as oon as born, in a cold River.

The third thing neceary to be performed, is to eek out a young Nure of temperature hot and dry, with which two qualities the much cold and moit will be corrected, which the Infant brought from his Mothers Womb; he hould be innur'd to hardnes and want, to lye on the bare ground, to eat little, and to go poorly clad in wet, drought, and heat, uch a one will yield a firm milk, as being acquainted with the alterations of the air, and the Child being brought up by her, will come to enjoy a great firmnes of body. The coure then which is to be oberved with the Nure, is to take her into the Houe about four or five Months before the Childs birth, and to give her the ame orts
of meat to feed on, which the Mother ueth to eat, that he may have time to conume the blood and bad humors, which he hath gathered by the harmful meats he ued before, and alo to the end that the Child may uck the like milk with that which relieved it in the Mothers belly, or at leat made of the ame meats.

The fourth thing requiite to be oberved, is not to accutom the Child to leep in a oft bed, or to keep it over-warm in apparel, or give it too much meat, which are things that fatten and enlarge the Fleh; whereas the retraint of them diminiheth and dries it up, which drines increaeth wit, and much availeth toward long life, According to this Rule which I have precribed, was He, who of all men living that ever the World had, was the wiet brought up; for as oon as he was born, he began to be inur'd to cold and other alterations of the air; his firt bed was the Earth, his apparel coare; and a few days after, they went with him to Aegypt, a place very hot, and the meat they gave him, was that which I have already mentioned to have been ued by the ancient Greeks. Whereupon it is that the Prophet Eay aith, He hall eat butter and honey, that he may know to echew evil, and chue the good: For though he was very God, yet being alo perfect Man, he omitted not to make ue of the ame natural remedies as were ued by the ret of the ons of men.

Thus we have hown what the qualities are, which the Brain ought to have, and what the ubtance; having proved according to the opinion of Heraclitus, that drines maketh the wiet oul; and that by age from the day of our birth, 'till that of our death, we till acquire more and more drynes, and by conequence more knowledge. We have alo proved, that the ubtile and delicate parts of the Brain are corrected by what we eat; for thoe that always feed upon Beef and Pork, mut of neceity have a Brain o gros and of uch evil
temperature, that the reaonable oul cannot be o capable of echewing evil, or adhering to good.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Some farther Coniderations than have before been mentioned concerning the gradual progres of the Births Formation in the Womb.
div.p: COncerning the Gradual Formation of the Infant in the Womb; of the growing up of the Fibrae within the firt even days; of the Umbilical Veins and Arteries, of the Formation of the Liver, the Heart, the Brain, the Nerves, the Gritles, &c. a particular Dicoure hath been already made in this Book: It remains only that we touch upon ome things, in reference to the ame matter.

As the ue of the two Membranules that enwrap the Birth (whereof the firt is called Ambiens, Avicius, Amnium, Aurela, Abcas, Abigas, Sela, Aligas, or the Armature of the Conception; the latter Alanthoides, Bilis, Acari, Secca, Involucrum) which hath been formerly delivered, is a thing of great conequence, to be known and well conidered; o likewie is the conideration of the Umbilical Veins and Arteries a matter no les important. Thee Veins meeting together a little beneath the Navel, and extended along that concavity where the Liver is to be formed, erve for the purging of the mentruous blood, which is to be detributed through the members. The two Arteries are connected with ductile ligatures unto the great Artery: Through thoe the heart of the Embryo receives ventilation, and draws pirit, and the purer part of the blood from the Womb.

Then after the firt ix or even days, the lineaments of all the members are decribed. Next, the Lineation being perfected within the pace of between four and
eight days after, a certain anguinous matter drawn through the Navel, paeth all along through the whole Birth, and being pre-dipoed toward the formation of the members, fills up at that time the lineatures. The following days from the ninth to the fifteenth, this anguineous juice is converted into Fleh. At which time alo the Members receive their colour, and that degree of hardnes or oftnes, which is peculiar to them; like as a Painter when he hath drawn the outward lines of any Picture, in the next place, he fills it up with various colours, according as the nature of each everal part requires.

Otherwie thus,
Injectum emen ex primis rite diebus,
Et quai lac, reliquique novem fit anguis; at inde
Conolidat duodena dies, bis nona deinceps
Effigiat, tempuque equens producit ad ortum;
Talis perficitur praedicto tempore forma.
The firt ix days to milk the fruitful eed,
Injected in the Womb, remaineth till;
Then other nine of milk, red blood do breed,
Twelve days turn blood to fleh by Nature's skill.
Twice nine firm part, the ret ripe birth do make;
And thus foregoing time doth form man's hape.

To conclude this ubject, the ancients were of opinion, that the heart (which in all animals poeeth the middle eat, (like a King which hath the chief Seat of his Empire, in the midt of his Dominions) is both the firt principal member which is formed in mans body, and the lat which dies: But later Phyitians hold that the liver is firt formed, next the Heart, and latly the Brain.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Concerning the Notes of Virginity, and whether or no it may be Violated without the knowledge of man.
div.p: ABOUT the orifice of the inus pudoris, vulgarly micalled the Neck of the Womb, is that pendulous production, by ome termed the Hymen; by others (more rightly) clautrum Virginale, and by the French Bouton de Roe; for that it beareth a near reemblance with the expanded bud of a Roe or Gilli-flower; Hence therefore originally prung that common expreion of the Deflowring of Virgins.

Foramuch as the Integrity or Violation of this part is accounted the mot certain and infallible ign of Virginity intire, or violated, ome Learned Phyitians that have written of this Subject, eteem it a great vanity and folly, to think that there is any other Hymen.

Moreover, this word Flower, is ued in divers acceptations, for beides the proper ignification it is commonly taken for the prime or chief part of any thing, and o youth is called the Flower of a Mans age; or for that which is handome or elegant; and o Rhetorical expreions are called Flowers; or ele for uch things as are not marred or poiled by ue; and according to this ene a Woman deprived of her Virginity may be aid to have been Deflowred, or to have lot her Flower.

Now this Clautrum Virginale, or Flower coniteth of four Caruncles, or Flehy ubtances, called Myrtle-formed, in regard they reemble Myrtle berries.
