Thee four caruncles are ituated as it were in the four Angles of the aid Sinus Pudoris, and are connected together by certain Membranes or Ligatures, which are each of them ituated in the intertices or paces between each Caruncle, with which they are in a manner equally extended; which Membranes being once dilacerated, are an apparent ign of devirgination; nor can it be denied, but that this dilaceration may be caued by other accidents, beides the accompanying with a man; as by violent Coughing, Sneezing, or loud Vociferation; all which may occaion a violent flowing down of humours, to the breaking of thoe ligatures or membranes; but as for any Stories of a Hymen, as that it hould be a tranvere membrane, ituated now in the lower extremity of the Sinus Pudoris, now in the midt of the concavity, that it is perforated all about in the manner of a Sieve, or in the middle only with one larger hole, or that the breaking of this Hymen hould be the only caue of Devirgination, are all to be rejected as vain and Frivolous,

div.head: CHAP. X. Whether there may be a mutation out of one Sex into another; and of Hermaphrodites.
div.p: BEfore any thing can be poitively determined concerning this argument (o much of uncertainty there is in it;) it will be convenient to recite what hath been delivered both as to the negative and the affirmative, by Authors that have maintained each contrary opinion, Severinus Pinaeus, who holds the Negative, writes to this effect, viz. That the genital parts of both Sexes, are o unlike each other in ubtance much more in compoition, ituation figure, action, and ue, that carce any thing can be found more unlike, and by how much the more all other parts of the body (excepting the Breats, which in women are more tumid, becaue of their econdary ue) have an exact reemblance; o much the more unlike are the genital parts of the one Sex, compared with thoe of the other; and if their figure be thus different, much more is their ue. True it is, indeed, that both are appointed for generation, but in a different manner; for women contribute the matter, but men the form: The Venereal appetite alo proceeds from different caues; for in men it proceeds from a deire of emiion, in women, from a deire of repletion. In women alo the chiefet of thoe parts are concave, and apt to receive; but in men they are only porous, and in a manner olid.

Thee things conidered, I cannot but wonder, aith he, how any one can imagine, that the Genital Members of Female Birth hould be changed into thoe that belong to Males; ince by thoe parts only the difference
and ditinction of Sexes is made: Nor can I well impute the caue of this vulgar error to any thing, but a mitake of ome not over-expert Midwives, who have been deceived by the evil conformation of the parts, which may have happened in ome Male-births, to have had o mall a protruion, as not to have been dicerned; as appeared by the example of a Child Chritned at Paris, by the name of Joan, as if it had been a Girl, when as it proved afterwards a Boy: And on the contrary, the over-far extenion of the Clitoris in female Births, may have occaioned the like mitake. But notwithtanding what hath been thus aid in the Negative, there have not been wanting ome learned Phyitians, who have firmly aerted the affirmative part; of which number Galen himelf is one. A man, aith he, is different from a woman in nothing ele except in the having his genital members without his body: And this is certain, that if Nature having formed a man, would convert him into a Woman, he hath no other task to perform, but only to turn his genital members inward; and if a woman into a man, to do the contrary. And this, however held for a Fable, hath chanced many times in nature, as well while the Creature hath been in the Mothers Womb, as after the ame hath been born: For divers times Nature hath made a Female Child, and he hath o remained in her Mothers belly for the pace of one or two Months, and afterwards plenty of heat growing in the genital Members, upon ome occaion they have iued forth, and the Child hath become a Male; but yet retaining ome certain getures unbefitting the Maculine Sex; as a hrill voice, womanih actions, and the like. Contrariwie, Nature hath often made a Male, and cold growing on, and turning the genitals inward, it hath become a
Female; yet till retaining a manlike fahion, both in voice and geture.

Now to give an impartial judgment of thee two opinions, I cannot but hold that the latter of them carrieth a greater emblance of truth with it; for as to what Pinaeus affirms of the great difference of figure in the genital members of each, it will not be of o much force; if we conider that the inverion of them is that which chiefly occaioneth this difference of form; the reaon of which is evidently deduced from the contrary natures of heat and cold; heat enlarging and extending all things, and cold retaining and cloing them up.

Now as to the buines of Hermaphrodites, or thoe that enjoy both Sexes in one peron, many there are that will not afford any belief, or, at the leat, doubt whether or no there are any uch things in nature; but although there cannot be o apparent a reaon given for this as for the mutation of Sexes; yet in this we may uffer our elves to be guided by the ame Criterium, as in the buines of Specters and Apparitions of Spirits; concerning which, although it hath puzled many learned men to find out, what hould be the true caues and reaons, that uch things come to pas; yet it argues much indicretion not to give credit to them, both in regard Hitories have abounded with frequent examples of them in all ages; and alo, conidering the daily reports we have of uch things, both from the mouths and pens of erious and judicious men.

Perhaps it may be judged by ome, to have been more decent that thee things hould have been delivered in the Latin, than in the vulgar Tongue, that o the ecrets of Nature might not have been protituted to every unworthy Reader, that makes ue of uch things,
only for a mockery, and a May-game, and to promote idle and lacivious dicoure; yet foramuch as they are written for God's Glory, and the benefit and help of mankind, and intended only for the ue of ober, pious, and dicreet Matrons; and that the want of skill and knowledge in thee mainly important Secrets, hath been the occaion of very many mitakes, to the great miery oftentimes of Women in travail, and prejudice of the poor Infant, the concealment of them had been much more inexcuable, than the publihing can be.

q.p: vere 20 Therefore God dealt well with the Midwives.

div.p: RARE SECRETS Brought to LIGHT, Which for many years were locked up in the Breat of that mot Famous and Learned Phyician, Sir Theodore Mayern, Phyician to His late Majety, King CHARLES the Firt, Of Ever Bleed Memory.

In which are contained the ufficient Tetimonies of the renowned and happy uccees of his management in his general Practice on the greatet Ladies of the Court, and Country, in the ue of o publick a benefit, as that of the Excellent Art of MIDWIFRY.
LONDON, Printed in the Year, 1696.

div.head: TO THE Undertanding Reader.
div.p:
I Shall not need to pend many words in recommending to the World thee preent Obervations and Experiments in Midwifry, ince, had not my own knowledge and experience of them, warranted me to give a ufficient tetimony of them, It had been enough to ay, that they were the Collections of a Peron of o great a fame, and therefore of o general a practice for a long eries of years, both abroad, and in this Nation; that, not to mention his univeral inight in all parts of Learning, his judgment chiefly in matters of this nature ought not to be upected. He mut needs be an abolute tranger to all the Concerns of publick fame, and the knowledge of eminent men, who hath not been very well acquainted (though living in the remotet part of this Nation) with the high reputation of Sir Theodore Mayern, who not only as he was Phyician to the late King, but by the proof he had given of his eminent skill and perfection in his faculty, has gained the greatet eteem and generality of practice at Court, and among the Nobility, of any man in his time: By which it appears that thee preent Receipts extracted from the Muaeum of this excellent Peron, have been frequently made ue of by himelf among the greatet Ladies of Court and Countrey; Upon this account I having had the fortune (as being a near Relation of his) to get thee among everal other of his Papers into my hands, hould have thought my elf very injurious to the World, if I had not taken the firt
opportunity to communicate to the publick view a matter of o publick a benefit; epecially, ince it is a buines of no les importance than the preervation of Life, to be very cautious what to make choice of, and not eaily to be atisfied with every thing that may have, rahly and without mature judgment, been publiht of this Subject. The truth is, among all the Treaties of Midwifry that I have een et forth in our Language, I have not met with any to which I can more willingly ubcribe my approbation, than to the works of Madam Lowie Burgeoie, late Midwife to the Queen of France: Therefore hearing of a econd Edition of the aid Treatie to come forth, I thought it mot convenient to annex thereunto this collection, more coniderable for its quality than quantity; the experiences of the one having been no les approved among the Ladies of the French Court, than thoe of the other among our great Ladies of England: To conclude, I hall not for this upplement go about to implore the favourable cenure of the Courteous Reader, but commit it to the fortune of that free reception which it cannot but meet with, both from the advantageous Tetimony I have alledged, and the beneficial Effects I dare promie it will produce.

div.head: RARE SECRETS Brought to LIGHT, Which for many years were locked up in the breat of that mot Famous and Learned Phyician, Sir Theodore Mayern, Phyician to His late MAJESTY, King CHARLES the Firt, of ever Bleed Memory.
To know the time of Delivery, whereby the woman may know the better how to prepare her elf.
div.p: THE natural time of Delivery falls out to be at the end of nine months, epecially if at that eaon the Woman be wont to have her natural purgations; or ele if at nine Months end he happen to be near the full or the new Moon: For thee things hapning together, not only haten her Delivery, but alo facilitate the Labour.

To this end, it is neceary that a Woman hould be careful to remember and take notice of the time of her Conception, that he may be able to govern her elf according to the eaons, as he grows near her time.

It is alo very neceary for Women to have in memory the days and eaons of their natural Purgations, not only in regard of their delivery, but alo in regard of everal Maladies and Dieaes, which upon this
occaion happen at the aid time, and of which no peron can rightly judge of the caue, unles thoe things be well known.

Now if it happen that a woman have mitaken or forgot, as not being rightly able to oberve, either becaue of ome retention extraordinary, or ome extraordinary and tedious flux of her natural Purgations; he may redres her elf by the means which follow.

Mot commonly and ordinarily, women have their natural Purgations from the age of fourteen years to twenty one, at the new Moon; after that, from twenty one to thirty, in the firt quarter; from thirty to thirty even, or thirty eight, they have them at the full of the Moon; from thirty even to the time that they begin to ceae, in the lat quarter.

div.head: Signs which precede Delivery.
div.p: THE Woman having a regard to the end of the nine Moons, as alo to the times of the full and new Moons, as alo to the time that he ues to have her Purgations, as hath been aid, he mut be provided of all things for her aitance and preervation. Now when her Delivery is near, he hall know by thee igns.
Great pains in her groins thighs, the mall of her belly, and all the lower parts of the Navel, together with wellings, and hardnes in the aid places.

Shiverings and hakings through the whole body, as at the coming of an Ague; after that again a udden heat, feeblenes, laitude, and mall weats upon the face; after which the blood being inflamed, ries up into the face, which caues a heat, and rednes; great unret, and changing from hot to cold, from trong to weak, from weak to trong; and he hall feel the Child to make violent thruts. There will come bloody water from the lower parts. When thee igns, but epecially the bloody waters appear,
then he ought to commit her elf to the care of the Midwife, for before 'tis in vain, and may prove dangerous.

Nature hath o well ordered her works, that the Matrix never opens it elf before the time prefixed, at which time thee igns appear; and therefore a woman ought to be very diligent in the obervance of the aid eaons and igns.

div.head: To caue the Woman to contain the Birth.
div.p: TAke Mint, Roes, Marjoram, Saffron, Musk, as much as uffices of each; put them into a bag to be hung about the neck, o that it may reach to the tomach; this will keep the womb from falling low.

div.head: An Emplaiter to hinder the Monthly Flux in Women with Child.
div.p: TAke Oyl of Roes, white Wax, juyce of Male-knot-gras of each 2 ounces, Bole-Armoniack, Crocus Martis, each ix drams, of this make a plaiter: when the Flux comes down, let the woman contain her elf in her bed, and let this plaiter be pread upon her loyns. Lay a Goats-skin between the heet and the bed, becaue of the heat of the hollow Vein; or ele take Crocus Martis one dram, juyce of Knot gras four ounces, Roe-water and Vinegar, of each one ounce; mingle them all well together with the white of an egg, then dip a linnen cloth therein, and apply it cold to the loins.

div.head: An Emplaiter for a Woman that is fearful of containing the Birth.
div.p:
TAke of the root of Snake-weed, and Tormentil, each one ounce and a half, Joubertus atringent powder, Myrtle-berries, Pidia, Pomgranate-flowers, of each ix drams; Dragons-blood, Spong Bedeguar, of each half an ounce, Frankincene, Matick, of each three drams; Cummin one dram; Nutmegs, Cloves,
of each half a dram, Common Pitch ix ounces, Venice Turpentine, wahed in juyce of Shepherds-pure, Ship pitch three ounces, Wax as much as is ufficient; make of thee an Emplaiter to be applied to the reins.

div.head: Preparatory Oyntments to be ued before the time of Delivery.
div.p: TAke Oyl of Lillies, and Cammomil, of each four ounces, new Hogs-eam trein'd, new freh Butter, of each an ounce and an half, Mucilage of the eed of Fenugreek extracted in Mugwort-water, two ounces of powder of round Birth-wort, and Saffron, of each two drams, Wax as much as uffices, make a mollifying Oyntment to anoint the Thighs, Hips, and Matrix Or ele,

Take the roots of white Lillies cut mall, four ounces, leaves of Violets and Mallows chopt, of each one handful; oyl of Lillies one pint: boyl thee together upon hot embers, in a ilver dih, always moving them 'till they grow oft, in the nature of a Cataplam. Then trein it, and to the treined liquor add Gooe-greae, Hogs-eam, of each three ounces, Saffron one ounce, mingle them well, and make an Oyntment for the ue above-aid.

div.head: In cae of Vomiting.
div.p: APply to the Stomach a Stomachical Cerecloth prinkled with Galbanum powdered, powder of Cloves and Matick, and then covered with fine linnen.
Or ele give Aromaticum Roatum before meals, which is a mot excellent remedy.

A woman in the firt place finding her elf to be with Child for the three firt months, ought to keep from violent exercies, as alo at the firt quarter, at Full of the Moon, and in the time when he hath her
natural purgations; for at all thee eaons there is a motion of the humours, and of the blood, which many times caueth a dicharge of the Birth; neither ought a woman at uch times as thee dance, ride, or go in Coaches, but upon urgent neceity, and that very oftly.

In the fourth month the Child being alive moves and tirs, which caueth a queamihnes in the tomach, where at that time 'tis good for the Woman to eat alone, that he may neither ee nor hear of any thing of hurtful diet, to which he may have a longing deire. Neither is it good at that time for her to walk in the field, or in gardens, for fear he hould ee any thing to long after, offenive to her health.
The fifth and ixth months are not o dangerous, yet 'tis good to have a care.

In the eventh month the Child comes to perfection, and oft-times endeavours to come forth; for which caue great and diligent care is to be taken of the Woman at that time. For though the Child born in that month may live, yet it will prove weak, and harder to bring up. The eighth month in indifferent. The Child which is born in that Month is not long liv'd, becaue it is much weakned by its indeavours to get forth in the eventh, and has not yet recovered trength.

div.head: Regulation of Diet.
div.p: FOR the firt eight months, it will be convenient for her to ue uch meats and drinks, which neither moiten, looen, nor bind overmuch, but moderately; and let them be of eaie digetion, and good juyce.
As to Fleh; Capons, Partridges, Larks, Pullets, and Mutton afford good nourihment.
As to Fih; the Gurnard, the Sole, the Smelt, and many other firm Fih may be eaten.

Her Bread ought to be white, well baked, and light. Marmalade is good after meals, and ometimes before, neither are the bet ort of Pears forbidden. As for her drink, Claret is very good, as alo mall Ale and Beer well brewed; trong wines are very hurtful, epecially thoe that are white.
She mut have a care to abtain from Spices, opening and windy meats; as alo from raw herbs, and Salads, from Beans and Peae, and all baked meat.

In the ninth month he mut abtain from all atringent things, as Pate of Quinces, Rice, and Pears, Marmalad, and the like; on the contrary, let her ue mollifying and looening meats, as fleh that is young and tender, Pottages made with Borage, Buglos, Lettice, Violets, March-mallows, and uch like.

div.head: Other Advertiements relating to the everal accidents which may happen.
div.p: FIrt, if the Woman fear Abortion, and that he carry her Child low near her Privities, let her do as follows.

Take the Treddles of three new laid Eggs, and beat them well together, then take of Scarlet Silk as much as uffices, and cut it very mall, and mix it with the egg, and make the aid mixture into Pills, take of thee Pills in a little Claret-wine; do this three days together, and every month three times in the ame manner.
You may alo ue this following Plaiter.

Take of Myr • les, Orange-flowers, of each one ounce, Acorn cups, talks of Roes, each one ounce; Bole Armonick fine and true, Dragons-blood, of each three ounces. Turpentine two ounces; Oyl of Quinces or Myrtles as much as is ufficient to make the
plaiter: which is to be applied to the reins, and upon the belly, and withall to be tretched out upon the thighs. It may lye on five or ix days without changing.

However a woman ought not to tamper, nor ue any thing, unles there be very great neceity, which he hall know thus; If at the full or new Moon, or ele at the time when he ues to have her monthly purgation; if at that time her Purgations come down, then Abortion is to be feared, and remedies are to be applied.
But if the woman carry the Infant high, and that her belly wells, and extends o trongly, that there may be ome danger of fiures and clefts in the skin, then let her ue this following oyntment.

Take half a hundred of Sheeps trotters with bones and wooll; when the Moon is at the full, bruie them, and beat them, then let them boyl in a good quantity of water, for half a days time, let them cool, and then take off the fat that wims, and with this mingle four ounces of Sperma Caeti, four ounces of Oyl of Almonds drawn without fire, and four ounces of white Wax; melt all thee together over a oft fire, then put therein half a pint of Roe-water, then take it off the fire, and tir it till it grow cold; with this oyntment you hall firt anoint the part extended, and then lay ome of it on the aid part where ever it be, preading it upon oft leather, uch as Childrens gloves are made of.
About fifteen days or three weeks before he lyes down, he mut begin to ue mollifying oyntments, anointing therewith the lower part of the belly, her thighs and genitals.

The Oyntment of Sheeps trotters will erve for fifteen days, but ome eight days before he lyes down,
let her ue one which is more mollifying, uch as this which follows.

Take of roots of Lillies two ounces, Marh-mallow-roots two ounces, leaves of Marh-mallows, Mallows, and March-Violets, of each one handfull; of Hempeed, and eed of Fenugreek, of each one ounce; two Sheeps trotters with their Wooll on, cut and bruied: boyl all thee together in a great quantity of water, till all be boyled to a mah, then trein them hot, then et the treined liquor over a oft fire, let it conume and evaporate, 'till there be nothing left but the fat, and omething of a vicous matter beide. To this add eight ounces of oyl of Hempeed, drawn by expreion like Oyl of Almonds, and eight ounces of Hogs-Seam; This Oyntment mollifies very much, and renders the paages very lippery and eaie, to extend upon any occaion.
While the party is with Child, if he happen to be bound in body, let her ue this following Clyter.

Take one Sheeps trotter, Hempeed, and Fenugreek-eed, of each one ounce; Melilot-flowers two handfuls, boyl thee in Cows milk, then trein it, and take ix ounces thereof, and put thereto four ounces of Oyl of Hempeed, if he be near the time of her Labour, but if not, Oyl of Roes, and if the excrements be very hard, you may add thereto one ounce of Catholicon.

At the time of Child-bearing, it is good to take the above-aid Clyter, if it may be done poibly, for that, after the Woman is delivered, he is to be four or five days without a tool, as well becaue of the great evacuations which he hath o lately had, as alo that being to be kept continually hot in her bed, the excrements do thereupon harden, and afterwards putrifie,
and then generate putrid vapours, and many times a feaver.

There happens alo another inconvenience from the aid excrements, being kept in the body, and not emptied before delivery; and that is this, that when the Patient endeavours to deliver her elf of the Infant, the excrements do alo forthwith come out, which many ways give annoyance, as well to the Child, the Midwife, as to the other Aitants, by reaon of the change of linnen, and the troubleome mells.

Beide the foreaid inconveniencies, the Child will not come forth o eaily, becaue the Intetines being full, do compres the Matrix, and by conequence caue the paages to be more cloe and difficult. In the mean time, that is to ay, when the woman is in pain, and that all the igns of Child-bearing do appear, then let her take about two ounces of Cinamon-water, this will fortifie her pirits, and haten the coming forth of the Infant.

If the water alone do not uffice, you may give it her the econd time, adding thereunto the weight of a half crown of counterfeit Borax made of Roach-Allum, uch as the Goldmiths ue; it is neither offenive to the tate, nor any way dangerous, as ome Phyicians think, mitaking it for Chryocoll of the Greeks; for it is a overaign medicament both to caue the Child to come forth, and to expell the Secondines, if they come not forth in their due time.

If you cannot have the aid Borax,To help difficult Labour. then take two cruples, or forty grains of Date-tones powdered very fine, and drink it in Cinamon-water; or for want of that, in a draught of good Hypocras.

The weight of a Crown of the powder of the
leaves of Cretan Dittany, drank in Cinamon-water, worketh the ame effect.
Or ele take of Venetian Borax, one dram, Saffron three grains; drink this in one poonful of water of white Lillies: Or ele, take this following powder.
Take Cretan Dittany half a dram, Savin, yellow Amber, of each two cruples, make it into powder, and drink it in water of Cinamon, Hyop, or Rue.
Or ele,

Take of the powder of leaves of Cretan Dittany half a dram, of Penny-royal half a cruple, a little Cinamon, Myrrh one cruple; mingle thee powders well, and drink them in Hypocras. Or take this following water.

Take Water of Cinamon four ounces, of Hyop and Thyme of each two ounces, of Roewater one dram, in thee waters diolve half an ounce of Confectio Alchermes, let them tand a whole night, then ditill them in Balneo; the doe to be taken at a time is two drams; you may add, if there be neceity, a drop or two of Oil of Savin. Or, you may ue this powder.

Take of Myrrh, of Cinamon, and Saffron, of each the weight of the third part of a Crown, mix them well together, and put them into a raw egg, and caue the party to up it up; and let her drink after it a draught of Hypocras. Or ele take this potion.

Take of the juyce of Savin two ounces, Cinamon-powdered two drams, Saffron half a Scruple, water of Radihes four ounces, and a little Sugar; of this make a potion for the woman to drink in time of travail.
There be many other Remedies, but thee are the mot certain, and eaie to take, where the danger nor the pain is exceive; but in caes of urgent neceity, you may ue thee following remedies.

Take of Mugwort one handful, Butchers Broom and Fennel, of each one handful; of alt three drams,
of Aa foetida two drams, of bran one handful, of water and white-wine, of each eight pints: boil them to the conumption of the third part. Or take this, which never failed.
Take of the root of Gentian powdered one or two drams, take this in white-wine or honey, it never hurts the Infant.

div.head: To accelerate and haten the labour before the time of Child bearing, ue this following ointment.
div.p: Take of the mucilage of the eed of Fenugreek, and the root of Marhmallows, with water of Mugwort two ounces; oil of Lillies, and weet Almonds, and Hens-gerae, of each one ounce and a half, of Saffron half a cruple; of Wax as much as uffices: Of this make an ointment to anoint the back, belly, and privy parts, for fourteen days together before the birth: Or ele take this following Ointment.

Take oil of white Lillies, with hens greae, of each an ounce and a half, of Saffron half a cruple, of thee make an Ointment with as much Wax as uffices, to anoint the Back, Navel, and privy Parts, for fourteen days together.

Note that all thoe things which we have aid to be good, to be given at the time of delivery, mut never be given before; for that otherwie they will be of little ue, they erving only to facilitate the Birth without endangering the Child or Mother.
The Woman ought alo to walk about the Chamber as much as he can, being held by other Women.

Neither let any peron, whether Man or Woman, againt whom he may have any ill will, or whoe preence may breed any thing of hame in her, be at that time in the room, becaue any uch accident as that retards Nature, but let them be uch as he loves, ociable, merry, and helpful towards her.
It is alo neceary for a Woman in Travel to neeze and cough, which are great means to force down the Infant to the lower parts.

And as to the Midwifes duty, he ought to anoint the lower parts with oyl of Hemp-eed, or Nuts, if the waters which hould precede the Birth do not come forth, or if they be come down a good while before the Birth, to the intent to make the aid parts lippery to eae the coming forth of the Child.
If the Child decend not eaily, the Midwife may with her hand gently pres the top of the belly, to the intent to make the Child decend with more hat.

As oon as the Woman is delivered, and that the Secondines are likewie come away, it hall be convenient to wrap her in a warm heep-skin, which mut be flead near the Chamber, for that purpoe; which mut be done with as much expedition, and as near a great fire as may be, that there may be nothing of coldnes when the Woman is wrapt therein In this the Patient mut continue twelve hours. This will much help the Matrix in its natural purgation; when you take it away, you mut apply warm Cloths in the tead, and above all things take great care that no air do enter into the Matrix, which often-times is the caue of very great evils.

Or you may apply warm to the belly of the Patient, Tow dipt in the whites of Eggs, wherein the pouders of Cloves, Pepper, and Nutmegs hall be mingled, which mut be bound cloe to the body with wathbands.
Great care is to be taken how you apply atringent things to the Womb preently after delivery, unles after perfect purgation of the Secondines; for fear of very great michiefs.

Now if you ue the aid heep skin, and that you
find the woman notwithtanding tormented with very great pains, and that the aid skin doth not at all appeae them; let her take an ounce and a half more or les according to the height of the ditemper, of oil of weet Almonds drawn without fire the ame day; and two hours after, let her take the weight of half a crown of this following powder either in white-Wine, or Capon broth.

Take of the root of great Comfrey dryed, two drams, kernels of Peaches, Nutmegs, each one dram, yellow Amber and Saffron, of each one cruple, Amber greee half a dram, make a powder of all this. For, beides that it awages the Throws, it corroborates and fortifies the body, weakened by reaon of thoe great evacuations.

After you have taken away the heep-skin, if there be any excoriation in the privy parts, by reaon either of the bignes of the Child, or the treining of the woman, you mut anoint the aid parts with this following oyntment, which is infallible.

Take of Oil of St. John's wort well made, one ounce, Sperma Coeti half an ounce, balom of India two drams, white Wax two drams. This ointment doth conolidate all the parts. But if together with this excoriation, any thing of the Secondines remain in the Womb, Oil of St. Johns-wort only will uffice, or, for want of that, oil of Nuts.
If the evacuations after the Secondines be too much, o that they caue too great a weaknes, you mut apply to the Navel this following plaiter.
Take of Treacle one dram and a half, Bean-meal one dram Venice-Turpentine one dram, and thereof make an emplaiter to be pread upon thin Leather.

If all be well, and that only the lower parts be prejudiced,
after you have anointed them with Balom of the Indies, together with oil of St. Johns-wort, you mut foment the aid places with the following fomentation.

Take of Sage four little handfuls, wild Pomgranate flowers, Myrtle berries, Acorns, Cypres nuts, of each two ounces; let them be well bruied together; red Roes four handfuls, Roche-allum one ounce; put all thee into two little bags, and let them boil in Smiths water, or in water where iron hath been often quenched: when one bag is cold, apply another.
The Sheep-skin being taken away, if the patient be afraid of any wrinckles in the skin, which now is as much relaxed, as it was before extended; let her anoint the belly with this following ointment.

Take of Sperma Caeti, two ounces, oil of Myrtles, of Matick, and St. John's-wort, of each one ounce, white wax an ounce and a half, Turpentine of Venice, waht in Vinegar of Roes, one ounce; of thee make an ointment over a gentle Fire, with which you mut anoint the belly once a day, continuing o to do for ten or twelve days, laying when you have done upon the place o anointed, a linnen cloth dipt in the following ointment.

Take oil of weet Almonds, oil of Nuts, Sperma Coeti each four ounces; white Wax four ounces; melt thee together, and dip therein a good large towel, big enough to wrap about the belly; when you do thee things, great care is to be taken, that the patient do not take any cold.
If the patient have no mind to nure her Child, and deires to dry up her milk, then do as follows, ome ix or even hours after the Delivery.

Tak a linnen cloth cut round, about the bignes of the breats, making a little hole in the middle for the Teat to come through; then dip the clothes in the following
ointment, and lay them upon the breat, not taking them off again, 'till the end of ten or twelve days.

Take Venice Turpentine four ounces, wahed in one half part of Roe-water, and one half part of Vinegar, Populeon one ounce, mix them together, and apply them as is before aid. If the milk doth not dry up for all this, make the Cataplam as follows.

Take Bean-meal four ounces, Bole-amoniack one ounce, juyce of Plantain three ounces, Vinegar of Roes, two ounces, Fountain water half a pint; let them boil 'till they come to the thicknes of a Cataplam, adding toward the end two ounces of Populeon, pread this on a linnen cloth, and apply them to the breats without wahing them, changing the Cataplam twice a day.

The juice of Chervile boiled with Bean-meal, and a little Populeon, worketh the ame effect. Becaue the difficulty of Child bearing proceedeth from the los of thoe waters that break forth before the Child; therefore, to upply that defect, and to render the places lippery, let her ue thee following remedies.

Take Marh-mallows with the roots one handful, Mugwort, Savine, of each half a handful, Hempeed, and Fenugreek eed of each four ounces, Cummin eed one ounce and a half, boil all thee in water; then take four ounces of this decoction, and add thereto oil of Hempeed two ounces, Moch. gr. 2. and inject it into the neck of the womb. Then take this following pouder.

Take of the bark of Caia, Dittany, of each two drams, Cinamon four cruples, Sugar the weight of the other ingredients. Make them into pouder, and let the Patient take one dram thereof in white-wine, or Mugwort water.

div.head: An Oyntment for the Midwifes hands.
div.p: TAke Oyl of Hempeed, one ounce and a half, Oyl of Cator half an ounce, Gall Mochate half a cruple, Labdanum one cruple, make of this an Oyntment, with which, let the Midwife often anoint the neck of the womb.

div.head: After Delivery.
div.p: WHen the Infant is well cleaned by the Midwife, let her give unto it in the Winter nothing but a little Mithridate, but in the Summer let her mingle therewith a little conerve of Roes and Buglos.

If the Mother have not yet taken any thing, let the Midwife give to her the juyce of a Capon preed out in a pres, with a little Saffron, and the yolk of an egg. Then let her take this following powder, againt gripings of the belly, or after throws which indeed he ought to take before any meat, preently after Delivery.
Take of the greater Comfrey dryed, one dram and a half, kernels of Peaches, Nutmegs, of each two drams, yellow Amber, one dram, Amber-greee two cruples; or this,

Take kernels of Peaches and Dates, of each one dram and a half, Nutmegs four cruple, Pulv. Elect. Diamargarit. Calid. two drams, Anieed condited, one dram; of the bet Cinamon two cruples, Saffron half a cruple, Sugar as much as uffices, drink two drams of this powder in white-wine twice or thrice a day, if the pains be very great.

div.head: If the pains ceae not with thee remedies, ue that which follows.
div.p:
TAke the whites of twelve eggs roted under the embers, Cummin-eed and Hempeed, of each one ounce and a half, flowers of Camomile and Melilot,
of each two drams; boyl thee in oyl of Dill, 'till they come to the form of an oyntment; apply it warm to the belly, till changing it as it grows cold. Or thus:

Take the flowers of Dill, Roemary, Melilot, and Camomil, of each one handful; Fenneleed, Anieed, and Cummin-eed, of each two drams: boyl them in part wine, and part water, and make a Cataplam for the whole belly.

div.head: To treighten the Womb.
div.p: TAke of the leaves of Myrtle and Starwort, of each three handfuls, green Medlers, green Prunes, and the harpet wild Pears, of each one little handful and a half, the Stomacks of three Cocks newly taken out, ditill all thee together, then take Cotton and dip therein, and then put it into the womb, and let it continue there a good while.

div.head: To treighten the Womb without the help of Swathe-bands.
div.p: TAke the white of an Egg, and meal as much as is ufficient; make thereof a Cataplam to cover the lower part of the belly; where it lies upon the belly, there mut be a hole made, and that hole mut be covered with mos.
You mut cover the plaiter alo with powder of Frankincene.
This plaiter profits more in a little while, than a Swathe in many weeks.

div.head: A Fomentation to provoke the after-birth.
div.p:
TAke the Birth-worts, of each of them one ounce, or a handful; Carduus, Feverfew and Mugwort, each one handful; Dwarf Elder, half a handful, ground Ivy one handful, boyl them together in Wine, or Water, or Ale, epecially if there be any Fever, for then you mut by no means meddle with
Wine, adding to it one handfull of the leaves, or half a handful of the roots of Mater-wort.

div.head: For the ame.
div.p: TAke Savine, one cruple, rind of Caia, half a cruple, Saffron ten grains, Aa-faetida two grains, juyce of Wall-Ivy, half an ounce, Snakeweed one ounce, Pulvis diagar five grains, Syrup of Mugwort half an ounce, mingle all thee together, and make a potion to drink at once.
Or ele take four drops of the ditilled oyl of Savin in white-wine.

div.head: A Peary for the ame.
div.p: TAke the leaves of red Coleworts, and bruie them, and put them into a little piece of linnen cloth in the hape of a finger, then bruie them again, that the juyce may come through, and dip the cloth in a mixture of oyl of Lillies, Camomil, and weet Almonds.

div.head: For the ame.
div.p: TAke long and round Birthwort, Aa-Faetida, of each half an ounce, Myrrh one dram, Spike two drams, make them up with the decoction of Parley, and Apple-tree leaves.

div.head: For the ame.
div.p: TAke of Borax one dram, Cinamon one cruple, Saffron three grains; make a powder, and let the woman drink it in four ounces of water of Mugwort.

div.head: To expell the Child, and after-birth, in time of great neceity.
div.p: TAke of the water of Mugwort, Agrimony, and Penny-royal, of each one ounce, Syrup of Mugwort one ounce and a half, powder of Cator, round Birth-wort, Myrrh, Aarabacca, of each one cruple, mingle them together, make a potion.
Or ele take Origanum, Calaminth, and Hyop, of each two drams, roots of Orrice, Aarabacca, Savin, each one dram, Myrrh, Olibanum, Galbanum, Sagapenum, one cruple; diolve them, and make a Peary.

div.head: To expell the after-birth, another.
div.p: TAke one tone of a Cator, and ditill it with trong Vinegar; when you have o done, let the Patient take four ounces of this ditilled liquor.

Or, you may take of the Oyl drawn out of the tone of a Cator, with a oft fire, mingle it with a ufficient quantity of this Oyl, a little of the waters of Penny-royal, and Dittany, and a little trong Vinegar.

div.head: To expell the Birth, whether alive, or dead.
div.p: TAke the milk of a woman that nures a male child, and diolve it with a little Saffron, that it may not be known; then boyl an egg rear, and take out the white, and in the place of that, put in the milk, and let the patient up it up; if it prevail not in a quarter of an hour, prepare another egg, and fill it with milk, as aforeaid.
Or take of the juyce of Buglos, four ounces weetned with Sugar.

div.head: Againt pains of the heart.
div.p: TAke of the roots of Fennel, Buglos, and Cicory, each two ounces; boyl them in three pints of white-wine, to the conumption of two parts, then add Fennel-water, and Cicory-water, each ix ounces; then boyl them again till there remain but a pint and a half, take one poonful morning and evening.

div.head: To dry up the Milk.
div.p: TAke Honey newly drawn out of the Hive, and diolve it in water, and wah the breats therewith.

div.head: For the ame.
div.p: TAke of the juyce of Mint and Shepherds-pure, of each half an ounce; mix them together and drink them a mornings, with the broth of a hen or chicken.

div.head: A Fomentation for the ame.
div.p: TAke of the juyce of Parley, and the tronget wild Turnep, equal parts; and moiten therein a linnen cloth, and apply the aid Cloth to the Breats.

div.head: Another.
div.p: TAke Oyl of Violets three ounces, juyce of Mint and Parley three ounces, white Vinegar one ounce, Roe-water two ounces: boyl all thee over a gentle fire, to the conumption of the juyces; then add a little wax, and make an oyntment. Or,
Take of the tops of Elder, Sage, and Mint, one little handful; boyl them in common water, and make thereof a Cataplam to be applied to the breats.
If you would increae the milk, foment the breats with the decoction of Fennel,To encreae Milk. or ele give her the decoction of Mint, and lay the Mint boyled upon her breats.
Or, if thee things prevail not, ue this following Powder.

Take of Anie, Fennel, Cummin-eed, two drams, Ginger half an ounce, Carui, of both orts of Pepper, Coral, each one dram, Cinamon, three drams, eed of Daucus one dram, Siler montan. half an ounce, Cardamom, Long pepper, each three drams, Seelos half an ounce, eed of Seamum one ounce, white Poppy half an ounce, mingle them, and make a powder thereof, and take one dram at pleaure, in broth made of red Coleworts.
Or, you may ue this following oyntment.

Take of Venice-Turpentine, oyl of Roes, Vinegar
of Roes equal parts, add to this a little new wax, and therewith anoint the breats.
But if the Milk do curdle and harden in the breats.

Firt chafe the breats well with raw honey, then take of new wax two ounces, new oyl of nuts and vinegar two or three poonfuls, melt them together, and dip that in little round linnen clothes, with holes in the middle to lay upon the breats.
Now if there be any tumour or hardnes caued by the coagulation of the milk, then

Take of the leaves of Parley, Hemlock, Uinca pervinca, Box and Chervile, and let them boyl in the tronget Vinegar, and then train them; then take oyl of Roes, Lillies, and weet Almonds each one ounce, of the foreaid Vinegar four ounces, mingle them in a marble mortar for an oyntment, adding one cruple of Camphire diolved in part of the oyl and toward the latter end of your tirring it, add the white refrigerating Ceratum of Galen, Unguent of Roes of Meu one ounce and a half, mingle them all well together, and apply them to the hard welling part, it awages the tumour, and caues the milk to flow through the Teats.
If the Tumor be painful and enflamed, you mut not ue the Camphire, (for it encreaes the pain) till that the pain be awaged.

div.head: An Oyntment againt the curdling of the Milk in the Breat.
div.p: TAke of the roots of Marh-mallows half a pound, boyl them well in Vinegar, and train them thro' a hair ieve, add to this Bean-meal one ounce, powder of Rue, and dried Mint, one dram; Oyl of Matick as much as uffices.

div.head: Againt Fiures in the Breats.
div.p: TAke Gum-Arabick mot finely powdered, one ounce, Roe water and Aqua-vitae a ufficient quantity, prepare them together, till they come to a jut thicknes, make thereof an oyntment, and apply it to the aid Fiures.
Or ele, anoint the aid Fiures with Ointment of Roes, then apply the inide of the leaf of Ground-Ivy, changing often; this cures within ix or eight days.

div.head: Another of the ame.
div.p: TAke Lytharge of Silver, Myrrh, Ginger, and oyl-Olive, as much as uffices; mix them to the thicknes of an oyntment; before you apply this, moiten the Fiures themelves with pittle, but no part of the breat beide.

div.head: Pain in the Breats after Delivery.
div.p: TAke new Wax two ounces, oyl of Nuts half an ounce, oyl of Rape-eeed, or Turnep eed half an ounce; firt melt the Wax, then add the Oyls; dip therein the clothes cut fit to the breats; if there be any pain after delivery, the application of thee cloaths, will with great ucces awage the ame.

div.head: An Opiate to be given to Childern newly born.
div.p: TAke Mithridate of Alexandria three drams, Conerve of Buglos and Roes, of each one dram; mingle them well together, and keep them in a glas Veel well topt; an hour, or half an hour after the Child is born, before it hath uckt, give to it of the foreaid opiate, to the quantity of a Filberd; let it not uck till five hours after; continue thus doing for a month, giving the Child this opiate once in a week; and then it will be ufficient, that the Child abtain but an hours pace from the Teat.

It will not be amis to anoint the Navel of the Child
with an ointment made of Ambergreece, and Suet, equal parts, with a little oil of weet-Almonds. This will preerve the child from Epilepies and Convulions.

div.head: Againt Barrennes.
div.p: TAKE of Pine-nuts, firt well waht in Roewater, ix ounces; weet Almonds, wahed in like manner, and bruied, each two ounces, Citron pill, condited root of Satyrion, Erythranion, one ounce, Pulp of Sebeten, Prunes of Damacus fat, boiled in Sugared water, each one ounce and a half; Coriander prepared three drams; Pulveris Diambre one dram Penidium one ounce and a half, the inner rind of Cinamon, half an ounce, true Amber of an Ah-colour, one dram, Moo. one Scruple, refined Sugar boiled in Roe-water, one pound and a half; take all thee things and beat them, and powder them well, and make thereof a Pate o dried at a gentle fire. Let the woman take this at pleaure after dinner, and three hours before at pleaure, abtaining from liquid meats. The man alo may eat of this pate; but let him not ue copulation at the time of the Womans Purgations, nor when he bathes her elf, but preently after. Thoe mornings that he abtains, let him take one poonful of the water of Cocks-blood, with three or four poonfuls of the bet Broth.

div.head: For the ame.
div.p: A Syrup. Take Syrup of Hempagrimony, Simple, Oxymel, Syrup de rad. each one ounce and a half, waters of Nipp, Betony, and Mugwort of each three ounces, make thereof a yrup perfectly boiled, trein it, and let it he aromatized with Cinamon, for three does, morning and evening.

A Potion. Take Agarick infued in Honey of Roes, and a little white-Wine for a whole night, one ounce; Diacatholicon, half an ounce, Diaphenicon, Elect. Ind.
major, each one dram and a half; Syrup of Roes Solutive, with Agorick one ounce, with a decoction of red Chiches; make a Potion thereof, and give it after the Syrup is all taken, for ten days, and ten days before the coming of the monthly purgations.
Three days after the operation of the aid potion, let blood in Vena Saphena, of the right foot, and take away three ounces of blood at evening.

An Opiate. Take of the great Triphera without Opium, two ounces, Methridate three ounces, mix thee well together, and let her take thereof the quantity of a Walnut after he is let blood, drinking upon the aid Bolus, a poonful of Aromatick Wine, white or Claret; let the Patient take this when he is clean from her Purgations only in the morning, while he hath them upon her only at night, and then let her alo make ue of this Peary.

Take of Spike, Myrrh, and Agarick, and Colocynth each three drams, Benedict. one ounce and a half, mix them well together with the juyce of French Mercury, and wrapt in fine red ilk, make thereof little Pearies, and put one of them into the Womb in the day, and another at night: But, from the time that he is let blood until her Purgations, let her ue but one in the day; but from the time that they begin, until the time that they end, let her ue two, as is before aid.
Let her withal take this following Clyter two or three days before her purgations.

Take Feverfew one handful, Penny-royal, Calamint, and Savine, of each half a handful, eed of Juniper one ounce, flowers of Melilot, and tops of Dill, of each one handful, make a decoction of nine ounces of water, add thereto oil of Lillies four ounces, two whites of eggs, and one dram of common alt.

Latly, one day before her monthly purgations,
let her take three Pills of thoe which are called Pillulae Rufi, then after he is clean from her Purgations, let her lye with her Husband.

div.head: For the ame.
div.p: AN Injection. Take Cypres one ounce, Myrrh half an ounce Pulp of Colocynth one dram, Bdellium one cruple, water a pint; boil them altogether to the conumption of the third part, then trein them, make an injection of four ounces of the treined liquor into the Womb, three days before the Bath, and let the Patient keep it as long as he can.

A Fumigation. Take juyce of Bitort, Schoenanth, Cypres nuts, red Storax, and Matick, one ounce, Hares-dung; mix them, and pound them well together, and make a Fumigation; let the patient receive it itting on a tool with a hole in it.
Then let her ue this following Bath.

Take Bail, Calamint, Betony, Melilot, Roes, each two handfuls. Thyme, Elder Germander, Mugwort, Savin, Balm, of each two handfuls, Feverfew, leaves of Laurel, and Lavender, each one handful, bruie them together, and when the water boyls, throw them in; when they have boiled ufficiently, let her take the waters off, and bath therein.

A Plaiter, Take of the mas of Emplaiter of Matick, one ounce; of Plaiter for the Womb, two ounces, mingle them together, and extend them upon a round piece of red cloth; in the middle whereof, put one Trochich de galla Mochat. and ix grains of Amber-greece; the lat day of her bathing, when he goes to bed, let her apply that plaiter to the region of her Matrix.
That Night, after due concoction, let her lye with her Husband,

div.head: To increae Lut, and to help Conception.
div.p: TAKE of the juyce of the Herb Mercury, and clarified Honey, of each one ounce; of meal of Nigella, two ounces; make thereof a mas, and let the Patient take two or three every night.

div.head: An Opiat for the ame.
div.p: TAKE Conerve of Eringo-roots, and Satyrion, each three ounces, green Ginger condited, Citron rind one ounce and a half, weet Almonds, Pitaches, Pine-Apples, Filberds, Chenuts, Dates, the Pulp of Cocus's of each one ounce; of the reins and loins of the beat called a Skink, of the pizzle of a Bull, of the tones of a Hare, or Boar, of each half an ounce; eed of Parnip, Rockquet, and Nettles, each three drams, white Pepper, Galang. and cinamon, each half a dram; all thee things being well provided, and beaten mix them together with Wine, weetned and boiled to a thicknes, and make an Opiate; add thereto of the powder of Glow-worms killed in the team of Vinegar, one cruple.

div.head: For the ame.
div.p: TAKE Pine-Apples, new Filberds peel'd, of each one ounce and a half, brains of Cock-parrows two drams, new Satyrion, roted under the ahes in wet tow, three drams; Stones of a Ram roated, half an ounce, Indian Nuts, one dram, pound them all with the broth of young Pigeons, then mingle therewith ix ounces of refined Sugar, and boil it to a thicknes, and add thereto the following pouders.

Take eed of Bombax cleaned, the bet Cinamon, each two cruples, eed of Rocket, Onions, Nettles, and Parnips, each half a dram, the reins of Skinks, Long Pepper, Galang. White Ginger, of each two cruples, havings of the pizzle of a Hart four cruples; make a Confection, and take the quantity of a Walnut
after the firt leep, and two hours before you eat.

div.head: An application to be made upon the Privities preently after Delivery.
div.p: TAKE the whites of two Eggs, and oil of St. John's wort, of each one ounce and a half, oil of Myrtles one ounce; dip therein flat toups of Hemp, and apply them to the lips of the Privities; do this three or four times a day, but take heed that it touch not the neck of the Matrix, becaue it hinders its purgation.

div.head: The next day foment thee parts with this following Fomentation.
div.p: TAKE of Wine and water half a pint, of Madder, Roe-mary, and St. John's-wort of each two little handfuls, let them boil for a Fomentation, which is to be applied hot, with the Hempen toups aforeaid. This is to be done the econd day.

The third day, take wine a pint, water half a pint, Myrrh two drams, Cinamon two drams and a half, Allum two drams and a half; of the tones of Grapes two drams, the rind of Granates one dram, flowers of red Roes, one little handful and a half; make of this a decoction to foment the Womb until the ninth day twice a day.

Take oil of St. John's wort one ounce and a half, Sperma Coeti three drams, with a little wax; make of this an ointment to ue at the beginning, with the aforeaid Fomentation to the lips of the Privities.
When you have taken away the heeps-skin, as is before aid, you may not only do as is there et down, but alo ue this following method.

Firt, take Sperma Coeti two ounces, oil of weet Almonds, Camomile, and St. John's wort, of each an ounce and a half, Goats uet one ounce, oil of Myrtles half an ounce, Saffron half a cruple, with this ointment being lukewarm, let the belly be well anointed once every day, then lay over the whole belly this following Cerecloth.

Take of new wax four ounces, Sperma Coeti one ounce and a half, Turpentine waht in Roewater two ounces and a half, oil of Almonds and St. John's-wort, of each one ounce, Saffron half a cruple. Let them melt and boyl together; when all the ingredients are well mixed, take them from the fire, and put into it the hempen cloth, and when it is cool, make it mooth, and apply it; let it be bound on with wathes, and do this for eight or nine days together.
The Woman being thus duly and rightly purged, and being free from any Fever, or other bad ymptoms, he may make ue of thee following Baths.

She hall go into the Bath three mornings together, the firt being luke-warm, taying therein but a very little. The econd a little hotter, with omething longer continuance therein. But in the third let her tay as long as he can.

div.head: The Bath in Summer.
div.p: TAKE a very clean Tub, wherein wine hath for ometime been; put therein a quantity of the bet Wine, and fill it with River-water, and the econd day after you have filled it, put therein Marjoram, Mug-wort, Agrimony, Penny-royal, of each two handfuls, then let them boil, and as they boil, now and then quench a hot piece of Iron therein, then add flowers of red Roes, two ounces and a half, Camomile, Dill, and Melilot, of each one ounce and a half, trein them all, and o make the firt Bath, out of which let her come out as oon as he feels any pain.
When he comes out, let her take as follows.
Of the rind of Pome-citron, and Conerve of Buglos, of each two cruples, let her take this going into her bed; then let her weat, and the weat being wiped off, let her eat ome good and wholome meat.

Take the water of the firt bath, and add thereto Bean-meal, and Oat-meal, of each two pound and a
half, meal of Tares one pound and a half, of Lupines one pound, Roach-allum, and Salt, of each four ounces, Cloves and Nutmegs, of each one dram; let them be aromatized with Benjamin and Storax, then put them all together in a bag, and let them boil in the foreaid water.
When he comes forth, let her take the aforeaid Bolus.

div.head: The third part.
div.p: FILL the Tub emptied of the Wine with River water, then add thereto a quantity of white-wine; then take of Roemary, Mint, Marjoram, Mugwort, Savin, Ground Ivy, of each two handfuls, Scarlet grains, four ounces, flowers of Roemary, Camomile, Mint, of each two ounces; Bean-meal, Oat-meal, of each one handful and a half, meal of Lupines and Tares, of each one pound; Cloves, Nutmegs, and Cinamon, of each half an ounce; bruie all thee things together, and let them boil in a little bag, adding thereto a pint and a half of Aqua vitae, and let burning Iron be often quenched therein. This is the third Bath, wherein he is to tay as long as he can.
When he comes forth, let her take the ame Bolus, as before.

div.head: After he hath bathed, let her foment for one or two days the lower parts of her Belly.
div.p: TAKE of red Roes two handful and a half, Shoenanth half a handful, Myrtle-berries two drams and a half, Allum one dram and a half, Matick three drams; let them be bruied, and then boil together in ower red wine: Add alo two drams of Nutmegs; with this being taken lukewarm, let fomentation be made for eight days together.
The fomentation ended, let her receive this following Fume, in a Chair with a hole in it.

Take Lignum Aloes raw, half an ounce, Nutmegs, and Cypres nuts, of each two drams and a half; yellow
Amber one dram and a half, make all thee into powder, and let her it over the Fume.

div.head: A Fomentation for the Womb the econd day after the Bath.
div.p: TAKE Galbanum and Cypres-nuts, of each half an ounce, rind of Granates two ounces, red Roes dryed, one ounce, Marjoram a handful Schoenanth one handful; Allum a dram and a half, Thyme half a handful; let them be boiled in harp wine for a Fomentation.

div.head: To caue the welling of the Belly to fall.
div.p: SOme women have their bellies as much welled after Delivery as it was before; when any uch thing happens, do as followeth.

Take half a pound of Figgs, Barley-meal and Beanmeal, of each four ounces, powder of Brick two ounces, Cypres nuts one ounce; let them boil all together in Smith's water, 'till it come to a thicknes, then pread it upon a linnen cloth, and apply it warm to the Belly; re-iterate this often, and the belly will fall to its wonted hape. Or ele,

Take meal of Beans, Rice, and Almonds, of each two ounces, powder of Brick one ounce and a half, Bole-Armoniac two ounces and a half, Dragons blood one ounce and a half; of Cypres-nuts ten drams, Scarlet grains, three ounces, Galls half an ounce, oil of Myrtles ix ounces, wild Prunes, Roewater each a pint and a half; boil them to the thicknes of a Pultes, and apply them as aforeaid to the belly.

div.head: Pain after Delivery.
div.p: TAke heed, that when you find the Patient in pain after Child-bearing, epecially on the right ide, that the rednes, or high colour of the Urine do not deceive you, whereby you may be induced to give refrigerating medicines, finding the whole body to be hot for uch urine proceeds from the greatnes of the pain and commotion in the body, and the hot lying in bed.

Therefore if you find the Patient to be full of pain in
her belly, and ides, and likewie perceive a retention of humours that hould be voided more fluently.
Take of Sweet-melling Flag, one ounce and a half, Zedoaory half an ounce, Mace eight cruples, Cinamon four cruples; make thereof a powder, and give her one dram at a time in powder.

Now though there be a Fever which eems burning, yet refrain not at all to give this powder; for it doth not for all that augment the Fever, but caues the Womb which was o lately and violently moved, to return to its former etate, and the pain of the Matrix being ceaed, the Fever will ceae of it elf. Or ele, take weet-melling-Flag one dram, Dittany half a dram; make thereof a powder.
Or, take root of Dittany one dram, Seed of Hartwort, and leaves of Rue, one cruple and a half, make them into powder, and give it as is before aid.

div.head: Againt the welling of the belly, after Delivery.
div.p: TAke Origanum, Night-hade, Matick, of each one cruple, Sagapenum as much as uffices; make of this even Pills, let her take them all at once, and let her drink upon them four ounces of the water of the flowers of white Lillies.

div.head: Againt wrinckles in the skin after Child bearing.
div.p: TAke oyl of weet-Almonds two ounces, Capons-greae half an ounce, liquid Storax half a dram, Mucilage of Tragacanth, extracted with Roe-water, two drams, Wax as much as uffices, make thereof a Cerecloath, and apply it to the belly.
Oyl of weet-Almonds, with the marrow of a Hart, is good alo for this purpoe.

div.head: This following oyntment may be ued before a Woman lyes down.
div.p:
TAke the marrow of the fore foot of a weather in the full of the Moon, et it on the fire, and let it melt in Roe-water by degrees; you may conveniently
add to this Hens-greae, or oyl of Lillies.

div.head: Another.
div.p: TAke the Seam of a Goat, a Kid, and a Weather, of each three ounces; wah them diligently in Roe-water, adding Sperma Caeti, Roe-water as much as is ufficient, and as you beat them, and mix them together, add powder of Matick with the white of an egg, and o make an oyntment.

div.head: A Pomatum for the ame.
div.p: TAke Oyl of weet-Almonds eight ounces, Sperma Coeti, Capons-greae, marrow of a Hart, and the bone of a Weather, four ounces; melt them all together between two dihes, in water of Lillies, then in Roe-water.

div.head: An Oyntment for the ame.
div.p: TAke of the Mucilage of the Seed of Fenugreek, and Hempeed, extracted in water of Lillies, one ounce, oyl of weet Almonds and Lillies, of each half an ounce, the blood of a Hog fryed, the fat of a Capon, and a wild Duck, of each ix drams, with a little new wax; make thereof an oyntment, and keep it in a glas covered with wax.

div.head: Another.
div.p: TAke white Wax four ounces, melt it, and add thereto the marrow of fifty feet of black weathers, gathered in the full of the moon; when they are melted, add thereto oyl of weet Almonds, ix ounces, wah them in water of Gourds and Lillies, 'till it grow cold, then wah it again in Roe-water; if it be too thick, you may add a little oyl of Olive.

Or, you may take oyl of weet-Almonds, and oyl of Olives of each five ounces, Clove-water four ounces, Musk three grains; a little Benjamin; mingle them, and bruie them well together, and let them diget for twenty days together: Then dip your cloaths or skins therein, and keep them clean wrapt up in clean linnen.

div.head: THE COMPLETE MIDWIFE. Her Practice Enlarged.

argument.p: The erious and mot choice Secrets of Madam Louye Bourgioes, Midwife to the Queen of France; which he left to her Daughter as a Guide for her: And alo for the Practice of all dicreet Midwives, to prevent all dangerous Mitakes in a work of o high Concernment; neceary to be known by all Child-bearing Women, and others.

div.p:
IN the Year 1630. a young Lady whom I was wont to bring to bed, paing by my houe, came in to me, and told me, that he was four Months gone, and that he perceived the Infant to tir; about a Month after, he came to ee me, and told me that he was in much pain, for that he had not perceived the Infant to tir in two days, and that therefore he believed that it was dead, by reaon of a certain very great Fright which he had had; for at the time that he was frighted, he perceived the Child to move, but after that never; and her belly began by little and little to wax les; and about three weeks after he had that reflux of milk that Women ue to have that lie in; when this was gone, he had no grievance; yet eeing her often, and knowing her to be big with Child, he asked me my advice, to know what he hould do. Whereupon I asked her, if any ill vapours roe up into
her mouth? he told me no. If he had not lot her appetite? he anwered, that he never had a better in her life; her heart was light, her body in good temper, o that there was nothing that troubled her but an apprehenion he had, that the Child was dead: whereupon I made her try all means to make the Infant tir; but he notwithtanding felt nothing, only he perceived that omething did heave a little upon the operation of the Remedies, which was nothing but the Matrix, which being now ditempered and grown cold, did as it were anwer the hot Remedies, tetifying thereby ome good which it received thereby. I advied her to be patient, and to wait Nature's leiure, which is provident enough of it elf; telling her that I had een an infant which had lain a long time in the womb without budging, which for all that was not dead, although you could not perceive in the woman any thing, but the igns of a dead Child. I had oftentimes brought the Lady to bed, and he till had very good Deliveries, and very ound Children, of a good colour, o that I believing her to be of a ound contitution, thought that if the Infant were dead, Nature, which was very trong in her, would expel it in time convenient, and that he hould not be forced, not having given any tetimony of defect; reolving alo, when her Reckoning was out, if then Nature hewed it elf weak, that we would conult her Friends and Phyicians. Many of her Friends told me, that they doubted that he was deceived in thinking her elf to be with Child; to which I anwered, that they might be confident that it was o. In brief, he was brought to bed, ixteen weeks after the fright which he had. Now here arieth a great doubt, whether the Child died at the hour of her being cared, by reaon that it did not move in all that time? A reaon that the Child was not dead,
may be, becaue that the Gentlewoman had not her milk till within three weeks after; and yet I cannot but think that it died at the ame time; for certainly, by that fright the vital pirits were ravihed from it, and the blood of the Arteries retired to the heart of the Mother, not being ditributed to the Infant, but at the good pleaure of Nature; the coure of which being topped, it retired to its firt ource, through which the Child uffering a uffocation, gave a violent motion; and now, after the fright, was come to her elf, and that Nature would have returned to finih her work, he was not deceived, becaue the vital faculties of the Infant were extinct; and, notwithtanding all this, the Mother not ceaing to retrain the mentrual blood as he was accutomed; that finding it elf topped, and till increaing without that ue made of it that was wont, it made a reflux to the Breats, which flowed down again in five or ix days; for the Infant coming to decreae in the womb, now way was made for them, which came not down for all that, but in the Delivery and after; which was in this manner: At the end of the ixteenth week after the fright, he had pains in the night, he thinking to endure them well enough 'till morning, in the morning caued me to be ent for. I came to her, finding with her a Phyician, and undry others of her acquaintance. The Phyician that expected me, had ordered a Clyter to give it her if I thought it to the purpoe; I found her pale, cold, and yet in a weat, with o little pule, that I eteemed her dead; I touched her, and found he had been in Travail, which had been too long neglected, I called preently for a plain ilver dih, into which I queez'd the juice of half a Citron, and et it upon a Chafing dih of coals; being warmed, I caued her to take it; this retored Nature a little, and tirred up her
pains, and then I aited her; notwithtanding ome of the waters ran down: After her firt throw, the legs and thighs of the Child came forth: Now finding the Infant to be dead, and eeing that he was troubled with no more throws, I was afraid of drawing it forth, for fear it might be rotten: I did give her a Clyter without moving her, the force of which bringing the Child away, he was delivered of a dead Infant, all over of a leaden colour, without any ill vapour; the Secondine ound and fair as you hall ee, her purgations as clear as could be, and he had as good and as happy a Lying in, as any woman in the World; all which time he had not the appearance of any Milk at all. Hence we may admire the effects of Nature, which are wonderful! But in uch caes Women mut be ure in due time and place; for if a Woman do reit her pains, and doth not put her elf in a right poture, he runs a great hazard of her Life.

div.head: A econd Obervation of a Woman that had been in Travail nine days.
div.p:
BEing called to the Labour of a Woman that had been in Travail nine or ten days, of whom there was little hope; I went, and there found the Woman almot dead, her eyes open and fixed, her noe hrunk in, her breath melling like a Charnel-houe; and he took nothing down into her tomach, that he did not intantly vomit up again; he had drunk up above two pints of water in an hour, and by her bed, there was a whole ea of thoe things that he had vomited up. They gave her cold water, and the yolk of an Egg ometimes, though it came up again at the ame intant. She felt no pain of the Infant, but finding her Womb was open and her waters beginning to come down: I found that he had been in Travail; only Nature was oppreed, and had not had any good aitance,
o that the Infant was retired back again, which tifled the Mother, and provoked her vomiting. Upon which, I gave my advice, and though I thought my elf come a little too late, yet I reolved to do what lay in the power of my Art; and therefore I reolved to give her a good trong Clyter to awaken Nature, and to bring the Infant lower, which did according to our hopes; afterwards to drink a mall quantity of Rhubarb-water which tayed with her; a little after, I gave her the Yolk of an Egg, which tayed with her alo, cauing her to drink nothing but Rhubarb-water; and at every hour's end, I gave her the Yolk of an Egg, which did alo tay with her; by this time, Nature began to trengthen it elf, and the pains of the Infant came again; and in les than two hours, after the Clyter and other nourihment given, when I aw her pretty well, and that Nature trove to expel the Infant, I gave her half a dram of Confection of Alkermes in a little Wine; and a little while after I caued her to take another Clyter, into which I put a little Hiera, and a little Benedictum, which finihed the work; for he was then delivered of a very luty Child, which lived about two days: I came thither about noon, and he was brought to bed before nine at night. I wrote this thus particularly, to let you know that oft-times for want of knowing where the michief lies, the Remedies are miapplied; and indeed a Woman Travailling in the ninth Month, ought chiefly to be uccoured with Clyters.

div.head: Of a Woman here in Town that bare her Children eleven months, and could not be Delivered.
div.p:
BEing called to a Woman in this Town, that thought her elf three months and a half gone, which is one of the Terms of time, wherein commonly the Moles and Fale-births are delivered; having
then ome los of blood and pain, I was ent for, and judged it to have been ome imperfect Conception, and therefore I ued all means to ait her; yet could he not expel it, for all thee long pains: Whereupon finding ome trange apprehenions in her, I wondered; for, in all the time of my Practice, I never knew uch a thing as that dangerous in my life. But I afterwards found this apprehenion to come from a certain accident that had happened to a Siter of hers, who being with Child, carried it very well to the end of the ninth month; at the end of which he began to be in pain, as if he would have cried out: the pains were great and long, which they were not at all atonihed at, by reaon that it was her firt Child, yet were not thee pains accompanied with any igns of Labour, as, the opening the exterior orifice of the Womb: And they continued thus for the pace of two days and two nights. Many medicines were ued to facilitate the birth, but to no purpoe; and now he felt not the Child tir any more. And now it was concluded, that he had mitaken her time; and now being at ret for four or five days, and growing weary of the City, he went into the Country, and being returned without taking notice that he had received any harm, he was taken with the ame pains as before, which continued a day and a night, and then ceaed as before. This was adjudged to be certain pains of the Colick; after this, he endured one month longer in her former etate, which was now the eleventh month compleat; at the end of which he felt ome little pain like throws, which preently affected her heart; upon which he was laid upon her bed, and they brought her Wine; but at the very intant he died, without having any time to call for aitance: Seeing her dead, they perceived upon the right ide of her belly a very black
mark about the breadth of a Dollar; being opened, they found the Child all putrified. Hence we mut oberve, that in Women that are big with Child, who have frequent pain, and nothing coming forth, the Matrix that hould open, rather huting it elf cloer, whether it be at the time or no, you mut make for them clyters that expel wind, which are to be reiterated as occaion requires; which Rule if it had been oberved in this Woman, he, nor the Fruit of her Womb, had not perihed in that manner.

div.head: Of the common opinion, that a Woman even months gone, ought to walk very much; and of the Accidents that happen thereby.
div.p:
IT is a common error among Midwives, which is not to be paed by, that a Woman with Child, when he hath gone even Months of her time, is to walk much: Upon a conceit that exercie is very proper for her; for that, they ay, doth looen the Child from the reins, and facilitates the Birth. I confes, as to facilitating of the Birth, it may omething avail; only I mut add this alo, that it is better to draw away the Child than to break it; and moreover it is better to be omething longer in Travail, than to incurr two or three evils which ordinarily happen; the firt is, that the Child in the end of the eventh month, doth make certain endeavours to free it elf from the belly of the Mother; and without doubt his firt endeavour is to turn himelf in the belly of the Mother; for the Infant turns himelf a good while before the time of Labour; and therefore, I ay, Exercie is very dangerous: The firt reaon is, becaue by puhing downward the belly is dilated, and epecially in uch as carry their Children low; and beides, oft times the head drags down all the body of the Womb, and
looens the ligaments in uch a ort, that after Delivery it can hardly be put into its place again. Beides, the Children having their heads between the bones of the Mother, by much walking of the Mother, they come to be bruied, o that the Infants do many times dye, and no man is able to give a caue why; for the branches of veins which are for the nourihment of the brain open in an intant, letting out the blood which is contained in them; and when the corruption is ingendered, there follows immediately Feavers, and corruption of the Infant: At other times, Women coming to it upon a hard eat, do bruie the head of the Infant, which caues like accidents; and in all thee accidents, none but the Midwife is to blame, unles the belly it elf be poyled. This, they ay, is the fault of the Nure, who did not apply remedies fit to retore the fault. I mut confes that remedies do much avail to the recovery of the aforeaid malady, and do much avail to the healing of that dieae; but, to retore it to uch an etate as it was in before, I ay it is a thing impoible for medicines to perform: For the skin which is once eparated, cannot be cloed again without a car. I would now not only blame thoe that ait them, but, by putting the actions of people before them, hew them where lies the fault, and what reaon I have o to do: I mut confes that fale accuations have made the mot able Midwives timorous; for they lye liable to o many caues of detraction, that all that are either but indifferent good, or ele not good, are all accued alike, if any thing fall out amis with the Patient, as if they were the abolute caues of the evil, or that it lay abolutely in their power to hinder it. It happens alo many times, that a Midwife worthy of that name, doth deliver a woman from death, and yet in the place of much praie, he incurs
many times much blame; o that they are oftentimes contrained (to avoid the candal) to advertie them of their ill procedures, and to give place to thoe that know not how to do things with that weetnes and judgment. The fault is no where but in the ignorance, candal, and ingratitude of Women toward thoe of this Calling. Beides, there are a company of young Women, that becaue they have had one Child, do give themelves a great deal of liberty to talk of thee things. Cries one, I like not thee Midwives that handle me; I will change mine, cries another, for that trick alo; o that many out of a kind of fear have a greater deire and will to be complacent than to do well; and o itting with their hands before them, entertain their Patients with dicoure; who for all that feeling their pains, are contrained to thrut forward, upon which the head of the Infant coming firt, for the mot part the womb erves for a Head-band, which comes forth before it; whereas, might the Midwife be permitted to touch the Patient, they might put back the Womb, and prevent many accidents that happen in Lyings-in, which happen ometimes to be a total relaxation of the Matrix; of which when the Women complain to their complacent and flattering Midwives, they reply; why, Mitres, you know I did not touch you; and beides, I am not in fault if you have been touched: This is the fruit of their reproaches. You will ay, there are abundance of Countrey-women that the Midwife never touch at all, and they do not know carcely, whether a Woman lye in, or no, unles they ee the Infant appear. But they are not free from the Dieae whereof I peak; for I have een o great a company of them, that I have been afraid to behold them. This comes, ay the Midwives, becaue they touched them not, and
that it is occaioned, either becaue the Infant is too big, or they ay, it is a burtnes, or the coming down of the great gut; the mot ubtile put up a Clew of Thred, the others a Ball of wax, which eaeth a little while, but comes out again every hour.

div.head: Of a Child which they thought ick of the Epilepie, occaioned by the icknes of the Mother, and of the caue.
div.p: ONE day there came to me a Gentle-woman, to deire me, that I would give her omething for her Daughter that was ick of the Mother: When her Mother related what he ailed, I deired to ee her. I aw her, and he had in one hour two everal fits, which was an affrightment, attended with very much yawning, after which he remained in a very great weaknes; all which time the mouth of the Child was drawn more to one ide than the other; the eyes when he was out of the fit were open, and fixed in one place; I inquired of the Mother, at what age her daughter came to be firt troubled with it; who anwer'd, that he had been in this Town omthing more than a year; and that before that time he was never troubled with any uch thing: I gave her the bet Counel that I could; and firt of all I bid her to carry her again to the place where he was firt nured: uing ome few remedies that were convenient; which propered o well, that, after he came thither, he had but one fit, though he had them o frequently before. Of this no other caue can be given, but that the air of the place where he lived for that year being thicker then that where he was nured, caued in her a tirring of the humours, with which the mother was continually afflicted, he being dipoed naturally to that kind of dieae.

div.head: Of a young Woman, who being truck upon the belly by her Husband with his foot, was in great pain, and could not be brought to bed without the help of a Chirurgeon.
div.p: I Will here relate a thing which I have een in a young Woman; that, if the like accident hould happen, the ame Remedies may be applied. There came a Woman to me, to declare to me a dieae with which he was troubled, deiring me to do my utmot; for that hitherto, he could not lye in without the help of a Chirurgeon, who had already killed two of her Children. I, knowing what an ill Husband he had, and that he had given her a blow upon the belly with his foot, and had broken the Peritonaeum; which was the reaon, that part of her guts hung down upon the hare-bone like the bag of a Bag-pipe; to which place, being big, the Womb jutted out, o that when the time came, the Infant had not liberty to turn it elf; o that the Midwife eeing he could not have the Child without loing the Woman, was fain to make ue of Chirurgeon. I conidered her dieae, and ordered her to carry a watheband, uch a one as Women with Child carry to upport their bellies, only made a little more hollow; and I caued her to wear it as they that are burt do wear half-flops, lying mooth with cuhionets within, and never to rie without this, whether big, or no; which he did, and till does, and bears as fine Children, and lyes in as well, as any other Woman.

div.head: Of two Deliveries of one Woman.
div.p:
