THere was a Woman, who being come to a ufficient age, became big: he caueth two of the bet Midwives of the Countrey to ait her in her Lying in; the hour being come, they did as Art commanded them, which was, The Child coming well into the world; to keep her in a good ituation, to caue her to eat things which were only for the purpoe, to keep
her moderately warm, and then to bring her pains to a good iue. I excued the paion and impatience of friends, but I would not do any thing againt my duty for complacency; a fault that is oon committed, but not o eaily repented of; This Woman was pretty long, as mot Women are of their firt Children; in which time her husband, altogether impatient, and eeing her to doubt the report of the Midwives, Therefore, aid he, here is a Chirurgeon hard by, who may be ent for to reolve the doubt of the Midwives; he ent for him jut about the hour that the Woman was to be brought to bed: The Chirurgeon when he came, aw that the Child was ready to come forth. The Midwives who had given way to the Chirurgeon, thinking to take their place again as oon as he had touched her, to make his report, were deceived; for he eeing the buines ready to be done, told her Husband that it was neceary for him to operate, but that he would proceed with o much indutry, that he would not only bring forth a ound and a luty child, but moreover that he would render his wife alo into a afe condition. The Midwives when they would have poken, were put to ilence. The Gentlewoman was preently delivered, and he tayed but a little while to receive his reward: Thus the Midwives that had attended long, and all the while of the Travail, were dipied, and put off; and the Chirurgeon extolled and praied, and well rewarded with everal mot obliging and courteous invitations. About a year after, he was entertained upon the former core like a Prince; the hour of her Labour came again; and the Gentleman was gone to viit ome of his friends, having uch a confidence in the Chirurgeon, that he et his mind at ret for any danger. The Labour of this child was not like the Labour of the other child; for it came with the feet foremot; and when the whole body was come
forth, the head could not be got forth. He had brought with him no intruments, thinking that this Delivery would have been like the other; but eeing himelf at a tand, he ent to a Chirurgeon not far off for an Itrument: in the mean time, he ent into the kitchen for a Ladle, with a hook at the end thereof, to draw forth the child. He drew it o well, that he drew away the life of the child: and without eeking any further for any body to addle his hore, or bidding any body farewell, he fled his wayes. This may be an intruction to thoe that are o ready to entertain Mountebanks, and Empericks; than whom, there are no men more prodigal of the life of another for money.

div.head: Of a Woman, that becaue he would not be ruled in her Lying in, died.
div.p:
I Was one day called to the Labour of a woman, which had good Deliveries of her Sons and Daughters, at their due time, although her Deliveries of Boys were always more difficult than thoe of her Daughters; being come to her, I found her walking in the Chamber with her leggs bare, in a eaon that was not over-hot. I caued her to be put into her bed to warm her again, but he would by no means endure it; although I prayed her, he was angry with me, and told me, This was not the rule, to be contrained. The Mitres and the Nure combined againt me; the night approached; the waters being come down, I feared the ill ucces of this buines, that her dieae would be irrecoverable by reaon of her elf-will'dnes. I deired her husband to ue his endeavour, but he could do no more with her than I: about midnight, I prayed her to go to bed again, and to warm her elf, and unles he would do o, I could do nothing. She told me, I undertood nothing in repect of a certain Surgeon, who, when he had uch a kind of Labour before, only toucht her with his finger, and delivered her; and that he
would have him. I was content, and o he ent for him. He came very confidently, but his work was not at o eaie a pas as formerly: he put a good large Table-Napkin before him, truing it up to his elbows, aying he was as able to deliver her as before. She would no more ee me after his arrival: the Surgeon to whom I repreented (after his arrival) all that I had undertood and een, and the fear which I had of her, told me that all would be well. At day break, a neighbour of mine calling me away, I deired her Husband to let me go; but he was unwilling, unles I would promie to come again, which I did; and as oon as the door was open, one of the ervants told me, another Midwife was ent for. Her Husband deired me again, that ince the Chyrurgeon failed of his skill, I would ue my skill; but it was too late, for the Chyrurgeon left them, and the Woman died. See here how ill a thing it is to be opinionated, for I could eaily have delivered her, if he would have been ruled by me.

div.head: Of certain Women that bear Children, and lie in before their time: And others, at their full time, who grow big, and full of humours, which caueth the death of the Child, preently after their Delivery; their Children being nourihed in their bellies, like fih only with water.
div.p:
I Knew a Gentlewoman who had Laid-in three times, but yet none of her Children lived: I deired her to take a Phyician that might give advice both to her and me, and to order her ome remedies, and a government of diet to keep her from uffering the like accidents for time to come. We choe a Phyician, who precribed certain Tablets or Trochiques, to take from the time he began to grow big, until the time of her Delivery, twice a week; as alo to take the water of Indian Bul-ruh, and of Saraparilla, to mix in her drink, or broth, as often as he would, having a
due regard to the heat of her blood: She oberved every tittle of his directions, which made her to bear a Son, alive, ound, and healthful. She continued thee Remedies four years together, but the next time he grew big with Child, he thought that Nature of • t elf would be ufficient: I counelled her to the contrary, but he hearkned not; o that when her time came, he was brought to bed of a dead Child. I hall give you the Receipt of the Tablets, and of the water, for the benefit of Women that are ubject to an ill Delivery, by reaon of the great quantity of water, which hindereth the Child from turning in the Womb: The Water is made in this manner.

Take two pints, or two pints and a half of water; put therein half an ounce of the root of Indian Bul-ruh, and an ounce of Saraparilla; put this in the drink, and let it infue one night; mix it with the drink, or ele drink it pure.
The Tablets are made after this fahion
Take Mace, Saunders, Rhubarb, Pearl, and Coral, Sena, of each 25 grains, with one ounce and half of Sugar; let every Tablet weigh ix drams.

div.head: The obervation of a Woman, who was thought unable to bear any more Children; yet contrary to expectation, was delivered of one; and the reaon thereof.
div.p:
THere are certain Women who have the neck of the Womb long and hardned, by a cold humor that falls down thereon, and renders them uncapable of conceiving. One I have heard of, who was afflicted with this Dieae, and voided a great deal of putrified blood; by a certain fumigation that I taught her, he was cured. I can ay this of a certainty, that after this Woman had voided this putrefaction, he came to ee me with a very luty Child, and was big of another; for being dicharged of the burden of putrified blood, he found her elf marvellouly free for
Conception; for the Matrix that began to be ulcerated, was now fortified, and trengthned again, and the natural heat began to take poeion there again.

div.head: A good obervation in the choice of Nures.
div.p:
THere be two ort of Nures which I have found: The one is of uch Women as are of an ill humor, or juice; which humors ettle all in the milk, for that is the place where thee fluxes dicharge themelves. Thee Women are in a better condition being Nures, than when they are not Nures; and being not Nures are ubject to pains, ometimes in the arms, and ometimes in the houlders, ometimes in one of their legs or thighs; or ele they are ubject to the watring of the eyes, or welling in the corner of the eye or noe. Thee are good Nures, as long as Children are fat; but the fat is oft, and the Infants dull and ottih, giving no great igns of vivacity; coming to bear teeth, they are very ickly, and do ordinarily die, by reaon of the flux, that puheth out too great company of teeth at once. The Children that ecape this, are more ill juic'd in their infancy, than are their Fathers and Mothers in their old Age. If the flux that afflicts them be alt, the milk is of a blackih and blewih colour, if it be of Choler, it is more dangerous than the other, for that is more dangerous and venomous to the Children. There is another ort of Nures more dangerous than thee I have now poken of; who preently after they have Lain in (that is, three, or four, or five, or ix months) are taken with their Purgations, a thing which never happens to good Nures: for this is the coure of Nature, that all the blood which is retained, is dedicated to the nourihment of the Infant. This is caued by a moderate heat which is in their blood; and, to ay true, as oon as ever this happens, the Infant mut be taken away, for they are more apt to conceive, than to nure; and if they continue Nures,
they do but ruine the Children. This is but too much experimented, and I peak this to ave the lives of a great many Children, when eeing them uck I have dicovered their want of milk; o that I may ay, there dies a third part of the Children, for want of taking care in this particular, which yet eem fat, and in good cae.

This is the caue of great Cholicks and windinees in Children, which kills them in a moment; for the leat Feaver that takes them, carries them away. Beides this, there are ome whoe milk is o little, but withal o thick, that it ticks upon the tongue, palate, and throat, which caues, as it were, a white canker, which is more and more heated by reaon of their forcible drawing in vain; and poeeth all the throat, whereby they are hindred from ucking. Thee Nures will milk after this, a drop or two out of their breats, crying, Look ye, the Child cares not for ucking. I never knew more abue in any thing, than in Nures: for let them make what excue they will, it is nothing but neceity that reduceth them to be uch. Although the greatet part do ay, that it is to get acquaintance; yet when they have a Child, whether they have milk or no, yet they deire not to part with it, no more than they do to drown themelves; whereby the Parents are often deceived. And therefore the Mothers ought to have a great care, and to make it their buines to urprize the Nures at their own houes, that if there be any micarriage, they may find it out. And indeed it is very reaonable, that the caue of thee poor creatures that cannot complain, hould not be neglected; and thee She-murderers be made known, that they may not go unpunihed.

div.head: Of a Woman which I laid two everal times, and of the difference of her bearing of two Children, proceeding from everal caues.
div.p: I Was called to lay a Woman, who aid he was gone her full time; he had the ame pains that women are wont to have in the time of Travail, but her waters came not down. At one forcible Throw he cat forth a great membrane like a Hogs-bladder, all united within and without, only that it had divers branches of veins, as you hall ee in a bladder; which I preently cut, and found therein a little Infant, well haped, wiming in black waters: it had gone its full time, and was o lean, that it reembled a meer Picture; it had the Navel-tring holding fat to the bladder, where it is to be uppoed thoe mall branches of the veins do end. Here, as I gues, as long as it found any blood, it lay languihing; but, that beginning to fail, it died, and preently voided thoe excrements that were contained in the intetines, which being mingled in the waters, made them black: And as for the Woman her elf, he was the fullet of humours that ever I aw in my life. Another time I brought the ame Woman to bed, who was delivered of a Child that came the ordinary way into the World, with the head foremot; now I perceiving her in Labour, found nothing at firt but a certain oftnes, as if the waters were coming down: Afterwards I perceived a certain bag with hair; athwart which I aw certain great knobs or heads. The Infant being come forth was not yet formed; the face and the head were like vizards more than any face; it had the form of a noe, but it was oft like wooll: The head was full of water, and thoe knobs which appeared, were nothing but the futures of the head, which the too great abundance of water had disjoyn'd: in the hands it had nothing but hair intead of bones, and the toes were of the ame: The woman her elf was aid to be extream cholerick, and moit.

div.head: Intructions of a famous and dying Midwife to her Daughter, touching the practice of this Art.
div.p: DAughter, if the excellencies of what is to be known in this World are to be found not in one, but in everal Countries; certainly they are mot able to intruct who have had the greatet experience, and longet travel in the World; which is the reaon, that in this mall Treatie I have not tyed up my elf to the rules olely of my own Nation, but have earched the tudies alo of other Nations, that thou mayet be bettered, not only by my experience, but by the Labour of others.

In the firt place therefore, I exhort thee to be diligent, and to leave nothing unearched that may tend to the advantage of thy practice. And to this end, be always learning to the lat day of thy life; which that thou mayet not ceae to do, be always humble; for thoe that are proud and obtinate, never gain upon the hearts of thoe that are knowing in ecrets. Be ure thou never make trial of any new Remedy or Receipt, either upon poor or rich, if thou be't not aured of the quality and operation thereof; and that it can do no hurt, whether it be applied outwardly, or taken inwardly. Hide none of thoe good Receipts which thou knowet, either from Midwives, or Phyicians; for otherwie they will eteem them as little as thoe of Mountebanks, as if thou hadt but one cure, like them, for all Dieaes, and yet didt brag as they do of doing wonders, yet till conceal their Receipts. Thou mut peak freely of that which thou knowet, and give a reaon for what thou ayet. Be not negligent, but o increae thy Talent, that people may ay, you are better than ever your Mother was: I mut tell thee, thou hat taken a matter of great importance into thy hand; and that in this Art there are two ways eaie to take; the one to ave thy credit, and the other to loe
it. Above all things, you mut beware (for any treaure in the world) of adhering to one vice, uch as they are guilty of who give Remedies to caue Abortion; for thoe that do ill, and thoe that eek a damnable remedy, are wicked in a high degree. But it is a higher degree of wickednes for thoe that are no way ingaged in the buines, for lucres ake to kill both the body and oul of an Infant. This I do not peak that thou houldet refue to give Remedies upon jut occaions: but to take heed how you be cheated by ubtle perons, who hall tell you fine tories of the dieaes of their Wives, or Daughters, which they may ay are very honet, hoping to get from you ome Receipts to effect their wicked deigns, end them to the Phyicians, for you may give them a lawful excue, in aying that uch matters do not belong to your charge. Never keep the cawl called Amnios, which covers the head and houlders of the Child, for Sorcerers to make ue of.

If you are ent for to any houe, inform your elf of what condition they are, and whether they be rich, or whether they be the pooret creatures in the world, erve them with like pains and affection, and if you find them to be very poor, take nothing; for to them a little is a great deal: viit them alo afterwards with diligence, that for the mall time wherein they keep their bed, you may be aiting to them in trengthning and recovering of their healths. I charge thee, Daughter, that in all thy life thou never receive a Woman into thy houe to lie in; for that is but a kind of Panderim cloathed in ome pretence of Charity; neither doth thy profeion oblige thee to do it. If it chance to be a woman that is not wholly betaken to whoredom, that there is ome hopes of recovering her from that lot condition; if then he deire you out of a belief of your ufficiency, or ecrecy, you may then go
to her in an honet place. You mut comfort her, if he be afflicted, and put her in the right way, exhorting her never to commit the like again; but to receive uch perons into your houe, is but a means to encourage evil: As the receivers of tollen goods are a means to encourage Thieves; even o, the Midwives that bring uch a tench to their houe, do ait and abet the evil which they do, whilt they know where to dicharge themelves of the like burthen again. At the firt when I took upon me this Calling, I took two into my houe, the one of Quality, the other of an ordinary condition; I aw them ometimes in uch fits of depair, that I could hardly bring them out of them again. Thoe from whom the evil came; upon whoe account I had received them, came now and then to ee them, becaue they brought them maintenance; I was continually fain to keep watch with them, for fear they hould do any evil in the houe: And I mut needs ay, I had better have kept a herd of Swine. Such unrets as thee ought not to enter into the breat of a Midwife; for, her mind ought to be free and at peace. Beides that, a cutom of laying Women of an ill life, poyls the reputation of a Woman, and oft times endangers the health alo. To confirm which, I knew an honet undertanding Midwife, that laid a Courtezan that eemed to ail nothing at all; but he, having an inveterated Pox, gave it to the old Midwife upon her right hand, upon which there came a red Bubo; for all which, being unwilling to leave off her Calling, he poyled after that above thirty Houholds; for the Husbands got the Pox from their Wives, and the Children from their Mothers

Now let me tell thee, Daughter, that thou oughtet not to take it ill to ee the condition of Midwives depied; neither let this hinder thy Studies in the perfections of this Art, which are not to be comprehended by thoe
that depie it. Neither be dimayed if thou eet people in this condition, that do not deerve to be; for this doth not at all diminih the honour of thoe that are good: for it comes from hence to pas, becaue they that receive them for mony, do as Stablers do, put the good and bad Hores together; the good Hores are in no danger to be hurt by the Jades, but the Jades are in hazard of being kickt and poyled by the good Hores.

Never think of any think ele but of doing well, and erving thoe that hall call thee according to their own liking, if that which they deire be not prejudicial to them, but if that which they deire; be to their hurt, be ure that thou dicharge thy elf of them, and epecially excue thy elf to the aitants, that thou mayt perwade them to reaon. A weet dipoition in a Midwife is much more commendable than a rigorous: the pain of Child-bearing is a very hard labour, which thou mut conider, and accordingly conform thy elf to the humour of the Patient, knowing thy elf to be called to comfort and ait her.

Mark well, entring into a houe, in what condition the Patient is; if the evil be at hand, you mut encourage her, and prepare your elf with thoe things that are neceary; and firt you mut ee that the Bed be well made for the woman that is to be brought to bed, and then to put on her a little mock, and wate-coat, and other linnen neceary: And if he be o opinionated, as that he will not; tell her how much you do it for the better; and how great a pain it will be afterwards; content her though, for you mut make of a bad Market no more then you can. You ought to give order for things to be had from the Apothecaries with her conent; or if he be young, with the conent of her friends. You mut take order alo that ome good broth be made for her to take, in the time of her Travail, if it hould chance to be long; and alo two hours after her being
brought to bed. Above all things I charge thee, that what ever buines thou mait have there, that thou go not about them too hatily. For there is nothing o naueous to be een, as the improvident actions of over-buie women. Never be dimayed if every thing go not well; for, fear diorders the enes; and a peron that keeps her wits together, without uffering them to be cattered by fear, is capable of giving aitance in weighty affairs, and epecially where things are done with leiure; for in uch caes Nature helps marvellouly, when we are mot at a tand. There is a great neceity of prudence, epecially in the age wherein we live. There is now no need of Coloquintida to render any thing good in it elf, bitter and diagreeable to the tate. There are few Women now a days that do give that repect, or have that kindnes for them as in former ages; for then, when their Midwife died, they hewed a great deal of orrow, and prayed God that now they might have no more Children: which though it were not well done, yet it hewed their affection. Now adays, Women ue them as meer Hirelings.

There is a great deal of artifice to be ued in the pleaing of our Women, epecially the young ones, who many times do make election of Men to bring them to bed. I bluh to peak of them, for I take it to be a great piece of impudence to have any recoure unto them, unles it be in a cae of very great danger. I do approve it, I have approved it, and know that it ought to be done, o that it be concealed from the Woman all her life long; nor that he ee the Surgeon any more: for it is very inconvenient to Husbands, that (unles in caes of very great danger) uch things concerning their own Wives hould be communicated to any other men but themelves.

To this purpoe hall I tell thee Daughter, that being called to the Labour of a Friend, where were none but
2 or 3 of her acquaintance, they asked me what I thought of the Labour: to which I anwered, that the Child did not come well, but that I would do the work with the aitance of God, without danger to the Child, or to the Mother. They deired me that I would let a Surgeon ee her: for their atisfaction, I conented to it; provided that he might not ee him; for I was fearful, let he hould die with apprehenion and hame; I perwaded her to lide down toward the feet of the bed, and darkned the Room on that ide where he was to come; at the feet he touched her, and he was brought to bed without any other aitance, ave that of God and Nature. Since thee injuries have bin put in fahion, there have bin oberved greater hazards and dangers in lying in than before, which might be remedied by perons capable of their profeion, if they might be let alone. But this Detraction is o much in requet, that among ome kind of people, there is much ado to make them believe the truth, and epecially where they cannot get great advantage by o doing, and truly, Honourable perons which I have had the honour to erve, make other women eem montrous to me. You hall come into ome houes, where there are certain perons that hold uch fale lights to the Mitres of the Houe, that he ees quite contrary to that which is real; which perons if they are not humoured, your buines will be there oon dipatched. Take great heed of coming there, for it may chance to gain you nothing but a great deal of care. There are ome Women that have no Children, at which they are very much troubled; which is o, notwithtanding that they might eaily be helped, if they would tell an undertanding Midwife where the defect lay.

As concerning thoe, who are ent for to lay Women in the Country, I mut ay this, that as for thoe that are not very well experimented, they may incur many hazards by reaon of their ignorance, and the multiplicity
of accidents that may happen: And for thoe that are knowing, to leave their Patients in the City, is a thing that may dipleae, and wrong many, and run the hazard of being no more entertained among them, to their own ruine; neither is there any certainty of a Woman that will run rambling into the Country. My lat advice is, that thou do well, and in o doing, fear nothing but God, that he may bles thee, and thy endeavours.

list.head: Explanation of the firt Figure.
list.item: A A. The right and left Kernel of the Reins.
B. The true Kidneys.
CC. The Emulgent Veins.
DD. The Emulgent Arteries.
E E. The Spermatic Veins.
F F. The Spermatick Arteries.
GG. The Trunk of the hollow Vein.
HH. The Trunk of the great Arterie.
IIII. The Ureters.
KK. The Veels that prepare the Seed.
MM The Stones with all their Tunicles.
N N. The Veels carrying the Seed, retorted back into the Bladder.
O. The Bladder.
P. The Neck of the Bladder.
QQ. The two glaudulous Fore-tanders.
R R. The two Mucles that erect the Yard.
S S. Two other Mucles dilating the Ureter.
T. The body of the Yard.
U. The Praeputium that covers the Nut of the Yard.

list.head: Explanation of the econd Figure.
list.item: A. The Bladder turned downward.
BB. The inertion of the Uterers into the Bladder.
CC. The neck of the Womb, which Anatomits call the Sheath, which receives many veels.
EEEE. The two lower round Ligaments of the mouth, cut away.
FF. The blind Veel of the Womb annexed here to the uppermot and broad Ligament.
GG. The ame veel on the other ide, eparated from the broad Ligament.
HH. The different or Seed-carrying veels on each ide, ending in the neck of the Womb.
II. The upper and membrany Ligament of the Womb, like the wings of a Bat; thorow which many veels, that arie from the preparing veels, are cattered and diffued.
K. The preparing Veels of one ide, not yet dicerned from the firt membrany, or filmy Ligament.
L. The preparing Veels on the other ide, evered from the filmy Ligament: to hew you their inertion into the tone, with its films.
MM. The Stones; where one is covered, the other is bare.
NN. Many Veins and Arteries catered into the neck and bottom of the Womb; erving for the purgation of the flowers, and the nourihment of the birth.
OO. The Nerves cattered through the body of the Womb.
